Text: 4.5 stars.Brand new gastropub with enticing cocktails, beer and wine, plus interesting options on their food menu. The bar is elegant, spotless and relaxed... Cool music is being played, and you immediately get a good vibe after you walk inside. I didn't have anything to eat (but planning on doing it next time), and Jaime was very helpful in selecting a beer for my mood from the 16 drafts they offer. The guy knows how to relate to his customers. I can't say enough about his demeanor, friendliness and willingness to make sure you have a good time. He's the type of bartender you want to tell your secrets and ask for advice. I hope I'll find him there again when I return in the future. Go and have a blast. And tell Jaime I sent you (the Italian dude who used to live in the city with the horse race... I doubt he'll remember...lol).

Cons: 1) Bathrooms. Not enough of them and always a crazy long line. Really ruins the museum experience when you're waiting to pee for an hour. 2) They've done away with the "pay what you can" model for most patrons (it's now only NY residents or students from the tri-state region). I always appreciated how the Met made art accessible to all - while I understand the reasoning behind the admission changes, it's still disheartening. 3) The gift shop is basically extortion with those pricesPros: Just about everything else. The Met has the most incredible collection of pieces ancient and contemporary that you can possibly imagine. It's no wonder that I've lived in NYC for over a year now and I've still only seen a fraction of the pieces on display. I love the traveling exhibits (especially those hosted by the Costume Institute), but other must-sees in my humble opinion include the mummy/Egyptian exhibit, the Medieval armor, and the contemporary art, which has a number of Picassos/Monets/Manets/Matisses/etc. The museum staff is also INCREDIBLE. I have never come across a member of the staff that wasn't amazingly well-versed in the layout of the museum. I find that they are all eager to help and love to give suggestions about what to see and how to maximize your time. Bathrooms aside, the museum itself is breathtaking. It's no wonder so many people come here to study, to draw, to get away from it all. Excited to come back in a few days for the Heavenly Bodies exhibit!

They were "temporarily closed" for over a year due to a catastrophic fire, and my poor heart was continually tormented by the evil foreboding that they might never open again, which is the fate common to so many restaurants that are temporarily closed for an extended period of time, and lose their regular patrons to competitors. If ever mortal felt jubilant at being proved wrong, that was my state when Sarge's reopened a couple of months ago, dispelling all my irrational fears, and I was proud to be humbled [**oxymoron alert**] by the triumph of my beloved deli over the calamitous fire that had interrupted its operations. The pastrami is generous in portion and its texture is every bit as buttery as I remembered it. The chopped liver is smooth and tasty. The complimentary cole slaw is light and balanced, not too vinegary, not too sweet, just right. The corned beef hash is a prodigious portion and comes with three eggs. I am never able to finish it even though I tend to overeat every time I am at Sarge's. Oh, and the crinkle-cut fries are just right, with a crispy exterior and soft inside. The decor (or lack thereof) is unassuming and reminiscent of old school diners that are so hard to find these days. The service is friendly, familial even, if you dine here frequently and they start to recognize you. I used to live on the same block as Sarge's, and this used to be my haunt for a late night indulgence. Having long moved away from the neighborhood, I still make the urban trek to eat here every now and again. The fact that they're open 24 hours does not hurt. Eating here at the wee hours of the night also provides some interesting people-watching opportunities. Be aware that this is a kosher-style, not kosher, deli. I continue to be the heinous heretic who prefers Sarge's over 2nd Avenue Deli and Katz's.

Came here for dinner with my bf. Walking in here was an experience on its own. The decor and ambiance was absolutely beautiful. Very sexy and grown with areas for date night and a nice group family or friend dinner. We were seated in the back in a quiet couple area and I loved it. Super romantic! I had the chai drink and it was absolutely amazing! We tried a few others including the lassi (all alcoholic) and they were too strong and harsh for our liking.For appetizers we had the lamb keema, and chicken 65. Both were amazing! The keema came with some bread that was the perfect accompaniment! Delicious! For entree we had the onion and cheese naan and the butter chicken with a side of rice. Nothing special here, I've had better butter chicken before but definitely enjoyable. I liked the naan but my bf didn't. I guess it's a matter of choice. The service was exceptional! Probably one of my fave things here after the ambiance! The portions were a little small and it was pricey but overall it was a nice date night spot. I would definitely recommend going at least once. I want to try to brunch next!

This place has been on my radar for a quite a long time... I finally made it there for a quick snack! I was so happy to see all the beautiful, colorful, vibrant and adorable desserts lined up neatly, waiting to be chosen. At this visit, I just wanted something adorable, no matter what kind of dessert it was, or what kind of flavor it was. We got was Raspberry Lychee Tart and Lucky Hazelnut. The Raspberry Lychee Tart shell was rather hard, it fell apart as I tried to cut them in half... And it didn't have much lychee flavor, unless you eat the actual lychee on the bottom, I wish if it had more lychee flavor. Lucky Hazelnut was sooooo fluffy and bouncy, with excellent hazelnut and vanilla flavor. We also got Matcha Cream Puff. It had loads and loads of filling, it was simply awesome! The cream filling had a great matcha flavor, sweet without being overly sweet. Excellent cream puff!To wash off all the adorable, sweet goodness, we bought Praline Latte and Brown Sugar Tea Latte. Praline Latte was tasty with nice praline flavor. For some reason, it was not as hot (temperature wise) as it should have... Brown Sugar Tea Latte was much sweeter than I expected. It was tasty and I could really taste the brown sugar, but at the end, it was a bit too sweet for my taste. They had so many more pastries and baked goods that I still want to try, so we will be going back for more sometime in a near future...

A utopia for Nutella fanatics like me.When I heard a designated cafe for my favorite spread was coming soon, flashbacks from my childhood rushed into my head: my mom using it as a spread atop king hawaiian rolls for breakfast, my cousin and I sneaking downstairs past midnight to dip strawberries into the jar, and even seeing Kobe's face on the wrapper nearly 20 years ago lol. So with it occupying such a special place in my heart, you can probably imagine my excitement for the grand opening.However, I was initially rubbed the wrong way upon seeing the horrendous line wrapping around the corner -- not the fact that it was there, but how it was handled. Certainly, a long wait is to be expected at such a hyped spot and the capacity constraints must be abided by. But instead of letting a few people inside as a group was finishing up, the protocol was such that a table had to be emptied and cleaned before the next party could be admitted, which led to several minutes of these seats being unoccupied, when visitors could've spent the time perusing the menu. My friends will say I was just impatient and hungry, but I def think this process could be streamlined!But all is forgiven with a creme brulee, grilled baguette, and sourdough toast with ricotta and fruit -- all with sweet sweet nutella, of course. We also shared an espresso drink, which was a good palate cleanser between the more desserty dishes. The concoctions are endless: nutella popsicles, nutella gelato, nutella fondue, etc. I'll 100 be back for more, and hopefully the traffic flow will have been improved.

This is the "other" vegan dim sum restaurant in Chinatown except 100% vegan so I'm told. The one on Mott has some items with egg. The menu is super similar to the one on Mott. They have a large variety of dumplings with various fillings, rice rolls (cheong fun), steamed buns, and other typical dim sum items like turnip cake, siu mai etc. the stand out item for me is the baked vegan char siu bun-- omg the bun is so soft I didn't believe it was vegan and thought it had egg. They also have vegan Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) which I've never seen before (don't have this at Mott). However sadly I don't think it's that good. Doesn't really have soup inside and I don't like the filling. I prefer their other dumplings. The rice rolls are good! Steamed well and they are soft and chewy. Love the char siu filling or faux shrimp filling. Besides dim sum there's also entrees like noodles / chow fun/ rice dishes. Chow fun is good. They also have vegan sushi which looks kinda weird haha. Anyhoo, overall it's great to have a full vegan dim sum place around. In summary- try their char siu anything (by itself, baked buns, pastry, rice rolls). Great for a dim sum craving. Good prices. Best to come with a group of 3-4 so you can try more things & split everything! On average should be paying like $12-15 per person? Or less depending if you get entrees. They do take credit card. Service is average. Nothing outstanding, nothing too offensive. They're not gonna baby you like waiters at fancy restaurants trying to get more tip. They just take your order, serve your order then get you out lol. Would I come back? Yup! For the char siu bun. Do I have a preference over this or the one on Mott? I do like the one on Mott better. I feel like their dim sum tastes fresher and a bit more tasty.

I trekked to the barren tundra of way uptown in Harlem at 143rd street to meet up with a friend who was on the prowl for some quick late night D action, as I was acting as her wingman for the night.She didn't score any D, but a drunken gal at the bar showed her some quality D pics on her phone to tie her over for the time being. The night started off uneventful but turned into an epic evening of amusement watching the booze infused locals try and hook up. Solace is a fun little locals bar with nifty happy hour deals, a nice menu of food items made fresh per order, good bartenders, and some solid cocktails. Happy hour is twice as nice! Sunday-Thurs, 4-7pm and again 10pm-12 midnight. 4-7pm on Fridays and Saturdays.The mac & cheese was a tasty treat, the hell fire shrimp was ok, the fries were standard. The Hennygria cocktail served in a beer pint glass was tasty and sneaks up on ya!Solace also offers a weekend boozy brunch option with unlimited dranks! Maybe next time my friend can try some day drinking and score some afternoon delight D!

Great show! Fun and entertaining, loved their songs! Got my tickets through the lucky seat lottery for $45 each - $40+$5 processing fee x2 (luckyseat.com/lottery.php for anyone else interested). Picked the tickets up an hour before the show and to our surprise, we got seated right by the boxed area next the stage on the second floor! Super close to the performers, which is pretty cool. One of those classical shows you'd want to see at least once :) interesting storyline and great singers/performers on the cast.

This is Tao Group's newest rooftop lounge! Located in the Flower district. I think I read somewhere it's now the tallest rooftop bar in nyc which is pretty rad. Why it's cool: floor to ceiling windows, you're basically level with the H&M tower, they have awesome DJs at night coupled with a really sexy dark vibe-- and during the day it's classy and dainty. Yummy cocktails and probably the best Cosmo I've ever had in the city thus far. Also there's a crazy sick disco ball in the center of the bar. Super cute for Instagram photos!

I actually prefer The Pool better than The Grill because it's more brightly lit and I like seafood more than meats. However, you can't go wrong with either.First of all, the restaurant is wonderful from start to finish. Everyone is very friendly and they take hospitality seriously. The dining room is large, spacious, and sophisticated. People dress up here! I enjoyed my red snapper -- crab and shrimp on top were a nice touch. I really appreciated the attentive but not overbearing service. Michelin-level service without the Michelin star.

A nice novelty that everyone should do at least once. I live in NY and sometimes will do the touristy things during off season times to avoid the crowds. I've been up here before, but this was before Yelp so I obviously couldn't write up the review and a lot has changed since the 90's. I wasn't sure of the potential crowds during the day I went, so I played it safe and purchased the VIP tickets to avoid waiting in line for too long. It helped a bit, but the lines weren't overly long either. During busy times and the summer, I would imagine they would come in really handy. There's a little video in the elevator on the way up, which is a nice little touch. Inside the lobby, there is a lot to take pictures of, so have the cellphone ready. They take precautions here, so when going through security, bags, jacket, cell phones, and even belts are put into trays and you step through a metal detector. It's pretty much like an airport, but the added precaution is always nice. They do try to take pictures of you with a green screen to purchase later. They don't force you, but you can always reject the picture later on the way out if you don't want it. It's pricey for two pictures (either with the same background or one different) and a digital copy, but for a keepsake, it's not bad. On the deck, you have a lot of different angles to view from though it's not as spacious on the outside as you'd think for an iconic building observation deck. We didn't have any problems finding room and it wasn't really that crowded when we end. People tend to move around from areas a lot, so if you're patient, you can always find a spot to look or take pictures. Even on a nice day, it can be a little windy up there, so be warned. On a clear day, you can see pretty far. As mentioned, you need to come up here once in your life whether you're local or not. There is no time limit that I know of, but during a busy time it can be crowded and confining. Most of the staff was generally pleasant. There is a large gift shop on the way out. Obviously they have a lot of King Kong merchandise, though I kinda wish they had the Independence Day spaceship on top of the building though. Some of the items are pretty nice actually, but not cheap of course. Worth browsing for sure. There is a lot more to do and packages available, though most just come to get to the top. All in all, this is a historic building and should be visited at least once.

I have to agree with other Yelpers who say this place is a little overpriced, but I will also admit that for some reason, I like it a lot.  It's also a five minute walk from my apartment, so that might have something to do with it. But it's also a very relaxing place, with great drinks and very good food.Alp and I have been here for dinner a couple of times because it's so convenient and walking to 6th Avenue for dinner seems a little more refined than walking to some place on 9th Avenue.  Service tends to be a bit all over the place but usually ends up being pretty good when they see we are going to eat, drink and then eat and drink some more!Over the course of our meals, we have had chicken dumplings, fried cheese curds with olives (curds are amazing) and buffalo meatballs (seriously mouthwateringly good) and short rib mac and cheese (a bit much for me) for starters. For sides, I've had the fries and the saffron mashed potatoes. Loved the fries but the saffron overpowered the taters so I was not a fan.  For entrees, I have had the NY Strip as well as the ribeye steak. Both were good, but the ribeye was much better. Apparently they have seafood too, but I like my meat with feet!For desserts, the apple tart was good but the chocolate hazelnut cake was super delicious. This feels to me like a nice local spot to have a laid back dinner, although I've never gotten out of there for less than $300 on dinner for two. But, what the heck, I'm worth it and so is my baby.

Kefi is a wonderful Greek restaurant on the upper west side. Don't let the small entry fool you, Kefi is plenty big to accommodate groups of all sizes and even hosts an event room downstairs that is very nicely decorated.The wine selection is good and the food is pretty delicious. The food portions are pretty ample so do go with an appetite as it will be put to use. Of course, the lamb dishes are my favorite with meat that is delectable with just the right char and seasoned flavor. I mean this place even makes a delicious salad! It sounds crazy but everything is fresh, crisp and well rounded. The service is spot on, with a mix of friendly and professional. I think this would be a nice place for a friendly date. If you are looking for something romantic, speak up when making a reservation so that you can get seats near the entrance by their beautiful bar.Also, the bathrooms are downstairs but they are very nice. The facility overall is spotless and this is always a great thing.

Glad I rediscovered this place I forgot how good it is. First time back we had no rsvp no biggie wait time by the bar area is great since they have the late happy hour, we got the Lychee martini sooo good!! Great tasting & good amount of alcohol, usually my go too here. Kalbi short rib is amazing great tasting sauce grill just a few minutes each side & it's perfect.. definitely a favorite. Great tasting Filet Mignon. Meats tend to be excellent here. We also tried the Shrimp very good with the garlic sauce. The Sauté chicken was good as well, do prefer the meats. On the sides The Chicken garlic noodles are great, nice tasting noodles great flavor. Can't stay away from the Garlic rice lorddd so tasty. Sauté Spinach in garlic is delicious such a great taste. Appetizers can be tricky since it can be too much food, the Calamari is really good lightly battered great dipping sauce. Wings are good as well. Rsvp help but are not necessary, service is quick & prices are very reasonable great tasting food & drinks at reasonable prices will for sure keep coming back.

After opening its door in 2005 as a small stall in Flushing, Xi'an has come a long way. With more than 10 locations in the city (and still growing), everyone has one particular store they prefer or frequent. Among them, this location is my go-to because of its ample seating and spacious layout.Everyone talks about the Spicy Cumin Lamb Hand-ripped Noodles and for good reason. Perfect balance of cumin and spice, the aromatic sauce clings on to the thick noodles that are perfectly cooked. The dish is flavorful and quite uniquely delicious. However, my absolute favorite item on the menu is the Spicy & Sour Lamb Dumplings. The dumplings comes out submerged in red sauce, which may resemble fiery pits of hell for people who are spice-intolerant like I am. However, don't let its appearance fool you. The dish is more sour than spicy, and it complements and heightens the lamb filling. After discovering these serendipitously, I've gone back to Xi'an Famous Foods just to have these dumplings (and forgo the noodles completely). One important note: These Dumplings are not available at every location at the time of writing, much to my woe. The location on 54th Street happens to serve them, so if you happen to be dining at this particular restaurant, I would strongly suggest that you give it a try.

Really impressed with the vegan Sichuan dishes here. I was worried I would see dishes too similar to other vegan Chinese restaurants. But the standout here is the Sichuan style offerings. I appreciate the expansion of vegan friendly options but I like variety and creativity in addition to quality. I came for dinner and was taken aback slightly by the crazy colorful disco lights flashing. The place was packed with diners chatting and eating away. The service by the way was superb- super attentive from refilling our drinks, bringing extra sauces, to replacing utensils which my friend kept dropping on the floor (waitress was quite observant to have kept noticing and was so patient to walk right over with a new set)For food, we tried several dishes primarily from the small bites section.Favorites were the steamed vegetable dumplings and the vegetable wontons in chili oil. While I can get these veggie items at other establishments (these are not new to the scene), I did appreciate the flavor and quality - they were fresh and delicious. I also really enjoyed the Mala beyond beef meatballs and the honey walnut edamame nuggets because I'd never tried vegan versions of some of my favorite Chinese dishes. The Dan Dan noodles were also good with the beyond beef crumbled atop. The peppercorn brussel sprouts were good but were the least exciting compared to the other dishes. From the big bites section, we tried the Dry pepper style eggplant and Dry pot style tofu. The eggplant is deep-fried and has spice which I preferred over the tofu dish. Note you have options (eggplant, tofu, or mixed veggies) to pair with the various big bite dishes. Not sure if dessert is offered. We had other plans after downing the delicious savory goodies. Small spot packing heat in small and large vegan bites. I would like to take my mom here!

Last night at Mira Sushi was actually my 1st event as a elite member of the Yelp club. First, thank you Ruggy for allowing me to attend. I arrived a bit early and actually paced back and forth outside for about 15 minutes before I actually went inside. Honestly, I was a bit nervous lol.. After going inside, I was greeted by Ruggy who gave me a comfortable place to sit and a name badge which I thought was cool. Started off with a glass of sake and some Parmesan truffle fries that were flavorful with a good crunch not saturated or weighed by the oil. Good stuff . Shortly after, a sushi pizza appetizer was brought out .... it was pretty spicy! Just like I like it lol. Then we got to the the tasting menu which was fantastic. Small bites of innovative sushi style appetizers along with the sake, and oh yeah I switched to rose' somewhere throughout the courses lol, we're a delight. The one course that I had questions about was the authenticity of the Wagyu slider. Didn't have the fat content of traditional Wagyu beef. Tasted very lean despite being cooked at what looked like medium temperature‍. Overall the look of the place was great with its dim lighting and elevated table chairs. The waitresses were consistent with making sure our glasses were always filled cant forget to mention how cute the were . Got the chance to meet some great people who sat with me and talked about where we were from and what they did for a living. Great mix of people with diverse backgrounds brought together by our passion for great food. I had a great time!!!!! It's was definitely worth it.

All in all, I had a wonderful time here. "Is 11a too early for a glass of wine?" the receptionist asked. With a newborn that just got into sleep training and Mama averaging 6+ hours of sleep at night, I'll take a glass anytime I can get it.They were really understanding of my train delay too (Ihateweekendtrainswhodoesnt) and I still was able to get my full booking despite being 20 mins late. I enjoyed my glass of white wine in a jacuzzi before the spa got really packed. I received my facial-- never having got one done before cause I have really sensitive skin and hello, horror stories of permanent scars-- but now I'm hooked. They look at your skin under this ginormous bright magnifying glass x1000 and yes, I know I have blackheads. Did I know they extend to my cheek? No, not to my (nor anyone else's) naked eye. BTW, don't book any dates til a few days after cause your skin will look red, bumpy and blotchy. BUT a week later, and I have to say my skin is looking brighter and more... supple, yes... Next up, massagy time! Very good. I asked my masseuse why I have this annoying pain in the middle of my spine and she said that I had a mild case of pregnancy-induced scoliosis. Ahhhhh that made a lot of sense! Also, made sense why my epidural failed (which ended up saving my baby's life)-- a story for another time. Thank God for my scoliosis then. She also said I could work on some back exercises which may help it go away (working on it)Gift from The Husband was again, a huge win. Much improved from the early dating years of "What do you want for Christmas this year?" Overall, great customer service! From the receptionist to Nina-- the skin aesthetician to Sofia-- the masseuse. Reminds me, Nina is from Uzbekistan so I said, "Oh, according to ancestry.com, I'm actually 1% from Kazakhstan". She says "You look like you're from Kazakhstan. They are very strong" (my mind is blown but also flashes to Borat voice 'In Kazakh, the women are very strong. They pull the plow like ox'. Also, related unrelated: google Corey Buchek "Bing bong bing bong bing" song)Locker room a bit small and if you wear a size L or above, wear a suit under or bring your own robe. I'm a S/M and I comfortably was just able to pull it around me; but I also love a big loose spa robe. Also heard some other women complaining about the size. Bottom line: Clean spa, fun, great services

Six years I lived down the street from the school. I had the opportunity to enter for various reasons on many occasions. I found this school to be typical of most Public Schools in NYC. It captured my heart because I considered it my neighborhood school. I remember used book sales in the vestibule. It helps raise funds for school needs. I came to this location to vote during election time. They were gracious and the premises were always clean. Since I moved from the vicinity I heard of some disturbing incidents. That was a couple years ago. I'm not concerned because even prestigious academy's have had incidents not far from here. PS 169 tightened control and security since then. Just remember that trouble can show up anywhere! Unless someone tells me different, I'm giving PS 169 Four Stars. It's going to be forever in a corner of my heart.

So, it was my Birthday Dinner! We decided to spend it at Osteria Morini. I had heard so many great things about this restaurant. When walking into this dimly lit, rustic restaurant It is just so cozy and romantic. We were a little early so we found a little area to hang out by the bar and try one of their cocktails. We decided on the soho special. It had vodka, espresso, vanilla, cream and club soda. The first sip we took reminded us of a spiked Yoo-hoo. It was so delicious. Def a must try when you come here. Our reservation was for 7pm and they seat and the exact time. We were seated in the back close to the open kitchen. It was really cool to see them cook. Also, we were able to see the gentleman cut the meats for the antipasto. The staff here is so pleasant and accommodating. Our waitress answered all our questions and recommended a lovely wine. We started off with a meat and cheese platter. We ordered way to much but it amazingly delicious. Speck, prosciutto and bresaola and Squacquerone (a spreadable creamy cheese), Parmesan reggiano and a Lardo spread. With a basket of warm bread. This was Ahmazzzing start!!For our second course we had pasta.Tagliatelle bolognese this was rich and full flavor dish. Ton of meat and the pasta was perfectly al dente. Def a must try.Our next pasta was super unique and something you won't find anywhere else. Spallina which is a double ravioli. It has two envelopes. One side with duck the other side with apple and parsnip. It's enrobed in a beautiful robiolina and butter sauce. The ravioli was cooked perfectly and the flavors worked perfectly together.To finished our dinner portion we tried the prochetta with beautiful crunchy, creamy potatoes. This was a beautiful dish. The porchetta although a tad fatty was juicy and full of beautiful flavor and the potatoes was nothing I every came across. We ordered the mushrooms as a side and although good a little over seasoned.At this point we were stuffed but we did order dessert. We ordered americanos and the crostata. Although good it was very sweet. I only was able to have a few bites.Osteria Morini is just an amazing restaurant. The food is of the highest quality and so is the staff. I highly recommend having dinner here. Parking is a tad difficult. Signs change at 6pm (338)

Food for everyone!This is a clear go to lunch spot in the area especially if you are indecisive. They have chopped salads, poke bowls, wraps, hot bar of food, sandwiches. It's just endless food here.I am a big fan on their egg sandwiches and wraps this is a place you really can't go wrong. On certain food their prices are a little high. In addition the have a huge selection of drinksIn short:- Great lunch spot for everyone- Good food

We came here in November with a group of friends, after having my birthday brunch down the block. We weren't ready to end the party so we stopped by Locksmith for a few drinks and to watch the game. Since it was an early Sunday, there was plenty of space at the bar for all eight of us and my daughter's stroller; I was able to park her right up to the bar.The bartender was very nice; she offered to make me another drink after I ordered something that tasted more like a spiked green juice than a cocktail but I decided to finish it and order something else. I tried their jello shots which were ok but I've definitely made better at home. We all shared their wings which were really goodThe decor is sexy and bathrooms are huge. That was a big plus, considering I had to roll my daughter's stroller in there to change her. I definitely want to visit again to try out their menu, either for brunch or dinner.

After picking up all of my healthy eats for the week, I needed to satisfy my weekend cravings. Which on this day, I had a hankering for oxtails. Yelp searched and found Ajo E Orégano..a Yelper favorite, located a little over a mile away from the closed restaurant I thought would be open to fulfill my oxtail needs. Arrived a few moments later. Found parking as someone was pulling out. Confidently walked into what shocked me as the teeniest restaurant I've seen in sometime. Excused and squeezed myself towards the back of the colorful, Caribbean-esque, galvanized tin ceiling, shack-like, island replica of a restaurant. There were people lined up and seated in every single inch of this place. All these things were a good enough indication for me. All the employees were working efficiently to get the to go orders and seated patrons orders placed. After a few moments of waiting, I was next in line and the gentleman who served me, was pleasant and helpful as, Yo hablo muy poco Español. The fine gentleman filled my to go container with enough Moros, Chivo Liniero (Goat Stew) and Maduros to feed four. The gravy had a nice flavor, but the stew could've been a bit more tender.I would go back but either on a Friday or Sunday to try out their Rabo Encendio (Oxtail Stew) as those are the only days they are served. One last note. If you can I would stick to, to go orders to avoid long wait times during peak hours.

Just stopped by this place this morning and really loved all of the options that were there! The format was a bit hard to navigate -- as far as there is no directory and you may feel like you're stuck in an eating labyrinth --- but that has never stopped my excitement. I can't wait to go back and try the Frites bar where you can order to your heart's desire what kind of frites you'd like. Only had time to stop and try an iced chai latte from the coffee spot inside Le District and it was absolutely delicious and very affordable. It also came out very quickly, which doesn't happen in nearby coffee spots at Brookfield Place (looking at you Joe & the Juice). Will be back again to try more!

Amazing sushi and sashimi!I was happy to hear of Sasabune Express, we have eaten at the original a few times and it varies from great to so so but the price is always high.After spending some time in Bloomingdale's we wanted some sushi for lunch. The location of this spot is a bit iffy, between first and second on 59th - loads of bridge traffic. The space is very small, a sushi bar and small tables. It was also extremely cold outside and they couldn't keep the restaurant warm.We had:- Scallop (regular and bay) - delicious​- Tuna Belly - terrific- Salmon - very good- Sea Urchin - delicious, highlight of the meal- Blue Crab - very good- Spicy Tuna Roll - good and an interesting choice - at the original location, they don't serve spicy tuna rolls- Green Salad - good, it was a plain saladOverall a very good sushi experience.

So convenient in the tunnel under columbus circle. hop off a subway and pick up a arepa. The arepas here are fresh and flavorful. White corn meal pockets of flavor.Favorites here for me were the #3, 7, and 10. The arepa with avocado, cheese, and sweet plantains. A great snack. The ground beef arepa with cheese and sweet plantain, and finally the smoked brisket with sweet plantain. All are nice portions and definitely fill you up. Go with 1 or 2 to share. A bit pricey but i guess it'll be in this area.I'll be back.

In looking for the door to this place, I nearly walked into both the chopped salad place next door and the travel/luggage store on the other side but the end result was worth the minimal embarrassment. I'm not a big coffee drinker but I love a good Italian pastry or sandwich as much as the next person. I knew I had to come back once I saw the tub of Perugina chocolates sitting by the counter. If you've never had the pleasure of unwrapping one of these babies and savoring each bite, you honestly haven't lived. These make Hershey's taste like chalk. I usually go with a cappuccino + croissant, though, if you're in the area for lunch, do yourself a solid and grab the caprese panini. They'll toast it for you. Back to the pastries: Zibetto does an amazing chocolate cornetti (don't call it a croissant). I also love the tiny butter cookies that they serve with the coffee drinks. Planning on trying the cannoli and tiramisu next. Also, Starbucks has ruined all the traditional coffee drink names - like another reviewer pointed out, it's not a "latte" but a "caffe latte." I watched the barista gently point this out to someone: the two had a good laugh over whether or not the guy really did want a cup of steamed milk.

One of my favorite omakase establishments in the city. The chef seems adamant not to serve the American holy trinity of salmon, yellowtail, and low grade tuna which is truly appreciated. Most, if not all, of the selection of fish and other ingredients comes from Japan. When each course or nigiri is served, the chef presents a "flash" card with the name of the fish. This may seem a bit odd but I actually like the practice so that It may be reference later when I desire to partake in additional items. Note to self: control yourself! I'm a little fatty so, YES to adding more portions. It helps me to recall the delicious meal I just had. The fish along with the chef accoutrements are texturally sensational and flavors divine. I enjoy the pickled ginger offered for cleansing between each serving. The staff are attentive throughout the meal and may assist with selection of the proper beverage for your meal. The overall experience is personal and generally a low key atmosphere. A wonderful culinary experience...indeed!

Midtown "Fun" Dive // Unlimited PopcornRose All Day // PicklebacksLeft and event and was looking for a place for everyone to hang out. With a wide range of people, a dive bar seemed the most inclusive. Opened up Yelp and noticed Snafu was nearby. Had been to Snafu once before and remembered having a good time. It was late enough and a weekday so we had the run of the place.We opted for a high top table in the bar area which was comfortable. I walked over and grabbed a bowl filled with popcorn, salted it, and shared it with our group. Such a great way to keep everyone drinking... (smart bar owners).Noticed several people downstairs laughing over a beer pong table.And then a bride and groom walked in and sat down at the bar. #OnlyinNYC #YepThatHappenedSeveral dozen photos later I had uploaded some images for the happy pair and we found ourselves enjoying picklebacks with them.Pitchers of beer... smiles... and great conversations ensued... Love this spot. Will definitely be back.The Scene: Divey, FratDestination Rating: 7Date Rating: 4Hob Nob Potential: 7Strong Suggestion: Bring friends, come on a quiet night.

Great steakhouse! Definitely a fan of this place. The only reason why I didn't give 5 stars is because I ordered a bottle of wine and literally took 15ish minutes. Someone forgot not sure what exactly happened but I was a little annoyed. BUT the general manager came by and gave us a free ricotta appetizer which was nice. The food was amazing and the service was great. Things I ordered: - Ricotta: Pomegranate Seeds, Crispy Rosemary, Sea Salt, Chili, Honey, Grilled Bread (must get!!!) - Broiled Oysters: Garlic, Romano Cheese, Bread Crumbs, Parsley (must get!!) - Maine Lobster Ceviche: Cara Cara, Cucumber, Avocado, Cilantro, Leche de Tigre (its okay, I wouldn't get it again)- T-Bone Florentine: 40oz, 40-Day Dry Aged- Tomahawk Ribeye: 40oz, Market Onions, Romesco Sauce- Caesar Salad- Patatas Bravas

I didn't eat a full dinner, but this is an absolutely gorgeous space with an elaborate cocktail menu (including a smoky old-fashioned that comes in a large glass with a stem, a wooden cap that the waiter removes to release the smoke). The prices are high but matched by attentive though not overly aggressive/hovering service. The couple next to us was celebrating a birthday and they brought the woman a little gift bag and dessert (clearly they'd ordered quite expansively). Brian Newman's band plays on Saturday nights (9-12) and it's worth getting a table for drinks, appetizers, and dessert if you don't feel like ordering entrees or a full dinner. Chocolate cake was decadent, as were the truffle fries. If you're there to see Brian and choose not to get a table at the bar, I'd get there early. The stage is elegant, though small. The scallop appetizer is perfect, though not overly large.  I can't wait to come back.

A friend and I came in on a Friday night with a 6 pm reservation, but it didn't seem too packed yet. To start, we had the agedashi tofu, which I thought was good, but nothing too special. My friend loved it though. For my entree, I went with the assorted sushi and sashimi ($38). This came with 9 pieces of sashimi, 6 pieces of sushi, 3 pieces of a sushi roll, and 2 of those egg things (which I could have done without). It would have been nice if they explained each fish to us but they kind of just left the dishes on our table, and walked away before we even had a chance to ask for anything else. Everything was good though. I really liked the tuna (which is usually my fave), the uni, and the salmon - plus the fact that it was very lightly seared.It's a little pricier than other sushi restaurants of similar quality, but worth it for a once in a while splurge. Maybe next time I'll try their early bird special for $30, which includes sashimi, sushi, soba, and dessert (also avail on Fridays!)

A fancy-pants dim sum place on the upper east side that has a nice selection of delicious dishes.The xiao long bao (steamed pork soup dumplings) at $10 had good soup but was not as revelatory as others I've had. The shu mai (hong Kong style) was good but also not particularly special. The har gao was nice with delicate and thin rice skin. The pan-fried noodles with chicken was delicious as well.Overall, it was a satisfying meal. Just be prepared to spend a good amount in order to try the other things on the menu ($48 for Peiking duck, for example). I did like their partnership with Yelp, with 5% cash back and free chicken dumplings!

Came here on Sunday for a late lunch on a very rainy day. The staff was talking amongst themselves when we arrived, but were quick to help and jump into action. We ordered the Falafel Trio platter and the Deluxe sandwich with avocado. I probably would've added fries to my sandwich if I could, but the only option was to have them as a side, so we passed. The woman taking our order, noticed I was feeling under the weather and let me know that they also sell tea in case I wanted some =), that was nice of her.There are a few high tables and counters for seating, but I can imagine the place filling up during the lunch rushes, on non-cold and rainy days. The table we sat at was a bit dirty, but nothing a little wet nap didn't clean right up. The table was designed with photos of chickpeas, which was cute, and there is a water cooler at the front counter for you to take as you please. There is also a clean bathroom available for customers.We received our food pretty fast, and it was great. We were a little afraid that since the place was empty coming in, that the falafel wouldn't be crunchy or etc but that wasn't the case at all. The falafels were super crunchy, the hummus was great, and just all the food in general exceeded our expectations. The trio platter is definitely enough for two people, just get an extra pita bread, or two. Because we ordered two items, we ended up taking home half of the trio platter and it made for a great dinner the following night. The falafels were really good even when reheated in the toaster oven, and didn't get dry.All in all, we'll be back here for sure. I'm already craving it again.

Great new spot by the illustrious David Burke, perfect for brunch or dinner outings in a warm and classy space. A group of us came to enjoy a variety of lunch dishes. My favorite was the Wings & Rings with Korean-style fried wings and calamari on top. A cute nod to KTown steps away. The wings were perfectly crunchy and saucy, though messy. Pocono Pasta was nicely al dente and picked up all the cheesy goodness. Cheese & Charcuterie platter came with Humboldt Fog, manchego and a blue, alongside prosciutto and other meats.WDB also offers a variety of wood-fired pizzas, which seem to be a popular choice at the tables. If you're adventurous (or in need of a different protein source), try their Roasted Cricket Pizza. Tuna crudo, Broccoli & guacamole, Woodpecker fried chicken sandwich, Woodfire salmon were all enjoyed by friends. It seems their kitchen most certainly utilizes their wood-burning ovens in preparation of many dishes! Desserts were sweet endings, including a Creamsicle creme brûlée and Strawberry red velvet ice cream sundae. Banana chocolate pb cream cake with warm chocolate sauce drizzled on top was quite decadent. Overall a nice spot deserving of future visits, ideally for brunch next time!

It was a dark and stormy afternoon. As the winds whipped up the rain outside, my friends and I sought refuge from nature's battering against our umbrellas and coats. Like a mirage in a desert, 169 Bar's colorful sign called out to us and we quickly made our way into the establishment, huffing and puffing as we streamed in through the small entrance.As we entered, the familiar dive bar combination of bleach and spilled drinks of the past hit our noses. Dark corners abounded, others were lit by the various colorful lights set up throughout the bar. Kitsch abounded. To the right, a painting of a woman with strategically placed googly eyes. Right next to the entrance were two wood mermaid carvings that looked like they once roamed the high seas in the front of a boat. Towards the bar was a functional (and shockingly clean looking) water fountain, complete with a pile of cups. The bar was very clean and organized and not exactly what you would picture when someone says "100 year old dive bar". I appreciated the decor and sense of whimsy.Our party had arrived at an odd time, so there were not a lot of people. We only wanted to grab one drink and rest a bit and so we ordered. The bartender was a friendly, easy going gent who seemed very at ease behind the bar. I wound up ordering CC's Bourbon Mint Lemonade featuring Bulleit Bourbon, Lemonade and Mint. This was served in a nice tall glass with bits of fresh mint in it. The drink is nice and sweet but the Bourbon definitely gives it a bit of a kick. It was also refreshing, and I could not help but think it would make a great summer drink.We headed back out into the thrashing rain soon after, but our respite had been a welcome one. Apparently the food in 169 is well thought of and I made a mental note to try it some time as I said a quiet goodbye to the wooden carvings near the door and exited.

Spacious, comfortable dining environment. Good service. Food is good as well - some value combo meals available. They have long happy hours though the price isn't much different.Grill your own meat, but it's easy to handle, and the server change grill for you frequently (without you needing to ask for it).

A friend told us about this place since it's near where we live so on a lazy Saturday afternoon we decided to check it out.ATMOSPHERE: Inside is very cozy and has a half cafe feel half coffee shop. When you first walk in you are hit with a blend of smells including spices and coffee. There are some high tables, small tables and then high stools facing the window. It was pretty crowded when we came so we were barely able to find a seat.FOOD: They have coffee as well as food. The menu on Yelp is a bit outdated as they seem to have other options as well. We opted for 2 things and shared them. They both come with a tahini sauce I believe and an orange slice.PITA LABNEH - basically it's like a flat pita bread toasted with cheese and spices inside. It kind of me reminded me of a bagel with cream cheese but really thin. I honestly don't know why they charge so much if there's no meat, I think it was almost $10. It was pretty tasty.GREEN OMELETTE SANDWICH - a large omelette with veggies stuffed inside of a pita with lettuce and tomato. It was pretty hefty and is definitely enough for 1 person to feel full. I don't normally like omelettes but this wasn't bad since it was in a sandwich form.Overall, good food and I would definitely like to try some of their other items and hummus as well.

When I started seeing these cutely packaged bubble tea drinks on Instagram, I had to check out where this place was! Upon stepping in, I was expecting to see the pink and blue couches. But the store is actually pretty huge. You order by the counter first and walk further down for the cute seating area. At the time we went, they were doing $2 drink promotions, where each day offers a different discounted drink! This is an amazing deal as my Mai Tai Tea only ended up being $2.18! So take advantage! Aside from the cute aesthetic interior, they also had a clean, sleek bathroom, and played fantastic music. There is even a heater in the seating area, perfect for the cold winter day. Unfortunately, the drinks were not on par with everything else. The lid for the Haitai Tea was different. I had to lift the flap open to put my straw in, which is really weird. But the other photos didn't have that lid, so maybe it was just that day. And while people raved about the bubbles, I personally found the bubbles undercooked tasting. They were hard, and not the good kind of chewy. The Mai Tai Milk Tea with Milk Tea was too sweet. Fortunately, they look out for lactose intolerants here and had soymilk & almond milk options! The Mai Tai didn't taste as sweet with the soymilk but was overall, nothing special. I would not pay full price for this ($5) as the size was pretty small too.Overall, I had a fantastic first experience here but their drinks are otherwise pricey for the quality.

The place itself is very small and all the seats were taken. I went on a Thursday night, but given the size and how good the food is, I wouldn't be surprised if it's always full. As an appetizer, I split the dumplings filled with potatoes and herbs (#13). There are 8 dumplings, so even though it's listed as an entree, sharing this is a great appetizer. I don't remember what my friend got, but it was a vegetable entree in a kind of soup or very liquid sauce. There was a side of rice so all mixed together it was a great combo. I got the pan fried noodles with shrimp (#31) and it was amazing. I would definitely eat here again. I either recommend coming alone or with maximum 3 other people. Two tops are the best option in my opinion.

Was looking for a fun happy hour spot with healthy-ish (new year/new me) food options and so glad the decision finalized on The Folly.Walked in expecting for it to be busy for a 5:30pm Thursday and I was pleasantly surprised there was a ton of room at the bar. Grabbed a couple seats, greeted quickly, and ordered drinks immediately.Decor is awesome and I love how the goth/nautical theme makes you feel like you're in the downstairs of an old, dark, cool pirate ship. We ordered the Halibut Ceviche, super fresh and tasty. Also got the Octopus Skewers, usually like my Octo a big on the charred/crispy side, so it was a bit chewy for me, but still well done. Side of guac it's served with was delish.All in all the couple hours spent at The Folly were definitely happy ones, and I would absolutely stop in again.

I visited Tomino after the restaurant had been added to the list of NYC's 2019 Michelin Bib Gourmands, and I have to admit that I was pleasantly surprised by the restaurant. Little Italy needs a little more diversity in the style and cuisine of restaurants in the area, and Tomino is a much needed addition. The first half of the venue is set up in a true tapas restaurant style - with plenty of counter seating for guests to get a glass of wine and enjoy a variety of small plates. The second half of the restaurant is a traditional dining room, and good for parties both large and small.My guest and I started off with a number of tapas. The classic Pulpo, or Octopus, was cooked to a perfect texture and sprinkled with a generous amount of paprika. I did find the flavor to be a little monotonous, however. Loved the Huevos Rotos, and the Lamb Chops were so flavorful and paired deliciously with a chestnut puree; however, I will note that while we asked for medium rare, it was cooked to a very noticeable rare. I would skip the Scallops - three of them are served in a scallop shell and covered in a generous sauce. The scallops were slightly undercooked and had no sear or texture.The star of the dinner was definitely the Tomahawk Steak for Two. It was beautifully cooked and presented, and at the ideal medium rare we asked for. Each cut was so flavorful, and I appreciated the range of lean to fattier portions of meat available. I wasn't a huge fan of the semi-soggy potatoes, but my guest enjoyed them more.Service was on point and very attentive, and our water was refilled constantly. While I overall enjoyed the experience, there are some tweaks and misses on dishes that make the place fall just shy of perfect.

38 Parlor is a unique venue that can be an out of the norm event space for your next event. On the 3rd floor, you will find a full floor uniquely designed with some ornate vintage pieces, exposed brick, luxurious wall paper and an old skool phone booth. (great photo opps)The main room is ornately decorated with vintage rugs, wood end tables and velvet couches. There is a small bar and a vintage claw foot bathtub that is used to chill beverages. Additionally there is a full kitchen with two additional specially themed rooms and a small private alcove. You can bring your choice of food and beverages (the kitchen is useful) to be served to your guest for whatever event you are celebrating and there is room for a DJ to set up also. I was in attendance for a private party and there was good use of the entire space. The opportunity for dancing was readily available however, the rugs can be a trip hazard so it's important to be careful.Unfortunately I failed to get pics of the awesome highlights about the space that I mentioned but do know it was pretty cool and a great change of pace and atmosphere.  Just A Note:The elevator was out of service (12/30/18) and there were extension cords running up and down the stairs which was a cause for concern. I'm not sure if it's a regular occurrence or if it had anything to do with something on another floor.

Plenty of seating, fantastic customer service.Rotisserie chicken was great and the potatoes were super delicious. But the honeycomb Lasagna....man! Definitely stopping by for lunch since this place is near my office. Didn't get a chance to try dessert because i was in a hurry but great ambience and lovely staff.

What a pleasant surprise this turned out to be. I was coming from Lukes lobster shack, after picking up a delicious lobster grill cheese sandwich and they no longer had any of their soups available. I happened to pass this restaurant on the way home and see they had a lobster bisque available so I went in to order some to take home and I was greeted by such a lovely host, that I decided to sit down ordered me some wine while I waited for my soup. The restaurant itself is quite small but very romantic, perfect place for date night, or just to be low key while grabing a bite to eat, or sumthin to sip on. My lobster bisque was worth every penny. It had big lumps of lobster, it was so smooth and creamy filled with such flavor, cant wait to do another visit and explore the menu. F.Y.I. This restaurant honors your yelp check-in only if you stay and have dinner, thats what I was told, so I saved mines for another time.

New Mediterranean corner spot that cooks up schwarma & falafel plates and pitas in a spiffed up key corner right next to Cinepolis.Great pice point with sit down and take out. I went with a falafel platter. Really cute packaged hummus, babaganousch and baklava. Price point is very reasonable for healthy Med. fare. Soft opening today with more options coming and always need more Med in our lives. Glad to see this spot in the 'hood. Welcome to Chelsea!

I first saw The Polynesian float around my Yelp feed a few months ago. I was instantly hooked; being someone who is a fan of tiki and Polynesian aesthetics, I smashed that bookmark button hard. I was in midtown for a meeting the other day and one of my colleagues suggested we go here afterwards, so naturally I eagerly said yes. I haven't seen too many tiki bars around NYC; most of my experiences with them have been in Florida at Disney's Polynesian Village Resort. That's really my reference point, which can be a good and bad thing since Disney tends to exaggerate many of their themes. Either way, I went into the Poly with an open mind. The bar is located inside the Pod Hotel on 42nd street. We were instructed to check-in on the ground floor where we received wrist bands and then went up to the lobby level where the bar was. I really didn't get the whole wrist-band and check in thing since the space was mostly empty when we arrived, but whatever maybe it's part of their operating procedures. Anyway, the space was quite large; they had a combination of lounge seating, tables, booths, and outdoor/rooftop space. The decor was *perfect* - it captured the tiki bar feel but also had a sophisticated edge to it that prevented the space from being kitschy. They really paid attention to details like low lighting and branding on the plates and coasters - I really appreciate little things like that. We were not hungry so we decided to all share some of the large-format drinks. We tried the Barbossa's Punch first which was rum-based and had a number of fruit juices plus other goodies in it. The drink was tasty, strong but also smooth. It was served in a ceramic treasure chest which was a nice touch. The second one we tried was the Humuhumunukunukuapua'a which was served in a large fishbowl. This was also rum-based with some absinthe, coconut, and juices. Like Barbossa, it was smooth and fun to drink.Contrary to some reviews here, I thought service was fine; they checked in at just the right moments and got our drinks out relatively quickly. The bathrooms are also worth noting - the stalls are private with full-sized doors for optimal privacy #bless. Overall, I enjoyed the Poly - the drinks were good and the aesthetics were on point. I would definitely come back to explore more of their cocktails and perhaps try some of their food.

Katz's is probably the most famous deli in New York, if not the world.I've lived five minutes from here for almost three years but my first visit was last weekend. Somehow my desire for meat and willigness to wait in line never quite dovetail. But around 11 am on a Sunday the lines were mild and my boyfriend and I decided it was the day.Katz's is chaotic in a way it doesn't need to be. Confusingly, there's a small section for table service. There are at least three places to queue for food, though I believe only two of those serve sandwiches. The lines are self-forming and unpoliced, which leads to a lot of cutting.It took us maybe 20 minutes to get our sandwich, and that was with a negligible line compared to the hordes coming in when we left. Service is rushed and indifferent. Tables aren't very clean and if you get soup there'll be about as much on the plate as in the bowl.So, why go?The pastrami is truly all that. Thick cut, mildly smoky, moist, reminiscent of a pleasantly fatty brisket. Excellent. All it needs is that nice sharp mustard and a few bites of pickle. Absolutely worth the $22 split between two people.We also had a chocolate egg cream (unknown, at least $5) and matzoh ball soup ($8). The former is a great example, a bit creamier than typical. The latter is mostly broth and ball, but both are solid. It's massive so split this as well.After tax and tip, this somehow added up to $60. They're cash only and you pay with your ticket on the way out.Overall, the experience is stressful but it's worth doing at least once. I may look into delivery to get that meat without the hassle, but I know I'll be going back for it.

Went to see Dear Evan Hanson here. The theater is not very big but quite nice. I was a bit upset that the upper section seats were not cheaper. After now having gone, I will say there are not many bad seats. I was in the middle row of the upper section, stage right and the view was almost completely clear. The seats are comfortable and rather spacious for relative to most theaters.

Whenever I stop in to kill time because I missed my bus I am greeted by such a warm smile. Claire, the bartender is a true gem. I normally get a well drink that consists of Jameson and ginger ale for $7. They also offer Happy Hour specials for certain drinks for $5.Their menu is not extensive but some of the items are decent. I've tried the mozzarella sticks which can be a hit or miss, the chicken quesadilla which is not so good, and their boneless wings which are so-so.

Delicious soondubu in Chinatown!! I don't live near Chinatown but this was worth a trip. My new fave soondubu in NYC! They have various soup "flavor" options (meat and seafood) and also mushroom and veggie (ask for vegetarian broth). The tofu was smooth and silky; the soup was delicious and flavorful!! There was depth to it and not just salty spicy broth. The medium spicy was not too spicy and just right for me! Yummy banchan dishes too and they refill it constantly without you even asking. So nice of them!Lots of other menu items- appetizers, bibimbap, bbq, ramen. Service was great- really warm & friendly staff/ owners. It made me feel like I was eating a home cooked meal. The decor was inviting and overall great ambience. Not too noisy and just great to enjoy a nice meal. I'll be back !

this is probably my favorite ramen place around the area in ktown (not that many ramen options to choose from anyway). Service is great, friendly staff and the ramen actually tastes good too! Totally recommend giving this place a try if you like ramen. Koku Ramen with wavy noodle is the best combo! tan tan noodle had a very peanutty flavor soup base, not my favorite. I prefer the original koku pork broth over that. Add a little spicy if you can handle it!

Think this place should come with a warning: waiting for the egg sandwich will take about 30 minutes out of your day. Also, it is hideously expensive, but luckily (?) I've become largely immune to the meaning of money after living here for so long. With that said, yes this was Top 3 best egg sandwiches I've ever had. My anger and anxiety that had built up during the wait (my friend and I had an appointment and we were in danger of running late) vanished with the first bite. Not sure how they do it, but they've managed to turn a sausage, egg, croissant sandwich into a True Culinary Experience. In addition to that, they also offer a very solid cup of Counter Culture coffee.Aside from the wait in the very small space, I have no real complaints.

Loved loved loveddd this place. I can totally come back here multiple times. And all you yelpers, make sure to check in. You get a free cocktail. They have two options for the free drink , boilermaker ( bourbon based) and Greentini. Both of them pretty good & strong. Between the three of me & my friends, we got a few different dishes. Highly recommended dishes would be the wild mushroom croquettes, Gambia's Al Ajillio & Tuna tartare. Very very well make and great flavors. The lamb chop was alright. We like it more well done and this was rare so maybe that's why the opinion. I loved the decor of the whole place. So cozy, intimate and so inviting. The service was pretty good. Very well informed servers and hostess.

Very good Thai place, that is in the area of Midtown, the restaurant from outside looks smaller than it is, but this place has two floors, with making it good for any date night or a good meal with a few friends.I came here with a few friends, and we decide to go to the second floor, our waiter was nice and fast I and my friends share a few appetizersCurry Puffs a light, golden puffs stuffed with mixed vegetables and served with cucumber relish come with two pieces, this looks similar to a empanadas very good taste even that was only a veggie option, I really enjoy each bit of it.  Slow-Cooked Pork Belly a deliciously juicy, very tender pork belly that melts only with touching my palate, very tasty the best of the night. For my main course, I had the Drunk noddles, with was good and the portion was very big, and the price was reasonable.

Picture man bun wearing hipsters from Brooklyn invading your grandparents old finished basement to play Bocce Ball while drinking craft beer and cocktails. Yes, an indoor Bocce Ball court!Yet, I did not mind it as I was sipping on a cold brew sitting on a couch in front of a fireplace surrounded by a 70's look and feel. That's a heck of a lot of wood paneling! All that was needed was an old TV with rabbit ear antennas with Scooby Do and The Jetsons being shown.Its actually kind of neo-retro cool, and a different look over the cookie cutter Irish bro-fest bars that occupy Yorkville. Taking up residency in the spot that the tired and boring Jack Russell's was in, Jack and Fanny's is a welcome addition to the neighborhood, and offers up something dissimilar from the norm up here. Someone needs to tell some of the Yelpers here giving two star reviews to lighten up and get over themselves a bit. Have some fun and open your minds up just a little. There are still plenty of boring sports bars on the UES to watch football at while drinking crappy beer and eating fattening fried food with all the bro's. You'll be just fine.I have not tried any of the food here yet, but the house cocktail list is fun and there is a decent selection of craft beer to choose from. I found the bartenders to be polite and helpful. It's a big space with more than enough seats to chill at. Some funny signs and pictures on the walls too.Brought here by the same owners of Bondurants across the way, yet it's a totally different type of style and worth giving a shot or two. Total nostalgia, and brings back fond memories of visiting long gone relatives while chilling out in their "finished rec room" downstairs.Now, hand me a Bocce Ball and stand back!

Yesss finally made my way here first things first ID check go figured honestly didn't think they would even check it. Cake batter & Maple Bacon ... we're our choices Cake batter vodka martini wow what a great flavor & taste to this really surprised at how much u can actually taste the alcohol really didn't think that the ice cream would have such a strong alcohol taste. The Maple Bacon Bourbon was good as well nice combo the sweet & salty would b nicer if the bacon was more crispy. Second time around we had the ice cream flight great way to try few flavors. Vanilla bean bourbon good flavor, Hot buttered Rum was delicious, Red Velvet martini was not bad & the cake batter martini great flavor too. Small location not a lot of room for sitting down, cute decor ... they offer an ice cream happy hour very cool. Quick service & prices are decent great boozy ice cream will really make the time to visit from time to time.

I came here with two of my friends for dinner. My friend reserved a table and we were seated once everyone arrived. The waitress was very informative, patient, and helpful in explaining the menu. What I love about this restaurant is the palette. The menu changes daily so there are so many dishes you will never try unless you come here all the time. There are so many different flavors which beautifully come together. The whole experience was an 8.5-9.0/10. My friend really wanted to try the rotisserie duck, but you need to reserve that so maybe next time... My favorite dish was definitely the sizzling Grilled FlatironWe started out by ordering from the Raw section of the menu: the Maine Uni over rice. It was filled with a variety of flavors. I am not used to the fine-dining experience so when I first saw the dish, I just thought "that's it?" That's when I realize uni is a delicacy. Then, we ordered from the Large section of the menu: the Grilled Flatiron. The waiter poured shaoxing cream sauce which caused the dish to sizzle. The beef was cooked and cut beautifully and the sauce made it all the more appetizing with the enoki mushrooms. The meat was very tender. 10/10 (I loved it!) Then came another dish from the Large section: Shellfish & Sambal. I thought the Sambal made the noodles very flavorful and spicy. The coconut flavor was very evident in the dish. The shrimps were huge and nicely cooked, though I was not a huge fan of the shrimp. I thought this dish was not incredible since there are definitely places that serve curry just as good, but way more affordable. Finally, we all decided to order a slice of coconut pie for each person. This pie was a wonderful surprise. When the pie slices came, we slowly stared at what was on our plate. When I think of coconut pie, I pictured a giant custard pie with white coconut cream on top. What we saw was a dark slice of coconut pie with coconut whipped cream on the side. I placed my spoon and took a piece of the coconut pie and smattered it with a small smear of coconut whipped cream. The slice of coconut pie was so well put together. Sweet and savory. I applaud! This is probably the best coconut pie I've ever tried (so far) in my life.

Came here expecting the bare minimum. The NYC lunch crowd has been watching their waist lines, drinking kombucha, and taking early morning barre classes. by Chloe serves vegan food that is "fresh" and "not processed." It's the restricted diet answer to Panera Bread or Cosi. Well, surprised to say that it is actually good. I thoroughly enjoyed my vegan mac and cheese (large portion) and it definitely filled me up. The rest of the menu looked very appealing and I was tempted to get something else. This mac and cheese was good for vegan food (obviously nothing beats the real deal), and I enjoyed sampling their chipotle aioli sauce.It's expensive to eat out in this neighborhood, and as far as prices this is on par with what you would end up paying at Dig Inn or any other "fresh ingredients" sort of place.

This Japanese transplant is popping up like daisies in NYC, for good reason. It is delicious. They design their seating, and operation to be good and fast and arguably a place to steak for one. You pay when you leave. You order the steak at the grill station and the server takes your order for sides and soups. High tops are meant for side by side seating or seating for one. Might not be comfortable for some, and don't recommend for groups. Takeout is available... definitely want to try that one day and see how that is. It is inexpensive for steak at a restaurant but to be clear, it is not "cheap." Meats are still a range of $3 per oz and up. My hubs got the ribeye cause that's his fave. I don't like ribeye, too fatty. You have to order a 10oz min. I ordered my fave which is the filet, min 7 oz. They have other cuts, like assorted cubs, sirloin and even wagyu which I think is pricey but guess that is pricey everywhere. When the steak comes out, it comes out on a VERY hot plate so you want to order it rare. That's what they recommend and they might glare at you if you don't actually. It cools down quick. Be sure to pour some steak sauce on top of it before it does. They put a dollop of garlic butter atop. The steak is really really good and 7oz for me, of filet is plenty. Also, you can add on a garnish for $1. This is where I think they make a ton of $$$. They give you little for $1 and I think this should be included anyway. But, they do include basic onion and corn I think. I got potato, green bean which I could have done without. My hubs got broccoli as a garnish. You can get a beefy miso soup (comes as a mug), and side house salad for $5. Some might say it's small but I think it's fine for me. I got two mochi for $4, pretty good mochi where more ice cream was tasted, less flour and gelatinous chewy parts. The green tea and strawberry was good. Service was pretty good- typical Japanese politeness and attentiveness with water refills. I'd come back but I'd skip the side salad, soup, and maybe go with just one garnish. Good for them for trying something different. Total bill was some $66.

All you can eat finally in NYC!! Came here twice in one weekend! Reservations can be made through Yelp which was great. I came here for both a dinner and lunch. I would say both are worth the price. Lunch has more limited selections but still has the prime good stuff for what you are paying like pork belly, brisket, short ribs, tofu stew. I would say meat is not the all time best quality but it sure came plentiful. I was partial to the none marinated meats. Ate it all and then some. The meal comes with bon chan like kimchi, a light cabbage slaw, onions and bean sprouts. For dinner, it came with cheese corn as well. Wait staff was very attentive and they truly earned their tips by helping you bbq and cut the meats. I would say this place is great for small and big groups. They can easily seat a party of six to share a grill which are large in size. Overall, I would definitely come again!

Can't believe I've lived in NYC since the mid 90's and never come here! Actually, I don't listen to jazz music that much so that could explain it.  A buddy from college wanted me to go see the Slim Gambill quartet with him so I said "sure".  (Slim is the guitarist for Lady Antebellum and he calls his music "fake jazz" but I can definitely say it was amazing!)Anyway, so I came here and had a wonderful evening. Drinks were small but strong, so that was nice. Everything was a little pricey but I liked my food (except for the "jumbo lump crab cake" which was neither jumbo nor lump-see picture) and I had a very relaxing and memorable evening.The show I saw was in the lower level and it was very nice. I felt so sophisticated, like I was in a Woody Allen movie! The acoustics were great but it wasn't deafening so I was really able to enjoy the music. The staff was great...every interaction I had was wonderful so I will definitely be back.

We truly had no idea how good this place was going to be. Why? Let me explain.Tiny Shanghai is tucked in Little Italy, looks a little too new to compete with the cult classics of Chinatown, and draws in a hipster crowd. It took a few minutes to understand, but upon tasting the food, everything made perfect sense.The soup dumplings were simply amazing. The skin was very deliciously thin, but held just enough strength that it did not break or let any precious soup out. Sometimes the tops can be wrapped too thick to enclose the dumpling, but these were flawless and delicate. The scallion pancake with beef was 100% THE BEST I've ever had. The pancake was the perfect amount of crispy, and loaded with cucumber and a sweet sauce on the beef. I cannot recommend this dish enough!Chinatown is filled with a certain type of Chinese restaurant- they've usually been around for decades and you can tell the chefs are immigrants that passed on recipes and have been cooking food their entire lives. You can taste the hard work and dedication, and sense the chef has been seasoned with generations of cooking experience. Tiny Shanghai reminds me of a hip, busy restaurant in Los Angeles with bombbbb ass food. Everything about them says young and west coast. They are the next generation of authentic Chinese food, taking those same old recipes, making it their own, and doing it well. Major kudos to you, Tiny Shanghai!

This will be a list-y review:-Highly instagramable-Floral arrangements on point!-Small, private, away from crowded areas-Food is out of this world! *Butternut squash w/ ricotta & fried chicken & waffles are our faves!-People will be taking lots of pictures, just like you will be doing-There may or may not be a poor man's photo shoot going on outside your window for about an hour plus (except in inclement weather)-Great brunch and/or date spot-Amazing drinks!

I came in for a quick lunch and had a really solid meal. They have a few lunch specials but definitely could add a few more sushi options. Their chicken dumplings were really great. Not a life changing meal but great quality sushi. I'll definitely be back to see how they are for dinner.

My fiancé loves a good cigar so we stumbled in to Carnegie Club (his spot) for a Sunday funday. I've never been to a cigar bar before and had a blast. Grab a drink and get your smoke on! Be careful though, your clothes WILL smell.

We all know that nagging feeling when you're debating whether to go to a buzzy Midtown mega-restaurant: Am I just an adorable-yet-foolish sheep running into a pricey pen with mediocre eats?I definitely had that discomfort when I booked Empellon, but after a thoroughly lovely Sunday night meal, all my angst was a distant memory.Most surprisingly, the meal ended up being affordable -- if you're a fairly light eater and don't feel the need to splurge on A5 Wagyu beef, you can fill up for a very fair price. Yes, you'll probably spend anywhere from $14 to $22 for two tacos, but they're substantial tacos, not to mention delicious. The wine list caters to high rollers, but it has plenty of options for the hoi polloi.Most importantly, the meal was a brilliant combination of fun and fine dining. The servers are pros all the way and not the least bit snooty, and many of the dishes -- from the chips with guacamole and seven salsas, to the seasonal fruit dessert assortment -- are just flat-out good times. In closing, "Empellon" means "shove," and if you're on the fence about stopping by this hotspot, I hope this review helps push you over the top to book a table.

Bad analogy- but I feel Jagua is like that long-standing Broadway play that either gets better with time- or slightly shifts with time. Let's be right on the money though- I think I have a say on this one and have been coming to Jagua on and off- for almost 20 years. During that time, things have changed, portions changed, as well as taste. But on plus side- they ditched the vinyl table covers for faux-wood table tops and "woven" neutral place mats. Don't get me wrong- Dominican food here isn't horrible at all. But it's enough for me to notice obvious differences- or maybe I'm just wishing for Dominican food- the way my Mom makes. With the ever-changing Lower East Side, high rises, chichi Lounges, yada yada yada- it's downright nice to see Castillo is STILL pumping out Dominican food after all these years. Hubby would come here on a daily when he lived in the LES in the late 80s- so I guess these guys are doing something right. Seems small, but Castillo has plenty table seating plus more at the counter. Go in and sit yourself with Merengue, Bachata, Perico Ripiao or Salsa always playing- so you're all good with the music. A few slips along the way, but really nothing to make me not want to return. Will brutally say though- it didn't dawn on me til midway our Lunch- that on my most recent visit with Mom and my hubby- Maduros I ordered, tasted like they've been fried using the same oil for other stuff (Chicken? Meat?- none I eat) and left most behind ;-(. Camarones Enchilados were substantial and good. Mom liked her Mofongo and my hubby always enjoys their double-broiled pork chops. FYI... Forget about all the other "Jagua" restaurants- this right here folks is king. Crowd? A real nice mix of cultures digging in plus prices are real damn good. Service? Very attentive but other times it lacks- so don't take insult if the all Dominican crew on deck isn't smiling ear-to-ear. Just come for the food.

KenScale: 8.25/10I have been very excited about a Renaissance of sort with all the exciting Chinese restaurants that have opened in New York City that create their own paths with distinct menus and culinary styles. In particular, the restaurants showcasing Chinese-style rice noodles called mifen, starting from Little Tong Noodle Shop, are quickly challenging the stronghold that Japanese ramen shops currently enjoy in the city. Hunan Slurp is one of the new trailblazing newcomers in this regard, with an interesting background story of the chef who was once an artist who "seek to cure his homesickness through cooking" (directly quoted from the restaurant's website) at this new sleek operation with futuristic décor. While Little Tong's noodle dishes are based on the influence of Yunnan province in the southwest of China, this restaurant, as the name suggests, draws influence from the Hunan province in central China. The biggest mistake my wife Jun and I made once we sat down and browsed the menu was that we did not realize that the restaurant does not yet a liquor license and therefore can't serve any alcohol. We both like to wash down our food with some sips of wine, cocktails or beer so that was a huge oversight, even more so once we realized how good the food at Hunan Slurp was.Contrary to my initial thought that this was a noodle-centric shop, Hunan Slurp's menu is surprisingly expansive, starting with hot and cold appetizers followed by mifen and seasonal specials sections.
