We weren't quite sure about the portions of the dishes and ordered only three which turned out to be a wise decision because the portion was quite generous. As if reflecting the chef's background, the plating of each dish had a certain artistic appeal to it, starting with the skewed beef with cumin in toothpicks that was a beauty to look at under the lights and was a great way to start the meal with chewy beef piece that was a perfect bite size. We also tried the Farmer's Egg dish consisting of stir fried egg accompanied by pepper and pork. I very much liked its robust flavor with spicy kick although Jun thought the seasoning was a little too aggressive and ordered a bowl of white rice to help neutralize the seasoning. For the mifen, we decided to go the other direction of spiciness spectrum and ordered a bowl with fish fillet and seasonal green. The broth was pure white and already smelled wonderful when the bowl came in front of us; its aromatic flavor helped balance out the bold flavor from the other two dishes and turned out to be more and more addictive as I slurped the noodle. Jun remarked that the soup reminded her of a Korean delicacy called jiri (a type of mild fish stew) known for being a perfect hangover cure and generally a very popular food for good health. Combine with fresh fish fillet (there are some small bones here and there so watch out while you eat the fillet), and this bowl turned out to be quite a stand-out noodle dish that would've been even more wonderful on a rainy evening.The restaurant does take reservations, but if you don't want all the hassles, you can probably walk in on the earlier side of evening (which is what we did on a recent Friday). As noted above, I lament that the restaurant does not have liquor license yet and hope they do soon and find out some interesting alcoholic beverages to match their dynamic food offerings. The dining space and vibe of the restaurant would work for a number of different occasions such as casual dates, get-together with parties of around 5 or 6 (I actually think large groups may work pretty nicely because the menu is large enough to allow for sharing of several dishes), etc. If you want to see an evolution of contemporary Chinese cuisine in a modern setting that also gets the cooking right (unlike all the Taos of the world), I highly recommend that you check out Hunan Slurp.

I love the uniqueness of this place as, the menu changes per season. You may encounter some familiar dishes, but prepare to come each season to try all the delicious food. I came here for the first time for Restuarant week and it was well worth it (and yes, the menu still changes with each restaurant week)! The portions were decent and they chose a great selection of their delicious dishes. Well worth it when you are a struggling student who wants to eat fancy for a day. I do recommend bringing buddies with you to enjoy and share multiple dishes with. I brought 2 other friends and we were able to try a majority of the items on the restaurant week menu! ( 2-3 more people would have been perfect)The second time I came here was with a company dinner. I couldn't have been more blessed to have dinner paid for by a company and of course have a learning session along with it. The food was amazing as usual and I definitely savored every bite.Setting: it's busy, crowed and loud, but very cute inside. Date night approved, but you just may need to have a louder conversation. Service: I have to admit, there was nothing "special" I recalled from the service when I was there for restaurant week. They were not as attentive as those had previously commented in their reviews, however, it wasn't a terrible experience. -Of course for the company dinner, since you are in a private room, you get full attention all the time.Restuarant menu 8/2015:Drink: Strawberry Rhubarb BelliniStarters:1) Corn bread with maple butter2) Watermelon amuse-bouche - I wish we got more of these, but only 1 per personAppetizers:1) Tomato capriccio - I am not much of a tomato fan, but the seasoning was amazing for this dish2) Corn gnocchi - very flavorful 3) Soft shell crab - this was ok, not what I am used to like at sushi placesMain Dish:1) Dr pepper ribs - I thought this had the best flavor out of the dishes we had. They were tender and I loved the sweetness to it.2) Creekstone Skirt Steak3) Viking Village Scallops - my only gripe is that I wish they had more piecesDessert: 1) Sticky toffee carrot cake - to die for!! highly recommend 2) Mint Chocolate sundae with lavender fudge sauce Round 2: Menu for company dinner:Appetizers: Sheep's Milk Cavatelli - lamb finocchiono. Fennel and chiliMain: Dried aged sirloin - cooked to perfection, juicy and tenderDessert: 1) Spring blueberry sundae2) spring market fruit - white strawberries...what??, first time for everything, delicious and healthyOverall: great experience and food selection, just some dishes I wish they had all the time, because waiting and hoping it will come back next time is heartbreaking.

Part of the offshoot of the 11 Madison park team you'll know you'll get a nice meal here. Specializing in chicken. It's a fast casual spot. You'll find it a bit more pricey but its worth it with the great ingredients. The space is nicely spaced out with ample seating and a nice modern way of ordering and picking up your food. The decor here for a fast casual spot is great.Come here for the chicken as they serve it up roasted and fried. You can choose between the thigh meat or white meat for the roasted chicken but they have flavorful fried chicken strips as well with a spice dusting and a mustard dipping sauce. I usually come here for the roasted thigh over kale salad with a hard boiled egg. The avocado in it is a nice touch as it is also roasted. The chicken and rice platter is also great as it has tomato and fried shallots. The rice to me though was a bit undercooked. They have great granola here as well and wonderful bite size dessert pastries like apple, peanut butter and chocolate, and seasonal pumpkin. But the secret here is the chicken pot pie only served seasonally. Wow so tasty. Lots of chicken and ingredients and love the touch of maldons sea salt. This is the order to come back here over and over again.

Friendly service and cool vibe. Of the speakeasies I've visited recently, EO did not let me down and is in my top five. For drink, I had the Fraise Sauvage - Fords Gin shaken with wild strawberries & Tahitian vanilla, finished with EO prosecco. I also ordered the bone marrow poppers because I had read about them in other reviews. I have to say I wasn't impressed by the poppers so don't feel like you have to order them. It's a tiny space so best to come at off peak times to avoid lines to get in or crowds. I came early and got to enjoy the space without too many others in there.

This is a tough workout. I do this when I really want to push myself. It is a combination of treadmill, weights and floor exercises. All very challenging.The space is very clean, with just one exercise studio. The prices are comparable to other classes in the area. The packages don't have any expiration so there is no crazy rush to take the classes.The only negative is after 1 ripped class, I am sore for a week.

A great place to venture for bespoke cocktails and elevated bar food. Be warned it could become your bane. No longer is the spirit considered a menace to society but falls inline with the rest of the luscious spirits. The atmosphere is casual and fun with a hint of sophistication. Definitely a stopping point when in the area.

Fun little chill spot to grab drinks with friends. They have some creative non-alcoholic drinks. Orange colored sky and the flight no. 1 are both enjoyable, though Orange colored sky is more memorable.A slightly pricey spot so be prepared to pay a pretty penny for the experience.

I'm a big fan of ipic theater because my love of the cozy, private seating pods. It's definitely pricey and have spent over $100 on food and drinks alone. I've had some great experiences and some mediocre experiences where the food took a long time & was cold by the time I got it, but I've remained a loyal fan of the brand & concept. I love the luxury aspect of private waiters, in seat dining, & complementary popcorn. And who doesn't like a good alcoholic beverage or glass of wine while watching a movie? I will be taking a hiatus from attending this theater as there's a new luxury dine in movie theater that just opened in Manhattan and ipic's food menu can get a little redundant & boring especially after you've tried everything. In the last 2 years there hasn't been any new menu items and I wasn't impressed with the food on my last visit. The hamburger bread was stale, the food came 45 minutes into the movie, the food was cold, & they forgot part of my order. I'm over it!!

Saw this and it looked like a legitimate boba place. They are a chain from Taiwan and this is their first US location.ATMOSPHERE: The inside is very small with only 1 small bench and a few counter spaces where you can stand. It's definitely not somewhere you can hang out in. Otherwise, the inside is more of a rectangle that is very narrow and long, it's open and has a lot of greenery. I also liked that the TV displayed how they make their tea and other items so you can see what the tea looks like and where it comes from.FOOD: They have a few signature drinks and one interesting thing is that if you get a cold drink you have to get the "large" size, which is starting around $5. The cups are paper and not see through so you can't see your drink.GOLDEN OOLONG - I wanted to try this since I had never heard of it, when I asked him what it meant he said it's just oolong but a bit sweeter and very good. I added honey to mine (extra 50cents) and got the brown sugar boba (extra as well). My total came out to be over $6, but I guess you are getting a larger size than you normally would. The oolong was good, I could really taste the tea flavor and it had more of a roasted taste. The honey was pretty subtle, I got 70% sweetness but for someone who likes their drinks sweet, I think next time I would get 100%. The boba really does taste like brown sugar and I feel like that flavor overpowered the tea sometimes. Overall, pretty good chewy boba that was slightly warm.My friend got the strawberry milk tea and it had actual bits of strawberry and at 50% sweetness I thought it was pretty good. My friend doesn't like sweet drinks but she still liked it so I think if you don't like sweet drinks, you should get 50% or less.Overall, although it's pricey the quality of the tea is good and they have some interesting flavors. I would want to try more next time.

Came here on a Sunday night around 6 pm and only had to wait about 15 minutes. Once you get seated, you get your food fairly quickly. They run like a well oiled machine. I got the 6 roll set menu. All of it was good and it was the perfect amount of food to satisfy some sushi cravings. $28 for toro, yellowtail, salmon, scallop, crab, and lobster. Good deal especially since they're a no tipping restaurant as well.

I do not walk along this block as much as I used to, but on the way to meet friends for dinner I was stopped dead in my tracks when I saw Fournos Theophilos. The space once occupied by another business had been completely renovated and made into a gorgeous restaurant/bakery so I could not resist checking it out!The inside of Fournos Theophilos is like a modern day steam table style restaurant where a long (and I mean long) counter starts in the front and goes all the way to the back. At the very front is a small seating/waiting area. The back has what appeared to be a food prep area, but I did not go all the way back there. With Earthy tones and wood in play, the decor is warm and welcoming.It was the evening rush hour when I visited and the place was largely empty. In this part of town your big crowds usually hit at lunch time and in the morning so that was not a surprise. What was great however was seeing how even after a long day the staff was super friendly and happy to explain what was what behind the counter. Since I was already meeting friends for dinner, my focus was on dessert. Here is what I picked up to go (and would try later at home over the course of several days):Baklava: One of the best I've ever had. The dough was crunchy and light while the nutty layer was the perfect thickness for a for to crunch through. Sometimes this layer is hard as a rock, other times there is not enough. This was just right. The flavors were on point and the syrup was not overly sweet.Mini Baklava with Chocolate: These bite (or two bite) sized Banklavas had something I had never seen, a small dollop of chocolate on top! It occurred to me I have never seen this combination so I snapped it up to try. Man am I glad I did! It was a bit more dense than the regular sized Baklava but it had the same flavor punch and the chocolate added a wonderful element.Portokalopita: This Green Orange Pie winds up having a fluffy, cake-like texture that was really nice. The orange zest does not overwhelm the flavor at all, but it is present enough that you taste something very different from most cake-y treats!I have to emphasize again that the staff here was very nice and patient with me as I tried to make up my mind on what to get. I really liked my first impressions at this place and hope to return for another visit soon!

Growing up, I was never a fan of chicken nuggets; after all, the only types I encountered were from the school cafeteria, or the ones served up at McDonald's. The ones that are served up at The Nugget Spot, though, are far from your typical chicken nugget.Now that I've visited several times, I'm happy to report that the nuggets are consistently made, and feature real chicken; take a bite and you'll see the actual protein inside. Not only that, but the owner is frequently there to oversee the kitchen, and takes real pride in the product. My personal favorite items are the Cheese n Chong, which dusts each nugget in an even powdered cheese coating, and the Tso Swag, which is a riff on General Tso's Chicken. The variety of dipping sauces is no joke either, and I would highly recommend the OG Ranch and their Truffle Mayo.They do rotating monthly specials, which is an even bigger reason to come visit on a regular basis. The space is ideal for a quick dine in or take out, so I'd definitely recommend making a stop next time you're in the area.

If you approach the location and are mystified because you thought another business was located here. You would be correct Manchi has taking over the square footage previously occupied by The Bombay Sandwich Co. with some of the same players involved in this new creation. Manchi (means good) is their new concept that aims to take Indian Cuisine and give it a lighter feel in a fast casual manner without sacrificing any of the flavor that it's known for. It is often said that Indian food is tasty but way to heavy and leaves you feeling stuffed after consumption. With Manchi's twist you get the Indian flavor profiles with healthier options that eliminate the heaviness. That way you can grab a bowl bursting with flavor for lunch and still be able to go back to work without needing a nap. At an event last week I had the opportunity to taste test an option from their still developing menu along with some of their house-made sauces and lemonades. Since their menu has yet to be finalized I can't say if what I had will make the final cut or not but it was sure a hit to me. Bowl:Super Salad: cracked chicken w/ cauliflower, potato, string beans and rainbow slaw, served over kaleSauces:Mild- Coconut ChutneyMedium- Manchi sauce Spicy- Crazy sauceDrinks:Homemade Mint LemonadeHomemade Hibiscus Ginger Lemonade Home-brewed Masala Chai Tea Desserts:Hot Chocolate CookiesHomemade Tahini Bliss Balls: dates, tahini, pistachios, agave, cocoa powder & sesame seeds.My decision to go with the Super Salad bowl was a great choice and I went with the Manchi sauce and the crazy sauce both were excellent to compliment. I would like the crazy sauce to pack more heat and the Coconut chutney was ok but not particularly for me. As for the drinks the Mint Lemonade won me over especially when spiked, didn't care for the Hibiscus Ginger Lemonade nor did I try the Chai tea. Lastly you can do no wrong with either desserts both were worth the treat. Overall a great spot with some very pleasant owners and staff so a big thank you is definitely in order for their hospitality. Just A Note: When you need to refuel after tackling the one day sale around the corner at Macy's stop by Manchi... I know I will because it "means good" and it is!

This place is definitely good. I only ordered two things, the samosas and paneer tikka masala. They were both good and flavorful. I'm very sensitive to spicy food, and usually these two things aren't very spicy to me but here they were. I didn't mind, but I needed more rice than usual, and kept chugging water. The price isn't bad, but there are also places that are just as good and a little cheaper. Delivery time was about average. I'm currently just trying different Indian restaurants that deliver from seamless and new ones keep being added. This won't be crossed off my list by any means, but before I order from here again I'd like to try all the other places I can order from around here.

I would love to say I loved it. I really did enjoy being there - new restaurant, talented kitchen, interesting sounding dishes on the menu, beautiful space (60th floor was always spectacular even in my JPMC days). Just look outside the window!Had dinner reservations here and knew for sure which starters I wanted to try.For the first course, shared the following from the prix-fixe menu:CAVETELLI & CLAMSTomato, Breadcrumbs & Sausage-Pasta is usually a safe choice and this dish is a sure bet to please most diners as long as you're not vegetarian LOBSTER QUENELLESpring Onions & Trumpet Mushrooms-this was very interesting. Lobster is mushed and combined with starch to create this round chewy piece. It's accompanied by chunks of mushrooms and more lobster and a very tasty gravyFOIE GRAS MOUSSEStrawberries & Brioche-I was not a fan of this combination. I did not appreciate the strawberry gelatin and the brioche was too flaky and not substantial for my liking. I forgot to mention the complimentary bread basket but the baguettes come out nice and warm and the butter salted and perfect. I could have eaten bread all night. In my opinion , the baguette paired better with the fois gras than the flimsy brioche From the snacks/bar menu, also tried the following as first course:CROQUE MADAMEBéchamel, Ham & Quail Egg-easy to finish in 3-4 bites. Perfectly crunchy , salty, cheesy, and eggy, and delicious RAW MARKET VEGETABLESTarragon & Sesame Crumble-simple, light and refreshing For the second course, tried a few items:TURBOTRoasted Fennel & Sauce Mustarde-this fish was much more flavorful and meatier (yet tender) than I had expected. Light, fluffy texture and satisfying WAGYU BAVETTESquash, Pommes Anna & Creamed Spinach-while you might think steak is heavy, the flap is small and juicy; and the accompaniments actually create a balanced dish. ZUCCHINI & SQUASH ROULADEOkra, Eggplant & Vegetable JusAlso from the bar menu, tried the:FRENCH ONION BURGERGruyère, Caramelized Onion Jus-All-beef 70% protein and 30% fat resulted in a very juicy burger that is difficult to finish if you plan on eating anything else. A few bites is satisfying and it actually began to hurt my tummy to try to eat more- it's on the greasy side For desserts, I tried:STRAWBERRIESOlive Oil Sablé, Basil & SabayonCHOCOLATE MOUSSEToasted MeringueBURRATATomatoes, Herbs & SorbetThe desserts were too rich and complex for me. If i could turn back time, I would re-think my selections. Of the 3 I tried, I did like the chocolate mousse. Not my favorite of all time, but I enjoyed it most compared to the other 2 desserts. I thought the strawberries would be refreshing but the cream and jelly textures continued to weigh me down. I like sweet and salty but the burrata was not doing it for me. The blend and temperatures did not appeal to me. Not a fan of the desserts here. Due to the richness of the entrees, I prefer the smaller dishes / lighter bites. I know there are overlaps, but in general I feel the bar menu appeals to me more specifically the snacks. Curious to see if and how the menu evolves are more reviews come in

We came on a Sunday for lunch and were seated immediately. Pork sisig is so good. I haven't had pork sisig in the states, but I loved it here. This is a very popular dish in the Philippines and it was perfectly balanced here. It comes on a sizzling hot plate and has a good balance between meat and cartilage. Well flavored, crispy, and not salty.Garlic rice is good. It's flavored with fried garlic and not salty either. This pairs well with the pork sisig. Palabok was good as well. Dry noodle dish topped with boiled egg, boiled pork, tinapa flakes, and a few other toppings. Good mix of flavors with lots of noodles. Service was excellent. Constant water refills and the food quickly came out.

Came here with a group of coworkers on a balmy Friday afternoon. The Polynesian is located at the top of the Pod rooftop - minimal signage, but just go right into the hotel elevator and head up. We got to the bar shortly after it opened. There were no seats left outside, but we got a standing table and later moved to seats when one opened up.The space is beautiful and the roof is spacious. Think we got lucky with seats because it's relatively new, but I can see this spot blowing up as the summer progresses.Fun tiki theme, however the cocktails are way more complex than your average pina colada which may throw off the casual drinker. Reviews of the drinks amongst my group were mixed, but I was generally a fan of everything I tried (note: I am very easy to please). There is one shared drink that comes in a fishbowl that I would not order again as it was too sweet and medicinal.Side note of vessels that our drinks came in: a flaming skull, a boat, a fishbowl (with fish), an Erlenmeyer flask wrapped in some kind of leaf, a treasure chest....you get the idea.Didn't order food except for a side of spicy fries, which were good to soak up some of the alcohol (despite appearing so, these drinks are no joke), but seemed slightly overpriced at $7 for basically a handful of crinkle fries.5 stars for the vibes, 3-4 for everything else.

Sel Rrose is a French-ish cocktail and oyster bar popular with fashion folks, offering up spritzes and small plates in a faux-industrial space off the Bowery.This place is best used as a post-work happy hour, and is accordingly mobbed 6-8 pm with hour-long waits and no texting system, though it isn't too tough to grab a reservation a day or so on OpenTable ahead of time. I came with my boyfriend on a Friday around 7 after we finally bit the bullet and planned ahead.The space is gently photogenic, with weathered walls and dim lighting, and despite the frou frou branding and prosecco-topped drinks, the tech bros standing near the bar didn't look too uncomfortable. There were also a good mix of couples and groups of girls. Buzzing atmosphere and on the loud side.Cocktails are $15 across the board, with gin, rye, and tequila well-represented, and egg whites, grapefruit, and mesquite honey guest starring. Lest you think this means girly, low-ABV drinks, the drinks tend to be spirit forward and very good.French 27's thyme-infused rum came through more than its sparkling wine topper, but I wasn't complaining. Even better was the White Rose, a well-balanced and sweet rye-based sour with nice notes of ginger and pineapple.Oysters are $3 - 5 each, with a paper menu to check off your order. We had a half dozen, largely West Coast, and were happy but not over-the-moon. Well-shucked and presented on a tiered platter; I would bet their plateaux are impressive.They also have a varied list of plates, ranging from risotto croquettes to watermelon salad to duck leg confit, from around $10 to $20. We opted for brussels sprouts ($9), a balsamic-drenched, slightly crispy version with apples. Steak tartare ($17) was a similarly satisfying rendition.Service wasn't ideal; super hard to get them over and we often would start an exchange and have them walk away before we could tell them the second thing we needed. I was sitting under air conditioners and was continuously dripped on (as were the couple of booth seats next to me).Sel Rrose is not as amazing as you want it to be for the price, but it does a lot of things well and it works for many occasions. It's not pushing any boundaries here, but it doesn't need to-- it's the equivalent of upscale comfort food, a nostalgic reminder of European vacations past on the Lower East Side.

I met a colleague here for lunch before heading to a nearby meeting. We both wanted to sit but didn't want anything too adventurous. When my colleague sent me L'Adresse's Yelp page it seemed like the perfect fit so we booked a table.L'Adresse is located right across the street from Bryant Park. That and its close proximity to Times Square predispose it to heavy foot traffic. That kind of seeps its way inside; the dining room is huge and open, filled with people eating lunch. The aesthetic is very contemporary with clean lines and dark wood colors throughout. The restaurant was loud but also really spacious and modern. L'Adresse describes itself as an American bistro, and that's really apparent on the menu. The dishes looked interesting and upscale, but also tangible to almost everyone. My eyes immediately went to the salads - more specifically the wild arugula salad. It was served with grilled shrimp (aah!), butternut squash, and shaves of parmesan. The salad was good - it was dressed well and had a tangy/pungent flavor. The shrimp could have had a bit more flavor, but it's forgiven since the salad itself had strong components in it. It was a win overall.Service was great, food came out fast which I kind of expected since most of the diners (including us) had to go back to work. Overall, there's nothing that will knock your socks off at L'Adresse, but it's a solid spot to dine at if you're in the area. I would definitely consider this place for a quick yet comfortable and tasty lunch.

This Rosyln import is a sexy addition to the Flatiron. Very fancy and attentive service with a chef from Nera,i this Greek spot has posh Greek eats.Ate:Bread with sundried tomato dipBeets with skordaliaTiger shrimp with black skordaliaThe food here is super tasty and super pricey. I don't know the total as I was treated to dinner. My dining companion had lobster spaghetti and it was delish. The tiger shrimp was a real treat and it's a lovely albeit pricey dining experience.

There's not matcha to it other than straigthforward matcha flavors in drinks, ice cream and little green pastries. There's a long list of items you can get, but on my initial visit I tried their 24k Gold Matcha soft serve ice cream in a strawberry cone. It was very flavorful and overall the richness of the matcha is very good in ice cream form on a hot day. Though the gold doesn't really taste like anything and it's just a bit of texture and for visual aesthetics. I am not really sure what the gold adds to the ice cream aside from the cool look and something unique they serve at Matcha n' More. I will probably be back and try some of their other items. Don't forget to ask for a stamp card, after 8 drinks or ice cream you'll get one free.

What a great find in the neighborhood! This place is fast, efficient and well-organized. I went on a Tues night around 6pm and ordering was a breeze. You can create your own poke bowl or order one of the ones they recommend. Either way, you get to add whatever extra toppings you'd like; however, some select items are an extra charge. I opted for one of their recommended poke bowl and added some extra freebie toppings. Lots to choose from! If you don't like raw salmon or tuna, you can have it grilled. Lots of different bases to choose from - brown rice, quinoa, salad, etc. They make it really easy for you to order. You fill out a card by selecting from a list of everything they have to offer. You can take your time filling out your card without the pressure of holding up the line (and getting dirty looks from hungry poke lovers!). Once your selections are made, simply bring the card to the order line. In a matter of minutes, your poke bowl is ready!Also, they have free lemon water, which is self-serve. Cool!All in all, i had a good ordering experience and a great poke bowl. I will definitely be back! Very satisfying and healthy meal!

Drinking in the park with a riverside view is just the best way to have a beer! How can you not love this? It's kind of a hidden gem way uptown on the west side and buried in Riverside Park off the 103rd street entrance. Walk down and over and you will see it overlooking the river.There is a small bar up top with outside seating offering great views. Walk the stairs down and there is another larger bar below level with both outdoor and some covered seating. Also offers great views of the river and sand volleyball courts. You can also find the bathrooms down here too.Decent beer list on tap and in bottles. Friendly bartenders serving up drinks. I was here last night to run a 5K race and was able to hang out and enjoy a post run beer and some eats. They also have a small menu of food items to choose from.So choice and the best thing about this place is that very few seem to know it's here other than those who live in the area - and no annoying tourists!

Love Souen! My second experience here was much better than the first. Healthy, macrobiotic style Japanese restaurant which is primarily vegan except for some fish dishes. I love the ramen soups here. They are flavorful yet not too salty, and they have a zucchini noodle option! I am able to satisfy my craving for ramen without being overloaded with sodium. They also have brown rice noodles as another gluten free option, in additional to regular noodles/ udon.The menu is huge and they also have bento boxes, salads, sushi and vegan gluten-free desserts! The entrees are $12-$15 range but may have to pay more for things like zucchini noodles, fish, etc. The portions are huge so overall pretty worth it. I will be back next time I am craving Japanese vegan food but want something on the healthier/ lighter side!

I'm so happy I got to experience what Anthony Bourdain raved so much about! Pastrami Queen is really something special. We came on a Friday night around 7pm, when the small eatery was surprisingly empty. You can place to-go orders at the counter, but they also have waiter service if you plan on eating there. The tables, chairs, sauce bottles, and walls are all just a little icky, but that's because this place has been around for 6 decades. If you can look past this (and I recommend you do), you can expect to have some pretty amazing Jewish deli.We had the Overstuffed Pastrami Sandwich ($18), a side of cole slaw ($4.95), and a Snapple ($2.60). The sandwich is composed of a 1/2 lb serving of pastrami on rye bread with a side of pickles. The meat was soooooo tender and tastes like it had been slow-cooking for hourssssss. The rye bread was softer and less dense than ones I am accustomed to, and didn't hold up to the meat too well. Expect to use your knife and fork. The cole slaw was also delicious and not too liquidy or mayo-y. The pickles were way too salty and almost had a fishy taste to it that I didn't like. Our waiter informed us that they sometimes have half sour pickles that might be more to my liking, but they didn't have any that day.Oh, and a word to the wise. Unless you're feeling ravenous or are part grizzly bear, order 1 sandwich and share with a friend. The serving sizes are very generous here. And this way, you'll be able to try other menu items as well!

nice place to hang out with friends and try their happy hour deal. Dollar wings and oysters on Tuesdays nights, pretty good deal even for ktown. Food's ok, the vibe is great here and the bartender's really nice. I'd recommend checking it out if you're looking to try a new place around the area.

Newly opened Thai restaurant in the neighborhood. Would have given a five star if not the larb gai (minced chicken salad) - mostly just sour and spicy taste. Their menu is divided into classic section and more traditional Thai food section. We ordered two items from the traditional list - pad thai bolan and kaeng rawang neur bai cha poo (marinated beaf in a mix of two types of curry sources). Both dishes are good, especially the beaf. The beaf was very well braised and the curry tastes so good! Also tried the bua loy sawan (glutinous balls stuffed with coconut) for dessert, which was good as well.The restaurant put some thoughts into their decoration I guess, but it can get very noisy and hard to enjoy any conversations during busy time. Also, though their staffs are friendly, there was this one person wondering around and trying to take over the waiter's job for every table during random time of your meal, which was very weird and messes up the flow. Another comment would be they are quite slow serving the food...

Awesome place with an interesting and extensive beer list, great laid back vibe, delicious food and wonderful staff.I've been here twice- once to check out the place and then a second time for a beer club meetup-- and both times were great. French fries are really good!  The most recent time I had a patty melt which was amazing (and filling) and it was much better than the brisket sliders I had on the previous visit.Beers are always great. Just about any style you want, you can find. Many from local brewers.  The staff is great also. Both times I've had great service and it was because they were so nice that we arranged the meetup there. At the meetup, Howie was definitely the man. He kept everyone full of beer and was very entertaining as well.Very cool place.

A very unique concept that revolves around the tapioca pearls which is the key ingredient in bubble tea.Unfortunately that was not what I ordered, but instead I got the Tea Latte Soft Serve Swirl which had both the Oolong and Black Tea flavor. If you had the Green Tea ice cream flavor before, you definitely want to try this flavor and enhance your ice cream tea flavor pallet. Again, I should have gotten it with the bubbles, but I ended up getting it with Oreo cookie crumbs.Overall, loved it and will definitely need to come back to get something with "bubbles".

If this wasn't all the way up in Midtown, I'd probably be here more often. The owner stars in this "movie" that they play on a loop, which according to The Husband-- since I've yet to watch it-- is described as "unintentional comedy". Anyhow, he's already seen it three times and counting. We're really hoping for the sequel soon.The Shanghai bun and the juicy pork Xiao Long Baos (they call them Kung Fu buns here though) are the reasons we keep coming back. Yes, there is an automatic 15% service charge but I've never had any complaints of lousy service. Idk, maybe it helps that I actually speak Mandarin. They can get busy, the acoustics in this restaurant aren't the best and your ears may be ringing from the loud guys sitting in the corner next to you, but the food is good. I'd stick to their XLBs, scallion pancakes and the Shanghai buns (!) Although the noodles do look good, do not expect Japanese style ramen. "La-mein" (ra-men) technically means "pulled noodle" (hand-pulled in this case, which the owner is well-known for) so I can see where people would misinterpret the style of noodles they are expecting. So hope that clarifies it for ya. Definitely one of our faves.

I solemnly swear I've never had pizza anything like what they're serving at Oath. The crust -- seared in avocado oil -- is thin, bubbly and equal parts crisp and chewy, like what you get with a fried empanada. Cheese and toppings are applied with restraint (maybe a bit too much restraint, unless you've got a light appetite). Overall, the product is a winner. Bonus points for the wide variety of California-style toppings and the "ethically sourced" meats and cheeses. A distinctive and delicious addition to the neighborhood.

My go-to these days for cheap Viet takeout. The spot is very hole-in-the-wall and a little dingy, but the food is excellent. My 4-star review is mainly driven by the value you get here.Favorites:Banh Mi Bo (beef)Vermicelli Beef or Spring RollPho BeefClay Pot Ginger ChickenSpring rolls are really meaty and dense, and they even poke a hole in the containers so they don't get (as) soggy. Banh mi are all a great bread to meat ratio. Flavors in general are really strong and yet, not too salty. I unfortunately can't eat cilantro, so I'd imagine it's probably even better for cilantro eaters.Prices are again, an outstanding value, especially given the neighborhood. $8 for a huge beef banh mi. $8.50 for serviceable pho. Can't beat that!Really great for takeout or a cheap, low-key meal.

We came here on a Sunday for brunch we were celebrating a birthday. Restaurant seems to be upfront but the brunch is set up in the back which is the Arka Room area. Brunch includes Sangria & Mimosas, we had both I had the Sangria this was pretty good didn't try the Mimosas but the ladies liked it. Appetizers Platter to start this includes Mozzarella sticks Spanish style made with the queso blanco gotta say it was crack very good , good Croquettes nice & crispy on the outside supposed to have pastellitos but they were more Colombian style empanadas not bad, Small green salad good tasting dressing & Watermelon with ricotta just to balance the fried stuff Lolll not bad. Main dish I had the Mangu Benedict this sounded intersting truffle mashed plantains with an egg Benedict along with grated queso blanco & crispy salami a must say it was really good. I gave the Penne pasta a try & this was delicious creamy type sauce very tasty. Other dishes included the Salmon good as well & a lighter option a popular choice at our table was the Steak & Eggs comes with home fries eggs your choice good piece of steak.Service was good, price wise not bad $39.95 a person .. great music playing keeping u entertain after your 2 hour brunch u are welcomed to stay & party in the lounge which we did all good & fun, decent brunch worth the try.

I think I've found my neighborhood Indian spot! When it comes to Indian food, I think I go with the boring basics: lamb vindaloo, chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, and mango lassi. Oh, and my all-time favorite, saag paneer (otherwise known as delicious cubes of cheese in creamy spinach). And I can't handle anything above a medium spice level. The lassi was incredibly creamy and thick, as it should be.Don't have any complaints with what we ordered: the salmon curry, saag paneer, and one of the lamb dishes. I couldn't stop proclaiming how good everything was. A little on the salty side. The salmon and lamb chunks were incredibly tender and satisfying. The thing with Indian food is that it fills me up almost immediately. I tend to always keep eating even though I start hitting the satiety brick wall. The three of us ordered three entrees (that looked small-ish as they were being carried to the table) and a side of naan and couldn't finish everything. Our waitress was incredibly friendly and re-filled our rice bowls; the food came out quickly and piping hot; and there's a 20% discount if you check in on Yelp. We left full and happy for half of what we would have paid at other UWS restaurants (granted, we did not order any alcohol).

This is a true hidden gem! Beautiful views, plenty of comfortable couches and seating, great pop playlist, and friendly staff. Plus the frose is pretty solid. You get a perfect view of the adjoining Empire State Building and the Midtown skyline. Be sure to take advantage of the weather before it gets too cold to enjoy the rooftop.

The Blue Note is a venerated NY spot for jazz and that aspect needs no introduction. Instead, I'll focus on strategies for attending a show and the food offerings. Depending on the day/performer, you'll have varying degrees of luck for getting in. It seems that the best way to guarantee getting in is to show up 30-45 min early. Reservation or not, if the space fills you're out of luck. That being said, the staff are cool and laid back and I've been able to scope out a spot in advance (even during the last song of previous show). However, during popular, busy shows the line / waiting outside is enforced more strictly. My favorite spot is the front of the bar - the two seats facing the stage! On my student budget, it's affordable and has a great view. The place is small so it really doesn't feel that far. Now onto food and drinks. As you can imagine, there's a nice mark up and I've always preferred to go to a bar in the area before hand and have just one or two drinks during the show. For food, I've tried the brunch and the cheese plate. Both are good, but if you have the option, I'd eat elsewhere first too. I found the hash browns to be mostly flavorless. The cheese plate had a good selection but the bread it came with was cold andhad raisins in it! Perhaps this is just not my taste but I didn't enjoy it that much. But of course at the end of the day, the Blue Note is an amazing mecca of music. The caliber of music they bring in, the cozy venue, and the affordable price point for tickets makes it one of my favorite places in NY hands down.

I was able to snag reservations about a week in advance for July 4th week and am glad to have finally tried out the burger and pizza here!The burger is really everything as described - deliciously messy, juicy, and the pretzel bun is NOT a gimmick. I would definitely come back again and again for this; am drooling now just thinking about this. We also got the Colony, since it seems like a popular choice, and it was great but not mind blowing. The honey is not overly sweet and the pickled jalapeños were not overly spicy so it made for a well-balanced slice. Nevertheless, it didn't hit the spot the way I thought it would - probably because I realized I'm not a big fan of the thick crust style of pizza and also Prince Street's Sicilian slice with pepperoni is the unbeatable number one in my heart. They have one dessert - a deconstructed s'mores, but this fell short for me. I think they should reduce the size of the dish to 1/4th of what it currently is because it was way too heavy and sweet for even the two of us to finish, particularly after a meal of burger and pizza.

So many interesting flavors that are rare to see in America. I had carrot, olive oil, and shiso, and they were all DELISH!!! Although it's gelato, it's very creamy and rich and flavorful. 3 scoops were gone in less than 5 minutes! I also tried something called Lucuma (South American fruit) and loved it! It tasted like some squash or avocado texture wise, and also creamy and milky. I'll get it next time with other flavors I wanted to try such as basil, rose petal, corn, and yellow Watermelon!!! Just come hungry!!! You won't be disappointed!!!

They make good premium Italian sandwiches with quality ingredients, during the mad rush that is the Midtown lunch crowd. I've ordered their sandwiches on many occasions, and my trading floor often orders platters for catering, but catering is ridiculously stingy with their fillings. I wouldn't recommend.The place itself is always packed and they may omit an order here and there. After watching others grab their sandwiches, I inquired about mine and they hastily assembled it. I prefer their hot over cold sandwiches, especially the Pinocchio filled with prosciutto, sopressata, fresh mozz, sweet roasted peppers, and a pungent olive paste. The bread is a bit hard and the meats were salty, but definitely top-notch cured quality. Their donnoli pastry is a cross between a donut and cannoli. It can be oily, and the white cannoli cream is significantly better than the chocolate hazelnut. Pulling the spiraled pastry apart is half the fun. Overall bellissimo spot for a fine lunch option!

Beer & Chicken is all I need!This small shop right in the heart of alphabet city is the perfect restaurant before a night out on the town.The counter/bar in here is about the length of the restaurant and perfect to come to for their happy hour which I did. With every beer they give you a fried chicken wing! The one thing that could annoy people is that all the seats are tall bar stools for the tables but it has a cool vibe.When I took a seat at the bar the bartender was really cool she told me all the good stuff about the restaurant like the restaurant is named after the bobwhite bird not some guys name. Let talk food! The fried chicken is very tasty and flaky and the chicken literally falls off the bone exactly how you want it to be. For my entree I got the buffalo chicken sandwich with ranch and that was perfect level of crunchiness, spiciness, and creaminess. It also comes with a side and I got the mac and cheese which was good but I was not impressed I thought it was a little bland and needed to be richer in taste. In short:- The chicken here is awesome- Cool Bartenders- Fun little spot- Happy hour beer comes with chicken- All the tables have high barstools- Good date spot

Haiku Scarsdale has a good fresh selection of sushi sashimi compared to other Westchester establishments we have patronized in the area when seeking a casual spot.The service is top notch, friendly and fast.Love their tea and hot sake too.Haiku serves Japanese, Thai and a few Chinese items on the menu at moderate prices. Get there early, it fills up fast on the weekends.

The Green Tea Ice Cream Sandwich is off my bucket list. Now it's added to my addiction list. The Coconut Cookies were so delicious. The coconut was all between my teeth when I finished. This cookie is not just a coconut flavored cookie. The price is great. $3.97 plus tax. It came to $4.30. The restaurant is comfortable and very clean. Beautiful wood booths with a modern feel. The space is large and airy. The room has only one window in front facing 86th Street. I brought my desert to a booth and relaxed while savoring every bite. The counter help was so nice. She answered all my questions. The kitchen is open and the kitchen employee greeted me with a warm smile and welcoming greeting. We discussed my food allergies. I will most definitely return for lunch. The music playing was modern. Very enjoyable. There is a unisex bathroom in the back. It was very clean and well stocked with TP!! There must have been ten rolls. I'm going to return for lunch. My desert experience was great. I can't wait to try the burger. I was told it would be prepared to order taking my allergies into consideration. If you're in the neighborhood have lunch and write a review. Be sure you get desert!

KenScale: 8.5/10It's been almost two years since my wife Jun and I had visited Le Coucou, a hit French restaurant behind chef Daniel Rose (who, as a Chicago-born American, made his name in Paris with a modern bistro called Spring) in partnership with restaurateur Stephen Starr. Too often (and sadly), when a restaurant opens in the city and receives all the buzz and accolade, it's hard to see the restaurant sustain that initial success. Part of that has to with notoriously fickle New York City diners who constantly move around to the next big openings. I, for one, am probably guilty, but once I got married, it's become more difficult to check out restaurants as frequently as I used to as I don't have the luxury (or even willingness, thanks to Jun who is a terrific cook herself) to dine out all the time. Another reason that a restaurant loses its momentum has to do with the fact that chefs constantly look around for the next opportunities and therefore do not always pay attention to their existing ventures with the requisite care. At least that doesn't seem to be the case for Le Coucou, which is still chef Rose's only restaurant (although his wife Marie-Aude Rose has her own restaurant in La Mercerie which we have yet to visit), getting a reservation is still as hard as the moment it opened, and it recently entered the World's Best Restaurant list at number 85. I've been meaning to go back to Le Coucou for a while now, and booked for an early dinner table before heading up to the Lincoln Center for a ballet show. And I am so glad that we did, as Le Coucou is still firing on all cylinders.Le Coucou's French cuisine is in that ideal state between classic and modern. No single dish jumps out at you with some gimmicks, but each dish that you can brings so much satisfaction with careful execution and balanced flavor and texture. Case in point: an outstanding dish of lobster and scallop stuffed cabbage with Pineau de la Loire (a/k/a chenin blanc) sauce. Once you open up the cabbage shell (which I didn't do as elegantly as I should have), you have a mixture of seafood that was expertly prepared, and the addition of wine sauce underneath, which tasted slightly sour at first but over time grew more and more interesting, worked beautifully with it. How about the French classic Sole Veronique, which the server enthusiastically recommended? It was more or less perfectly cooked, and the addition of grapes and champignons mushroom further enhanced the texture of the fish, while the creamy broth underneath was rich but not overpowering. At $63, the price is certainly not cheap, but then a dover sole dish is expensive everywhere in the city, so might as well have a great one, right? It was certainly one of the best seafood dishes I have had in a while. Jun and I weren't initially sold on the other main dish that we had in prime filet with bone marrow jus (as we thought the seasoning on the meat was a bit too aggressive to our taste), but complementing it with the side dish of hearty oxtail potatoes greatly helped to neutralize that sensation. For dessert, Jun and I hadn't had the Baked Alaska last time we had visited, but that was a mistake. The server poured the brandy on top of the dessert to create a beautiful blue flame that lasted for about 15 seconds. The result was a decadent pastry dish with perhaps a bit too much brandy (Jun winced as she realized what she was eating had the potent brandy), but still a very delicious one with pistachio ice cream inside.As noted above, getting a reservation for dinner tables, especially during prime teams, still requires a Herculean effort. The beautiful dining room that gives you a sense that you're at somewhere special without having to always show up in black ties was still as elegant as I had remembered on our first visit. There is full bar with French-centric wine list to complement your meal (they do make some really good Old Fashioned cocktails). New Yorkers can't seem to get enough of delicious French restaurants (Jun and I still need to visit newcomers such as the above-mentioned La Mercerie and Frenchette from the team that previously worked at Keith McNally restaurants), but when it comes to a restaurant that one must go to explore the rich culinary tradition of this beautiful country, Le Coucou will always stand out to me as a top candidate. May the restaurant thrive for a long, long time!

We have walked past Le Coq Rico a few times and I love roasted chicken. It was only a matter of time before we found ourselves at Le Coq Rico for dinner.When we arrived, we were very quickly shown to a table by the bar (near the big rotisserie). Our waiter and the manager were lovely. They answered all of our questions and made polite conversation. We had:- Deviled - Deviled eggs - very tasty- Meurette - Poached egg with wine reduction and pork belly. With pork belly, you can't go wrong!- Jersey Giant - A very delicious roasted chicken- Mac n Cheese - very good- French Fries - tastyFor dessert,​ we had a very tasty meringue confection. Overall we had a lovely meal. The child in me got a kick out of menu items that had "gizzards" in them. I would come back at the very least for brunch or lunch.

A brown little mermaid got to check off another bookmark under the sea @ the seaglass carousel. A short whimsical ride that transforms you to King Titan's magical kingdom momentarily. With spinning colorful fish changing colors to music, you definitely feel like you're having an under the sea moment. A price tag of $5 is worth the experience for both the kiddies and the kids at heart.Nighttime will give you a better view/experience to appreciate the lights and colors.Just A Note:The seats inside the spinning circles go up & down the highest.

The falafel was very good, and I wish I had ordered more since they were in the small side and only four of them. But they were soft and not over cooked, and just the right amount of moist. The flavor was subtle, but it was there. It also came with a tablespoon of tahini sauce on the side. The cauliflower was pretty good. I'm not sure I love the way it was cooked, but I had never tried it like that and decided to get it anyway. It also came with a tablespoon of tahini on the side. This lacked in flavor and found I wished I had more of the tahini to dip the cauliflower in. The Mediterranean chopped salad was just tomato, raw onion, cucumber, with parsley on top. The dressing was olive oil with lemon. I like that when it came (I ordered in), they were all separate and not mixed together. Everything I ordered happened to be vegan, but what would've been a great dressing for this would've been a light yogurt instead. It was still good, and it was refreshing to have after the falafel and cauliflower. I would order from here again, but next time I'll try other things on the menu. Although I might have to get that falafel again. Delivery also only took 15 minutes, although my friend said it usually takes 30-45.

Flip Sigi has just renovated their menu and thankfully kept a number of dishes that I love. I've been to their restaurant a fair number of times and while not everything on their previous menu was a favorite, they seem to have found what works for them.First, the classics. My favorite burrito of theirs is the Cali Burrito, which is loaded with seared pork belly, chicken, avocado, and french fries. The textures and flavors work incredibly well together - and while it's great to share, I often wish I didn't have to. Their Plan B-Rito is now available on weekdays (it used to be a weekend-only item) and I love the addition of longanisa in the ingredients. The Dan Dan Noodles are also a favorite of mine, which utilize the typical ramen noodles in a ground pork-based sauce which is savory, spicy, and sweet.From the newer items, I would 100% recommend the Longanisa Poutine, which are generously portioned and are covers a pile of fries in melted cheese and longanisa sausage. It's a great dish to share but if you eat it all by yourself - hey, I don't judge. Also got to try the Wonton Nachos, which are a creative take on the typical nacho dish and substitutes wontons for the classic tortilla chip.It's a fairly casual place, so ideal for coming in with a friend or two or getting some food to go.

Nice addition to the area and a good option for Sunday lunch!WAIT: Came on a Sunday around 1:30 pm and there was no wait for the 2 of us. There are 2 larger tables for 4 people and then counter space that lines both facing the kitchen and facing the window AND an entire back area with more tables so it's pretty spacious inside.ATMOSPHERE: pretty simple inside, with an open kitchen. It's a slightly weird layout in that there is a front section with the kitchen and then a back section that I wasn't able to explore too much. It's bright and cheery.FOOD: They have lunch specials (on Sundays too!) that are available from 12-3:30. The menu is a bit more limited but their dishes are probably about $1-2 cheaper. They also have a promo right now that if you take a picture and post it on social media you either get a free kale salad or mocktail.Si-Lom Chicken Stewed Noodle - for $12, you get a huge leg of chicken (thigh + drumstick) plus wonton like egg noodles, soup and veggies in a bowl. The portions are small to medium so not the hugest amount but for a lunch it's satisfying enough. The soup is just OK, mostly tasted like a soy sauce based one dimensional soup. The noodles reminded me of the kind you get with wonton noodle soup (very thin and eggy). The chicken is like a stewed soy sauce chicken, tasty and a great addition. Just ask for a separate fork, knife and plate to help you eat it.Proong Tom Yum Noodle - husband got this, at $11 for the lunch special. It has pho like flat rice noodles in a more interesting slightly spicy broth. Comes with an egg, these wonton crunchies on the side and some pulled chicken breast on top. Pretty good, I think I would get that next time or something with rice noodles.Overall, good option if you are craving for a Thai noodle soup or something less traditional than your typical pad Thai. The lunch specials are good prices too!

The Little One is a Japanese dessert shop in a sleepy area of Chinatown close to Two Bridges. The space is serene and cutely decorated, and though small, it wasn't too crowded on a holiday Friday afternoon.Kakigori is my new dessert obsession-- light and flavorful shaved ice-- so I tried out their hojicha version ($7ish). It came out quickly and was magnificent. I would definitely recommend splitting.The flavor of roasted tea soaked into the flaky ice well; the whipped cream had the light touch of lime zest. However, I think it ended up being too much of a good thing-- it was also stuffed with cream, so it ended up being heavy. The flavors started reminding of a root beer float. I wished there was a textural element like Bonsai Kakigori adds to keep the experience interesting.Worth a try for unique desserts.

I found myself at Gyu-Kaku with some colleagues for happy hour drinks and apps. I've been to a few Asian barbecue restaurants before but this was my first time at this particular one. Even though Gyu-Kaku is a chain and initially made me go hmmmmm, I had heard good things so I was excited to try it out. Walking in around 5-ish on a Saturday, the place was pretty crowded but not crazy yet. Happy hour was going on in the entire restaurant until 6 and then only at the bar after that. Since we were just looking for happy hour and didn't want to move, we decided just to stay in the bar area. From what I can see, though, the restaurant looks typical of a do-it-yourself barbecue restaurant: woods contrasting with lighter colors, compartmentalized booths, etc. We ordered a number of apps - fries with sauce, Japanese-style fried chicken, fried calamari, fried bacon strips, shishito peppers, and shrimp dumplings. Looking back, it was a lot of fried stuff (oops) but everything was very tasty and with good flavor. I also partook in a cocktail and got a Tokyo Sunset - tasty, refreshing, fitting for the one warm day we were having in NYC. Service was good - even though it got pretty packed as the evening progressed, the staff was on top of it with all our drinks and food being cranked out at a good pace. Overall, I was impressed with Gyu-Kaku and would definitely return for happy hour and to try out their full-on barbecue experience.

If you're looking for a place with lot sof Brunch options, no fuss about getting a table, and good for a group, BR hits the mark. It's pretty and spacious, disguised from the crowds by the hotel that houses it.New Yorkers are so easy to trick with canny marketing, especially for brunch. While the sheeple are filling up the walkways outside overrated no-reservations joints like Jack's Wife Freda and Grey Dog, my friends and I took our OpenTable seats (including a high chair for my friend's daughter) in calm, orderly fashion.Professional service and reliable food. Peeky crab toast, short rib benedict, and the luxurious French Toast are dishes to try.

I was craving a falafel pita sandwich, so trekked to Maoz...imagine my surprise to find Pokebab instead! Apparently, Maoz has closed and Pokebab has taken over the space! What a nice surprise!!So many choices! The hard part is picking what you want! The have plenty of signature bowls; or you can create your own. They also offer regular sizes or large sizes, depending on your appetite. I opted for their signature spicy ahi bowl (regular size) for $11.95...GREAT CHOICE!! First, you pick either white or brown rice; then they add salad; then they create your bowl with their signature ingredients (or just choose your own). The guy who was making my bowl said I could basically add whatever I wanted as well, so I added jalapenos because why not? This bowl was absolutely delicious! All the ingredients were fresh and tasty. I love that they have so many ingredients to choose from. Something for everyone! Can't wait to go back to try their other dishes!Restaurant is small, but super clean; with seating in the restaurant. Service was super friendly, courteous and efficient. Besides the bowls, they also offer burritos, and salads. Great addition to the neighborhood!!p.s. Don't forget to get a punch card - after 10 purchases, you get 1 free!

Found ROKI after walking around the Flatiron area. They have a small entrance, but once you go in the space really widens out to a high ceiling and open dining area. I like their cooking/serving bar which is really unique since it was centered in the entire room. I had come expecting something simple but was instead surprised with unique and tasty dishes. Presentation of both the decor in the restaurant and the plating of the food were pleasantly fun. Use of dry ice in certain dishes gave it a visual distinctiveness. Japanese food with a hint of Chinese and French influences certainly makes ROKI stand out as a bit amongst other izakaya in the city. I would like to come back and try their Nabe in the future as the tables nearby that ordered them looked very good.

Much more than just comfort food is served at this Hell's Kitchen location spin-off from Astoria. Friendly manager Bentley calls it "comfort food on crack". A professional and personable staff welcomes you here for all day brunch and inventive comfort food that it's truly on steroids. We tasted wide array of dishes, one more flavorful than the other. Pancake burrito (scrambled egg, sausage, bacon, cheddar and maple syrup stuffed into a pancake wrap): a fist for me, this is a double punch of greatness. Don't order it unless you're ravenous! Mac balls (buffalo mac & cheese rolled into balls fried until golden with chipotle ranch): mac & cheese in a ball that's deep fried... tasty and crunchy, and easily one of my faves for the night. Chicken waffle (fried chicken breast on a waffle with bacon topped with cholula honey and creamy bechamel sauce): loved it. Crispy chicken on top of bits of bacon on top of melted cheese on top of crunchy waffles... mmh.Grilled cheese sandwich (no description necessary... d.e.l.i.c.i.o.u.s.): another favorite of the evening. Loved the avocado. Jumbo chicken wings (tossed in buffalo and smoky bbq): rich and smooth... definitely for a bbq lover. Heavy metal fries (topped with cheese curds, peppercorn gravy, chopped chives, pickled onions and siracha): yummy. Mac pancakes (sweet and savory with honey cholula drizzle): expect an an avalanche of cheese...Vegan mac n cheese: also good, although I prefer the real stuff Bedrock pancake (fruity pebbles pancakes topped with berries, berry maple syrup and whipped cream): since we didn't get enough pancakes for the night, we ended the meal with yet another giant beauty topped with fresh fruit. Mmh...If you like sangria, this is the place to get it.Overall, we had a great time. You want to come HUNGRY, because these guys know how to satisfy your stomach. It's a fantastic spot for groups, whether it's for a drunk brunch, or a get-together for a World Cup match. You won't be disappointed.

This location is located inside the Grace building plaza across from the BOA building. They have a huge window, so I love the bright natural lights and bar sitting by the windows. It's a great place for people watching and not always too crowded. Of course, their famous avocado toast is amazing with smoked salmon or Proscuitto but I think they're a bit overpriced. Their banana toast is a great alternative for $4 especially when you need some extra protein in your diet. You can't go wrong with their coffee. When you're in a mood for some sweet drinks, try their chai latte. Mm, delicious.

I have to say I had a great evening at Sagaponack. I made reservations for three on yelp. When we arrived, there was a sweet young lady that greeted us and after I told her about my reservations she kindly escorted us to our table, it was our own lil corner near the bar, so we did have a group of guys kinda standing around near us having there beers. It didnt bother us because the place is really not that big and we were just amaze and astounded how great the place looked. Our waiter came to us right away, and had someone pour us our water, as we made our orders because the hostess had already givin us our menus when she brought us to our tables. To start we were dissapointed with the cocktail list for happy hour, I mean sorry, but some people dont always want to have beer and just wine. As a matter of fact the party I was with, none of us drink beer, unless you bringing me an ice cold bottle of Corona with a straw and a lime in it, but thats not what we were there for. We wanted a better cocktail selection, and yes they did have many cocktails but only two were apart of happy hour, and one of my friends didnt even drink hers, for she didnt like the taste. So we decided to get some white wine. Now down to the food.Grilled oysters - 4 stars, they were a lil pricey for 6, but they tasted really goodShrimp dumpling- 4 stars, they were cooked well and had an interesting crisp to themCrab tacos and Fish taco- 5 stars, nothing left to say.Paella - 4 stars, hot! pan was hot plse be careful.Fried ravioli and truffle fries- 3 stars, they were both o.k.I would say I would make a return here someday, but not today, plus I have plenty on my bookmarked list to visit. With that being said I think and hope that if I return that they have more options for the food and the drinks for happy hour.

My friends and I were looking for a place to hang out on a Saturday night, but we didn't want to go to your average bar nor did we want to wait in long lines to get into places that have pool tables and shuffleboards. A Yelp search brought us to a BOARD GAME CAFE. Whaaaaat?Even though they serve beer, this place is NOT a bar by any definition. They could do a better job of creating a more nightlifey atmosphere with the lighting and music, especially for the late-night crowd, but that might not be the audience they're targeting. They serve coffee drinks, smoothies, beers, and cafe snacks like muffins and pastries.Seating is mostly communal, though there are a few smaller 2-person tables. The walls are stacked floor to ceiling with just about every board game you can think of. They even have certain games for sale (new ones, of course).When we came on a Saturday night around 9:45pm, the price was $5 per person per hour ($20 per hour for my 3 friends and me), or $40 to play until closing time at midnight. The price is definitely reasonable, but I felt there should be a discount for larger groups because individual play time is shortened if there are more players.

New Ramen place in the heart of K-Town. My husband and I went here on a Wed night around 6:30 and the place wasn't packed compared to other restaurants in Ktown, but it was decently filled. It's a narrow place with a bar seating on the left when you enter. When you head to the back, there's a couple of tables for groups. We started our meal with the Chashu 'Pork' Buns (2 for $7.00). I was disappointed with how fatty the pork was and that it left my mouth feeling really greasy. In addition, we also tried the Shishito Peppers ($6.00). I'm not a fan of peppers, but found these rather satisfying due to the cheese on top and the sauce they mixed the peppers in. For the ramen, we ordered the Koku Ramen ($14.00) and Kimchi Tan Tan ($14.00). Both ramens had the right amount of noodles. Koku Ramen was the winner of the two. Its soup tasted light and buttery and it's noodle was a bit thinner than the other one. The Kimchi Tan Tan, I really wasn't a fan of it. It was spicy and extremely salty. In my opinion, it tasted like they decided to just add kimchi to the pork soup, which both together just makes it really salty, and then decided to add some more spicy flavoring on top. If you're not a fan of spicy food, I would highly not recommend this one. As for the service, it was decent. One waiter was really attentive and friendly, the other one really lacked at his job. We had to ask for water in the beginning, which was brought in this tiny cup; nice waiter had to keep refilling it after I couldn't stop drinking water from the spicy ramen. The waiter who lacked at his job tried to clear our table even though my husband was clearly still eating. Verdict: We'll probably come back here to try the other ramens.

Where do I begin...I am very surprised by this restaurant. I was expecting your usual Korean bar food which you can get in most places in Ktown, but this place offers just a little more...in summary: tasty food, delicious cocktail, and $1 happy hour oysters (big and fresh!)!I started at the bar ordering half dozen happy hour oysters and a drink waiting for my party to arrive. Not expecting much, I was really surprised by the quality of the oysters. Everything we ordered was really delicious. The chicken wings are probably among the best I have ever had. Short rib was amazing. The only thing is that the portion is very small and dishes are quite pricey. But we had enough to eat and didn't leave hungry at all.

9 years later since my Korean friend intro'd me to this place and I still stop by to grab take-out for home/picnics. Think: a small space with a variety of daily-cooked packaged Korean meals. They've gotten quite experimental with their dishes over the years and now, their entrees come with a side of kimchi, soup, salad or small water. If you get their frequent rewards card, you'll get a stamp for every $5 spent and you can cash those cards out for prizes (packaged noodles, thermos, water etc-- prizes are located on the wall behind the cashiers). Cheap, yummy, fast!

Been meaning to come here for a while, but held off since MáLà is located in that stretch of East Village Asian restaurants that is always packed to the brim on weekends. My friend and I arrived around 6 on a Saturday night and managed to secure the last two spots at the bar (which is full service). Our bartender/server was pretty stressed as people kept walking in to be told the wait was 1.5 hours, but she was always attentive to us and checked in frequently. We ordered about 9 items in a shared dry pot and the 4/5 spiciness level. I didn't find it super spicy but everything was delicious (might come back and try the max level next time). Since it was the Lantern Festival, they had a special on tang yuan and we were delighted since we weren't sure where we would secure those otherwise. Everything came out to a very reasonable price of ~$35 per person after tax/tip and we left full and happy. I'm definitely going to come back, but will have to arrive at a weird time or make a reservation!

Had beers at the bar and really enjoyed the atmosphere and service. Great selection of bottles and a decent selection of beers on tap, although there weren't that many of them (maybe 10?).  I liked the various breweries they featured on their taps and had a delicious Founder's Red Rye but the other draft selections skewed heavily toward IPAs which are very popular so I'm not surprised.Great bartenders, relaxed vibe...I'll definitely come back.

This was a fun and interesting experience for us! I enjoyed their Indian tapas/fusion vibe and cute cocktails. Ambiance/Decor: This place went from being very empty when we arrived at 7 pm to pretty full around 9 pm when we were about to leave. It went from no music playing to 90s hip-hop blasting so loud you had to talk over it. I was not a fan of that, but I understand that instrumental Indian music which typically plays makes the restaurant sound boring and less trendy. Cute industrial style seating with black and gold colors. Service: No trouble at all with the service. I really appreciated that they changed our plates and cutlery after we transitioned from apps to dinner part of our meal.Price: We paid about 65 a person (with tip) for apps, dinner, and dessert including one drink each. It's definitely not cheap but it's also not wallet breaking. I really thought for all the food the price made sense. Portions for the entrees are a little on the smaller side, but if I wanted more I could have gone to an Indian buffet.Food: Onto the good stuff. Definitely get the Bhatti Murgh ki Champ if you want your snapchat/instagram story to be lit AF. I had so many people asking me where I was after posting this app. It was to its credit also delicious (so tender and well-seasoned). Paratwala Paneer is great for the vegetarians, and was also yummy/memorable. The butter chicken (Khade Tamatur ka Murgh) was well-flavored, but the Achari Bangain was bland and a miss on my end. The Yakhni Palao was just ok, nothing too memorable for me - but I loved all the stuffed kulchas! To be honest, I could not really taste the meat in the lamb/chicken ones - by eating with the shared plates it was hard to decipher, but really enjoyed eating them overall. Dessert was delicious! I forgot what it was, but it was perfect end to the meal.I definitely could see myself coming back here, but maybe not for a full meal. I would love to come back and sit at the bar and have a drink with the appetizers!

So the formerly secret restaurant that isn't so secret anymore behind the former butcher shop that doesn't exist anymore is still around. And as you would probably expect, the beef is good here. We almost opted for the tasting menu but so glad we didn't. The"fondue" looked more like a center piece from edible arrangements. That said, we went with the tuna poke, the washu tartar, the mac and cheese, and the rib eye steak. The meat dishes were absolutely on point. The mac and cheese was good but a bit too runny for my taste. If I come back, it'll definitely be just for the meat.Let me know if you want to go. I'll refer it.

It's a wrap, this place is great!Been here a few times and although they have a decent menu, I've only ordered wraps from here - all of which are good, fresh, healthy, and filling.The Hail Caesars wrap is probably my favorite and is basically a wrap form of the salad. The Texas Hold Em and Popeye's are other favorites. I do intend on trying more when I come back to the area. I've had take out and ate in. There is a decent amount of seating as far as both table and lone eaters on a stool. If you order in, they bring it to your table and add a free slice of watermelon. The drink selection is on the weaker side (I like large drink selections because that's the way I am), but most options are healthier. The staff have always been friendly. Located in a busy area, there is metered street parking and local streets to try your luck in finding a spot. A great option for an area with good options. I will be back.

Came to Yoon Haeundae Galbi during their opening month. Until April 30th, they have 15% for 2, then 25% for 3-4 people off your final bill.Another korean BBQ joint near Ktown? I think not. Order the prime short rib, it is so tender and juicy. As far the beef options in Ktown, this restaurant may beat every other similar joint. The price point is steep at $40/order but I personally think it's worth it .We also got the Busan Neighborhood Pancakes because of other Yelper's recommendations. I didn't love this dish. The concept of this dish is kind of confusing to me because it has egg and beef and seafood in it... more of a fusion pancake than your typical seafood pancake one is used to seeing.Interior is very clean and modern. Lots of tables and even has a room for private functions. Upstairs is a separate bar with additional seating. Service is very good. Welcome to NYC and thank you for bringing amazing prime short rib :)

I'm a fan. Higher-end Korean steakhouse (somehow with a Michelin star in its first year!), with servers who are a little more hands-on with the cooking, which is good for people who are first-timers.We got the butcher's feast, which includes all courses, including dessert. All meats are just fatty enough to have some flavor, and there's a good mix of veggies and carbs. Favorites are the souffle, galbi, and the spicy kimchi stew. Dinner gets finished off with some soft serve with salted caramel. Pretty satisfying and delicious.The flat prix fixe for the butcher's feast is a decent value for what you get. Service is pretty great overall, both in recommendations and in guidance, which I feel like you don't get at most Korean BBQ joints in K-Town.If you can get a reasonable reservation time at Cote, I suggest you take it!

Lets make these places great again!This is true NYC. Gritty, rough around the edges, and no frills. $2.50 gets you a decent hotdog with kraut. 3 bites if you're a cafone 4+ if you're a normal human being. In and out in less than a minute.Nothing more to add here.Hipster scum need not eat here.

Authentic little pizza place nestled in Little Italy with loads of history! This place has been around FOREVER so I had to check out the hype! But caution -- CASH ONLY. Food: We ordered two pies for 5 people, one small and one large which left us full! We got a classic tomato sauce pizza and a classic white pizza. Personally, I was a bigger fan of the white pizza but others in my group preferred the tomato sauce pizza. Both, I thought were a bit bland though. I think the white pizza sauce could've used maybe some garlic and basil in the sauce and the tomato sauce was more sweet than savory. Cost: CASH ONLY!!!! (which was annoying but they have an ATM, try to hit the bank before you come though to avoid the fees). The prices were very affordable and I thought they were adequate for the amount and quality of the pizza. Service: mehh, not bad but I think they struggle to check up on people with so much going on. But despite being super busy, pizza was out in less than 20 mins! Will I be back? Probably not. It's a cute little pizza place to bring your family or friends but nothing special. Loved the charming style with the picnic style set up (paper plates, checkered linens) but just a one time visit was enough.

This place has it all! Hipster coffee shop meets chill bar with nostalgic top 40's. Reasonably priced drinks, great happy hour, friendly staff and wait.. oh.. yes.. make your own s'mores! Perfect for a fun night out with some friends or a nice cozy date spot (I do hope to take a date here soon). Easily turning into one of my favorite spots in the city.

Vegan // HeavenHealthy // Guilt FreeYep. It is that good. Kudos for healthy Vegan that even carnivores don't mind. Had the burger with Guac which was great! The Scene: Casual, Quick, VeganDestination Rating: 7Date Rating: 3Hob Nob Potential: N/AStrong Suggestion: Save room for fries!
