Whether it's Soundview, Castle Hill, Parkchester or even Throgs Neck, Dominican restaurants, are just few and far between. So when one opens up nearby, trust------us Dominicans go nuts and wanna try it out. Took notice when John M. visited then I wanted a piece of that itty bit of action too. You'll miss this place if you're zooming down White Plains Rd. Heads up- Ajo is right in between an auto body shop and a Barber. But their rustic wood exterior, is a unique and dead giveaway for these parts. Ajo Y Oregano's first impressions took me way back to my Homeland: hearing rain hit the typical Tin roof, colorful window shutters, Caribbean furniture and walls. Ajo is small. Only 3 tables- seating 4-5 people comfortably on each. No reservations taken. But my Mom and I lucked out and practically a table waited for us. But if you so happen to come when there's a crowded house, Ajo has a makeshift waiting list taped on the wall. Place is casual and Salsero Frankie Ruiz's music, took it way back while we lunched. Started with good Arepitas de Yuca (Yuca Fritters) and Bacalaítos. Other than good taste, I guess the cook didn't drain the excess oil in the Cod Fish Fritters and by the time they got to the table, they were real oily. Mom had Mondongo with a side of white rice, shared a salad with the butteriest Avocado and I had the Garlic Shrimp and a side of Tostones. My dish was tasty with mostly a mix of Large and baby shrimp (odd- I thought). And Garlic-Cream Sauce, was just way too much for me. Our waitress was pleasant but wasn't efficient and my Country Club soda, came past midway our lunch. By the way, keep an eye for whatever's not flowing with you. I really appreciate how Ajo isn't totally breaking the rules on old school, Dominican food or taste. Everybody has a good time here and Food is good. Be considerate and remember...place is tight. Eat your food. Don't linger and be on your way.

Boucherie is a French brasserie in West Village, whose menu centers heavily around meat, as well as traditional French dishes like escargot and foie gras. I had stopped by this chic restaurant last year for a Yelp event, and had such a fantastic time that I decided to give them a try on a regular night.My friend and I arrived a few minutes after our reservation time. The seating hostess greeted us warmly and sat us down immediately. Our waiter walked over shortly and welcomed us to the restaurant. He kindly explained the menu and recommended some of the popular menu items. My friend and I tried the escargot as the appetizer. Drenched in a garlic-parsley butter, these delicacies were absolutely delicious and perfect to get us started for the feast to come. After that, we shared the 36 oz dry-aged tomahawk rib-eye. The steak was cooked perfectly and the portion was very generous. I loved the roasted bone marrow that came with the steak. The waitstaff made sure that we had plenty of bread to soak up this fatty goodness at all times. I really appreciate the restaurants that pay attention to small details like this, and it really made my dining experience special.The dining area is intimate, making it an ideal place for a romantic date night. In addition, the restaurant is quite spacious (a rare find in New York City) and therefore can easily accommodate large parties. I would absolutely recommend hosting your next holiday dinner party at this elegant yet trendy restaurant. From the impeccable service to delicious food, I would absolutely recommend Boucherie if you want to combine your love for steak with classic French dishes and wine. Like some reviews mentioned, the food is on the pricier side, but the quality of the food is superb.

Would you pay almost $10 for a soft serve ice cream cone with 24k gold? Well, I did so that's gotta say something. Like most people, I was swindled into the 24k gold madness. I love matcha. And I love a good food photo. So I really couldn't resist.The place is very similar to many small trendy shops popping up around New York. Fun atmosphere, funky wallpaper, trendy neon sign with a clever saying. I've seen it, but it will always attract the instagrammers and foodies. Now, I would have given this gimmicky shop less stars, but I really did enjoy my experience. The green tea ice cream is really good, not too sugary. The matcha is the right amount of sweetness. And the staff was really friendly. So I have no complaints besides the fact that it's expensive for what it is, and another one of those places to go once for the experience.

Overall - good place for creamed ice What I got - American yeti or something like thatTaste - good, the creamed ice had a good flavor and texture. It was as blue with something delightful in it. It was served with a second flavor that was white but not nearly as good. I let my wife choose a preset mix of toppings and even though it was enjoyable I would have preferred other toppings. From what we did get the fruit was fresh but found it odd to have corn flakes as a topping. It was lighter than ice cream and served as a ideal treat in a hot day.Value - average/high, ~$12 for yeti sized sundae. Even though the portion was large it was still more than a decent dinner in the city.Service - average, no complaints but seemed a little slowAtmosphere - very casualFacility - ~10 ppl can sit. I went on the first warm day of the year and they had the heat on like it was still winter. Odd for a business whose product melts.Need to know - This is not ice cream or frozen yogurtWould I come back - YesWould I go out of my way - YesAdditional info - I didn't realize how much I enjoyed this until I was craving it recently and tried something else that just didn't hit the spot.

The guys at work love running to Park's for a hearty Italian sandwich. And I can hang with the best of them, so I always ask them to grab me a Chicken Parm sandwich. Good luck if you plan on traveling with the Chicken Parm for more than 10 minutes though. Your bread will be a soggy mess. Not the worst thing if you like marinara on anything, including wet bread. But I'm glad we're not too far from Park's for that exact reason.Alas I can only eat half of the thing, while the guys scoff it all down. But I'm not the one sleeping at my desk for the rest of the afternoon. In layman terms, go get the Chicken Parm sandwich.

Love their spinach pie croissant, flaky dough outside with a sting of cheese on top. Very flavorful and creamy but a bit too salty. Croffin was yummy, too, not overly sweet as it appears to be, and the texture was interesting. However, the white sesame donut was not impressive, because I barely tasted any sesame flavor. It tasted just like custard cream, although the cream was actually light and of the right sweetness.Coffee was a bit plain as if it was watered down, but overall I enjoyed my breakfast here.

Yummy my friend got the melon tea it was her first time trying it and she really loved it! She said it had a cotton candy taste. I can't put my finger on it but anyone who's tried melon tea will know there's a distinctive umami flavor. I got the red bean tofu. The soup the liquid was soo good. It was sweet but not too sweet. And it was chilled perfect on these hot summer days! The tofu was a lot and really filling! The best part is the red bean which is delicious! Their red beans are chewy but not hard and soft but not mushy. It's like the perfect texture mixed with the syrup yumm. I'd love more syrup ratio. The service here is great. They helped me with what to order and they were really lenient about sitting. We moved a chair and they didn't mind. I stood by the window by the door next to the door and I felt relaxed and enjoyed my experience!

TLDR: quaint French bistro with smaller portioned plates; fast service; cramped seating; famous for their steamed eggs, but also offer other delicious breakfast options; come during the weekday for no waitAfter hearing multiple friends rave about the steamed eggs here, decided to finally try Buvette on a Tuesday morning around 9:45am. The restaurant was reasonably busy for a weekday morning, but my friend and I were able to grab seats at the bar right away, where we could watch the steamed eggs being made using the espresso machine. The waiter was very friendly and poured us water / took our orders promptly.We both ordered the famous jambon cru (steamed eggs and prosciutto with shaved parmesan served on toast). While I prefer my eggs over easy and generally don't like scrambled eggs, I decided that I should give this dish a try after hearing so many positive things about it. While I liked that the dish had a variety of different textures, I found the eggs to be too mushy and the prosciutto to be overly salty. However, the portion size was spot on, unlike most breakfast / brunch places where leftovers are usually a given. My friend was extremely bothered that I only found the dish to be okay (he thinks the steamed eggs are phenomenal), and insisted that we come back to Buvette another time so that I could try a different dish.The following week, we returned with another friend at 9:15am on a Friday. This time, we were seated at a very small table near the back, which left little space for our coats and purses. I decided to share the croissants with butter & raspberry jam with one of my friends and then ordered the belgian waffle (buttermilk waffle, berries, & creme fraiche). The croissants were good, but not unlike others I've tried before. On the other hand, the belgian waffle was simply delicious--the waffle itself was cooked perfectly, the berries on top were ripe and tart, and the creme fraiche and powdered sugar added an element of sweetness to the dish that truly made it a treat.I'm glad I gave this place a second try and would recommend it for both those who love scrambled eggs and those who don't, as the steamed eggs aren't the only thing on the menu worth trying.

I'll up it to a 4 given the value.  As everyone says -- 7 rolls for @21! Amazing to find in this city. Place was so busy at an off time, no wonder they opened another a few blocks away. Please open one in Midtown!  Sure the rolls weren't the absolute freshest or incredibly good tasting. But they were all okay...maybe even pretty good.  Cash only but if you order online you can pay with card.

KenScale: 8.5/10If you look at the menus of the recently opened The Loyal and other restaurants like Narcissa or Nix, you wouldn't know they are all from the same chef. John Fraser has long been known for one of the best chefs in New York City for his exciting vegetable-centric cooking, and everywhere I go, his restaurants didn't disappoint for the kitchen's ability to maintain balance in creativity and execution as well as its commitment to ingredients. When I heard that he was opening a more straightforward American bistro last year, I was somewhat puzzled. Is chef Fraser playing safe like many others in the city who are facing the crunch from soaring rents and labor costs? The Loyal's menu doesn't really seem to have a distinct identity like chef Fraser's other restaurants; it has a bunch of crowd-pleasers with heavy focus on meat. Well, my recent dinner with my wife Jun at the restaurant proves that even if a more "boring" concept, chef Fraser surely knows how to pull it off beautifully. The menu at The Loyal is divided into raw bar and bar snacks, appetizers, pastas and entrees. Any meal at the restaurant should absolutely start with the delicious bites of drunken eggs with chili oil and sesame that had a pleasant mix of spicy and sweet sensation all mixed up wonderfully. Lobster cocktail with smoked tomatoes was another winner that you should consider kicking off your meal with. For a chef who has made his name for vegetable dishes, chef Fraser has quite impressed both of us for the two meat entrée dishes we had ordered. The burger with comte and "22-step" tomato was perfectly cooked medium rare and its richness was even more impressive considering that the seasoning itself was kept at an optimal level. Add a side of duck fat tots, and you have one of the best new burgers in town. When I saw the beef tenderloin covered in salsa verde béarnaise sauce, I regretted that I didn't tell the server to bring the sauce on the side. To my surprise, the béarnaise wasn't too strong in seasoning and its subtle flavor actually enhanced the very nicely grilled tenderloin, accompanied by stuff mushrooms on the side for a fantastic meat dish. Jun and I had no problem making a quick work of both the burger and the beef tenderloin. For dessert, the Sonoma harvest sundaes with concord grape and yogurt sorbets accompanied by delightful honeycomb crunch led us to conclude without reservation that The Loyal is a very good restaurant. Getting a reservation at The Loyal could be difficult during prime times on the weekend, so always book in advance. Service was overall good although Jun was a little upset that the hostess tried to lead us to the table right next to the door (on a freezing Sunday evening) even though there were other tables for two on the inner part of the restaurant. There is full bar with some aptly concocted cocktail selections (there was one called Willy Wonka with Korean chocolate stick called pepero). The restaurant's vibe is that of a typical West Village bistro that works for multiple occasions (Jun and I could tell that all the people sitting on our rows of tables for two were either couples or on a date). The Loyal may not be the most exciting dining destination to visit right now, but if you want to walk out with a satisfying dinner, it is definitely a place I would recommend checking out.

Bar Thalia is conveniently located in Symphony Space. Very cool modern vibe. Full service bar and a selection of food at typical prices. It nice to have an option for food and drinks when you're attending a performance. I was attending a special event and enjoyed the night in the cozy atmosphere. The employees were friendly and knowledgeable. I searched for free WiFi and was surprised to see YELP WiFi! It was a link to sign in to the WiFi provided by Symphony Space. The atmosphere is clean and the lighting relaxing to me. I used the restroom adjacent to the Cafe. Very clean and spacious. A Cute step stool is provided on the floor for children. This venue is child friendly. Ok, I know what you're thinking. I am short, but no I did not need to use the step stool! While waiting for my show to begin I enjoyed looking at the wall decor. Photos of past performances are tastefully displayed around the room. It's a shame I didn't realize Bar Thalia existed. I ate before the event. I'm definitely returning. There's a layer cake I saw with my name on it.

Up until about 2 days ago, I had no idea that Detroit, like New York and Chicago had their own classification of pizza. This was one of the suggested pizza places that Yelp recommended to me, so I decided to give this place a try for dinner tonight. Upon walking in, you're greeted with trays upon trays of pizzas with different toppings and colors. The little "pepperoni cups" caught my attention, so I opted for the pepperoni pizza. The pepperoni that they use here reminded me of the pepperoni that is used over at Prince Street Pizza and Grimaldi's. These pepperonis are essentially small cups that capture the char and the delicious oils that are left over after being heated up in the hot oven. I'd definitely recommend asking for extra pepperoni as you can never have enough of it! What makes Detroit pizza unique from any other pizza is that it is served in a long rectangular box and the dough is especially crispy. Other than that, the pizza here reminded me of the Spicy Spring at PSP, just without the slightly sweetened dough.If you asked me, I'd still prefer Prince Street Pizza over this place. It doesn't fall far behind though. Its just that PSP set the standard so high for me haha. The slightly sweetened dough gave PSP the slight edge. Overall, I had an excellent first experience here. According to several of the Yelp reviews, this place is run by the same folks from Artichoke's Pizza. They're obviously up to big things and playing a huge role in the pizza culture here in N.Y. I'd definitely recommend this place if you haven't been here before. Side note: I finally figured out why this place has the name it has after giving it a second thought. It's named after the football and baseball teams based in Detroit. Clever indeed.

Came here on a Friday evening at 745pm - my hubby, me and two friends (a couple). Place is very swanky. It is a relatively small dining room but it's cozy, and skews between romantic or a corporating outing feel. They have live music (classic jazz, and a nice rooftop for pricey but good drinks. We couldn't go up because the weather was icky. Also, I suggest coming on a Friday because they have a $42 pre fixe, and also I easily booked on OPT and somehow got a 1000 points. Think it's more of a work feel here given the area so they're probably trying to get more on a Friday. I did have the pre fixe menu, and I got the:- Delicious French Onion Soup - awesome beef broth flavor, crusty cheese atop yum. Probably the best FO soup i ever had (it's so messy to eat!) -The bacon wrapped filet mignon. Med rare. It was more on the rare side but that was fine by me. No one should get a steak more than med rare, lol. Honestly not sure the bacon - I'm not sure that it added much flavor and I normally go nuts for steak house bacon (it was steak house style just more cooked and crisped). The filet however was great! It came wth blue cheese atop. It looked like a small portion but was great for me. -Came with pomme anna which is a kind of a potato gratin type of thing, was yummy. I would have preferred a vegetable but alas they can't substitute for the pre fixe. Most others I was dining with got the pre fixe as well. The main being the filet mostly. My hubby got the wagyu beef stew, but it wasn't really a stew. It was like beef tips with root veggies on top of potato so that should have been clarified cause he was trying to do few carbs.As far as the appetizers; there were a lot of the octopus salad (delicious, grilled), and the root veggies salad (meh). The octopus salad or FO soup would be the best choices.We shared delicious, hearty vidalia onion rings for the table. They could have used more flavor but they were well fried and held up.The pre fixe comes with a good choice of desserts, and since we all got it we shared. Among a chocolate mousse, cake thing - I'm not a fan of chocolate so this wasn't for sure. Then, a grapefruit shaved ice thing with ice - tart and refreshing. Then, probably my favorite, strawberry shortcake which was not too sweet and on a biscuit. Came with green apple sorbet. You can wash it down with some good quality coffee.For $28 you can also do a sommelier wine pairing with the pre fixe, where you get two glasses of wine paired with what you're having. You can make a request on the style of wine you like but they will choose for you. I got a cab and.. I forget the other maybe syrah or shiraz. My other gf did the same and got a cab and rose. The men got amongst cocktails like Old Fashioned, and/or a large selection of bourbons. I could see this being a great space for events. I will say - if not for the pre fixe, they place is very very expensive. I would argue more expensive than a lot of steakhouses that have real street cred in NYC. But it is a nice ambiance.

I have to say that the number of Hawaiian-inspired eateries opening in NYC has been a welcome addition - and Mahalo is one of the first bakeries of its kind that I've encountered. The bakery is conveniently located in East Village, and while the space isn't very large (there isn't really space to dine in, so you'll need to take your treats to go) there definitely is a full range of items to choose from.I was able to try their Taro Coconut cupcake, and the cake itself is unbelievably moist (soaked in coconut milk, I think?) and the buttercream is light and has just the right amount of sweetness. I also loved their panna cotta, which is topped with a guava jam on top which adds just a little tartness to counteract the denseness of the dessert.The owners are super sweet and it's clear they've put in a lot of work into their items. Definitely worth a stop and taste as they have some truly unique treats!

One of my colleagues and I decided to grab some dinner; he left location up to me so I took to my bookmarks to find somewhere equidistant where we can meet and catch up. Jacob's Pickles had been sitting in my bookmarks for some time so I suggested we try it out. Jacob's Pickles is a trendy brunch and dinner spot on the Upper West Side. Their main fare is Southern comfort food, and the interior tries to augment that in a way by serving us low lighting (too low for me personally), metal fixtures, and light stone pared with darker woods. The restaurant starts out kind of narrow with a bar to the right and some tables to the left but opens up to a broader dining room in the back. They play modern music which doesn't add to the aesthetics much but makes the place more lively. They do not take reservations for parties less than 6, when we arrived at ~6:30 on a Sunday night the wait was about 30 minutes for a party of two. They took my number and texted me when the table was ready. As the name suggests, Jacob's offers a variety of pickles in addition to their Southern dishes. Additionally, many of their entrees come with pickles or have them incorporated in some way. The menu structure is traditional with apps, salads, sandwiches, and entrees. The sandwiches stood out to me since they were all served on biscuits - ooh! I decided to get the honey chicken and pickles sandwich. This contained buttermilk fried chicken, hot sours, and clover honey served on a biscuit with a side of grits. The sandwich was pretty good and quite generous in size - you would think by the sound of it the meal would be heavy but it wasn't at all. The chicken was juicy, the biscuit was light and fluffy, and I could really taste that honey. Because of the size of the sandwich and the delicateness of the biscuit, I ate it with a fork and knife - no biggie (actually I preferred that ;-). The cheese grits the sandwich was served with had good flavor, though I was puzzled as to why it was served in such a deep bowl - you had to reach in to get that cheesy goodness. Service was good; our waiter was friendly and our food came out in a timely manner. Overall, I had a good time at Jacob's - they serve tasty, quality food with friendly service in a trendy atmosphere. That being said, I don't know how destination-worthy this place is. I'm glad I experienced it, but this isn't a place I would be waiting hours to get a table at for brunch or dinner. It's worth trying if you're in the area, and if given the opportunity I would return.

Solid four stars! This place is a haven for home cooked meals that warm your heart. The dishes are served very much like the portions your favorite grandma/auntie would give you. Large, piping hot dishes of love that you really shouldn't finish but you do because you don't want to disappoint (millions of gluttons were born this way). The owner can often be found cooking in the back. A warm slice of sweet potato pie is almost always offered as dessert because it's house made and a true delight. If you've lived in Harlem long enough you'd remember that there was an incarnation of this resto on 135th between 7th & 8th Avenues. This pie and this owner cling to ones memory like the food will cling to your heart, in a good way of course.By the way, this is a non-tipping establishment. This didn't stop me from leaving a tip because the hospitality is like nowhere else. Be warned, this is not a place to hop in and out of for a quick meal. If you come here, you're welcome to linger and get comfortable whether at a booth or at the counter. There is a sign that will subtly let you know that fresh pressed/squeezed juice is also made here. Oh the juiciest of oranges and strawberries and sweet bananas and crisp-green kale (!!) can be assuredly found here. Settle in and feed your body. You will surely enjoy all that is to be found here. The decor is rustic, homey and somewhat kitsch-y, but it works.Don't be fooled by the humble, simple decor and feel at home in Home Sweet Harlem.

FINALLY got to try this place! If you don't know, it was Danny Meyer's first restaurant back in 1985 (the same guy as Shake Shack) and very popular. It underwent some renovations within the past year so I wasn't able to visit but now it's open again.WAIT: Came on Easter Sunday and was able to get seated right away for a table for 2 at 6:30 pm. It was decently crowded but still had a good amount of space. There's an upstairs and downstairs so I think it can fit a lot of people.ATMOSPHERE: This is definitely not the most cutting edge, trendy restaurant that is in New York. This has more of an old school vibe and let me tell you...we were probably the youngest people in that restaurant.  I could see this as a good option for business lunches or dinners or to take your parents to a nice restaurant or somewhere for people to go on their 20th anniversary. Nevertheless, the atmosphere is "fancy" in that it has white table cloths and good service.FOOD: The prices are a little on the higher side at the cheapest thing being the side dishes at $14 per dish. The appetizers themselves are almost 20+! We opted for the USC burger and a side of the roasted carrots.BREAD - it's free! came with 3 slices of their rustic sourdough, the perfect kind with a thick soft inside and then crunchy, crusty bread with a bit of a toasted taste to it. Whipped butter and salty olives on the side make for a great beginning course.USC BURGER - since this is the same person who helped found shake shack we knew we had to try the burger. We got it medium rare. The burger itself is a decent size, for 1 person finishing it you'd be pretty full by the end. We got it medium rare and they definitely follow the medium rare request. It was pink inside and very juicy, soft, and not dry or overcooked. The meat was good quality with just the right amount of fat, although not overly seasoned or that flavorful. It might be because it didn't want to overwhelm customers with the bacon + cheese. The bacon is a little crispy with a good amount of fat, very taste and the cheese is almost like a sharp cheddar, melted on top. A brioche bun on top makes for a very good burger. At $29, it wasn't as good as Emily and it was probably a notch below Minetta Tavern, but it's still up there. I think one negative thing was the whole burger felt a TAD too greasy. The burger juices and bacon grease soaked the bottom of the bun and at the end I felt a little greased out. FRIES - the fries were your typical slightly browned medium thickness fry with a very potato taste. It's hard to describe, but it was not the kind I like.Note that this restaurant is a no tipping restaurant so I assume the tip is kind of built into the prices. It's sort of nice but something to keep in mind since the prices may seem a bit higher than others.Overall, definitely would recommend trying at least once and if I had another business lunch or dinner or parents visiting from out of town I might take them here.

It was one of those days where I was craving Vietnamese food so I ordered a classic dish: pho! It was #4 Tai Nam Gau Gan Sach (Combination Rice Noodle Beef Soup with Fresh Eye of Round, Brisket, Tendon and Omosa). The pho broth was just right - flavorful and light without tasting too salty. The various types of meat in it was well cooked too. I thought it was a fine bowl of noodles for $7.50. There is an option to size up your pho by ordering the Combination Extra Big Bowl options but the regular size bowl itself is just as filling to me. If I were to judge a restaurant by one dish out of their whole menu...this might be one of the slightly better Vietnamese restaurants in Chinatown. This place has plenty of tables with a brick interior that has a funky decor that includes mirrors, neon lights, religious statues and Asian rooftop. And of course, the noticeable train hanging above.

The good:Service was phenomenalPlace was niceFood: Delish and served family styleWe were a group of five and decided to follow the server's recommendation and got 2 appetizers, two choices of thin sliced steaks (right side of menu) and one order of thick cut steak (right side of the menu), and 2-3 sides.Appetizer: Salad was good and meat sushi: flavor was just okay, but you get a cool presentation.Thin cut: We first began with the Saslik which was really juicy and probably my favorite (although the portions were super small). For the second thin cut we had the Nurst-Et special which comes with a cool presentation and it was also tasty (but when something is bathed is butter, it is difficult for it to taste bad).Thick cut: The ottoman: Most filling steak. Please have it medium-rare.Sides: Mushroom, creamy spinach and asparagus (all good, but portions could be bigger).Dessert: Baklava stuffed with ice cream= A food orgasmDrinks: All super deliciousThe Bad:Everything is overpriced!Flat water? ExpensiveSparkling water? ExpensiveA glass of wine? Expensive ($23)A martini/mixed drink? ($20-30)Steaks: Now don't get me wrong, they were all delicious but this restaurant probably overcharges you $30-50 more when compared to tops steakhouses in NYC. I am no steakhouse expert, but my boyfriend and his sister have been to their share of steakhouses and agreed that this place overcharges.Verdict: I am glad I came here and I think it is a nice place for special occasions, but unless I win the lottery, or someone else is paying, I doubt I will return.

Sometimes, you just want a casual quick food with strong flavor, instead of formal restaurant dining. We have been wanting to visit this spot for a while, so we decided to give them a try. Although they didn't have many customer in the inside, the kitchen was in full steam. It seems like they have lots of delivery orders. They only have counter table that goes all the way around. This is a self-service spot, no waiter service. The way you order the noodle dish is to first pick the noodle style, then the preparation style, and finally, choose the level of spiciness. I went with Ribbon Noodles, Spicy Cumin Lamb, and Low spicy. If you are vegetarian, this dish can be made with seitan also.It was a pretty good portion, lots of Ribbon Noodles and chunks of lamb meat which was tender and packed with flavor. The spice level was great for me. Not too spicy but had a little kick to it. My hubby ordered the same thing, but with different style of noodle. He chose Ding Ding Noodles, which is chopped noodles. The Ding Ding noodles are their house favorite, and it can be described as mini Chinese gnocchi. In addition to our noodles, we also ordered Mama's Jumbo Dumplings to share. We chose Pork & Chive. They took a long time to come out, we were almost done with our noodles about the time dumplings came out. They were nice size, but I wouldn't call it "jumbo"...but certainly tasty and filling.It ended up being not-so-quick food, but we were not in any rush, so that was ok. The food was really good, much better than I expected. The price point is not "fast-food" price, but you do get delicious, quality food here that are made from scratch.

Red Rooster is a nice brunch hub on 125th Street. Make sure to make a reservation. The bar area is a comfortable place to grab a cocktail or two if you're waiting for your party to arrive. They also have a small but good draft list, with a strong leaning toward locals. 5 Boroughs IPA was on offer, which I happily quaffed for the duration of my meal.The menu is definitely one of the better ones you'll see, with a nod to southern fried cooking. We started with cornbread, which was probably the most memorable part of the meal. It was hot, wholesome, and melted in your mouth, very much unlikely standard cornbread or hush puppies. The chicken dishes are outstanding, though orverpriced due to the celebrity factor. My shrimp and grits was spot on, with perfectly cooked, soft grits. We had three kids in our party and they were satisfied with their thick french toast--a feat not easy to pull off.Service was pretty good for such a busy brunchery. Halfway through our meal a singer swept through the room, serenading us and selling CDs. Might be worth a visit to the Supper Clu downstairs where food comes with music.

One word: CHEESE-DDUKBOKKEE (cheese spicy rice cakes)Absolutely delicious. It's been deemed as my favorite spot for spicy rice cakes in NYC Ktown. My friends and I must have mentioned how delicious it was every 30 seconds while eating it and we couldn't stop talking about it the day after. I am going back to this place very shortly for more cheese ddukbokkee. God, I already miss it and it's only been a couple of days. However, their soju cocktail was way too sweet and not worth the $40 price tag for a bottle. $40 for a cocktail that has one bottle of soju and yogurt flavored mixer? Come on... Well, we could barely taste the soju, which made it worse. I won't return here for their drinks but will definitely return for their food and service. They have TVs at the bar for watching sports.

Came here after a yoga class and enjoyed every second of eating back double the calories I had burned. The Cuban was a mouthwatering delight of different flavors from the toasted bread, moist pulled pork, flavorful ham, rich cheese + sauce, and tangy pickle. All of this I doused with heavy amounts of Tapatio and Dijon mustard. Love how many difference sauces and various forms of foil/to go containers they have. Their menu is extensive and I look forward to come back for more!

Upscale hot pot place with a hip vibe, compared to the nearby Chinatown AYCE places, this place is trying hard to appeal to younger crowd and wider audience. They have beautifully photographed menu, nice decor, delicious soup base and fresh ingredient. We got the Tang pot, which is pretty unique to this place. The red soup base is very spicy, but not overwhelming. Great flavor too, as I didn't even need the dipping sauce. Wide variety of ingredients, as well as some very authentic Sichuan specialties. Overall I was very impressed with this place. The reason why it's not a five star is the price. Definitely the most expensive hot pot I have ever had.

A really cute dog cafe. The cafes are split-- one where furry creatures are allowed, the other, hoomans. The furry cafe was just crowded and there weren't much space for our furry ones so we hung out front on the benches. A bit far out of the way, but if you live in the area, this is a pretty cool spot to take your little one to socialize and meet up with friends or other fur-parents. The coffee, banana bread and hot cocoa my friends and I ordered were all yummy. Scruffles really loved her sample of krack'em chicken skins. Just a day of cuteness overload. Staff were terrific and overall, great service. Scruffles gives it two paws up.Reply to Logan H: Awesome. The pups could use more space

Errbody in the Tipsy Scoop Ice Cream Barlour gettin' tipsy. That's right, alcoholic ice cream is a thing and an amazing, delicious thing at that. My friends and I decided to get ourselves some post-boozy brunch boozy ice cream because, well, we're alcoholics and I mean, wine not? Now I know that you guys are prob thinking that that was a really bad idea, but let me reassure y'all, it was a fan-freaking-tastic one because those flavors were DELISH and thankfully not *too* boozy enough to kill us whew (but rest assured to all my fellow alcoholics, they were DEF boozy enough so we felt like we were actually getting our moneys worth). We shared an ice cream flight of Cake Batter Vodka Martini, Strawberry Rhubarb Bourban, Tequila Mexican "Hot" Chocolate + Strawberry White Sangria Sorbet and man, they were all pretty tasty. Being the tequila loving bish that I am, my favorite was ofc the Tequila Mexican "Hot" Chocolate which had just enough tequila to make the ice cream even more tasty and fun. Now, definitely don't come into Tipsy Scoop expecting to get drunk outta your minds, but DO stop by if you wanna get a little alcoholic ice cream wasted!

I've passed by Shorty's so many times but have never dropped by...until now. I went on a Tues night around 6:30pm and the place was packed! This is a small bar with some high tables. We were lucky enough to snag a table. The menu has lots of variety but we both chose to go with the classic cheese steak with whiz and onions, along with their beer battered onion rings. The onion rings came out first and was served with a chipotle mayo dipping sauce, which was delicious; however the rings were great on their own as well. Next came our cheese steaks - they were huge! For my personal taste, I thought it was really good but I would have liked a little more whiz and onions. My friend thought it was perfect the way it was. We both thought it was a tad bit too salty.Lots of TV screens (on mute) all over the bar; music playing in the background. On the night we were there, there was an extremely LOUD crowd at one of the tables which made the entire bar just too LOUD. But other than that, there was good atmosphere, great service (especially considering how busy it was). Next time, I'll have to try some of their other menu items and their happy hour specials!

I came for the braised beef wrap, and boy was I not disappointed.The beef was tender, smoky, sweet, with just a perfect amount of hoisin and wrapped in a crispy scallion pancake that made it almost like an egg roll. It's heavy. You split it and be happy, but eating the whole thing is bliss. This hip take out spot around the east Broadway scene is worth a stop in a bar hop, or for take out.  Scallion pancakes by themselves are $4, and pork buns come in a few different spins. It's a young fun staff. The combo special on my visit was two buns and curry fries for $12, which although too much for one, might be perfect for two. Bar stool dining only but you won't mind too much.

I was brought here by a friend of mine where we were debating where the best ramen spot in NYC was. Naturally, this was on the list and it belongs on that list.The place is rather small and always packed with people. I had to wait for a table to clear up to be seated for about 15 minutes. Must be worth the wait as three other groups are also waiting.We pretty much got whatever seat was available at this point so we took two seats by the bar area I guess you can call it looking into the kitchen. I got the spiciest ramen they had to offer which was the Volcano Tonkotsu Ramen. It had 6 peppers next to the name so it sounded dangerous. I also shared Steamed Pork Buns which came out first as they were appetizers which were tasty. The ramen was spicy alright, but I wouldn't say 6 pepper spicy. I was sweating after finishing the entire bowl, but was expecting to be in pain, so I guess that is a good thing! The portion of the bowl was enormous and really filling.Summary: If you're looking for an ramen spot in West Harlem, don't mind the wait, and you're really hungry (hopefully not hangry), voila!

As many here have stated, Negril Village is more of a club atmosphere than a restaurant, although the food is very delicious. Authentic good Jamaican cuisine with a mostly Jamaican staff.  The place is always packed. We have only experienced Sunday brunch and can recommend - - - Starters:Codfish fritters with avocado, Grilled Jerk chicken wings, grilled Jerk Shrimp, Ackee tostones, plantains Mains:Negril's Oxtail stew, Jamaican breakfast of Ackee and salt cod fish, Jerk chicken with waffles, Calypso Shrimp & Grits, Curry Goat with Rice and peas.Drinks: Potent and good. Dark & Stormy is a favorite. Mojitos, Sorrel, Ginger beer, many punch type drinks Music: Reggae, Caribbean and a DJ on top. Very good for dancing, but TOO LOUD for dining and conversation! "What did you say? Loud" Irie!

I like ramyun and not love it for a few reasons. One of them being that I get sick of it half way through. Jeju noodle bar's broth is one I crave and I would go back after my first experience.Clean, modern restaurant with good service and quality food. Menu is quite simple with hot/cold apps and three types of ramyun. Interesting fact: no servers, but the food is brought to the table by the cook! *Chicken Wing: Comes with six pieces, crispy skin and well cooked. Seasoning was your typical chicken wing plus more korean spice. It's not the soy-garlic or honey mustard sauce, just for reference.*So Ramyun: comes in a cute stone pot, veal broth with combination of rare and medium rare thin beef slices and bean sprouts. Noodles were cooked through, kinda wish they were al dente so they can cook with the residual heat from the broth. Broth was memorable. Kind of reminds of me Korean soulungtang because it is very hearty and flavorful. This was my fav of the night.*Gochu Ramyun: don't be alarmed, its not pepper broth and it's not super spicy either. Broth was okay on this one, based on the broth, I recommend the so ramyun over the gochu ramyun. The torched pork belly was very good. Outside was crispy and inside was soft and tender. Recommend if you are in the mood for good classic ramyun with delicious pork belly. Interior is truly beautiful. I love the open layout and the kitchen merges with the bar. I love the wall decorations that have various plates and barware. Minimalist feeling yet modern chic vibe that is suitable for dates and casual meet ups.

CHEESE. GLORY.I made reservations several weeks in advance because I'd heard the wait times can be pretty lengthy. My friend was running late on the Tuesday night we visited, so I was asked to wait at the bar. Even though their policy is to only hold a table for up to 15 minutes, we were seated promptly when my friend showed up about 25 minutes after our reservation time, which was greatly appreciated. Furthermore, service was surprisingly efficient for such a small space.Their drink menu consists of beer and wine only, which makes sense since those pair better with cheese than cocktails. The food menu is equally as uncomplicated; there are sandwiches (tartines and croques), raclettes, and a couple of additional entrée dishes. There were a couple of items that I knew we HAD to try because they were unique and had been incredibly hyped up on social media. We ordered two sandwiches and one raclette to share. The fig tartine ($14) was a delicious balance of sweet and savory and so unique--an absolute must-try. The croque madame ($14), a grilled ham and cheese sandwich with a perfectly fried egg on top, was also very good, but flavors were more predictable. Both sandwiches came with a side of arugula.And finally, the pièce de résistance, the raclette was of course out of this world. We selected the Suisse Complete ($27), which came with potatoes, cornichons, white pearl onions, arugula, 2 baguette slices, and 4 different cured meats. From the 5 raclette cheeses we got to choose from, we went with the black truffle (+$3). The cheese was very mild and didn't taste much of truffle, which was a little disappointing. The texture of the cheese was great though, very smooth, and went very well with the starchy potatoes. Pro tip: eat while warm.

HH here is crowded as heck from the top entryway to the downstairs bar/lounge area. Expect to get well acquainted with your party, as well as the surrounding patrons as it was elbow to elbow when we arrived. I made it a point to mentally note all the exit signs just in case, that's how overly crowded it was. Aside from that, the atmosphere is dark and cozy, kinda speakeasy dark. The apps that were ordered by a few in the crew looked really good. I got a chance to taste the Lamb Nachos, they were made fresh and were not your typical tasting or looking nacho. These included a thin crisp chip topped with tender shredded lamb, goat cheese drizzle, siracha, cilantro and another component, very flavorful and addictive. Good amount of time afforded to HH from 4-8pm. Having a quick fast barkeep managing the many orders of drinks and small plates was impressive considering the huge crowd.Thanks to Dino K for putting this UYE together. Haven't seen Dino in many years, so it was nice to catch up. It was also great to hang with Yelp friends and meet other Yelpers. If in the area, I would try them again during non-happy hours to get a better feel of Cask Bar without the crowding and to get a plate of those addictive Lamb Nachos.

Such a fun place!!!! Came here for dinner on a Monday with two friends around 6 PM. I had originally made a reservation but the place wasn't crowded at all. It started getting more lively around 7 though! The drinks and food are alright, but I definitely think the atmosphere is what makes this restaurant great. This place looks classy but still casual and fun. Our waitress was SOOO nice and very funny. She checked up on us quiet often even when things started to get busy. The punch bowl was definitely not very strong, but it tastes pretty good. A little too sugary for me but if you're looking for a drink without too much alcohol, this is a good one to go with. We shared it with three people, even though it says "served two". They honor the buy one get one margarita on yelp deal! And the margaritas are VERY strong. They don't use mix apparently but only stevia, which definitely makes the margarita healthier (probably not, but sometimes it's okay to lie to yourself). Their guacamole is SO GOOD. They mash it in front of you and it is absolutely delicious. Hands down the best thing in the restaurant. Empanadas are okay, they weren't that warm when they came out and quite dry. The flavor was not bad though. The nachos are monstrous! Can get very messy, but they taste alright. My friends and I thought the beans in the nachos tasted really good. Overall I would definitely come back. This place is a good spot to hang with your friends after work and get a few drinks.

Good local pizzeria. The slices are good - while not the best I've ever had and not the best in Yonkers as some other reviewers will claim, you can do a a lot worse as well. But everyone's opinions are different, as is mine. However, overall the slices are good. The selection behind the glass is pretty decent. I had 2 plain slices and a chicken Marsala. Everything was good.The drink selection is a little weak, but there was enough options to choose from. There was no menu to take inside and only limited choices on the overhead. This is one of those places that don't take debit/credit, so you need to have cash. The staff was friendly and welcoming. Who I think was the owner was very friendly. There's a decent amount of seating inside. There's metered parking and side streets and you can usually find a spot, though when the church is in session or one of the 2 schools is having a function, it's a lot more difficult. All in all a nice place and one I'd return to.

Birthday dinner for a party of two :) - So I have been dying to go here and every single god damn time I make reservations to go here something comes up and I end up cancelling so many times & these people must hate me. So I asked my s/o make RSVP's under his name instead. We were this close to not going here because he heard from his friend that Del Frisco's Grille was better (I was almost persuaded but no - made it this far no going back) Upon entering through the revolving doors felt like a grand ballroom with these high spiral stairs. Checked in with the hostess and was seated upstairs table with an overall view. Our waiter's name was Paul. - VIP Cocktails- Rose- Del Jumbo's Lump Crab Cake w/ Cajun Lobster Cream Sauce- Alaskan King Crab Legs - One Pound- Creamed Spinach w/ Smoked Bacon, Egg, Mushroom & Aged Sharp Cheddar Cheese Sauce- Lobster Macaroni & Cheese- 22oz Rib Eye Bone In w/ Truffle Butter Sauce- 32oz The Double Eagle 45 Day Dry Aged Double Bone Prime Ribeye w/ Santa Fe Sauce **Deserts were on the house** I honestly don't remember what we had for desert- I was so excited to go here I literally forgot to tell the waiter it was his birthday but the conversation came up and I didn't even think to let him know. I don't even know what I was thinking that night. I was just happy that we finally made it. Paul was amazing enough to put a candle in it and when he brought out deserts..That was when I realize oh sh*t I forgot. lol but thank god we have dinner reservations the next evening and it was already noted prior. (Haha) Food was great not spectacular like I hope it would've been but well worth an experience. Service by Paul was superb.

After dining multiple times here and their other locations, I'm a fan of this brand of restaurants. The selection of seafood and varieties of their preparation is wonderful to experience. Any non-Asian place that has enough confidence with their fish quality to prepare it raw is a indication of the freshness and confidence of its ingredients. The only minor complaint is having to wait when there seems to be open tables and a reservation was made. I feel it's more of a protocol than anything else. This brand of restaurants has gotten food, service, presentation, and customer satisfaction right on point. Definitely worth the price tag associated with dining here.

Minamoto Kitchoan is a popular Japanese chain that sells high quality Japanese wagashi. They have several franchises globally, with the Tokyo location being its flagship store. The New York shop, the only location in the east coast, only offers their delightful confectionery, ranging from fruit jellies to dorayaki and kasutera to mochi, to name a few.While many of their sweets are extraordinary and delicious, few are worth a special mention. Hakutou Jelly, one of their signature items, is a soft white peach jelly with incredibly smooth texture. Best served chilled, it's light and refreshing - like a slice of peach in the summer. Their mochi is quite special as well. I typically do not like mochi due to its chewy texture, but these are extremely delicate, with just the right amount of sweetness. At the time of writing, they offer Hakutou (white peach), matcha, and mango flavors.Like many Japanese goods, each dessert is beautifully wrapped, making these delicacies an ideal gift. As other reviews mentioned, the treats are on the pricier side, but they are sure to impress. The customer service was incredible as well - attentive and friendly.

I'm sooo conflicted on whether to give Natsumi 3 or 4 stars but I'm rounding up. Natsumi is a slightly nicer alternative to the other relatively cheapish sushi places on Seamless so I've started exclusively ordering from here whenever I have the craving. The lunch bento boxes are almost impossible to beat for the value - with an entree (I love the chicken katsu but the teriyaki is good too), white rice, some edamame, a california roll, and veggie tempura for like $12, it's impossible to beat. The three roll special ($16) that comes with edamame is also one of my go-to orders. I love how there are so many rolls to choose from for the special too - I usually get a spicy tuna, yellowtail jalapeno, and a california roll. All in all, Natsumi is a very welcome alternative to the other sushi places on Seamless.I'm taking off a star because of some major delivery issues I've had. I've noticed that it only happens when I place a "future" order on Seamless (which I tend to do here because it doesn't show up on Seamless until noon so I like to place my order as soon as possible). I won't get a confirmation email, and I'll call the restaurant and they swear they never received my order. They have been very flippant and rude about this in the past and last time it happened they blatantly hung up on me. I've had to go through Seamless Corporate care twice now because of the service issues. Another less-than-appealing experience: the last time I ordered, the sushi did not taste fresh at all. I ordered a piece of uni as a special treat and it was so rancid that I'm gagging just thinking about it. I'm going to disregard this experience as an anomaly though. TL;DR: FIX YOUR FAX MACHINE. My last order and some frustrating experiences aside, though, this is easily the best cheap sushi on Seamless.

Harlem we got a new neighborhood bar and I really feel like it is for everyone. I have been here a total of two times in a 2 weeks time period. The mural of a beautiful black woman with NYC's skyline in her fro blew me away. The bartender (Hey Jordan) knew her stuff and made some delicious drinks. They have a bomb happy hour until 8pm so you have time to get in where you fit in when you get off work. The entrees are great and the sides are MEH. It's a new spot and people are catching on so get there early. Tuesdays they have live music so that is a great time to check em out for the first time. Tips:- Get the red sangria on happy hour- Signature cocktail Sean Combs of Edgecombe is smooth and tasty- Fav food choice: Salmon burger

We had brunch before catching a show in the area once seated we started with some drinks the Mimosa flight was our choice 4 flavors Passion fruit, Pineapple, Blood orange & Meyer lemon...Good passion fruit & blood orange, I didn't like the lemon kinda harsh tasting the Passion Fruit was the best in my opinion. Main dish I had the Distillery flatbread pizza this is Irish sausage & bacon, onions on top of scrambled eggs whoa very good flatbread great tasting combo. Also tried the Baked eggs caprese good dish nice tasting sauce just needs more cheese. Friends had the Crab cake burger w fries good sandwich & fries as well as the Zucchini noodle salad good option for our vegan friend. As for the restaurant nice size w a bar area upfront, simple decor & good amount of seating. Service was good our waitress was nice & attentive, good brunch options at decent prices. We enjoyed our brunch.

Another plant based restaurant that just opened next to 00+( the best vegan pizza). The space is cute with a lot wine choices. The service is good but the Mexican inspired place seems nothing special. The menu is creative /use different ingredients/sauces to bring out the flavor. But it's not somewhere that I'm impressed. The best comparisons will be jajaja but has less choices.I got Farro chorizo tacos ( very spicy and a lot flavor with avocado/cream) totally worth it. Plantain chips are good( the sauce is weird to me but my friend loves it). My friend got wild mushroom tamale. She likes the mole sauce ( while I don't). The mange cheesecake isn't very sweet but seems to be premade that just got from the freezer. ( like those Daiya ones in whole food).The idea of plant based healthy-ish place is great ( vs those "vegan" places with comfort food- too much oil and too much fried food). But here is more a place for drinks and few bites than food tasting

On a rainy Sunday, sometimes you just want to curl up in a ball on your couch and watch netflix. Other times you want to head out and enjoy the much emptier city with a rain jacket and umbrella and ultimately end up at brunch. This past Sunday played out exactly like that. We had looked up a pulsd deal and Bazar piqued our interest. After getting out of class, we wandered down to 26th street and got ourselves a table at Bazar. I love the way this restaurant is decorated. The old school mirrors and colors were perfect. The smaller front opens up to a larger back area which is where we decided to sit. The 90 minutes included bellinis, mimosas and bloodies. I opted for bellinis and was pleasantly surprised that the service did not slow down. If my glass was empty, our server was ready to bring us another round, which is refreshing after a few past lackluster brunches. We decided to start our meal with the beet salad (not included in the deal) but it was well worth the extra money. It was delicious and I rarely see labneh so I was thrilled to get it. I got the croque madam for my entree. It is served on a baguette which was delicious and unexpected (my only complaint is that the under side of the bread was hard to cut through so perhaps ask for a sharper knife next time). The ham and cheese were great quality. The side salad had a lovely mix of small colorful tomatoes which was a nice bite of acidity to balance all the cheesy goodness. I will definitely be returning here for brunch. Everything was really tasty and the staff were all very friendly and welcoming. Even without the deal, brunch is 29.99, which is a great deal for booze and an entree.

I don't eat burgers often, so if I'm gonna eat one I want it to be a BOMB ASS burger, and I'm not gonna lie, this was a pretty bomb ass burger. I substituted sweet potato fries, which was an additional $2 I believe, but I really enjoyed my meal. The burger was on point. It was juicy, seasoned well, and perfectly cooked. Now of course when you come to black tap you HAVE to get one of their FAMOUS shakes. My friend wanted the cotton candy shake, which would've probably been my last choice, but whatever... cotton candy shake it was. When the shake came out, I had to wonder to myself if people actually drink the shakes and eat all the toppings. So if you go, I recommend you share with a couple people, because they can be a little overwhelming haha! If I were to come back, I probably wouldn't get another shake, but I definitely recommend their burgers.

Fun, lively environment with pricey noms and libations but worth it.I came here with some visiting family members for a slice of pie on Thanksgiving. I had the apple strudel. Omg. It was a huge piece and it came with a scoop of butter pecan ice cream. It's like they know me or something!!! It was DELICIOUS. Like, idk what else to say about that gorgeous slab on apples.The servers were kind and, even though it was a busy night, they were still pretty quick. The decor was festive and fun and the music was perfect for the mood.Stop through here if you get the chance especially if you can grab that slice of apple strudel!

I've come to Onegin several times for private parties and it's always a pleasure. I'm Russian so I take my Soveit eats seriously and my biggest pet peeve is overly fancy-fied Russian food, where it's Americanized to the point it looses its authenticity. I want babushka's cooking, dammit! Onegin doesn't disappoint. Yes, it's fancy-fied, but it still tastes like home.The good part about private events is the buffet, so I've sampled many dishes. Always stick to the goods: anything with salmon or some sort of smoked fish, and I'm a huge fan of their potatoes with mushrooms, they taste just like mama makes!Inside is super quirky and I love the decor. Onegin walks the fine line between being a very nice, classy restaurant, that still makes you feel you're getting a true, authentic experience.

I'll admit: I don't know much about Greek food beyond tzatziki sauce, gyros, and avgolemono. That's not too bad...right? Okay, admittedly, I need to bone up on my Greek menu knowledge some more. Voula NYC definitely dished out some education to me! From small plates to large dishes to potent and unique cocktails, Voula NYC dished out some amazing dishes in a sexy "date night" environment. Starting at the bar, I tried Penelope's Cobweb - it's a bit Pimm's Cup-like with a spicier bite - and I tried a friend's Always On Sunday - like a White Russian appearance-wise with a unique creamy nutty flavor - and both were great, though I favored the former drink much more. Moving onto apps, I had tzatziki - BUT OF COURSE - and some spicy feta with pita bread and Koulouri, a unique Greek bagel-shaped bread sprinkled with sesame seeds. The Lahanosalata was a crisp salad made with finely shredded cabbage, parsley, mint and sesame seeds in lemon-olive oil dressing topped w/ kefalograviera cheese; needless to say, I felt super healthy while eating it. Ha! It's so incredibly refreshing and counters any heavier dish there extremely well. Pan-seared feta, crusted with sesame seeds, well, it's just what it sounds like, and it is fantastic!The pièce de résistance was the Astako Makaronada, spaghetti with lobster (and I DO mean the claws and all!), fresh tomatoes, onions, garlic and feta. I am not a huge seafood fan, but there was something about this dish that made me put my notions about it aside and try a few bites of the lobster itself...though I largely stuck to the flavorful and perfectly-cooked pasta and left everyone else to pick at the crustacean, the bit of lobster I had was pretty good! I'm glad I tried even a little forkful. I'm glad I visited Voula NYC! It's not often I can say I've had a truly unique dining experience in NYC, believe it or not - there are so many restaurants but it's all burgers / ramen / pho / crazy milkshakes, it seems - but I ate dishes I have never even heard of, and that made my experience there truly special.

KenScale: 8.5/10I've been to some of the best sushi restaurants in New York City during my culinary journey, but I haven't had the kind of experience that Mayanoki offers. The restaurant, which is showcasing what it calls the "sustainable sushi" experience, has one single counter helmed by a Caucasian chef Jeff Miller, who recently came onboard after working in Texas. When I showed up with my wife Jun for a Sunday evening, we were the only diners at the counter, and as much as I hate to admit it, having a non-Japanese chef was a scary proposition at first. I am very glad to be proven wrong about my trepidations, though, since Mayanoki had some of the best locally sourced fish (i.e. mostly on the East Coast) with quite unique attributes. While speaking to chef Miller during our dinner, I was very impressed with his knowledge of the fish and the way he tried to showcase an alternative vision of a sushi dinner. None of the fish on our menu (I would say a relative bargain at $95 per person for 15 courses) came from California or Japan; in fact, there was only one from Iceland (more on that later). Yet, many of the pieces that we sampled were very delicious and made me truly appreciate what the kitchen was trying to do here. After an outstanding dish of kale and quail egg, chef Miller handed us a roll with oyster and salmon roe. I don't remember ever getting an oyster at a sushi restaurant but I wasn't complaining as the combination of the two distinct species made for one heck of a bite. Shrimp that was farmed indoors nearby in New York State, unlike the traditional ebi, had the crunchy feel to it that was quite wonderful, and bay scallops from Nantucket Bay had the silky smooth texture that is not easily forgettable. Others like swordfish from Montauk and fatty bluefish (a Rhode Island version of o toro in two different cuts) were also outstanding. The only non-U.S. fish was salmon farmed in Iceland, and Jun was raving about how the lightly smoked touch made it so much more interesting than a typical salmon nigiri we've had before. Others like albacore from Oregon, Spanish mackerel from North Carolina, herring from Rhode Islands, Boston mackerel and fluke from Long Island had varying levels of success. For the pieces that I graded at a lower level, I felt the seasoning could've been slightly toned down to give greater pleasure to the texture of the fish. Still, at the end of the night, Jun and I really enjoyed our meal while chatting about chef Miller about his background and the philosophy behind this potentially pioneering sushi restaurant.Mayanoki accepts reservations, and while we were the only diners on a chilly Sunday evening, there is only one single counter so I recommend booking in advance. There are some interesting sake and wine options that can go well with your meal that I suggest checking out. The cozy counter, combined with the friendliness of the manager and chef Miller, will make for one good date idea. I am very looking forward to seeing how Mayanoki evolves over time; its unique concept is certainly worth exploring if you are tired from all the high-end omakase places in the city and want to see a fresh set of perspectives on the art of sushi.

Cote is definitely pricier than your typical K-town Korean BBQ, but ultimately I felt that it was worth it. There were a few hiccups in service but overall my friends and I had an enjoyable experience, and I would definitely go back. Make sure to make reservations well in advance!The ambiance here is really nice. I really appreciated the free coat check, as it's a peeve of mine to leave KBBQ joints with my clothes reeking of it. The decor is very elegant and there is a spacious bar at the front to pass time while waiting for your table. The bartenders were really sweet and friendly, and very good at what they do. We had the Agave Sour and the Seoul-Side and both were delicious, albeit a bit small in volume for the price ($15). We had a reservation at 9 PM and were seated around 9:20.The Butcher's Feast was a no-brainer for us, since it allowed us to sample 4 different types of beef. For $45 per person, it also comes with banchan, two stews, egg souffle, a plate of lettuce for wraps, rice, and soft serve. It's my understanding that the beef types rotate based on the night, but we were served hanger steak, aged ribeye, wagyu, and short rib/galbi. We also ordered the Korean bacon as an appetizer, but I think we would have been plenty stuffed sticking just to the feast. It was delicious though - crispy slices of pork belly paired well with jalapeño and a mustard sauce.The quality of the meat is definitely apparent in every bite, both in flavor and texture. I usually like to have dipping sauces with my KBBQ, but found myself just savoring the meat as-is here. We were a little confused as to whether we were supposed to be cooking the meat ourselves or waiting for our server. Initially, it seemed like the server would be handling the cooking, but our first meat almost burned/became overcooked so we started just doing our own thing. We didn't mind cooking ourselves, but would have appreciated better communication. The ribeye was by far my favorite and the most tender, but I also loved how perfectly marinated the galbi short-rib was. We also liked how well-timed the side dishes came out. We received the stews and souffle about half-way through and it was a nice way to break up the meats. The souffle was so fluffy and I loved the mushroom tofu stew. Dessert consisted of a seasonal soft-serve, which was shaved peppermint this time around. It was SO GOOD. I'm a huge fan of soft serve and this one does not miss the mark. There was a slight situation with one of the other patrons near our table on the night that we dined, but I was impressed with how well the restaurant handled everything. They were extremely courteous and a staff member even came up to us afterwards to apologize if it had detracted from our experience in any way (it didn't, but the gesture was nice). Yes, I had a bit of sticker shock when we received the bill but again - I felt like it was worth every penny. Already thinking about my next viisit back!

I came with a group of 4. Everyone was held upstairs until the reservation starts and then we were brought downstairs all together. First impression of the downstairs was that it's akin to a speakeasy bar. The difference was that they happen to also serve a prix fixe menu of only desserts.Gin and tonic - tilt head back. Drop it onto your mouthMoliterno with Black truffle, crispy cracker - nice savory treat First dessertWine pairing - french 75, herbaciousOlive oil ice cream. The cocktail brings out the flavor of the olive oil and the eucalyptus smoke was a real visual delicacy. Smelling it made me feel like I was in a spa. Second dessert yuzu honey - Sweeter and tangy, mango parfait, pearled barley.Mango parfait was so light and fluffy. Honeycomb was super sweetMoscato D' Asti Wine is a bit sweeter. Third Dessertpb&j - Dried Raspberry, Banana sorbet, black currant. this was my favorite dessert of night and I absolutely loved how it was served in a jar. Morentina - fortified wine. Cuts through creaminess. quite strongFourth dessertgin and sake infused with rosemary, cinnamon, cardamom, gin and sake. served warm. The contraption for serving this drink was very novel. miso pink grapefruit - served on a block of Himalayan salt. The salt and sweet contrast only gets stronger as the dessert sits on there for longer. Cashew cookie. Miso tart. Meringue. Pink grapefruit sorbet is very tart. Fifth DessertCloverclub - vermouth, egg white, gin, raspberry Black sesame yuzu truffle - the dumpling has black sesame on the inside topped with fruit caviar. I felt like it was pretty basic, but that may be because I've had lots of black sesame before. Final desserttoffee apple tonka granny smith - Puff pastry, tonka bean, dehydrated apple. Tasted like an apple pie but more like a jelly consistency. 2011 Sauvignon blanc - honey, caramel. This was my favorite wine of the night. Final small treat.Gummy bears infused with different alcohols. Maro, tremburi, port, brandyFirst time experiencing a dessert prix-fixe. Ordered the wine & cocktail pairing. It didn't really enhance the desserts, but there was one really interesting drink that was sake infused tea. I'd rank the desserts as follows: 3,1,6,4,5,2. Music is a bit too loud for my liking. Someone needs to pick calmer / chill music. Service here was excellent and they made all the desserts in front of you. Felt like eating at a sushi bar where they are perfectly crafting the dessert like it's an art.

I have legitimately been watching this place for a while. I've have been checking it out from afar and lusting after a taste of their food. I'm now going to warn you that this is about to get a little out of control, take your PG-13 warning and stop now if you can't handle the heat. Can you handle it?I sure can handle it!!! Let me clarify, this place is a plain, hole in the wall buffet that has a long seating area. In the center of the place, you will find the treasure trove of a buffet. So you actually are invited to feed your greediest of desires. Grab a container and serve yourself. Bring your fare to the counter to get it weighed. They give you a cup for water, a spoon, fork and knife to dig into your plate.I was filling my mouth slowly to sample all of the flavors and textures. Not all items are labeled so I welcomed the idea of using my tongue and tastebuds to explore. ((Shudders)) I stopped short of licking the styrofoam plate. I think it was really obvious that I was enjoying the food as two random patrons sat with me to break bread in unison.Staff is friendly, they have a variety of beverages and the price is right. There is an atm and a well-maintained bathroom onsite!

Ok - after realizing that UES is more than just an ice cream shop, I can see the appeal and why the ice cream front is really just a front.So while the ice cream is just OK, come here later at night (maybe after 8?) and you'll notice a nicely dressed man who is actually a bouncer. Ask him to look at the "storage room" and show him your ID. Then, you need to find the "switch" and then wait for the door to open! It's magical and totally awesome. If you love speakeasies or hidden bars you definitely have to try this out. WAIT: We came on a Friday night at 8pm and there was only 1 table left so it was nice that we didn't have to wait. ATMOSPHERE: The ice cream shop is tiny but inside is pretty large, so it makes sense why there isn't much space. Once you walk in you're greeted with neon signs and a hostess who can check in your coat and show you to your seat. The inside is very eclectic giving it that haunted mansion/Alice in Wonderland feel with things coming out of the roof and lots of paintings/pictures on the wall. They play loud popular music and the lighting is very dim. Tea cup candles on each table, which are usually small and narrow for 2 people or they have larger booths and a bar. Very whimsical and cool, definitely not like something I've seen on the upper east side.FOOD: Their menu is an Upper East Side "guide" with unique names. It's a pretty extensive menu with lots of descriptions and they tell you how strong the cocktail is, the wow factor etc. and then the cost. This place kind of reminds me of a cheesier aviary because they have drinks that look cool and some that have cool quirks to them. For example, the gossip girl one has this piece of corn husk/straw/hay that they light on fire. MILLIONAIRE - I forget the exact name but we got it because it has mochi. You can make any drink a "mocktail" since I don't drink and my husband wasn't in the mood for alcohol. It probably didn't taste right since it didn't have the alcohol but the presentation was cool. It was a cup within a cup and on the bottom of the first larger cup were 4 "smoked" gumdrops that tasted like they were roasted over a wooden campfire. The top had the drink, whipped cream and a quarter of a mochi. A little stale/overfrozen but not bad. I like that most of the drinks have an ice cream or dessert/sweets theme to them and they use the soco creamery ice cream they have out front. I wish they would serve scoops of their ice cream in the bar in case you dont want a drink or you want dessert and a drink.Overall, I would say this is pretty ingenious since you would never be able to tell it's a hidden bar, very cool, very trendy and I like that it's so close to us!

Her Name Is Han serves photograph ready brunch and authentic, fresh flavors. We came here for a weekend brunch with friends. Their menu is on the expensive side, with entrees easily costing you a good 20 dollars or more. The decor is dainty and detailed, giving off a bookworm, chill vibe. Our tuna tataki rice bowl was refreshing and simply made, showcasing natural flavors and fresh ingredients. The tuna itself was flavorless, but married well with the sauces, crisp radish, fresh greens, and bonito flakes. The banchan, in my opinion, was the star of the meal. The softened, sweetened lotus root had a great fulfilling mouthfeel, while the deviled egg was smooth, savory, and perfectly eggy. In all, for what you pay for, you can expect delicately prepared, fresh food that can easily be shared with a friend. I'll be looking here for a dress-up brunch next time I'm in the area.

I've known of Eataly for quite a while but have never actually been until today. Half the reason is because I just never made a real effort, and the other half is because I've always been suspicious of its authenticity. The fact that it's a big tourist spot and its celebrity chef backing never put it on the top of my list of authentic Italian eateries in New York City. However, I've been to other Batali/Bastianich restaurants which were quite good, and since I was in the area with some friends today we decided to check it out.The best way to describe Eataly is a hybrid of various cafes, restaurants, and shops - all carrying a variety of Italian cuisine and merchandise. Walking in on a Saturday afternoon the place was loud and packed - judging from other reviews that seems to be the norm. It didn't bother me too much though, I had already eaten so I really just wanted to explore the merchandise and absorb it all. There seems to be everything one would want - in addition to the restaurants, there's stands for bread, fish, meats, and cheese. They also have a number of Italian grocery items and Eataly souvenirs. Walking through the shops they have a number of authentic Italian food items - I noticed a lot of tomato products (including Lidia Bastianich's canned sauce) as well as pastas and cookies. Like other reviewers, I noticed prices were high - I can get pretty much everything Eataly sells on Arthur Ave in the Bronx for a lower price. Eataly has piqued my interest, and it's a fun place to shop, eat and explore. I would return to pick up some quick items, and maybe sit down at one of their restaurants - but I would make an effort to come at off peak times (if they even exist). Eataly seems to deliver the goods, just be aware of the Manhattan prices.

** only seats you for a reservation when your entire party has arrived **(so be punctual)*did not try the hands-on (literal) Kamayan experience*($45/pp on weekday & $55/pp on weekend)Arrived with a reservation for 13 and was seated promptlyFree street parking after 7pm$29pp bottomless brunchRecommendation list:Tahong (Steamed Mussels) Batangas Bone Marrow (this can be a meal in itself)- comes with garlic rice and absolutely shareable Coconut rice (this was absolutely delicious)Sigsig tacos (kind of pricey though at $13 for 2 pieces)Bicol ExpressPineapple cocktail for 2 - comes in an actual pineappleWhat was less impressive, and recommend to skip:Pancit (without the shrimp) - better at MarharlikaHalo halo - ratio was totally off as it was 70% ice to 30% stuff

The Quick: It's all about who you know for the Norwood Members Only Club. Very cool relaxed and hip vibe. Great artwork, outdoor space. Semi reasonable drinks (if you ignore the members fee). If you get invited absolutely go to check it out! There's always something exciting about a Members only spot specifically those targeting the artsy crowd.

My friend Pam and I got here at 6pm on a Wednesday... We were pretty much the only two people there for an entire hour, and between 7 & 730 the place filled up completely. We were expecting a restaurant with a hostess and waiters, but it's a regular "find your own seat" pizza place. Usually these types of places are smaller, and the tables aren't as nice or clean. But it was a very laid back and casual environment. We each had a suppli, the fried risotto croquettes stuffed with mozzarella. They were like arancini, I'm not exactly sure if there's a difference or if there's more than one name for this appetizer but either way, they were good. They weren't greasy or dry, which is usually what can make these not taste great, but the crisp was just right. Then we had our two pizzas which we shared. One was the mushroom pizza, with onions, thyme, and fontina. The other pizza was a "my margherita" (which is a regular Margherita with your choice of toppings), and we got the mushrooms and truffle oil. Although the two pizzas both had mushrooms, they were quite different. Equally good, and after a break I could've even split a third pizza. We had wine with dinner, and although the drink options are very limited, it actually didn't taste bad for a house wine at all. And lastly, we split the vanilla soft serve gelato, which was also good. I really want to try the pizza with Brussel sprouts, cheese, and pepper... I'll definitely go back, hopefully soon!

As someone who grew up on homecooked Chinese (Sichuan) cuisine, I can see why a lot of diners might shy away from Philippe. The prices are definitely higher than your typical Chinese restaurant, but neither the food nor the dining experience here is typical.I dined here with a larger group so was able to sample a number of dishes. From the appetizers, I would recommend the Chicken Satays which are super tender and served with an addictive peanut sauce. The noodles are also solid, but my preference was for the Vegetable Lo Mein, which are hand-pulled and served with fresh vegetables and cooked in an addictive sauce. The Lobster Noodles were also a seafood lover's delight, with plenty of chunks of real lobster meat.I think where the restaurant really shines is in their Peking Duck, which is carved tableside and there's elements of showmanship and skill from the chef. The skin is crisp and packed with flavor, and the meat has just enough fat to make for a delicious bite.
