It's served with pancakes, hoisin, and celery, so you can make yourself the perfect Peking Duck wrap. The Beijing Chicken was also a group favorite, featuring tender chicken meat in a bright red sauce.For the dessert: the Cotton Candy Baked Alaska makes for a great closing spectacle, and features a Baked Alaska hidden in a dome of cotton candy. Yes, there's fire, and yes, it's delicious.For special occasions, I'd recommend visiting Philippe for a unique dining experience and a modern take on traditional Chinese dishes.

TL;DR: Finally a quality, mainstream, fairly-priced, indigenously-flavored Latin cuisine spot in the Theatre District! The whole thang:I have at least a decade-long issue with this area, in that - more times than not - you need to know hole-in-the-wall joints to get authentic non-American flavor, rather than the more typical "let's season everything for the average, no-adventurous tourist palate" approach. I'm especially particular with Brazilian cuisine, since my travels and having one of the best options for it around the corner from my apartment has informed and molded my palate.Samba = the real thing!The Pão de Queijo made me stop convo and give side eye to the bowl.The Caipirinhas were on point in all three flavors we tried, including me ordering a Cashew Fruit Juice one (technically off the menu). They're offering really nice Brazilian-themed specialty cocktails, just the right portion sizes (the low- to mid-range dishes being not enough to take home, but just enough to keep you full and happy but not stuffed...and the higher-priced dishes packing a huge bang for your buck), GREAT service, nice chill environment, seating isn't too close, good vibe...just really good stuff!

Yes. This is the place to be for your next k-bbq. I love their food but also their service. Personally, I like the more family and big group oriented vibe of the downstairs (quieter) but the upstairs serves the younger crowd. I love their side dishes and the egg & corn that's served in the gutter of the hot plate. Their galbi was so fresh everytime I was there. Try the pig-skin! if you like chewy food. So good. The wait can get quite long here but I don't think they take reservations for small parties.

When I heard there was a new Russian fast food chain opening near my office I was stoked. Memories of a very early and amusing attempt at a "Russian McDonald's" in FiDi circa 2000 recalled decent food, low prices, and Soviet-style rude service by unhappy female workers wearing Micke D hairnets.No such poblems weigh down the streamlined Teremok, a franchise in a global chain of successful Russian-influenced blini-n-kasha cafes that is smart to localize dishes for its New York audience (see pastrami kaska bowl!).The food is relatively authentic, with the blini and kaska comprising most of the menu choices, but other staples such as pelmeni (dumplings) and kvas (fermented bread "soda") available at reasonable price. Other items may vary. The "venegret," for instance, was nothing like the beet/ potato/pickle salad I grew up with. All the ingredients were there, but left in their individual piles rather than mixed, almost as if inviting you to DIY your own venegret. The blini, which my friend ordered, were soft and delicious, though I was just as happy to lay on a dollop of dominant sour cream flavor (it comes in large condiment squeeze packets here!).There was some order confusion (I had asked for the aforementioned pastrami kasha) but I was more than happy to hoover the "mistake" order of lox and kasha. That buckwheat! Took me back to all those lunches I ate growing up, the only thing missing was the required cutlet. Staff was extremely friendly and made up for the order mixup by offering me a cup of kvas, which I promptly handed to my buddy who was a kvas virgin. Needless to say, I am a fan, and, should the universe will this place to thrive in the location, will be back.

My only regret is not visiting this place sooner. I always pass by it and never go inside... I been dying to try the woolys shaved ice. Today I stopped by for lunch and this place is pretty cool when you enter there is a quote on the wall that stands out. They have both stairs and elevators. The food offered here is a great since there is a variety of food. The vendors offered are Azuki(sushi), BOX(Mediterranean) Dough (donuts/hot drinks) , Gabriela's Taqueria(mexican) , Kuro-obi(ramen) Lukes(lobster/crab rolls) and Whitmans. Today I had whitmans as i have tried some of the other vendors elsewhere. Whitmans has burgers, cheese steak and salads. The cheese-steak which is what i ordered looks small but its very fulfilling and tasty. They also serve wine and beer. Place is connected with row hotel and it has lots of seating. This is a great place for quick bites for pre theater food or just if you're on the go in the theater district.

I crave hotpots now and then and decided to come here one cold Friday night to cater to my cravings. Asked how long the wait was and they said 3 hours. Yes, 3 hours! Made a reservation for another Friday evening. This time the wait was 30 mins. Yes! We had a wait despite the reservation. Once seated, you are handed a wet napkin, a hairband and plastic bags to place your jackets in to avoid the lingering sichuan smell. They also provide ziplocks for your phones on request."All you can eat hot pot for $22.99" is popular here. Pick your soup base from original, chinese herbal, spicy, pig bone, curry, tomato, kimchi, mix mushroom. Unlike other hotpot places where you have a single pot with a divider placed in the center of the table, each seat gets a small pot and is placed on your very own mini stove. We ordered 1 spicy and 1 original broth. While the spicy broth needs no change, you can experiment with the flavor of original broth by adding additional (around 20) sauces. I personally loved the spicy broth as the spice was flavorsome and not over-the-top. Pick the add-ons from a plethora of veg and non-veg options and devour the spread. Highlights:* Make a reservation* Get the all-you-can-eat hot pot for $22.99* Get the spicy broth or experiment with original broth* Free meal on your birthday. You've got to show your ID.* Birthday +-3 days also gets you a free meal if you or your friends get an 8" cake.* If you get a cake, you get a minute to fame with a cosplaying, dancing monkey who sings for you. They also take your picture and print it for you as a souvenir. It's as embarrassing as it sounds.* Yelp checkin gives you a free scoop of icecream. No one-per-table rule.

I like this place. It's pricey but you can get great cocktails here. I've been a couple of times and sat at the bar. It gets really crowded but if you can snag a seat, it's worth it. Only drawback is that because the cocktails are carefully created, sometimes it takes a long time to get a refill so make sure you order when you have about 25% of your drink left.It's a great place for a date and the bartenders I have encountered are very friendly.It's easy to spend an entire afternoon here, which I did on a blind date once. One drink led to two, then three. Time flew by and I thought we were having a good time, but when I asked if he wanted to go out again, he said "no". I had been planning on picking up the check but luckily hadn't received it yet, so we just split it. The point is, you'll have a good time here even if the date doesn't work out.

Dinner for four last night at The Red Rooster. We all had the glugg, hot Scandinavian spiced wine. It was great and very strong. We ordered cornbread and a kale salad split for the four of us. The salad was ok and the cornbread was terrific. We had two half fried chicken dinners with mashed potatoes and collard greens. And I had the blackened cat fish over baked beans. All our choices were exceptional. Five stars all the way, less one star deducted for the one hour it took to get our food after we placed our order.

I absolutely love hard ice cream. I'm not one for the soupy, melted stuff so this place was just perfect for me! Seeing them make it in front of you, choosing your toppings, though the place is small, they try to get your order down and make your ice cream quickly. There isn't a place to sit so park your tukus outside or take it to a nearby stoop

Due West is a fantastic addition to the West Village. I was skimming Eater NY recently and stumbled upon a list of new openings. When I saw "cocktail bar" and "West Village", I was immediately pleased. Don't get me wrong--there are a number of fantastic cocktail bars in the West Village. Employees Only, Slowly Shirley, Little Branch, the Garret, Highlands--the selection could certainly be worse. But I've been to all of these bars plenty (quality problems, I know), and there hasn't been anything new in the area in quite some time. Due West offers a fabulous variety of originals, draft cocktails and bottled cocktails, as well as a pretty substantial food menu. We only came for drinks, but from what we saw during our visit here, the food alone is reason enough to return. In a nutshell: fantastic drinks, appetizing eats and some cool ambiance to top it off. We came to Due West for a pre-dinner drink, at around 8:45pm on a Saturday night. Somehow, with just 17 reviews on Yelp, this place appears to have gotten on the radar of the masses. It was snowing pretty heavily on this particular night, and we still needed to wait a bit to get in. This was partially due to the fact that the owner appears to not like folks congregating at/crowding the bar. Normally this would irritate me, but I actually appreciated it once we did get in. The space itself is decently-sized, but there's not a ton of standing room by the bar. There are far more seating options. The owner was able to seat us at a communal table soon after we ordered our drinks at the bar, so it worked out well. The vibe here is more chic than the average West Village hangout. Though less homey/cozy than a lot of the other popular bars in the area, it's still warm and friendly. Servers are super accommodating, bartenders are knowledgable and prompt, and not surprisingly, the clientele skews higher-brow finance-y (as opposed to, like, the 13th Step kind of finance-y). The drink menu at Due West, as I mentioned, is impressively varied. You've got your typical shaken and stirred originals, along with draft and bottled cocktails. If none of those suit your fancy, there's also a Create Your Own Old Fashioned, which looks unbelievable. You have your pick of whiskey, bitters and sugar. Can you imagine Maple sugar and Orchard bitters? Fabulous idea, surprising more cocktail bars don't offer this. For once, I was sad that the restaurant we were waiting on summoned us early, because I only got to try one drink here. It was not an Old Fashioned, but it was still seriously great. I got the Green Witch (Greenhook Gin, Absinthe, Pamplemousse, Saffron, Toasted Rosemary), which is one of the cocktails on tap here. Really interesting, complex, great flavors, well-balanced, nothing too overpowering, refreshing yet substantial. A great drink to kick off a night. The bf got the DW Sour (Fords Gin, Tangerine, Tamarind, Lemon, Egg White), which was frothy, elegant and citrusy. Two great drinks, and I'm sure we'll be back for more soon.

Trendy, intimate bar for a drink. But - then it stops. While my service was perfectly friendly - it was just soooo slow, so don't be in a rush to just have a drink before dinner somewhere here. But - this is one of the few Latin and non-Spaniard focused places in Midtown w/o heading to Queens or Harlem. Things to Note on the Food:1) Absolutely pass on the Paella - ehh2) Bacalou Fried Fritters were awesome!3) Focus on Apps vs. Mains to share 4) Lots of fusion stuff going on and I don't know if I love that. And Asian Latin food is a real thing but I don't know about the execution here5) Love the Arepas and beef empanadas6) ceviche is good but not greatOverall - it was a great experience but not my consistent local hole for my Latin weekly needs.

With Boqueria just 2 blocks away, I give Pil Pil a lot of props for holding their own. Not because Boqueria does Spanish tapas better, but because Pil Pil just does it with much more modesty.We came for late brunch on a Saturday around 2pm. We didn't have a reservation, so we were asked to wait at the bar, where we were allowed to start our unlimited sangria for brunch ($16pp, 2-hour limit). The sangria was good, not too sweet. And it's worth noting that the waitstaff were VERY good about refilling our sangria, sometimes before we were completely finished with the glass we currently had! Bravo!For food, you get your choice of one of four trios of tapas, categorized by different regions of Spain ($15.95 each). We had the Galicia (Spanish omelet, pan-seared salmon, and croquettes) and the Basque (Spanish omelet, steak and fries, and chorizo and egg on an English muffin). All of the tapas were tasty, and paired perfectly with the sangria. Portion sizes are a bit small, but reasonable given the price.To top off our delicious Spanish brunch, we got an order of churros with chocolate sauce. Unfortunately, the churros were too hard for my liking, as though they were fried a smidge too long. But dunked in chocolate, it's still pretty good.

Came here for breakfast with a friend today. Very nice quiet ambiance. I got the French roast w over easy eggs and ham and it was delicious. I added fresh strawberries and bananas to my French toast because why not? I never finish my food but today I did. The French toast is nice and fluffy not too sweet, not dry at all. The food comes out pretty quick too. My friend built her own omelette. By the time we were finished we couldn't move. Would definitely come back for breakfast. Wasn't pricy either. This place only takes cash by the way, so make sure you come ready with your dollar bills.

As I passed by this bakery, I noticed a line....why is there a line for this bakery? It was early 7:50am and there were about 5 people in line already, I might as well give it a shot.After the place opened it's doors at 8:05am, the customers walked down the long table where the bakery showcased what they had and the labels on the bottom described what the goods were and the price.I pretty much ordered everything except from the Cruffin; which was what they were known for.Got a box and paid the bill.The most expensive croissant was the peach and the banana split, topping out at $8 each.Everything tasted awesome, my favorite pick would be the squid ink donuts and pistachio croissant. The cream filling in them weren't too sweet and it balanced just right. You can skip the $8 items, the banana split and the peach croissant was just too overly sweet and just looks pretty with the few gold flakes on top.The box they give you is very shiny and makes a great background for those photo ops.

Tucked away in East Village, Ho Foods is a cleverly named (after its owner) Taiwanese noodle shop that specializes in Taiwanese beef noodle soup. I recently dined here on a soft opening night and it was a pleasant experience. From the cozy atmosphere to minimal and clean décor, the intimate seating arrangement to old black-and-white family photographs, I felt like I was dining in my grandmother's house, although I do not have a Taiwanese grandmother lol.Currently, the shop offers one entrée item: Taiwanese beef noodle soup. Served with a bone and marrow broth that is carefully simmered for 24 hours, it is a solid dish and I had no complaints about it. The broth, the owner's family recipe, is delicately balanced and absolutely satisfying: Spicy, fragrant, and hearty - perfect for a cold winter night. You can opt to slurp this delicious broth with either thick noodles or wide noodles, which are from local purveyors. I personally preferred the wide noodles because I enjoyed the amount of grease and broth it picked up in each bite (yes, I'm all about those surface areas). However, I really liked the texture of the thick noodles, as it had a little more bite. The beef was cooked to perfection - the fat beautifully rendered and very tender in texture. The pickled mustard greens is absolutely delicious and adds a lot to the beef noodle soup.Because the restaurant is quite small, I wouldn't recommend dining here with a large group. But it is an ideal place to grab a quick bite by yourself or with a small party. As Ho Foods recently opened, I am positive that they are in the process of figuring out what works and what doesn't, as well as what kinds of other dishes they can add to their menu. As their business grows, it would be interesting to see if they venture to make their own noodles. Either way, I can't wait to come and check this restaurant in a few weeks and see how they are continuing to evolve.

When it comes to contemporary Middle Eastern fare, look no further than Nur. They offer some fantastic bites and especially some wonderful entrees to share. Highly recommend to bring a friend or friends to get in on as many of the dishes here. I was thoroughly impressed by the originality and uniqueness of the food, or perhaps a lot of these dishes have just been unbeknownst to me. Either way, Nur was worth the trip.My friend and I came when Nur was fairly new, having been opened for only a month (opened earlier in 2017). Even so, service was running smoothly and the restaurant was pleasantly packed. Reservations were quite tight at the time, and I can only imagine they still are. We had many dishes in mind to try, but we decided to try four dishes on our first visit. Portions are quite substantial, and so pricing seems fair. Our dinner included the Horias (Crispy pita filled with spiced lamb), the Smoked Eggplant Carpaccio (fire roasted eggplant with feta, raw tahini, dates, pistachios, rose water), the Casablanca Chraime (poached fish stew with tomato, mussels, and hand-rolled couscous with pumpkin tershi), and the Kubaneh (a special Yemenite pull apart bread with schug and grated tomato). I highly recommend any and all the breads available. The Kubaneh was delicious, maintaining a fine soft interior texture. Schug happens to be also one of my favorite Middle Eastern condiments (hot green chilies). The Kubaneh reminded me a bit of challah. As for the Eggplant Carpaccio, it is quite similar to hummus or baba ganoush in flavor and texture, but the pistachio really adds to it. I really enjoyed this with our Kubaneh. Our starter dish, the Horias, was quite tasty. They are basically mini lamb pita sandwiches. The Chraime was good and while I remember enjoying it, it was still probably the least memorable. I would definitely go for the Kubaneh and Eggplant Carpaccio next visit but opt for something over the Chraime and possibly the Horias. Nur was wonderful the first time, and my mouth only waters as I write about the Kubaneh. Their breads are definitely the thing to get and make sure to dive into that side of Schug. I loved the Eggplant Carpaccio as a pairing to the bread as well. For a new restaurant, service was steady. The restaurant space is clean and modern, though some may think the lighting is too dark at the very back of the restaurant (which made taking food photos a bit tricky). Nonetheless, I am a a fan and highly recommend Nur if you like Middle Eastern food but with a bit of added flair.

After walking around the high line I was starving & needed a drink I saw this from above & was like yesss!!Came in & sat at the bar, drinks I went with the Brooklyn lager beer, good beer nice & cold. Pizza wise I wanted the Vodka slice but they didn't have any .. ironically I've never tried their signature Artichoke pizza since they were out of the vodka I went with the artichoke. Wow giant slice of pizza that unless u r starving is good for sharing.On the slice Artichoke hearts with some spinach topped with cream cheese, mozzarella & pecorino cheese all finalize this delicious slice I gotta say it was very good nice thin crispy crust just adds to the cheesy goodness that is the slice very flavorful. As for the restaurant not very big with seating inside & out plus a small bar area. Simply decor, service at the bar was good prices are decent for the slices I believe it was $6 for the slice & $7 for the beer hard to go wrong this was a great pit stop.

I will stay this is kind of hitten spot, a great unique pizzeria where you will find that they make the pizza with the old oven, the place is not that big, but they have a little patio in the back with is a bit cozy. I came with a few of my cousin because one of them recommend the food over here. We decide to share a few appetizer before attacking the pizza, The eggplant parm stack a fried eggplant with ricotta mozzarella, I have to say I m not a fan of eggplant but the way this was prepared make it that I considered from that day to have more eggplants, simply delicious, We also had the crispy Brussel sprouts a honey garlic aioli, with Spanish paprika even although some of my cousins said that this was the best dish in the place I did not like much, although it was not bad.The taste of pizza was delicous the oven give that homemade taste that make it very good. For our dessert we had the Nutella pizza what I can say about it, it fell heaven just hit your palate each time I had a bite.

Dough doughnuts are always delicious! I stopped in on this Saturday. It was the perfect snack after a day of shopping in the snow. We ordered three doughnuts for the two of us which is way too much because these doughnuts are huge!!!My favorite is always the cafe au lait and my fiancé loves the cinnamon sugar doughnut. We had to try the gingerbread and I am glad we did. It was so tasty!!!!

One tip of advice: Do NOT underestimate the portions.I was in the SOHO/Chinatown area and my friend and I were in DIRE need of some ice cream. I kept seeing Milk & Cream on Yelp so I figured we try it out. The space is very open and bright with a bunch of bar stools, so you can see the ice cream being made, which was cool.As I was looking at the menu, I thought it was kind of pricey, so I figured that my friend and I share, but we didn't want the same thing, so we decided to get our own. The guy at the register was super nice and friendly and just seemed like a cool ass guy.When we got our ice cream, I was taken aback by how GINORMOUS the ice cream was. I definitely understood the price tag after seeing the portion sizes. I told myself that there was NO WAY I can eat the whole thing, but....... of course, I ate the whole damn thing, without any regrets either. The ice cream was actually really good and the whole concept of mixing cereal with it is super cool, so I definitely recommend people come check this joint out.

Oh flying cockONE OF THE BEST BURGERS EVER..Damn their beef blend is amazing. This was arguably one of the best burgers I've had in a while, and I would say defn Top 15 Burgers in Nyc. Juicy, tons of flavor, and monstrous sizeTheir $15 LUNCH SPECIAL with a beer is hard to beat. Not a huge lunch crowd, so you'll get a seat. Great service and great food at the good ol' Flying Cock!

KenScale: 8.5/10I've been to every restaurant opened by the super-duo of Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone and loved every one of them. Starting from humble beginning at Torrisi Italian Specialties (which recently shut down temporarily to elevate its already-outstanding tasting menu to another level), they've been on an expansion mode for a while now. Santina is the latest project from this duo, this time a coastal Italian restaurant below the High Line inspired by chef Carbone's grandmother from Sicily. This is another winner from the growing Torrisi-Carbone empire. I've always been a fan of intensity and boldness of food served at Torrisi-Carbone restaurants, from the retro Italian-American temple of Carbone to the twist on French cuisine at Dirty French. If you walked into Santina not knowing who opened this restaurant, you wouldn't imagine in your dream this is a place from Torrisi-Carbone duo. Everything is so lightened compared to the incumbent restaurants, from the bright dining room to the music that makes you feel like you're sitting at a café somewhere on the Caribbean to the airy feel to all the dishes that I tried. Every meal at Santina must start with cecina (chickpea-flour pancakes) that you can wrap different food of your choosing (my recommendation is to go with lamb tartare) and house made spicy sauce. I proceeded to try two pastas, and this is where the restaurant truly shined. Both chitarra santina (which came in a pretty unique combination of lamb and seafood) and spaghetti blue crab don't have the rustic touch that you would expect at other outstanding pasta restaurants, but they were exceptional with the way pasta noodles were cooked and the cleanness to flavor without overpowering your palate. In particular, my dining companion couldn't stop raving about the spaghetti blue crab, and I agree it is one of the best pasta dishes I've had this year so far. Santina is more focused on seafood and vegetables than meat, so for the main dishes, I sampled two fish dishes. Swordfish tasted a little bit like pork chop in texture (which is by no means a bad thing), but the seasoning could've been lightened a little bit. On the other hand, bass was truly outstanding, working beautifully with peppers and tangerines for an airy dish that you would love to have on the Mediterranean coast. For dessert, chocolate diplomatic was a nice finish to the meal, with salted chocolate that wasn't overly sweet to my liking.I really loved the bright décor and lively ambiance of the restaurant. It would probably be the lightest and most fun among the restaurants in the Torrisi-Carbone portfolio. The restaurant has a full bar with some fun cocktail menus that all look tropical in appearance. Getting a reservation, as with any hot spot from Torrisi-Carbone team, would be quite difficult to make sure to book way in advance or try your luck at the bar. It's been a brutal winter in New York, and Santina would offer an welcome sanctuary where you can explore the ethereal touch of coastal Italian cuisine.

Lovely little place we stumbled on after my boyfriend got his haircut near by in China town! We were surprised to find this little tofu place in the out of no where!! But we are so happy we came! The restaurant is much larger on the inside once you walk in. It's very cute with a garden theme. Lots of interesting things to look at. The menu is very similar to BCD tofu with your tofu soups, BBQ, bibimbap, and combos. I love how it's used as your table mat since I like to read the menu while waiting sometimes. We ended up ordering a bugolgi + tofu soup comboand regular size tofu soup. Then on came the yummy banchans! All of the food and banchan were yummy and it was really nice that it came with a steamed egg! We also received a side of regular tofu as well too. What I did notice was that all of the items here were not as salty and heavy compared so many of the other Korean Restaurants I've been to (which is a good thing!!) that makes me feel like I could definitely come here more often!The service was also wonderful. They are attentive, kind, and you can tell they are passionate about their restaurant.Overall we concluded that we would definitely come back to Tofu tofu when we are craving Korean food home style and just want to unwind. Yummy and not too heavy! Also cheaper than ktown!

I ventured to Squish with my four year old niece. Got her a birthday cake, apple pie, and banana pudding marshmallow for $5. We got the banana toasted (they blowtorch it) and my little niece knew it was banana flavored instantly. They do a good job of really flavoring the marshmallows with unique flavors and they have a nice soft texture. I honestly with full disclosure didn't taste a single one but they felt soft and came with instructions on how to preserve the marshmallow soft texture. I'm assuming it was good given the flavor variety and how quickly my niece gobbled up the roasted one. It's a cute spot offering something different. Not sure if I'd go out of our way again but it was good to try it and I'd come back. I'd also come back to try the many creations they have on ice cream, etc

OH MY GOSH, another place to get epic matcha and mindblowingly good pastries! Curse you all! My stomach loves you but my waistline HATES you! I've gone to Project Cozy quite a few times since their lauded summer opening; honestly, the lines aren't as crazy as Cha Cha Matcha (as much as I love them!) and the space is incredible. They only recently added matcha to their menu, but prior and still, they dole out some tasty treats and beverages. Their matcha lattes are rich and creamy, and their lychee matcha iced tea is perfectly fruity. I am not a coffee drinker, but I've sampled their Cozy Mint Coffee, an icy-cool mint-infused cuppa, and it is rather refreshing! They bring in Bibble & Sip cream puffs; go for the matcha! (Can you tell I'm a matcha fan yet? Ha!) Also, their smoothies and juices should not be overlooked! Just Beet It, Feel Like Pablo, and Kale Yeah will have you feeling some sort of way...that way is healthy AF. Made fresh and free of additives, they are really bursting with flavor, almost a light meal in themselves. Their motto is #cozyasfck, and they definitely live up to it. Whenever I'm in SoHo, I find myself coming here more and more. I'm drawn!

We order here for work lunches a lot since they are Kosher, and all of my coworkers love it. They have a huge menu with lots of options; one of the unique menu options that I really like are the purple thai rice rolls! Everyone usually orders the 2/3 Roll Combo Special ($10.45 & $14.45) that comes with a can of soda/bottle of water. Also, the rolls are huge and come with 8 rolls a piece! I ordered the 3 roll special and only ate about half of it! The quality of the sushi is good. Definitely the best Kosher sushi I have ever had!

This omnivore enjoyed this family-friendly vegan restaurant. We arrived about 30 mins after it opened on a weekend and were luckily seated without a reservation, but noted that the place filled up very quickly. They were accommodating of the toddler at our table, and I noted many other families and children around. I tried the "tuna" sushi and the burrito, both were super tasty. Also shared one of their big smoothies. Many other tempting menu items - will be back!

The restaurant itself is cute, tiny, & packed! If your back isn't to the open windows at the front of the restaurant, it might be a little tight. I had the smoked salmon small plate - it comes with a handful of crostini's as well as a decent portion size of smoked salmon, with capers. The salmon was properly cooked and yummy!My friends had the Scallops with risotto & the clams with fettuccine. They were both impressed with their meals and had no leftovers at the end. We all agreed (about each meal individually) that there was just a bit too much salt.It is a limited menu, and all seafood.At the end, there is free whiskey cake! A thin slice per guest it seemed (but a perfect portion after eating the entire plate). Plus, one could taste the whiskey, and my friend said that the cake was rather buttery, though I thought it was pleasantly moist.Worth a go if you are near the area and hungry for some seafood.

BaoHaus is one of my favorite spots! Whenever I have friends over from out of town, I always take them on a food tour of NYC (you gotta admit... we have some of the BEST food in the world and the variety here is astounding!). One of the places I like to take my friends is BaoHaus. It's great for a quick bite to refuel and keep the tour goingFirst impressions: after coming here multiple times... you'd think I'd get used to the crazy crowds and small cramped location... nope... there's almost always a long line, no seating available and I can't wait to get some noms. The TV is playing a loop of the Vice interview of BaoHaus and owner Eddie Haung (from Fresh Off the Boat!) and there's graffitti and stickers everywhere from past patronsMy favorite things to get: The Birdhaus Bao (or get it spicy as the Fire Birdhaus) - crispy fried chicken with the perfect amount of seasoning and the crispy crunch to meat ratio is perfection. The Fried Fish Bao- fried fish filet with cabbage, tarter sauce and sprinkled with peanuts. I feel like this one is the least ordered bao (compared to the pork belly)... even when I recommend it to my friends... but the ones who are smart enough to order it, all love it. Taro Fries- everyone has heard of french fries (potato) or sweet potato fries... even yucca fries (shout out to Pio Pio!) but not many people have heard of or have tried taro fries and that's a DAMN SHAME! These carby, crunchy, seasoned fries are delicious. They are a bit denser than regular potato fries but they have that same satisfying crunch. I could eat these by the pound. I highly recommend coming here earlier in the day because they do run out (it's happened to me twice!) and it's awful to hear that they've run out! Don't be that guy! I've also tried their Sweet Bao Fries (both the black sesame and the pandan, which is my personal favorite) and I love the fried, doughy sweetness that is a great end to the meal without being too overwhelmingly sweet. The hype is real, the food is good. I wish the prices were just a smidge less... you can eat a bao in 2-3 bites (kind of like a slider) and to pay $4-5 per bao becomes pretty steep... all the small bites are delicious but you have to order several things off the menu to get full. One or two baos are fine (~$10) but any more and the meal becomes pricier.

I thought I had already written a review on this place so let me get right to it. If you are in the area and you are craving a salad this place is the BOMB DIGGITY!!! You can pick from up to 5 different types of greens, add whatever toppings and protein that you want or you can just be basic and order a specific salad from the menu. I like to mix things up a bit. They also have other foods other than salad. I have tried the Acai breakfast bowl. It was AWESSOMEEE! The service is really good and they have a rewards card that you can get punched every time you order. If you are like me and you like to get a lot of different toppings you can easily end up paying close to $20 for a salad but hey, it is what it is. My only beef with this place is that the salad isn't organic and for the price point, I've been to other salad bars that offer organic salads and are about the same price and parking sucks but other than that its a great place. Oh! Btw, the Garlic Caesar dressing is CRACK!!

This small gem in midtown is amazing. There are about 10 counter seats available and has a few carbonated and Asian drinks available for purchase. There are a lot to choose from: bowls, salad, burrito, or just poke. You can also ask for brown rice. The staff here is really nice, they ask whether the toppings that you ask for was enough or not. If you say no, I kid you not they just keep adding more. I got the regular poke bowl with brown rice. With a scoop of tuna and salmon. The sauce I got was the regular shoyu and the sweet unagi sauce. As for the sides I love the mango and seaweed salad. The scallions also add a nice taste. For me, the regular fills me up pretty good already, $12 was really worth it! Avocados are now 2 dollars to add, though

Wagamama. Oh you had me at Flat iron. Let's do this place justice for a second. As you approach from the corner of the block, you immediately notice that this place has a striking presence that draws you in. You want to walk through the glass doors and find what those floor to ceiling panes are holding within.Upon entry you encounter the bar on your left and it is an impressive open concept view to the rear. The host approaches and escorts you to your spot. Luckily, as I was painfully early, I got to strut down a very cozy pseudo-catwalk. It's almost like you are surrounded by the fury of a busy open kitchen but carry your inner peace. We were in the mezzanine. Upstairs and away from the bathrooms. I walked to the corner seat, closest to the windows and watched as the others filed in. They oohed and awwed the two signature drinks. But I knew once the bartender said Whiskey, with home brewed tea that I'd found the one for me. Their Mai Tai was flirty and fun but not the type that would hold me for the night. So as I sipped my tea, I was immersed in art chat and edu-scientific speak with a fantastic crew who lightly provoked my inner wild child.I tried my best to refrain but the beast was out of the bag later on. As for this part of the story, the food was flavorful but not the star of the show. This is a perfect place for conversation, cocktails and coming full circle.

Came here for my birthday celebration with friends and it was exactly what I was looking for.RESERVATIONS: I called to make a large group reservation about a month in a advance. If you have more than 10 people (so 11+) you have to do a pre-fixe menu of about $88/person. Since I didn't want to do that, I opted for a group of 10. When I arrived, my husband and I were the first to get there so they said to let them know when the majority of our group was there and they'll seat us.ATMOSPHERE: I loved ABC Kitchen's vibe and this one looked even more awesome. It has lots of white everywhere and feels very modern and trendy. There are obscure/modern looking light fixtures and artwork. One side has a bar/open kitchen and then the other dining area has a slightly open kitchen and more tables. Each tables is adorned with various plants and succulents, candles and low lighting. Perfect for the birthday celebration I was planning.FOOD: It's a vegetarian restaurant, which I was skeptical about at first but like most people have said, despite that, their food is very flavorful. I think with a smaller group, most of the dishes are meant to be shared but because we had so many people it just made more sense to order 1-2 appetizers and then each person order their own dish. Don't expect to be very full coming out of here.SPAGHETTI - very chewy green spinach noodles with lots of lemon/zest. It is a big on the tart side so beware of that but it was perfect for my dinner portion. CAULIFLOWER - a whole cauliflower was enough for 10 of us and is a great sight to see with the knife stuck in it. Pour all of the sauce because it is delicious. It has a curried cauliflower type taste, almost reminiscent of some Indian side dishes. Highly recommend and makes for a great photo.HUMMUS - people raved about this so I asked for it with both the crudite and pita. A pita has 4 triangles so we got 2 (which they charged extra for). It's good with the hummus, which has a slight thai basil taste and is just very flavorful. If you enjoy hummus, I would get this and skip the crudite.*CAKE CUTTING FEE - they charged $7/person because we brought our own cake and they helped us cut it. I did appreciate that they lit the candles AND put it on this classic white cake stand.Overall, I enjoyed my birthday celebration here and would recommend it for a nice date night or birthday or celebration dinner. It IS quite pricey for what you are getting (small, simple portions) but I gave it 4 stars because of the entire package (food + atmosphere).

For a sushi experience in the East Village definitely try out Kura. It's definitely pricey on par with price with sushi yasuda. Went with the 20 piece omakase. As most of the menu here is omakase and they do have some hot kitchen specials though most patrons i saw this night order the omakase. It's a small place only encompassing a sushi bar with 3 sushi chefs. They specialize in torched sushi here. Service was attentive and explained every piece of fish and specials they had tonight. WIsh i had more stomach room as i would of ordered the special grilled fish collar. The omakase comes with a few items that stood out. The monkfish, seared salmon, seared tuna, uni, and eel. I like that they added a few chefs amuse buche dishes as well and they had a nice potato rice dish. The sashimi also stood out as well which came first in the omakase. For the price its a special occassion kind of place but it definitely had fresh great sushi.

The place is well lit, which isn't always a plus for me. But the place was casual while being clean and decorated, a Japanese nod. There was also a big weird painting of a Japanese girl taking a selfie surrounded by textbooks and a cartoon girl face behind her. The waitress was oddly both super aggressive and hateful right out of the gate.I got sat at the bar and she sort of scolded me to quickly scoot my chair up.  When I got up awkwardly, she moved the chair all the way against the base board so I had to squeeze in. On the menu, almost all of the ramens said "soy sauced based".When she came back to take my order, in a rush, I asked her if there were any pork broth ramens. She impatiently nodded and urged me to order.  I asked for more time. I then waited about 8 minutes, and she came back with attitude. I asked if the natura ramen was pork based, because on the menu it said "soy sauced based". I was holding the menu close since I can't see very well.  She sort of rolled her eyes and said that all the ramens were pork based and started pointing at the menu. "Get your hands out of my face !"I said and moved the menu out of the way, where it fell onto the counter with a thud. Everything kind of stopped. "Well that's what I want." I said.Menus were removed. Damn it was like she was my angry x girlfriend in a past life. About 8 minutes later, a different young woman approached and asked me if I wanted to order.I said I already ordered."No you didn't order." She kind of looked at me like I was an idiot. My angry x girlfriend in a past life's side kick."I did order, but if you give me the menu, I'll show you what I want." I was gonna tough this out. I was just praying the banshee chick didn't accost me again in the name of rushed hysterical service, or that I wouldn't be taunted by a staff who could care less.Ramen for $11 was a good deal in New York, and the kitchen smelled good.  I really wanted to order many things on the menu. The fried rice and the pork buns were both $5, so were octopus balls.Ramen arrived, delivered by the cook, whose energy was much more tranquil. The broth was so good. Wether it was soy based or pork based who knows, but I think I tasted both. The protein was big chunks, luscious, just a little fatty.  You have your choice of pork, chicken or beef. At first I assumed it was going to be pork, but it tasted more like pot roast. It was so satisfying after a tiring busy week.  Luckily I was left at peace as we moved on.  Every time I needed a water refill I had to move my cup to emphasize its nature.  There was only one other table and my water cup just sat there empty as they giggled to each other. It was annoying, but the food was so good. I got the octopus balls to go for dessert.  I had most of the noodles left over and I asked for them to go as well. Our interaction was much more gracious this time. (With the sidekick, the first one remained appropriately invisible.) The sidekick paused with large eyes that almost looked humorous as she started to say that all to go orders that began as sit down must pay .50 per container. OCD heaven.She got a lot nicer when the check came. I was wondering if she was even going to bring back the change but she did. She even suddenly refilled my water.I checked the octopus balls right before I left to make sure they had no mayo as ordered.  They had mayo. I left the box open on the counter and she eventually walked by and said she would remake them. No apology. No kick in the a$$. Just the feel of being slighted. Summary A young immature staff clouded a very delicious meal.The ramen was great, different from most with the broth and the protein, so delicious. Omg so good. The octopus balls had full tentacles inside, and they were a little crunchy but the dough was tasty and pillowy, as described.Good value if you can handle some abuse.I'll go back - prepared to battle.

I've been to quite a number of sushi places, but Sushi Mike's always stood out as a place I wanted to try. I'm not sure why - maybe because it's located in Dobb's Ferry (which has a number of excellent restaurants), or maybe it's because a number of my Yelp friends gave it good reviews, or maybe because I just like sushi. Whatever the reason, I wanted to try. Tonight my friend and I were feeling it so we decided to make our way to Dobb's Ferry to check this place out.Like most other sushi restaurants I've been to, SM's isn't large. Upon entry there's a small seating area where the sushi bar is and then more seating some steps down. We were warmly greeted by a gentleman (was that you Mike?) which I thought was really nice. The decor doesn't really flow throughout the space; for me, the upper seating area gives off one aura while the bottom gives off another. There are some nice paintings on the walls and music playing which adds to the atmosphere (the restaurant also smelled amazing). The menu is large, they have a nice variety of soups, mains, basic rolls, speciality rolls, and combos; it was one of the more extensive sushi menus I've seen - I was impressed. Since it was cold out I wanted some soup. I got the dumpling soup which had three pork dumplings and mushrooms in a tasty broth. The soup hit the spot; the flavors worked with just the right amount of dumplings - it was presented nicely as well. For my main I got two rolls - the spicy shrimp roll and the out-of-control roll. Both rolls were very good and tasted super fresh - the out of control roll had spicy tuna and avocado topped with eel and the spicy shrimp roll had just the right amount of heat. Service was very good; it was fast, friendly, and they were on top of it. Overall I'm a fan of Sushi Mike's and glad I tried it - definitely one of the better sushi places I've been to in Westchester. I would definitely return!

This place would definitely better as somewhere to sit down and order as opposed to takeout. Everything I got from here was good, but because the delivery takes a while to get to where I am, I wouldn't recommend ordering if you don't live very close by. Having said that, I'd still like to try as many sandwiches on the menu as possible, including ordering in. Because they really are good sandwiches. Since their menu is different than the other options I have here in the financial district, I don't mind the wait that much. But I definitely want to stop in and order from them when I'm there. So far their cheeseburger sandwich was my favorite.

There's a reason why Cafe China is the only Chinese place with a Michelin star, and after two years of Seamlessing their food to my office and two dine in visits I've never swayed from my opinion. Their take on Szechuan cuisine is delicious and well thought out, and I've enjoyed every dish I've had there. The most recent visit was on a Thursday night with a group of four, and the wait times are quite long, so I'd advise coming before you're actually hungry. We were given an estimate of 1.5 - 2 hours wait, but happily it ended up being more of an hour fifteen. Though their Seamless is quick, you definitely want to experience the food fresh out of the kitchen from time to time - our food arrived frighteningly fast after we gave the order to our waiter. I recommend the cold noodles, soup dumplings, and dan dan noodles to start. The jellyfish with pesto is interesting and more heavily flavored than what I'm used to, and I've only had it from takeout, but could be worth a try. For main dishes, you absolutely have to get their three pepper chicken. The heat is unbeatable and the flavor phenomenal. Their double cooked pork and vegetables are other tasty staples to keep in mind, and I really enjoyed their kung fu shrimp as well (my general favorite at Chinese places). It's definitely pricier than some of the other Szechuan and more authentic options around the area, but service is at least included in the price. The lunch specials on weekdays also seem like a steal, but I've yet to partake. Overall, I'm game to come back and dine in, but the heavy crowds and long waits reduce the experience to a Seamless-only one for me. I'd still recommend Cafe China to anyone who's never tried it - the standout food deserves your wait time.

I stumbled upon this gem by accident when strolling around in little Italy before dinner with friends. This is a very cute small place. The place was still empty when I got there around 4:30 but quickly filled up. Rebecca was the bartender there that day and she was great. She nicely explained to me the different cocktail options on the menu and I tried the classic negroni and negroni bianco and they were both delicious. My glass was never empty as well. As soon as my water runs low she would come and fill it and when my drink was almost done, she quickly offered another. She was just the bartender that you need. The drinks were very reasonably priced and strong as well Overall we had a great experience here and left happy and tipsy. would love to come back and try the food here

The great thing about working in Chelsea is all the yummy baked goodies around! Decided to check out BBB after work one day and wanted something yummy to nosh on. Decided not to get a scrumptious looking arepa and opted for two cupcakes ($3.75/ea)-- chocolate cupcake w/ chocolate frosting and a peanut butter one for The Husband. My chocolate cupcake was solid. Nothing spectacular but it hit the sweet spot. The taste kind of reminded me a bit of the BK Blackout from a famed UES bakery. Just a smidge. I'm not a huge fan of peanut butter...anymore. Something to do with gorging too much on it one day when I made a peanut butter sesame oil salad dressing that has since scarred me for life. I'll eat it in small quantities but it has now made it to the top of my Gag Reflex List (applesauce, really mushy eggplant, and White Russians are also on that list, for those that are curious). Anyhow I didn't like the PB topping but oh, something in their cupcake had me like whoa, maybe I don't have a PB aversion anymore. It was almost like a subtle peanut butter cornbread muffin. Just reminded me, must try that in a recipe one day. Small seating area in the back. Nice selection for a small store. Received great service. Goods were yummy. Looking forward to trying their guava cheese pastry and the cheese arepa next

Really really good food. There's a lot of adjectives I could use to describe how great the food tastes.I came here with a friend, walked right in with no reservation and they were able to seat us within 15 minutes. The interior design of this place is phenomenal.Let's get to the good part. I got the Fried Chicken and my friend got Fresh Penne Pasta. The chicken was very flavorful, the amount of breading was the perfect amount, with a tangy taste to complement the fried chicken. You literally fulfill all sorts of flavors on your tastebuds.The dessert was definitely the best part in my opinion. I got the Mango Tarte Tatin and my friend got the Deep Dish Chocolate Cream Pie. The mango tarte was spectacular that I would want to order another one. The price was what prevented me from ordering another one.For the price that you are paying, the food better be good and that did not disappoint. You are paying for a brand name, it's a Bobbly Flay restaurant, in which you are paying for everything, from the presentation of the food, quality service, and quality food. You want a bottle of wine?There's a server that will pour the glass for you. Any crumbs left on the table after consuming your entree, it's all cleaned up. I would not recommend you coming here if you're in a rush because it seems like everything is timed out on purpose; from being seated, glass being poured out, dessert menu, and getting the check that will make a nice dent in your bank account.P.S. I hear this place is closing down because it was too expensive to renew their lease for the space they're in so dine here for the experience before it's gone. Or for some of you you're saying good riddance!!!

Lotus Blue is a new Chinese restaurant in Union Square on 15th street serving generally Southern Chinese cuisine. Tucked inside the old Pizza Vinoteca location, the interior is narrow and long, then has a pleasant sky-light covered terrace area which is out of sight from the lower level. The ambiance and decor are best described as "Classy-Chinese", with framed pictures, gold carpet, glass chandeliers, and modern fixtures. Due to a soft opening, the place was nearly empty when we arrived early on a Wednesday afternoon, thus we were treated to tons of attention from the waitstaff and bartender.Food was pretty tasty, typical of what you would expect from a Chinese restaurant of this caliber. We started with some Soy-Braised beef, a cold dish of sliced, flavorful beef along with a delectable sweet dipping sauce. We then shared an entree and some veggies between two of us. The Cumin Lamb had nice flavor, and was still very moist as opposed to dry-like-the-sun, something other places tend to mess up on. The plate was on the smallish side, but still would be enough for one person. It included small lamb squares, sauteed onions, fresh cilantro, and spices, along with a nice heaping of Chinese dried red peppers to add some spice. We also got a plate of what they called "Sauteed Snap Beans" which were your standard Chinese-style green beans cooked with garlic. Each plate came with a small bowl of rice.We were not disappointed by the food, decor, or service. If they don't change anything about these before they fully launch, it could be a success story in a previously doomed location. My only complaint is that the value was a little low. Each entree was less than $20 so it wasn't THAT pricey, but the smaller plate sizes combined with a couple extra bucks per dish added up. I understand why though, the rent needs to be paid in that next-to-Union-Square location, but it's not the kind of place we could afford to go to over and over again due to that lack of value.

Umm, I know, I know, it's pretty much a sin for a burger place not to serve fries with their burgers, but trust me on this when I say that y'all should forgive Ummburger for their sins because their burgers are pretty damn good on their own. And I mean, it's not like you don't get anything at all with your burger--you do get a pickle, some chips + pickled cabbage on the side. At $14 for their standard Ummburger, I think it's pretty fair, considering there are many, many other burger places in the city with burgers (and fries) that are way worse AND way more expensive. Personally, I really did enjoy my Ummburger in all its cheesy, caramelized onion-y goodness, as evidenced by just how quickly I swallowed/inhaled/devoured the whole thing. It was cooked to medium-rare juicy, flavorful perfection and I loved every bite. My only regret? I unfortunately didn't get a chance to take advantage of the happy hour this time around, but I'll definitely make sure to do so the next time I get a burger craving.

When I first stumbled upon the Spaniard, I wrote it off as some run-of-the-mill bar on West 4th. This small strip on West 4th that separates the West Village and Greenwich Village has always been--at least since I've been in the city--an odd blend off-brand kitschy stores, college-y bars and yes, a Gristedes. This is not to say that I'm averse to this area--I just wouldn't expect a refined bar with seriously impressive eats to reside here. Though I already had seen the good reviews (hence why I chose to come here), I was still pleasantly surprised at how fantastic the food was here. Diverse menu, everything well-executed. Through in a nice cocktail menu and solid whiskey selection and you've got yourself a top-notch establishment.Made a pre-movie reservation at 6:45 on a Friday night. The place was pretty busy--a nice mix of folks coming specifically for food and those hanging around the bar. The layout here is a bit odd. There's a somewhat separate back room that's reserved for sit-down dinners, but it's fairly small and seems incongruous here. Occasionally, I felt like they forgot about us back here, but had we not been pressed for time, I likely wouldn't have thought anything of the service. We asked them to course out our plates, and they did. So that's that. I'm sad to say that I'm off both gluten and added sugar right now, meaning beer and cocktails are prohibited. Two of my three alcohol forms of choice! It's a hard life. But I'm grateful that the Spaniard is whiskey bar, because whiskey happens to the third form in that trio. And the selection is decent here. I went with the Woodford Reserve Double Oaked for my bourbon, and a Widow Jane rye. I had never tried that Woodford Reserve before, so it was a nice treat.For food, the Spaniard has a nice array of both small and entree-sized plates. The small plates are easily shareable so if that's where your head's at, go for those. The larger dishes are all sandwiches except for one (the trout, which we ordered), so if you're craving an upscale bar sandwich, let your eyes wander over to that side of the menu. Honestly, seems hard to go wrong here. Our eats, below: Lobster toast w/crème fraîche, tarragon, corn, filone: AElegant but super flavorful. A well-balanced bite. Nice texture, loved the addition of the corn. If you're gluten-free like me, it's completely appropriate to just eat this straight off the toast. I think the picture is reason enough to order this. We shared everything and though this toast is cut into two halves, one will not feel like enough.Oysters Rockefeller w/ spinach, bacon, parmesan: AWow. These were special. This felt like spinach artichoke dip meets shellfish meets potato skins meets some entirely new kind of appetizer. Some people might not be a fan because the oyster taste isn't too detectable, but the rest of the flavors were powerful and just plain addicting. Kind of silly serving the oysters of ice given that this is a warm dish, but that's a minor criticismSteak tartare w/ dijon, shallots, brown bread crackers: A-Not amazing but still very good. Seasoned well, pretty typical preparation and presentation (mustard, shallots, etc.). The crackers served on the side added some nice texture to each bite. Chopped broccoli salad w/ napa cabbage, pecans, sherry vinaigrette: AI loved broccoli salad, so when I saw this on the menu it was an obvious pick. Wonderful blend of flavors and textures. Healthy but still had some heartiness thanks to the nuts and crumbled cheese. Adding nuts to salad is usually a well-intentioned idea, because when done well, it's next-level. Seared trout w/ frisée, pumpernickel, almonds, brown butter: A-/AA light, refined entree. The rest of the bigs are sandwiches / carb-heavy, so I was happy to see this on the menu. The bf liked the pumpernickel croutons--I unfortunately could not partake in the consumption experience of those. Trout was cooked nicely and the almonds/frisée added some nice texture and kept the dish light. Surprisingly well-done for a place that presents more as a bar than anything else.

Really great. After hearing about some great experiences at Atoboy, I finally got a chance recently to try their 3-course menu. You're obviously allowed to order extra, as well as the roaming trays with their specials.The space is pretty austere, almost like you're eating inside a garage. That's not a bad thing, because you can easily just focus on the beautiful plating and well-garnished dishes. Definitely a more casual joint, the dishes are anything but. Favorites:- Corn with taleggio cheese, bacon, doenjang: likely the favorite dish of the night. The richness and creaminess of the cheese and corn mixed together well with the sourness of the doenjang. So dang good.- Beef tartare with nettle, potato and watercress: The beef is nicely cut, and fatty enough to provide some richness to the dish.- Littleneck clams with avocado crème: The balance of the spiciness from the clams and the cooling effect of the avocado crème was great, and the rice crackers provided a good amount of crunch- Pork jowl, barley, ssamjang, and Cipollini onion: I always enjoy pork jowl, as it provides the fattiness and chewiness of a pork belly, but not so fatty that that you feel like you're only eating grease. Definitely well-executed and something I would order again.Service was very attentive throughout the meal, although the only thing that was confusing was that we didn't know who our server actually was, since there were so many roaming around to take our requests and orders. Prices are extremely reasonable at about $35 for the three courses, and if you're sharing, you can try a bunch of different plates.In all, very glad I finally got to try this, and will definitely be back to try their other small plates. Great place for a casual date, or a small group dinner so you can share all the different dishes.

Hungry for some seafood, decided to give this place a try as my group was strolling though the area.Passing by I thought this place couldn't seat a fairly large group of 6 since all I saw were booth and bar seating, but they have a bigger space in the back with tables that can be arranged to fit larger groups.Good tasting oysters and lobster rolls with chips.Service was a hit.We ordered 2 dozen of each oyster on the menu and had only one bad oyster. Told the waitress one of the oysters was bad and she asked which one. Later she came back with two to make up for it. Awesome service.Lobster rolls are fairly large with a large heaping pile of fries. Tasted pretty good and buttery. At the end of the meal, each person gets a pudding and a Swedish fish that either curls up or lays flat. It's supposed to tell your fortune which was kinda cool.

Quality choice for a Brazilian Steakhouse in Hell's Kitchen.My co-worker was retiring so what better way to send him off than a little class and a whole lot of food. We walked into Churrascaria Plataforma on a Wednesday night (9/6/17), and we rolled out several hours later with full stomachs and good memories.Go for the prix-fixe menu and enjoy the rapid succession of food in what proves to be a proper Rodizio-style restaurant. Our service was excellent. If our card was green, then it took no more than seconds for one of many waiters to offer an array of meats. The selection included many cuts of beef, pork, lamb, chicken, turkey, and even seafood. My favorites were the top sirloin, filet wrapped in bacon, rib eye, and lamb chops. I was pleased with the quality of all served items. It should be noted that I did not have any seafood during my visit. There's also a salad bar and dessert cart, but I stuck with meat.After approximately 85 minutes of giving the green light, I had to turn my card red and call it quits. I did not have to eat breakfast or lunch the next day, and it was totally worth it. I'll be back!

Tried the burrata soft serve ice cream! Woohoo! I love it when my curiosity is answered. We were there on a Saturday afternoon. The line wasn't very long and they had a separate window for ice cream orders so the pick-up was painless and nothing like the experience one might have had at their SoHo location. There are only two choices of flavors on the menu but let me warn ya, it can be hard to choose because one's Burrata and the other one's Cold Brew. So bring a friend! and give yourself the option of ordering both and sharing :PMy friend and I ordered each flavor and shared. In summary - they were both really good but we thought the Burrata was slightly better. The Burrata was not rich and thick like I had imagined considering its base is cheese. It was rather refreshing and subtly sweet. A hint of balsamic and baby basil leaves worked beautifully as garnish but more importantly brought out the right flavors and completed the ice cream perfectly. I thought the soft serves deserved the recognition as one of Dominique Ansel's many brilliant creations.

After a long day of shopping around Manhattan, I came to Snack Taverna with my girlfriends for dinner. I made the reservation for 7:45pm, but we were wiped out from the day and arrived around 6:20pm. The restaurant wasn't busy and we were seated instantly. They even told us it was better we came early because the restaurant had a huge party coming in the same time as our reservation. It's a very small place, so it would've been chaotic. The restaurant itself is very cute, and the service is good too. I recommend ordering a bunch of plates to share. The food was very fresh and good, just a little on the pricey side.We had "the whole shebang," which is a sampling of all the dips and spreads which was very good, the greek salad, fava, spinach triangles which you could tell were fresh and not frozen, and my favorite...the veal meatballs. I also ordered the longacre cocktail which was their spin on a cucumber margarita and it was excellent.

This is perhaps the quintessential definition of a hole-in-the-wall restaurant. You wouldn't be able to tell that this obscure, non-descript building housed a phenomenal restaurant serving up some authentic Mexican fair. I have my favorite Mexican eatery in Jersey, but I have to admit I have found my second one in Westchester County. Walking in for lunch one day, I could tell right away that I was in the right place if I was looking for some bold, Mexican flavors. It is undoubtedly family-run and it seems that the clientele that come are an extended part of that family. This place is a no-frills café where people from around the area grab a quick delicious bite. I decided to go with their asada and lomo tostada. The asada had the right amount of flavor and kick with a clear, distinct poblano taste. The lomo was sourer than I expected--but not in a bad way--which complemented the umami flavor of the dish. Both tostadas were topped with a generous helping of avocado and lettuce. At the end of the meal I was happy and more than satisfied with what I was served. I wouldn't have a problem stopping every day and grabbing a bite from this humble place. Restaurant Tecalitlan does small mom-and-pops establishment proud. Their commitment to authentic flavor--making someone feel as if they are eating something their family would cook for them--is something that I highly appreciate. I always say don't judge a book by its cover and this is one of those instances.

Modern interpretation of nigiri . If you enjoy multiple flavors incorporated w/fish, this place has it. Do not just expect slices of fish with properly seasoned sushi rice touched with a hint of soy sauce (if necessary), wasabi, or salt. What you will receive, for example, is fish roe, Uni and oyster all together in addition to various other combinations. Furthermore, the place is very blow torch friendly. Try to sample their other creations offered with additional cost. However, keep in mind the cost. The $58 30 minute experience may easily turn into a $120 45 minute meal. A great place to sample some modern sushi techniques that may upset traditional enthusiasts. However, the new style and format is enticing.

I bought a solid juice after a hard run today. They take cards which is helpful but they don't have a bathroom for patrons. It's a really small place with limited seating but they have a decent sized menu, offering smoothies, juices and sandwiches.I would definitely come here for snacks and head to the Cloisters or go for a walk nearby. Parking was scarce, even on a Sunday but I lucked out with an open spot right when I rolled up.The juices take some time. I ordered the Real Green juice with spirulina, walked up to the ExxonMobil station praying they'd let me use the bathroom (bless his heart because he was very nice and allowed me to use it), came back and my drink wasn't ready. It wasn't that big a deal because I left my wallet in my car so by the time I ran across the street to retrieve it and came back, my order was ready and I was on my way.Don't expect to be in and out. Everything they use from what I saw was fresh and in good condition. I'll definitely come back if in the area.

Looking for new places to check out since I had to meet a friend in the area this place was the first option that came up figured why not give it a try. Stopped by Friday after work place wasn't crowded although by the time we left there was more of a crowd.We sat in the middle area, service is a bit slow Drinks I started w the Brooklyn Summer Ale good beer nice taste. My friend Tried the Roses are red, Violets are blue cocktail very good nice taste.The Sashay Away looks very cool but taste wise oh my lorddd ... talk about some serious jalapeño taste whoa wasn't expecting that too much for us. & finally the Green with envy cocktail very good as well nice taste. As for the place u head downstairs, dimly lit nice vibe & music playing. 4 stars instead of 5 simply because cocktails were good but when initially searching for "happy hour" this place came up except it does not they do not offer any happy hour specials kinda sucks cocktails are pricey at $15 beer was the cheapest at $9. Overall we did enjoy ourselves nice place for drinks.

Big gay and fabulously overrated.First timers - get the Salty Pimp or the Bea Arthur* SALTY PIMPIf you're a Salty pimp you'll enjoy the saltiness, or you may get salty at BGICS for thinking your salty self could handle the salt and sweet combo lol. I agree with Marlena K: actual ice cream isn't all that, really thought it tasted like Mister Softee tbh.PINTSThey recently launched pints. Saw 'American Globs' at my local supermarket the other day. It was good and I will gladly buy those again (~$4).Echo Lily F's comments: It's already expensive, yet you're charging extra for a waffle cone?!Big Gay Ice Cream shop. Good? Eh. Worth the line and $$? No.*If you don't know who Bea Arthur was or what Golden Girls is, please go back to your Ig stalking duck-face enlightened "woke" self that says things like, "what's a tape recorder"

We have been walking by this place for the longest time, and I always enjoy watching the weirdly addictive videos of the roll making process outside. There is always some sort of line, but yesterday, the place was pretty empty, so we tried our luck! We shared a large cup which gets you 1 ice cream flavor and 1 item mixed it, 2 toppings and 1 sauce. We went with vanilla cream and Oreo. The process is similar to Cold Stone Creamery, where they mix in you stuff on a cold stone and mush them nicely together. At Ice, the ice cream start off liquid. Once everything is perfectly put together, it is flattened on the cold stone and once hardened, it's rolled up in a few rolls that stay up straight in your cup! We topped it off with 1 more Oreo and mini mochi bites. Finally, we got the Nutella drizzle. The process took less than 10 minutes and the result was very tasty. We found the ice cream delicious, and super creamy. That's definitely a rich base. It was nice to try and enough to share!

"Picture it; Manhattan 2017. A new restaurant opens in the Upper West Side catering to a nostalgic TV show from the 80s." While the Golden Girls may have been off the air for over 3 decades now, it has developed a cult following in my family. Having heard that Rue La Rue opened way uptown, we made the trip up into Hudson Heights to celebrate a belated mothers day. Although Rue La Rue is tiny, it is covered wall to wall with memorabilia from the shows multi-season run, notably including Blanche's bedroom jungle print wallpaper, the phone from the kitchen and Rue McLanahans Emmy from the show. Having spent a few minutes geeking out at all of the memories, we sat down to eat. Given the very small footprint the cafe has, orders were placed at the counter and then brought to the table. We split a grilled cheese, which was very tasty and then split a piece of (what else?) Cheesecake. Sadly, the Golden Girls wouldn't be too impressed with this desert, as it was just a run of the mill slice from a bakery nearby. Though the desert did end the meal on a bit of a down note, I have to thank the wait staff for being a friend and making sure that everything was going well throughout our meal.

Finally got to try Egg Shop! After seeing their cookbook at Barnes & Noble a few weeks ago, I was even more excited to try this place.WAIT: Came at 11am on a Saturday and it was still a 45 minute wait for 2 people. We waited about 50 minutes total. We ended up just walking around Nolita and then came back at the 40 minute mark to wait around. ATMOSPHERE: It's pretty small inside, total with tables and counter it holds 30 people. Even when you're sitting you are very close to the people next to you, the kitchen, and the waiters walking around. I like the trendy music they play and the teal accents. Very Instagram worthy, cute, brunch place.FOOD: Husband got the BEC and I got the custom egg sandwich.BEC - panini roll, which is almost like a cross between a ciabatta roll and brioche bun. It comes with a tomato jam/jalapenos, cheese, sunny side up egg and bacon. It has a southwestern taste because of the tomato and jalapeños. The bun is OK...I think compared to Eggslut, the bun at Eggslut is much better. Overall, I actually wasn't SUPER impressed with this sandwich. But it's not bad for only $10.CUSTOM EGG SANDWICH - starts out with $7 and then you add more for the additional add ons.EGG: sunny side, scrambled or...poached? There was a third option but I can't remember what it was. I got the sunny side up egg and it was definitely runny! Sadly part of it was already spilled out when it came to me.BREAD: got the biscuit, it's a pretty good biscuit, very crunchy on the outside and very soft on the inside. Reminded me of an upgraded version of a Popeyes biscuit. $1 extra for the biscuit.CHEESE: Vermont cheddar, hardly tasted it in the sandwichSPREAD: caramelized onion aioli also very subtle flavorMEAT: got sausage which came like a sausage patty, good flavor (slight pink on the inside, which was interesting). $3 extra.Overall, my sandwich was a very standard breakfast sandwich (think biscuit sandwich from mcdonalds) but elevated because of the quality of the ingredients. To be honest though, I wouldn't say I was blown away by the flavors. The price isn't bad, the atmosphere nice but the wait is long so I wouldn't wait more than an hour for this. My husband on the other hand LOVED his sandwich and said the flavor was very unique. So maybe its better to go with one of their premade combos.

Kura had been on my mind for several years, given the fact that there was very little publicity given to the restaurant as well as the overwhelmingly positive feedback that came from friends. The man behind the counter is Noriho Ishizuka, a veteran chef who looks more like a welcoming grandfather than a stern sushi chef. My guest was running behind our reservation time, and he looked over at the seat next to me while I waited, giving a stern shake of his head. "No good," he scolded my imaginary guest with a slight smile at the corner of his mouth.When it comes to the sushi, however, Ishizuka-san clearly takes his craft with great seriousness. There are few places that prepare and serve sushi in such a traditional, purist form, and Kura does the art of omakase justice. There are several options for omakase, starting with 12 pieces and spanning upwards to 20 pieces with additional kappo-style dishes. My guest and I opted for the 12-piece, and despite thinking that it wouldn't be quite substantial, we both left more than satisfied with the meal.We were started off with two small plates; the first, consisting of marinated tuna and tororo (grated yam) and the second, a beautifully plate bowl of sushi rice, ikura, and nori slices. Both were light bites with delicate flavors, but I have to admit that my preferences lies with the second dish; the simplicity of the bowl and the pairing of the ingredients worked in perfect harmony, especially as I enjoyed the pops of brineyness of the ikura.The 12 pieces of nigiri that followed were all expertly constructed and each was a delight. The starting piece, a soft chutoro that was perched on a block of perfectly seasoned, loose sushi rice, was one of my favorites; it had just the right amount of fattiness and resilience in the tuna, paired with a slightly vinegary rice. We were similarly blown away by the crisp Red Snapper, the slight sweetness of the Scallop, and the edge of char on the Smoked Salmon. A number of pieces were fairly traditional - the Marinated Tuna, Giant Clam, Mackerel, and Unagi (freshwater eel) - but we were also surprised by the octopus, which was highlighted by the yuzukoshu. And the Uni, a delicious piece of Santa Barbara sea urchin, was one of the sweetest pieces I can recall having.The meal finished with a Chutoro hand roll, neatly wrapped in a crisp sheet of toasted nori, a soft block of tamagoyaki, and a fragrant miso soup with mushrooms. And, to finish, a small cube of Green Tea Tiramisu lightly dusted in matcha.For those who truly are looking for a memorable omakase, Kura needs to be on your list. The restaurant is small (~12 seats at the counter), so reservations through Yelp should be made ahead of time. But for what it delivers, it's worth the extra effort.

We have been wanting to try Sylvia's for the longest time and we finally got our chance. When we arrived for lunch we had a 10 minute wait and boy was it worth it!We were shown to a table in the main dining room. The atmosphere is very casual and friendly. The server quickly came and took our order and left a basket of biscuits and jam for us to enjoy before our food came. Truth be told, these weren't the best biscuits but they were good enough.We had:- Fried Chicken and Waffles - Delicious! Totally addictive combo.- BBQ Short Ribs - Terrific- Chicken Fingers - My girls loved them.- Mac n Cheese - Great comfort food.- Pickled Beets - So good!- Candied Yams - LovedWe wanted a slice of red velvet cake for dessert but they were all out. This gives us a reason to come back soon!

I'm not too surprised that I'm a fan of this place. After all, Chola is my favorite Indian restaurant in the city and it seems they are run by the same folks. The food here has always been consistently good at both of their locations. The one feels a bit less fancy than the other one a few blocks north but is still a comfortable place to dine. Their lunch buffet is solid and I've never had any issues with the flavor or quality of their food. The spread is always solid and the chicken marsala, tandoori chicken and fish curry are among my favorites. I also love the fact they serve pani puri as part of their lunch spread, which is always a nice treat for me.If you're looking for a place that serves a better-than-average selection of lunch buffet items for a reasonable price, this is a great pick. It also helps that the service is solid and folks here are pretty friendly.

Plane tickets to Osaka run about $900. So I'm psyched that DokoDemo can bring you there for under $10.This spot is focused on three categories of classic Japanese street food: yakisoba (noodle stir fry), okonomoyaki (meat and cabbage omelette), and takoyaki (deep fried balls of goodness). These can be filled a wide range of meat: chicken, pork, beef, shrimp, and octopus. There are also a few fried sides rounding out the menu, as well as a fridge of Japanese soft drinks.The atmosphere is very casual, with orders taken at the counter and the food being made right in front of you. You can take out or sit on stools at communal tables.
