It was a bit warm when I came in; don't know if their air conditioner is up to the heat of the open kitchen combined with New York summer.I went for octopus takoyaki, with 5 for $6.50. It was ready in about 5 or 10 minutes. My balls were gorgeous, with their requisite drizzles of mayo and a sweet teriyaki sauce and topped with aonori and bonito flakes.The batter was delicious-- eggy and umami and loaded with octopus and green onion. Unfortunately, it was undercooked and fell apart completely while eating it. The octopus was very chewy... I had to go traditional for the first time, but I'd choose a different meat next time.Nevertheless, I'm excited to try out the rest of the menu, and I love that this spot exists so close to me!

Delicious Neapolitan pies at this much-needed restaurant and cafe a short walk from Battery Park. We arrived early and were seated immediately, snagging a table outside. Can't talk about the wine -- I was staying dry before a show at the Jewish Heritage Museum. As for the food, the Tuscan pie was splendiferous -- white pie with thick layers of mozzarella and ricotta, with 2 poached eggs and prosciutto generously layered to top off this pizza cake. THe burrata caprese starter was pretty good, though very small.Prices are a tad high, but within reason for NYC.

I love this new fast casual spot serving breakfast sandwiches (until 11am), coffee, pastries, and pre-made lunch salads/sandwiches!My friend and I stopped in this morning and I got the FCK Breakfast while she got the avocado ricotta toast. The FCK sandwich is like an upgraded version of your standard BEC and all of the flavors work perfectly. Ingredients are fresh and I've never had such an interesting combo of chipotle mayo, black bean spread, avo, and the fluffiest little square omelette, bacon, all wrapped up with some veggies between a slightly sweet potato bun - the sandwich kind of reminded me of a shack burger. It was a pretty big sandwich that kept me super full for a long time. GET IT!!My friend's avo and ricotta toast was alright, felt like it was missing something so I recommended that she drizzle some honey over it and it was a good idea! Can't go wrong with ricotta, honey, and avo :) another thing was that the toast was too toasted, would be better if it was more chewy!Also, the pastries and cookies look bomb, the cookies remind me of ben's cookies.It's a really new place that opened up about a month ago and they're still experimenting with their menu but I have no doubt they'll do well. Love a place that focuses on what is fresh and in season and food that is crafted with thought. Service is so friendly, I'll definitely be back!

Very cute place in the East Village, with romantic interior and plenty of interesting choices on the menu. We were welcomed by a friendly staff, and got seated on the last available table at 7pm on a busy Sunday evening. Black miso chicken: I don't usually order chicken bc it bores me to death, but this small dish was tasty, mostly because of the rich miso sauce. Salty pork belly: the pork belly was tasty, and the sauce super yummy, but the shishito pepper that came with the dish stole the show: it was phenomenal. Tuna tataki: it's a pity that these pieces of delectable tuna were completely overpowered by the black pepper sauce. Una tama don: fantastic combo of flavors; you must get this, and if you don't like eel, I can only feel sorry that you'll never have the chance to appreciate this dish. Overall, we had a good meal, and I'd definitely go back to taste more dishes from their inspiring menu.

I have to say, I enjoyed this more than I thought I would.  Hadn't planned on seeing it, and tickets are tough to come by and you can't get a discount but a friend had an extra and asked me to attend so I thought I'd see what the hub bub was about.This is an old fashioned musical and it's a little corny and sugary, but the cast does a terrific job and I was completely entertained the entire time. Obviously, Bette Midler is the focus and she is great. She's 70+ so her voice isn't the same as it was 30 years ago but she can still belt it out and she really is the queen of comedy. With just a look (from the parts of her face that move..some don't and it's a bit distracting) she can bring down the house and the dining room scene is a show stopper.The best part is that the rest of the cast rises to the challenge and they don't let her steal all the scenes.  David Hyde Pierce is terrific, even with a terrible "Noo Yawk" accent. Gavin Creel, Kate Baldwin and especially Beanie Feldstein can hold their own and then some. The dancing is top notch, the songs are pleasant and 2.5 hours sails by.  If you're looking for something daring and groundbreaking, this isn't your show but if you like the glitzy old musicals of yore, with an added helping of star power, then you will love this show.

Sushi Ishikawa has a lot to offer to this neighborhood and the sushi game in general. At the comparably lower price point next to other sushi restaurants, expect a solid and highly impressive omakase by chef Don Pham. They offer two omakase menus, 12-course at $85 and 15-course at $125. There is no a la carte with valid reason, though I admit to missing this as an option. We opted for the 15-course for our first visit. It was extremely easy booking for two at the chef's counter through Resy app for a Friday night, a week ahead of our dinner. They seat only about 11 at the counter, and there are a few tables. It's a cute, small and modern space, and their staff is extremely friendly, personable, and kind. The chef was serving and his wife was there as a hostess.List of the sushi we had and in the order of which we had them (the best I could describe from my knowledge) --Black snapper (mild and smooth, great start to the meal)Japanese barracuda with ginger garnish (probably one of my favorites; very flavorful and nice for something that seemed deceptively simple)Clam (flavor almost like a scallop though with more bite) Prawn (nice hint of spice as part of the topping, and and it just melts in your mouth)Japanese Whiting (very mild, though this might be one of my least favorite)Smoked Skipjack Tuna (has a little limey flavor added, a nice punch at the end)Smoked Trout (reminds me of rich salmon, so smooth and probably one of my favorites as well)Japanese Sea Urchin with truffle (very tasty; it's Uni!)Japanese egg custard with mushrooms and shrimp (much like a silky tofu, comforting dish)Seared Bluefin Tuna with ponzu (good though lighter in flavor than expected)Stripejack with Uni (in a rich orange sauce, this was a very bold dish that I found hard to swallow after the custard)Amber Jack (unique and spicy)Sea scallop with Uni (served in a creamy uni jus; definitely a winner)Fatty Tuna with sturgeon caviar (this was really lovely and just delicious) Hand roll with tuna and salmon roe (simple and clean hand roll that was a nice finisher to our meal)At the end, they served a very refreshing and delicious yuzu sake alongside organic melon for dessert. My only complaint while eating was having been served the egg custard midway into the meal. It was tasty but also a very hot dish, and I felt rushed to finish it in order to get to the next course. Also the contrast of the hot dish to the sushi threw off my meal, and I may have preferred it towards the end. If I were to do the 15 course again, I would opt to just do another piece of sushi in replacement. There were outstanding pieces, nonetheless, and I enjoyed the unique sauces and garnishes. The rice was nice and warm in each piece. The fish was fresh and excellent quality. As the meal goes on, you will notice an elevation in complex flavors. The fatty tuna with caviar we had that night was not served with gold leaf, and I am not sure if that is a special request, but I was bummed it wasn't served as a part. All in all, this was a fantastic omakase, and I have recommended to many to give it a go. Especially at the price point in this neighborhood, it's certainly something to consider for your next omakase.

This is a family-run business and the restaurant looks antiquated, but the owner and the servers (who I believe belong the same family) welcome you with so much warmth that "out-dated" turns into "charming" in a split-second!I work at Times Square and come here often for work lunch with my team. Every entree comes with a glass of wine or soft drink; potatoes or rice; vegetables; hot French bread.A fab excuse to have some wine on a week-day! I almost always get one of the below 3 entrees and recommend the same to you.Duck Ragout: This was a Today's special and loved it! They have Veal ragout on most days.Salmon Filet with Dill Sauce: Took longer than other dishes, but the wait was worth it. The salmon was perfectly cooked.Chicken Livers With sherry, mushrooms and onions: That's a lot of chicken liver pieces in one plate. It's a feast if you're a fan of chicken liver dishes, if not, I wouldn't recommend getting this.For dessert, get the Creme Caramel. Every single time we've come here for work lunch, we've been granted an on-the-house creme caramel, thanks to the generous, super-friendly owner! It has a nice intimate atmosphere that's perfect for romantic lunch/dinner dates which is ironic considering I've only been here with my team of 10! Am I letting the generosity mask my judgment? Definitely no! Try the duck ragout and the genuine hospitality out for yourself.

Had Good Friday off so I couldn't give up the opportunity to try the lunch special at Tempura Matsui. This place is easy to miss as it is attached to a nice apartment building but once found, this restaurant itself exudes simple eloquence. We sat at the tempura bar, enabling us to watch the chef make fresh tempura for its customers. For $40, this meal was well worth a try. There was plenty of food to leave me feeling happy full. We got an assortment of shrimp and vegetable tempura on top of rice with a side of hot udon and little vegetable small bites. Everything was really delicious. There is a difference in broth between the soba and udon which was impressive. The udon had more of lime taste while the soba had more of a lemon taste. The tempura itself was just a tad softer than I would like it to be but the ingredients were splendid. Shrimp, peppers, squid, mushrooms, etc.At the end of the meal, we got some tempura vanilla ice cream. Also very delicious with a good hit from the fresh strawberry on the side. Overall, a great meal!

Do it for the cheese pull. Do it.In the space formerly inhabited by Northern Spy, Raclette has done a pretty good job gaining a following with all the cheese pull videos, and cheese wheel scrapes. When you enter the restaurant, you're immediately hit with the smell of stinky cheese, and that does not go away, so perhaps, make sure to wear older clothes. Not to mention, the space is very cramped, so you'll be in close contact with other people's raclettes too.Raclette suisse: potatoes, arugula, cornichons, and prosciutto di parma, all with a double scrape of raclette over the potatoes. After the first scrape, make sure to leave some potatoes, so they can come back and give you a complimentary second scrape. Perhaps best to come during the day for lunch, so the lighting is better for when you take a video of that first big cheese scrape. Do it for the gram, am I right?Croque havana: Similar to a Cuban sandwich, there was plenty of meat, and the pickles and Swiss cheese really do a great job of cutting through the richness of the pork. Nothing too out of the ordinary, but executed quite well.Service was really friendly, but it was so busy that it was hard to wave them down. The price was very reasonable for the portion, and it only ended up being about $20 per person without drinks. Pretty great for the amount of food you get.A great choice for a lower key meal in the East Village, and especially if you're in the mood for some cheese. The scrapes of melted cheese are a sight that really never gets old, and you'll never have to pay too much for your meal. Not too shabby, eh?

-First Impression- Directly in front of the train, greatly appreciated after dragging super heavy luggage all over town.-Service- All the employees I encountered were nice. The front desk explained the hotel rules and gave me the wifi code with the room key at check in. I usually keep the "do not disturb sign" on the door for the duration of any hotel stay because I just prefer to have the room left alone while I'm not there, but everyone was friendly in passing. Check out was super simple as well.-Price- This was the best priced hotel I was able to find in the area that had decent reviews/pictures and no outrageous claims-Did Not Like- no breakfast :(-Noteworthy- Yes, the rooms are small, and yes you can hear the street noise all throughout the day (and night). All I can say about that is, it's the city that never sleeps so...-Recommended?- Yes. I enjoyed my stay here and would stay again.

Because I live in the Washington Heights area, finding quality asian food is hard to come by and that was why I was so excited that I found Koko. Their Korean fried chicken is on par with the fried chicken that you would find in Ktown, making it more ideal for anyone in the UWS or WaHi. They fry their chicken correctly, leaving a very crispy outside and a moist inside (I did not know how else to phrase that, maybe not dry?). I really enjoyed their soy garlic wings, but found their half and half wings to be a bit too spicy for me. It is also conveniently located very close to central park, which gives you something to do after.

It's a busy lunch service as I sit here and write a review for this coffee destination. People are dropping in left and right but for some reason the place doesn't feel too crowded. It is rather larger compared to other coffee places in the area but with the amount of peeps stopping by, even the biggest of stores can suddenly become bottlenecked. Gotan, however busy they maybe, still feels welcoming and not stifling. I was able to grab a seat very quickly and noticed that there were still plenty of open spots left. Perhaps the customers in the area are in too much of a rush to sit and relax. Anyways more open space for me! I really love the classic coffee-house motif this place exudes with effective use of exposed bricks and air ducts. It gives it a very modern and NYC look...which obviously it should have. Anyways I ordered an iced chai latte when I came here and found it quite yummy. Nothing really groundbreaking but still left me satisfied. I wouldn't have a problem coming here again when I'm in the area. Maybe I can comment on the food offering this time around.

BOTTOMLESS BRUNCH FTW!Seriously, this place is legit. One of the best bottomless brunches in the city, methinks. It's $26! TWENTY-SIX! Dranks on dranks on dranks on dranks on dranks...and they let you mix and match between bloodies, mimosas, and sangria (but I advise you don't mix, trust me, I made that mistake).Anyway, the food is good and the service, considering this is the Sunday rowdy NYC crowd looking to get smashed, is excellent. I never had to ask for a refill, it was like magic, I'd finish one bloody and another would appear! The waiters are also magicians!Get the pizza, it's SO good.

Solid spot to grab lunch in Midtown East.I work down the street from this location, which has served me well considering my undying love for all things chicken. Lines can get long during peak hours for weekday lunch, which is common for most places in this area. Fret not, they do offer online ordering if you are in a rush. The location is clean and contains ample seating.I enjoy the food. Fields Good Chicken serves up herb grilled, grilled mojo, and pulled BBQ chicken in a variety of forms, including whole roasted, boneless, salads, and bowls. There are plenty of gluten free options so for those with such allergies keep that in mind. They also have a selection of sides and sauces to complement your meal. Normally, I order my chicken in a bowl. My favorites include the Bueno Bowl (mojo chicken, brown rice, black beans, guacamole, pico de gallo, and maple chipotle sauce) and Zeus (mojo chicken, brown rice, tomatoes, cucumbers, pickled onions, and tzatziki).I recommend checking this out for a casual lunch if you are working, living, or visiting nearby and enjoy chicken. I have plenty of more trips to this spot in my near future.

Take 31 has grown into a wonderfully hip and popular Korean gastropub/restaurant. They have a very creative menu, both for drinks and food. A lot of their drinks are Korean traditional drinks re-introduced with some very unique flavors. Just reading the names or ingredients makes you curious and want to give a try. The ambiance here is young, cozy, and lots of energy. Perfect place to drink and chat away the night with friends. Btw, the complimentary spicy rice cake you get here is better than any spicy cakes you can purchase elsewhere in the City. Overall, it's a homey place where you can share laughs, make memories, and bond with friends. Good for groups.

The fish here is very fresh! I loved everything I ordered: tuna tacos 9$ a pc we had 6 expensive for a bite size taco. Then, tuna tartar over crispy rice (do it yourself super yum) spicy edamame, a couple of rolls yellowtail and tuna rolls, miso cod, Brussel sprouts, all good. My only negative is the portions are tiny so you need to order a lot. The service was not great and it was not packed. We had to ask for water several times and it took about 10 minutes for a server to greet us when we had been seated. The bus boy was good about clearing our table but the people kept walking around with our dishes asking every table if thats what they ordered. At an upscale place like this its unprofessional to be asking around if thats what we ordered. The food was spaced out ok but we got our edamame after some of our apps. Overall 4 starts for the food.

Haven't been? Then you're missing out GIRLLLLL. $6 strong AF lychee martinis are available for happy hour until 10 PM. Yup, you're reading that correctly. I said 10 PM. Consider this my weekend treat to y'all. A solid place for cheap, happy hour drinks! Opt to try and sit in the front. The couches will provide ample leg room. The tables in the back seemed a bit stuffy and crowded. Also note the restaurant was blasting heat or something because I was burning up in a dress! GIrllll it's not that cold outside for this nonsense heat or lack of AC. Oh and service is either TOO good here or lousy. All perspective based I guess. The server dropped our check at 11 PM and continued to check back to see if we had paid every 5 minutes. Like girlllll let me enjoy my drink!

Popped in here while waiting to meet some friends for HH. We sat in the "lounge" area at the bar and ordered from the HH menu: pork buns, chicken buns, wings, and kimbap. For drinks we got the saketini which was alright, not my thing but my bf seemed to like it. I thoroughly enjoyed the food though, especially the wings which were delicious. Service was friendly and quick; the ambience was casual with a slight touch of intimate. I don't know what the regular prices are but considering the $$$ I would say the HH menu is definitely a good deal if you don't want a full course of dinner and/or want to grab some drinks. I wouldn't mind returning and try the lychee martini--I don't think you could go wrong with that.

Late at night, I forgo any real idea of finding a good slice on the fly. Midtown - Times Square, Penn Station seems to be the worst culprit, but downtown East Village and Lower East Side can still get me twisted with a cartoon muffled slow trumpet decrescendo. Late at night this joint had the usual drunk pizza consumers, and unbussed tables, you know that after party trash feel, but the dining area was larger and newer than most. Slices looked good, with an array of square slices with beefed up toppings like pancetta, apple and fresh arugula.My arugula slice tasted so homemade that it still had a little dirt crunch from imperfect rinse cleaning procedures.  The overall taste was better than normal, your paying $5 a slice for the grandma slices, but in the end - it's still after hours drunk food, and in my opinion these slices have WAY too much cheese.Williamsburg pizza is somewhat better than average for a slice if you're in LES.

Once upon a time in a land far, far away from Murray Hill called Morningside Heights was the world's greatest Chinese style restaurant nestled on the corner of 110th St and Broadway. Cafe China (CC) comes close. For starters, CC is spicy squared and not for the faint-hearted. If you prefer Cantonese style offerings go elsewhere. This is a Szechuan joint and they are proud of it.On my inaugural visit I ordered beef with green chili peppers, scallion pancakes (like all good boys that look like me order), sauted broccoli and the fried rice. All were excellent. Except that there was too much sauce. Dial the sauce back a bit and we may have an example of culinary greatness from the far east. While the scallion pancake was too greasy for my taste buds, It is noteworthy that the beef they used in my main dish had a texture and taste better than that of any beef dish from any other Chinese style restaurant that I have visited--and I've visited a few.Service was excellent despite my swinging by on a busy night. Moreover, while waiting for a table the bartender conjured up a couple of incredible vodka based martinis (so what if I'm old school)? I can't wait to return which I will do the minute the fire in mouth from the chilis is extinguished.

After all the years I've been coming to this Housing Works I'm finally doing the review! Housing Works has stores all over the city. They are a huge non-profit organization that works with HIV-AIDS individuals. I'm very familiar with the excellent work they do. I worked in the field for three years. I visited many of their residences and treatment programs. They make it a priority to hire their clients in the stores. And in all their programs. They have high end donated items. The prices are higher than other thrift stores. You can find specific pieces that you won't find unless you go to auctions. In fact they do their own auctions. Their hours of operation are not as good as Goodwill. I tend to go farther to donate my things because I don't want to wait until they open in the morning. You can see the quality of merchandise in my photos. The store is well organized and neat as anything! Not a book out of place. They are very particular about taking only cared for donations. No torn, stains or garbage items here. If you're looking for an unusual item you may find it here. I loved the picture from the African Queen with Bogart! But unfortunately it's not in my budget! I hope you enjoy looking inside a different kind of business. If you're in NYC stop by a Housing Works Store. You never know what you'll find.

Full of trepidation, I bring my beloved old-school, steel Schwinn to Larry's, unsure if they can fix my warped wheel. Before walking into the store, I confess I had looked at other bike options just in case they told me my beloved Schwinn was not worth repairing. I wheel my bike in and the guy, who I assume works there--he could've been a random shopper for all I knew, picks up my bike, pulls a spoke out and mumbles, "Yeah, this is broken. Hm...I'm not sure I can fix it." And without another word (no price quote, discussion, nothing), he wheels my bike to the back of the store. Tears threaten to well up in my eyes as my outstretched hand grasps the air where my bike once was. Unsure if I will ever see my bike again, I start to aimlessly look around at the other bikes in the store. I notice many large red signs with the words SALE written on them. "Um, you guys have some bikes on sale today?" I say with a shaky voice. The other guy in the store moving around heavy boxes grunts, "Yeah, some of 'em." He then continues pushing heavy boxes.I try again, "A lot of work today huh?" "Yeah, well every day." He shrugs while shoving a box behind a bike. Silence. After a few minutes, by when I'm sure he's forgotten about me completely, he points to a Canondale on sale for $325, "This one's your size." I contemplate asking him if I can test ride it but am hesitant. Is he going to be annoyed that I'm asking him to do something extra? Does he know that I'm a serious buyer here, that I could be convinced to abandon my 20-year-old bike for a shiny new one? Wait, am I really ready for all that? Where is my beloved Schwinn? I don't even know what's happening to it! In a moment of panic I run to the back of the store looking for my old bike. What is happening? I find my bike on a stand with the greasy bike repairer person (by now I've decided that he does indeed work there. He seems to know his way around and no one is yelling at him for using the tools). He looks at me and says, "Yeah, I'm working on it." I say "Oh, okay" and slowly back my way out of the bike operating room and go back to ogling the Canondale. In order to pass the time, I end up purchasing a replacement wheel for my kid's Micro Scooter, which somehow costs a whopping $11. It is way overpriced and I must say, these Micros are a racket. Good thing we found ours on the street for free. Buying the wheel felt good, like I knew what I was doing in the store. Like I belong in this world of non-communicative grease monkeys. Then grease monkey #1 wheels my bike back up to the front of the store, spins my back wheel for me to see it's all fixed and hands my bike back to me. "Um, how much?" I venture. "10 bucks.""Oh, sweet!" I'm elated and relieved. My baby is back to working order and for only $10! The guy then also replaced a screw on the rear bike rack free of charge. Repair ability: 10Affordability: 10Bedside manner: 0 Well, you win some you lose some. At least I get to keep my Schwinn a little longer.

This review is for the bar/club that Hotel Chantelle turns into at night. This seems to be a favorite spot for birthdays and I'm impressed that they have 3 extensive floors that all have very different vibes and consistently good music...if you're into hip hop :)One floor up from ground floor is their covered terrace with quaint street lamps and park benches that makes it feel like you're in a park and a rooftop at the same time, even though you aren't really in either. It's charming, and a marked difference from downstairs. The closest comparison I can think of is the rooftop terrace in Berry Park in Brooklyn, and that's a compliment!Ground floor is your typical darkened lounge with a bar, a few tables you can buy, and a large dance floor. The music tends to be throwback top 40s hip hop to a decade or more ago and I love it (think Destiny's Child, 50 Cent, lil Wayne, Wale and Kanye). There are bathrooms on this floor, and the bouncer is good at keeping an eye on them to make sure no one is passed out / taking forever. By about 1130pm/midnight, this floor gets pretty crowded, which means it's time to go upstairs or downstairs, depending on what vibe you want. One floor down is the basement, and things definitely get a grimier down there, and that's the point. Neon blue lighting, low ceilings and all. Coat check is down here and there's also bathrooms. +1 for bathrooms on each floor. The only complaint I've heard about this place is the door policy is pretty weird. I've not had an issue personally, but I've heard weird stories, like 3 girls not be able to get in, or getting questioned if you're on a list or have a reservation. I'm sure I'll be back for a friend's birthday again :)

David Chang's Milk Bar is always a favorite among local New Yorkers and tourists alike, and with good reason, too. Between favorites like the Crack Pie, Cereal Milk Ice Cream, or the varietals of cookies (like the cornflake chocolate chip marshmallow, for example), it's always a winner. I also love the chocolate-chocolate cookie, and the blueberry and cream - so many different types of treats that aren't really found anywhere else. The fidi location is convenient to all the Pier 11 ferries, right off Wall Street next to the water. However, this location is only a walk-up window, and can produce lengthy waits. It's also located under a very noisy ventilation fan, as others have noted, which can make it difficult to enjoy your treat. You're better off walking around the corner to the waterfront, where there are picnic tables and benches - be sure to bring lots of napkins!

If you have ever had to refrain from naming your child Camembert or Gruyere, for fear they would be incessantly bullied, Aldi is the place for cheese lovers like you. I had to upgrade Aldi because of the strides it has made in adding organic produce, truly lovely cheeses and for the good sales on produce. Are many of the brands no names you might shy away from? Well, just be selective, as I am. I always pop in just to check out the cheese. They won't cost you $20-$30 a lb but you can stock up and offer a cheese plate for that amount. I recommend sticking to the cheeses made overseas, like the exquisite cheddars I have found. Their guacamole is good too. Foraging here can produce Naked smoothies, brioche from France, and organic salad mixes(though beware the expiration dates!) . I tried their Belgium chocolate chips for baking and found them sub standard but I just won't buy them again. Shop smart. So the place has lighting that will age you and sometimes looks like a dump. You're here for the savings anyway.

What better way to spend the weekend then attending a food fair? One of my favorite summer activities :)With a name such as "taste the world" my expectations were a bit different, I was expecting a lot more international exotic foods, as well as more vendors. Nevertheless I still had a great time. There was a good turnout of attendees, but not overly crowded and the lines went very quickly. The variety of ethnic foods was as follow:  Indian, Spanish, Caribbean, Greek, Korean, Chinese, and Japanese.The highlight for me were the desserts. I really enjoyed the fresh Belgium chocolate mousse from chef Johan Halsberghe, it was so delicate, smooth and rich. I felt as if I was eating a fine dessert from a Michelin rated restaurant.I also very much enjoyed the Egg waffle with vanilla ice cream, Gai Dan Jai Wowfulls. I chose the vanilla rainbow color ice cream, with fruity pebbles and a drizzle of chocolate fudge. This was a fun treat to eat and very shareable.It was definitely a nice way to spend a Sunday afternoon.

Lived up to the hype.WAIT: Came on a Saturday night at 7:00 pm and waited 14 minutes for 2 people. It seemed crowded but the place is pretty big for New York standards so it's not hard to get a table.ATMOSPHERE: it reminds me of a cross between Cheesecake Factory and yard house. It's super big inside with a downstairs that seats even more people. Lots of large groups, large tables and booths. Loud music playing (throwbacks from the 90s and then songs from today). It looks like people would come here when they are celebrating or with large families.FOOD: They essentially have 3 things on their menu: burgers, lobster, and lobster rolls. There are the cheap versions and then the nicer versions with more add ons. Their famous "combo" is the Combo for 1 which is $33 and you get a 6 oz burger (cheese, lettuce, onions, pickles), fries, salad, and 1.5 lb lobster. Pretty good deal if you consider how much lobster usually costs. They let us split it so between the 2 of us, we got half a burger and half a lobster...it's definitely enough for 2 people but you won't feel super full.BURGER - medium rare is pink but definitely not like some of the more gourmet places. the 6 oz is pretty small, I think most burger places are 8-10 oz. The bun has sesame seeds on it and is decent, overall the burger is nothing spectacular but is a solid decent burger. The flavor was good.LOBSTER - got it steamed and it was so juicy! Each bite and crack had juices pouring out. We got the lemon garlic butter sauce, which is like a creamy buttery sauce, pretty good. The lobster is already cut in half so it's easy to fish out the meat. It was good quality (from what I can tell, I'm no expert). You get 1 claw and then half a body.SALAD - pretty good, small cup, well dressed (balsamic?) and tasty.FRIES - also surprisingly good, thin shoestring type with a slight crunch. Overall, I would definitely recommend this place for a fun dinner that is a little "different" and if you like burgers and lobster, you'll like this place. I would come back next time for the lobster roll.

I love this shop and am so excited that I found it (not that it was lost)....The hubby and I were trolling Park Ave South and wanted a cup of java. We headed into 2 Beans and were greeted with a ton of specialty chocolate and a super friendly staff. We had:- Camel Milk Chocolate - yes, the milk is from a camel. It was good, if a bit funky - in both thought and flavor. I have to ask, who milked the camel? Was it done on hump day? Mike Mike Mike.....- Milk Chocolate covered Marzipan - extremely hard to find, it is usually covered in dark chocolate. Delicious- Peppermint Mocha Coffee - delicious- Maple Latte - ludicrously goodThe presentation is beautiful. The coffee is served in a tall glass, with glass of water and a piece of orange flavored chocolate. I think I found my new favorite coffee shop!!!

The surrounding area will scream at you that this place cannot be where you are. Even as you approach you question whether you are in the right place. You push forward anyhow and walk into what is really an authentic Mexican oasis that has the best margaritas (Yes even with the house tequila), best chips and salsa, and the best quesadillas and flautas.You truly don't know what you are missing! All of this becomes compounded with the happy hour prices AND the fact that on Friday and Saturday evenings there is live music. Live music it is, as we along with others were serenaded and asked for requests. The lead guy really is a ton of fun and knows just how to rile up a crowd. This place is solid but it is a disappointment that it is smaller than it looks. There is only one bathroom available, though it is well maintained so no problems there. Bar seating is pretty minimal, with only about 6 stools so plan accordingly depending on your group size. Service was consistently effective, but non-intrusive.This place definitely stood up to the challenge and I wish I had stopped enjoying the food to take more pictures but the fun of the evening trumped any effort in that regard. I will keep that in mind for next time, though. That or you can go and see it for yourself.

This restaurant opened for dinner on 6/17. I always walk by this restaurant on my commute to work, and saw the progression of this restaurant. As a girl raised from the South, and when I found out that the restaurant is owned by Food Network star Cat Cora, I knew I had to try this place.Currently, the bar opens at noon and the restaurant at 5pm for dinner, they're expecting to open up for brunch and lunch the weekend of 6/24. I came here with a coworker and we sat outside despite the super hot day.First off, the cocktail menu has pictures! I ordered a gin cocktail and my coworker ordered a cocktail with whiskey. My drink had blackberries and raspberries in it - a perfect summer drink, not too sweet which was to my liking. The drinks and the glassware are beautifully decorated.We ordered the mac and cheese, which comes with a side of cornbread. The mac and cheese - easily the best mac and cheese I've ever had, better than those gourmet mac and cheese restaurants. It's excellent. Being from the south I'm pretty picky with cornbread, but this was perfect - the texture, the flavor, everything.My coworker and I ordered the salmon and the cheeseburger, as well as sweet potato fries on the side, and shared everything. The salmon was delicious, cooked at medium rare and placed on a bed of slightly sweet veggies, bringing out the natural sweetness of the corn. It was amazing yet simple, definitely one of the best salmon dishes I've had. The cheeseburger was good, although it tasted like a fancy In-N-Out burger. Not sure if I'd come back for the burger.The sweet potato waffle fries were good, especially with the brown sugar butter. However, I wish the fries were a little crispier and less thick. Tasty nonetheless.Service was excellent! The wait staff are so kind.I will definitely be back to try more of the dishes, unfortunately since they had just opened, the entire menu isn't available yet. I can't wait to try the chicken and waffles, and the biscuits! I'll be coming back to try the boozy milkshakes and get some more of that amazing mac and cheese!

I had been eyeing Milk Burger since before it opened; I remember when I was in Mott Haven last year I saw signs for it coming soon and was instantly intrigued. Since today was my day off and I had time to kill I decided to stop here for lunch. First off, I really need to applaud this company for opening their first location outside Manhattan right here in the Bronx. With all the Manhattan hot spots seeping into Brooklyn and Queens, it's nice to see my borough getting some love first. The space isn't large at all, but they make good use of it by having stools along the windows and counters, as well as tables strategically placed throughout to maximize space. Decor is mainly woods, think along the lines of Shake Shack.The menu is typical of most other fast foodish burger places, but I did find that Milk Burger had a larger selection of types of burgers and fries. I decided to go with a regular Milk Burger (single patty - you can order a double) with a side of fries. I decided to have it with everything - lettuce, tomato, cheese, onion, pickles, and Milk sauce. The burger was good - full of flavor, not too sloppy, and the perfect size. Note that the Milk sauce is mustard based, so if you're not a mustard fan go without or ask for it on the side. The fries were good but pretty run of the mill. I picked up some sweet potato fries to go and those were better - they had a nice spice to them which made them stand out. You can order online to pick up if you'd like, and they have a rewards program too - though just walking in and ordering I only waited like 5 to 7 minutes at the most. If you are staying to eat, the staff will serve your food to you - a nice perk. I'm happy I finally got to experience Milk Burger - definitely a welcome addition to the Bronx.

I've been here a couple of times, most recently after a park cleanup day. I like this place because it's cool, the beer list is really good and the food is tasty.There is always a good variety on draft and service has always been good. The food has definitely improved since the first time I was there. I had a chicken sandwich that was really delicious. My friends got wings and I had a couple and boy, were they excellent.Only drawback is the limited restroom space. If there are more than a few people in the place, there's usually a line.I'm sure during Yankees game this place is a nuthouse because it's kind of small and will get cramped immediately but if there's not a game on, it's a fun place.

Do not even talk to me until I've had my Canadian bacon and eggs from Studio 9C in the morning. If you do, it's HIGHLY unlikely I'll respond. Studio 9C is appropriately situated on the 9th floor of 30 Rockefeller Center. Accessible only to those with building access, it's mostly populated with NBCUniversal employees. The commissary is brightly constructed, with high ceilings and plenty of breathing room despite the volume of patrons. During lunch hour, it's filled to the brim, but I always find a table. The far end of the dining space is lined with windows which overlook Rockefeller Plaza, an incredible vantage point to look at the Rock Center tree and skating rink during the winter. Along the elevators are props from NBCUniversal films/shows as well as a mysterious giant wall of fake leaves (which looks nice and improves my mood, but I'm uncertain of its purpose).The food is typically stellar. The aforementioned bacon & cheddar eggs is a vital part of my day. There's something biological going on when I consume it before work. Without that fuel, I'm a shell of a man. A worthless hunk of flesh and bones. Come lunch time, there's always an interesting chef special and literally any kind of food you might otherwise desire. Sushi, burgers, pizza, salads, a variety of meats, Mexican cuisine, American grilled fare - everything! After rush hours, the place is largely vacant. Unfortunately the cafeteria closes before dinner, but the dining area is open 24/7, a great space to relax and enjoy your take-out. Occasionally events are hosted here, at which point it transforms into a stellar party space.Studio 9C is an essential part of the NBCU experience, a great place to bring guests for a view of down-below and culinary delights from around the world. My only warning: if you talk to be before I've have my bacon and eggs, so help you God.

Lucky enough to score a res- you are surrounded by historic photos of authors such as a young Arthur Miller and their writings in a speakeasy feel joint. The joint was jumping' on Wednesday night and we sat near the door on a fortunately warm night, but that didn't spoil the charm or good eats or super fun and on point service that awaits.]BTW- many people had the burger and it looked amaze if you are a burger aficionado. Ate:Pretzel with salmon roeClams with avocado mignonetteOcean troutCherry ice cream with chocolate cookeRoseThe pretzel, dark and yeasty is fab- with clever salmon roe. The oysters did not wow me as the avocado mignonette was too subtle(prefer the oysters at Vaucluse). The ocean trout with hubbard pumpkin, chili and shisito's was spot on, but the ice-cream oh the ice cream. Now I normally skip dessert except for the exceptional- this was super star. Intense house made cherry with cherry pieces, but unlike many homemade ic sandwiches of yore- the chocolate cookie was super crisp and a perfect marriage to the super cherry ice-cream. Fun spot- don't overthink it!

I love taiyaki so was excited to see this come out. I wasn't sure what to expect but I was pleasantly pleased with the end product. However, I was a bit shocked at the price of $7 but then again, the serving is gigantic that can honestly be split between two people. I got the swirl of sesame and green tea and found both flavors to complement each other well. The sesame was nicely pronounced but not overwhelming. As toppings, I got the mochi and the wafer stick. The mocha had a cute presentation and the wafer stick hit the spot for a much needed crunch. The taikayi itself was good. It held the gigantic ice cream well and the actual taste is what I would expect. I filled it with custard cream because I just love that but when I got to it, there wasn't much. I was actually okay with it because I was so full at the end. Overall, a good try. I wasn't fully blown away but it's a good try when craving for some soft-serve and yummy delicious fishies.

Quite excellent. After wanting to try for a while, I finally got a chance with a group of friends for a late Sunday night dinner. ABC Kitchen is one of my go-to restaurants in the city, and I've liked what I've seen from Chef Dan Kluger, so I figured I had to give Loring Place a shot. The menu is pretty similar, and seems to be very reflective of seasonal availability. The space itself is pretty modern-looking (also like the space at ABC Kitchen), and low-lit at night.Our favorites:- Spicy meatball pizza: Pretty standard, but the spicy meatballs were really tender and flavorful. Heh.- Dates pizza: The dates and the bacon made for a really good mix with the wood-fired pizza crust.- Baked ricotta with kabocha squash: This was really good, and we kept asking for more bread to dip into it.- Ricotta agnolotti with shaved black truffle: This dish is around $60, mostly because they shave a ton of black truffle on top. And it's totally worth it.- Seared scallops with sunchokes, apples, and lime: the fruit and sweet flavors actually went very well with the richness of the oil and the seared scallops. One of the best seared scallop dishes I've had in a while.Service was very attentive throughout the night, although it was hard to pinpoint who our actual server was, because it kept changing throughout the night. Nonetheless, we had a great time, and kept the drinks flowing. Prices are about on par with that of ABC Kitchen, so while it is a higher price point, you can at least know that everything is well-executed, with ingredients sourced from a lot of local farms.Overall, the concept is very similar to that of ABC Kitchen, but has a good number menu items give Loring Place its own flavor. Definitely a good place for a small group dinner or a date in Greenwich Village.

Yes, there's a waiting line for an eat-in restaurant. Yes, it's worth it.My only gripe is that they sometimes get too busy for their own good, and you will have to physically stop your waitress in order for her to remember you. But, as long as you're not in a rush, it's lovely!What stands out at this brunch spot is that you can order a mimosa with any fruit juice - grapefruit, pineapple, etc - and there's no upcharge for doing so.I've enjoyed both the Migas (a Mexican fare, sorta like rancheros) and the BLT omelette (sans L) on separate occasions. Both hit the spot. My BFF and I searched all of NYC for biscuits & gravy on his birthday, and Good Enough once again proved their awesomeness with their "Deep South" dish. His Southern heart was very pleased.Also, believe everything you read about the strawberry butter. It is what dreams are made of. We also split a chocolate milk on his birthday, which we mostly ordered because it looked so pretty in the glass....Good Enough to Eat is a yes. Four stars for the wait, but if you don't mind lingering, then definitely look into this lovely brunch spot!

I hadn't been to Ess-a-bagel since they moved to their new location across the street. I'd been to the old location in the morning, when the were long lines and people were kind of grumpy, but my visit to this location was very pleasant. I will note that I went around 4pm on a Sunday, so not prime time, but there were still people ordering and eating. There seemed to be two places to order. One for just bagels, and another line for everything else. I went on the everything else line, and placed my order. I got a whole wheat everything bagel with white fish salad. It was prepared quickly, and then I paid. I was happy to see they accepted credit cards. I don't think they had at the old location, unless I just hadn't been since they did. The bagel was massive with lots of white fish, and it was good! The white fish wasn't too salty, and I didn't find one bone in it! The bagel was pretty good too. A little fluffy, but not too dense. Overall I had a good experience here, and would definitely come back. Although probably at an off peak time again.

Mama, I made it, to another pizza icon shop here in NYCI got so many good feedbacks from friends that I know I have to be here one day. Location: it is usually packed or people are waiting outside fiercely just for the pizza on a weekend but during the weekday, if you are here early enough - like 6pm, you will get seats quickly. Decorations are old fashions : you can see all the famous people taking pictures with the owner. The smile from the owner made me wonder how good their pizza is because I doubt you can make anything special in a thin pizza dough. I was wrongPizza: pepperoni and white cheese pizza is incredibly goood. I first thought that I love pepperoni better but I can't stop thinking about white cheese pizza after I finished my first slice of perpperoni. Why? I guesss it's the enormous cheese and the density of the food quality cheese made me wanna eat more?What's even better is that when I felt so full that I still can't stop eating. Yeah, it is that good!Service is caring and nice. They even have a bar. Price is good if you come with a party of greater than 2Overall: damn, they are not the best in NYC but definitely worth your visiting noMatter you r a visitor or a local.

KBBQ is shaking things up on the Midtown East lunch scene. Finally, something new! I had been to the Korilla downtown and loved it, so was happy to see they opened up a place near my office. If you're not sure what to order, let me make it easier for you:Ribeye of the Tiger Cup - with the recommended toppings - add purple cabbage - then head over to the sauce station and stock up on Korilla sauce and the sweet and tangy Korean Hot Sauce. Done! Don't forget chopsticks!This is a small location and they only have a few seats in the window, so it's best for grab and go. Portions are a good size, and the food tastes fresh and has a lot of flavor. Service was quick and efficient. I'm really happy this is here and recommend trying it soon before insane lunch hour lines start forming!

I felt as if I was a celebrity judge on Master Chef deconstructing the perfect Almond Croissant. The pastries are a Balthazar Bakery exclusive. There was a delightful synergy of crunch, soft tear, and gooey butter love. A Kevin Yost jazzy groove was playing. Perfect. I felt naughty and free while savoring each bite. My shot of Cortado was cute. In a homely, but agape love way. The taste, however, was smooth. Yea. The fancy coffee art was not present. But I got what I wanted. And then some. The coffee is Dallas Bros. I became a fan with the New York Espresso Blend immediately. And had to grab a pound for some pour over bliss later. The shop is cozy with three bar stools and three two seater tables. Today was a rainy day. People traffic was episodic at best. I can only imagine how this place fills up on a sunny day down here. The product is quality. Precocious two and three year olds were instrumental in setting a resonant creative tone in this nook with their watercolor and collage art. There is an organic ice cream selection from Blue Marble that folk were sampling even on a dreary day. The YOLO. Have to try it later.

Georgian food is some of the best food on this planet. Trust me, I'm part Georgian and have actually been to the country. I know what I'm talking about. Red Compass is a new addition to the Georgian food scene in Manhattan and guess what? It can play with the big boys!The khachapuri is great, as are the khinkali. Georgian wine? Yes please!The only reason this review doesn't get a full five-stars is because the restaurant is actually a garden patio, enclosed during the winter. So yes, on a freezing, 25 degree winter evening, the restaurant was VERY cold. They even have space heaters in the bathroom! But I guess it's best to come here during warmer months because who doesn't love obliterating their summer body with glorious, cheesy, eggy, buttery khachapuri.

MUST HAVE: Mushroom dumplings. Before I elaborate, please note that I enjoy mushrooms but have no particular preference for them. That being said, the Mushroom Dumplings BLEW. MY. MIND. What soup dumplings? That's what you'll be saying when you try these Mushroom ones!! They are presented on a linen cloth so that they don't break/stick, and the dumpling itself was beautifully made. 1 dumpling = 2 bites so that after you take the first bite and experience the smooth, rich sensation, you'll want to take a look at what's inside. Diced mushroom with the distinct taste and scent of truffles! The waitress told us we had 'refined palates' as she had been told that the truffle was an added touch not easily noticeable. *humble brag* - Mushroom Dumplings - 6 to a serving - $10Now, being that the chef of Pinch Chinese came from the Michelin rated soup dumpling chain, Din Tai Fung, the soup dumplings here were nothing to sneeze at. As expected, the pork soup dumplings here were delicious! Just the right amount of rich, flavorful soup for the size of the dumpling. - Pork Soup Dumplings - 6 to a serving - $10I'm a huge fan of pork belly; I have a 'Pork Belly' album in my Pictures folder, which pretty much makes me a pork belly connoisseur, right? ... Anyway, the pork belly here was a perfect piece of lean meat with a fatty top, not too salty, too fatty, or too chewy. Served atop thin slices of fried tofu, which were also delicious and savory, with Chinese vegetables in a beautiful clay pot dish. I only wish that the portion size was bigger, for the price. - Dong Po Pork Belly - $18Something here for spicy lovers: the Dan Dan noodles! As someone that can't handle spicy foods on a regular basis, I'd recommend this for someone that likes having their mouth consumed with hotness, cause ya girl's mouth was on flames. I will admit though that the noodles were a great texture! There was shredded pork and garlic that you mix in but honestly can't comment on the taste because again, my mouth was on fire. - Dan Dan Noodles - $12 I overall enjoyed my meal, the only problem was that I wish there was more of it! Well worth a try if you're in the area.

The burgers here were exciting and flavorful! The bun was moist and super fresh. I liked the sauces they have: chipotle and garlic mayo among others. The burger is filling but quite small compared to other kosher burger places. My suggestions are if you make a burger or chicken salad you should offer something other then iceberg lettuce. It has no taste or nutritional value. I went for the burger because the salad didn't seem so exciting. Its good spot for a grab and go lunch. Enjoy

SOLID.What more can you ask from a Chinese restaurant than great service and solid food? Dined in by myself because Bae wasn't around and tried to finish the following:Cold Sesame Noodle: Like Naengmyun? Yeah?! Well, you're gonna like this too! (Especially if you're into peanut butter!) And for $8 ?? LIKE SIGN ME UP, RIGHT NOW! Get this, if you're down for some refreshing, filling, peanut butter-y noodles. Scallion Pancakes: YUM! I ordered one serving but I feel like the portion size was bigger than elsewhere or maybe they were cut into 1/8 slices instead of 1/4 slices. I'm not sure but they were SOLID. Actually regretting I didn't take them home. Wonton in Spicy Schichuan Sauce: This one was recommended by my server. I really don't know because this was OK, I mean I ate it all but it wasn't Schichuan enough for me. HAHA Yeah, I'm a spicy kind of gal and it just didn't have that kick I was awaiting. Also, felt like the meat inside wasn't seasoned well. This was a bit of a miss for me because the lack of spice and the lack of seasoning in the meat. Also note, they only take CASH and AMEX which is a bit of an inconvenience but luckily CHASE is across the street. Check the place out!

Compared to the flatiron location, I prefer this eataly. Either due to the location being out of the way or to the fact that it is new, it is much less crowded. They carry a lot of specialty items which are quite expensive. The one item that is actually a good deal is the fresh mozzarella ($3.70 a piece or a little over $7 for 2).We ate on the tables in the middle with the menu that had a little bit of everything. We started with a 5 cheese platter ($19) which we liked. The honey that came with it was amazing with the ricotta. We also ordered a side of mushrooms ($7) which is really small, and the Crudo special ($15) which was hamachi and pomegranate. I didn't care for the pomegranate seeds but the fish was good. We picked up some chocolates (the pistachio filled one is amazing) as well as 4 mini pastries. I would come back here. It isn't outstanding or anything special but has a variety of good food and worth checking out

One thing you need to know about your girl here:At the age of 32, I still have an overwhelming child-esque "Ewww, eggs! ICKY!" additude. Texture-wise, unless the whites are set and the middle is at least creamy rather than runny, I'm not down. And scrambled eggs? Oh HELL no.Eggslut has changed my mind. At the very least, these folks have nailed making an appitizing scrambled egg.Admittedly, I got a nice sneak peak of Chefs Club Counter via a P.R. company prior to the opening of the establishment - full disclosure - and I had my first bite of Eggslut there as mini (and I do mean MINI) egg sliders were being passed around. However, I wanted the real deal, the egg sandwich everyone in L.A. has been clamoring about for ages.One Monday morning - lucky me, I had the day off of work - I headed down there around 9:30 a.m. Part of me was expecting some egregious line out the door, but that was not to be found. I got to the counter, ordered my egg sandwich and an iced tea, and had it in my hands in three minutes, flat. I got the lauded Fairfax: scrambled eggs with chives, cheddar, caramelized onions, and sriracha mayo in a warmed and buttered brioche bun. WOW. The eggs were perfectly cooked - fluffy with a tiny bit of jiggle, the cheese was perfect, and the caramelized onions sealed the deal. The brioche bun was out of this world, so hedonistically buttery! The girl that hates eggs nine times out of ten found that egg dish that throws the curve a bit. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'd go back for more of that eggy goodness! Dare I say it was...EGGCELLENT?(Yes, hate me. It's fine. Haaaa.)

So my GF's friend said from the back seat of the car, "We went to this really great Cambodian restaurant last night in TriBeCa and it was OK." I disagree. The place looked like every other West Village/SoHo/TriBeCa joint complete with a complement of good looking young folks in various stages of sobriety. Thank goodness we visited because not only did we increase the average age of patrons but we singlehandedly also lowered the aesthetics to that of middle-American mortals instead of chiseled grecian gods. Since this review has been loitering in my 'unfinished reviews' folder for a long while I don't recall what I ordered. However, I most certainly recall the excellent experience. The GF thought it was overrated while I thought it was excellent. But then again I'm a white dude reviewing an Asian place and she, is, Asian.

One of my favorite sandwich delis in the city. In the border of soho and little italy. Service can be a bit hectic as there is always a line during lunch but only a few sandwich makers. It's a no frills shop. Sandwiches are to go and no place to eat inside. My go to is the Dennis. Great balance of chicken, fresh mozzerrla, tomato, peppers, proscuitto, and pesto. A great italian sandwich on a nice crusty soft hero. The portions are huge and can easily be shared with another or be eaten in two meals. If i'm hankering for a great italian sandwich with fresh ingredients this is my go to spot.

This is a serious falafel spot with a few quirks that led to a 4 star review. The falafel sandwich was probably one of the best I've had in a while after my favorite place closed up shop. The falafel balls were super fresh and moist. The sandwich itself was loaded with great tasting hummus and fresh veggies and held up great meaning it wasn't a soggy mess.The eating area needs to be cleaned just a little more often. Dirty napkins littered the floor which is a little unappealing when checking a place out for the first time. Employee moral might need a boost in this place too as the back of house peeps seemed a bit miserable.There isn't much more to add to this popular falafel spot because after all the premise of falafel is supposed to be simple street food. Do expect to pay $10-15 for your meal. Simple street food prices right? I'd recommend this place if you could find an area to eat.

Been wanting to eat here all winter long but decided the perfect time to do so would be on the mother of all days, you guessed it, Mother's Day. Onto the bar area we sat, that, or endure a half hour wait, and our bellies said No thank you!Even though it was crowded, we didn't need to wait too long for our orders. The Montauk brew and Summer in the Garden drink were yummy! The Messy breakfast sandwich is delicious. You can taste the butter everywhere on your palate! The burger and fries were pretty tasty as well. I'm not a huge pickle fan but I can tell by the texture of them that they are made in- house (confirmed by the bartender that this is true).We will definitely return here. Everything we ordered was delicious. Could've eaten more!

I came here last week with three colleagues for lunch last week and it was very good. They have the restaurant week pricing for lunch which is $29 for a three course meal. I ordered the Caesar salad, lobster ravioli's, and the chocolate cake. The caesar salad was good, nothing out of the ordinary. The ravioli's were amazing! So tasty and filling. I would definitely go back for them :) The only reason I am giving the restaurant a 4 out of 5 is because the chocolate cake was subpar. It was served freezing cold which made it hard and have no flavor. I think if the cake was served room temperature it may have been better.The service was great and the atmosphere is nice. I would go back again with work colleagues. My colleagues had the salmon entrée and said it was good as well.Sorry no pictures. I did not want to be rude in front of work people :(

Came here the other day with some friends- it's been on my bucket list of speakeasies for a while now! I didn't realize how often I pass by and didn't realize it was right here... but then again, it is a speakeasy... and a well hidden one at that! I've heard from many people how great Mulberry Project is, so I am so glad I finally got to check it out myself. We didn't get to sit at the bar because it was a crowded Friday night, however we were able to get a table on the side near the dj booth, so we were quite pleased with that. It was a nice little private nook, great for catching up with friends and having a few delicious drinks! You can order off the menu or you can pick your spirit and one or two items, and the bartender will make you something magical that puts the ingredients well together. Overall, it's pretty chill here- everyone is quite laid and and not pretentious (like some speak easys/ cocktail bars can be). The drinks are all beautifully presented and also are quite tasty! Just wish they had a little more kick to them- but that's probably just because I drink too much in general and nothing quite really hits me anymore. I probably have a drinking problem, but I'm not quite concerned about it yet. Anyway, I do love me some bespoke cocktails! Can't wait to come again on another night! Really love how the door is quite hidden and really is an authentic speak easy- we need more of these in Manhattan!

Solid lunch stop, really nice staff, lots of spots to sit even during lunch hour & good prices. Well, I find it cheap - not as cheap as some hole in the wall Mexican places but a hell of a lot cheaper than most fancy sit down Mexican places for dinner. Tacos are about $3 each so you can easily order 3 for under $10 - that's more than enough for lunch! Shout out to the cashier who gave me a plastic cup after I didn't order a drink, thanks! They have water on tap in the back btw. I highly recommend the carne asada even if it's a bit more expensive - worth it, super tender! And you gotta try the masa fries - best new trend, I hope it catches on!! French fries made with corn dough - half fry half tortilla chip!! Great with their dip.Hmm, next time I'll try the horchata drink. Very simple menu so its fast and not confusing to order. Prep time is super quick if you're in a rush.

When Tim Ho Wan first opened in Manhattan at the end of 2016, I was flabbergasted at the multi-hour waits that immediately ensued. Compound that with the fact that it was in the middle of winter, and I resolutely assured myself that I would wait several months until the hype died down... That is, until several of my friends coordinated a trip here on the morning of New Years Day.If not for the fact that our rare early bird of a riser and runner was here to get our place in line before 9AM (thank you Elaine!), I would not have been able to rouse myself in time to get a reasonable seating. They seem to have a system in place now, and will text guests as tables are ready, so there's no need to wait in line outside for the full duration. There's a fair number of tables and booths available, and unlike your typical dim sum joint, the interior is modern, spacious, and clean. Ordering is also simple and straightforward; simply mark the dishes on a sheet of paper and hand it to your server, who may also note any dishes that aren't available as well.As a whole, I was impressed with all of the dishes we tried. The much-loved Cha Siu Bao (Roast Pork Bun) is definitely worth the hype; what it lacks in size, it makes up for in its flaky, buttery shell reminiscent of a traditional pineapple bun and the sweet-savory interior that's comprised of fatty and lean cuts of pork. I also appreciate the fact that I could actually see the shreds of radish in the Pan Fried Turnip Cake, and that I could taste the distinct ingredients. The Pork Siu Mai were plump and juicy, the Har Gao tender and perfectly wrapped, and the Rice in Lotus Leaf was steamed to the perfect consistency and had generous amounts of lap cheong and chicken interspersed throughout. We also ordered the Spare Ribs, the Steamed Bean Curd with Meat and Vegetables, the Steamed Egg Cake (which reminded me of egg custard-y sponge cake), the Beef Rice Roll, and two of the desserts (Pumpkin Cream and Osmanthus with Goji)... The wonderful and terrible thing about dim sum is that it's so easy to keep on wanting to try more and more dishes, especially when dining in a large group. Also worth noting is that the sambal available at each table is significantly better than the typical jarred versions you'll find in supermarkets; there's plenty of heat and body in each spoonful, and I could actually see the ground chilis and garlic in the sauce.At the end of the day, I'm not sure I can fairly say that the entire effort of waiting several hours to get inside and seated is worth it. That obstacle aside, however, I think the elevated prices (ranging from $4.50-$5.50 per dish) is certainly justified, especially when considering the quality of the ingredients and the actual composition in each plate. Perhaps in a few months when the weather is warmer and the lines are shorter, you'll find me back here again...

Very pretty bar that stands out in the area due to the dearth of cozy options in Times Square. Though, technically, this bar is firmly Hell's Kitchen Territory, planted right on the corner of 44th and 9th.The interior was pretty and low-key, with pleasant holiday decorations in early December. Beer list was respectable: enough good choices without making your head spin over too many tips. Really, the only rub with this place was that it took a weirdly long time for us to get anyone to notice we were at a table. I'll cut them slack, just thought it was odd given how few customers were actually in here.

The hype got to me - the capri sun drinks were awesome!WAIT: Came on a Saturday night at 8pm and there were no available big tables for 11 people until 11pm so we had to drink at the bar. Otherwise, they do offer reservations for groups of 6 or more but you have to have a preset menu.ATMOSPHERE: The bar is slightly awkward because there isn't enough space to really hang out and not get in someone's way whether it's the waiters or people walking to their table or other people ordering drinks. We stayed there about 30-45 minutes before leaving.FOOD: Get the capri sun drinks! They are $12 ($9 on thursdays) and super fun, cute, picture worthy and actually tasty.LYCHEE CAPRI SUN DRINK - I BARELY tasted the soju and I always taste the alcohol, believe me. I'm also a super light weight so sharing this I was totally fine. It has soju, mango and lychee. There are actual lychee bits inside the drink, it has a more tart/sour taste almost like grapefruit which I think helps cut through any soju taste. It also has a light up cube in it, which they actually ran out of so we had to go back to the bartender when they collected more.My friend got the strawberry/red one and it tasted like fruit punch AND has a little garnish, making it look more tropical-y.Overall, despite the space constraints and no reservations I really liked this place and would take people again.

This place is iconic! Opened for over 50 years, the joint serves Chinese and Spanish food. I thought the food would be Chinese food meets Spanish food, but really, it's just a menu that serves both types of food, sometimes on the same plate, and it's totally cool (and carb-y, and oily). We ordered the special combo plates. Both of our entrees came with the special fried rice that had two types of pork and shrimps with scallion. It was very tasty!!! I ordered the combo with broccoli, pork and brown sauce. It comes with a fried veggie roll. The hubs got a combo plate with the same Chinese fried rice and a Spanish grilled steak topped with onions. We were given a bread basket. And fortune cookies at the end! It was a fun food dinner, we had a ton of leftovers, the bill was super cheap, and best of all, the guys working there were super awesome! Very kind, welcoming and helpful in making a decision, they are as much as the yummy food part of what makes this place successful throughout the decades!

Upon walking into Amy Ruth's, you can tell that this place truly does have an immense sense of history. I came on a Friday night at 8pm with a party of two and was seated immediately. For their entrée, I got the ReverendSharpen (chicken and waffles). This dish was extremely satisfying and is everything I was looking for in chicken and waffles. First off, their portion size was large, with two large perfectly friend pieces of chicken and a large waffle. While I wanted to order additional sides at first, I was happy I did not since I was so full by the time I finished my meal. I would highly recommend that you order a sweet tea with the meal in order to further make the experience that much better, however, the sweet tea is extremely sweet so keep that in mind. I tried my girlfriend's sides of fried okra and mac and cheese and was not greatly impressed. Most of it was personal preference where they bake their mac and cheese and lightly fry their okra. If you like that style then you will love those sides, I just do not prefer it. Overall great meal and would recommend coming if you want to blow your tourists friends away with the best fried chicken in Harlem.

Was looking for a place for brunch in this neighborhood, so I hit up Yelp (naturally) and was led here. It was crowded and they said it would be an hour wait so we were prepared to go somewhere else. Since it was freezing outside, I stood by the door to check Yelp again when suddenly the hostess runs out to get me and says "We just had a table open up!".  Happy for our good luck, we were led to a table in the back and were able to enjoy a terrific meal. My friend had an omelet which she absolutely loved. I had a waffle, plain with just butter and syrup. The butter had big chunks of sea salt on it and the waffle was perfectly made.  This is seriously the best waffle I've ever had. I've had dreams about that salted butter, mingling with the crisp outside/soft inside waffle, with the salt offset by the sweetness of the syrup. It was so good.Service was great too. The vibe was lively but not too loud. I recommend this place!

Get the five dollar burger. So cheap and more than worth it. Idk how they do it but it's so good. We had to get a second one. Even after the second one, I was contemplating on getting a third. My dining companion and I have a theory that they purposefully made it so cheap but it's so darn delicious so you don't feel bad about getting another. On top of that the burger is just the right size to just ALMOST make you feel satisfied and leaves you wanting more. Genius move but Such a tease, I know. Ethyl, you dog.

I've stopped in here more than my fair share of times without reviewing. Each time, they add new eateries here for me to rediscover this place again and again. It's another one of many food halls in the Chelsea/Meatpacking area. You can get your fill of anything from Korean, macarons, poke, bruffins. I stopped in for The Truffleist, a Smorgasburg favorite for their truffle cheesesteak and it was amazing as anywhere else I've had it. This location is an improvement over the previous one nestled in between Gansevoort St. which is far less accessible than 14th Street, which is heavily trafficked by passerby heading to and from the High Line. Airy, with high ceilings, its definitely a nice retreat from the hustle of Chelsea.

Who: Basic millennials -some from flexed Murray Hill Apartments -some taking a day trip into the city from their parents' houses in the 'burbs.What: A boozy brunch, in a trendy restaurant, with man-bun waiters. A snapchat cluttered with geotags such as "Brenda's Betchy Brunch" and"Tina is Twenty-Four No More". When: Although I have heard great things about dinner, this establishment has been branded as a brunch spot. Where: Murray Hill Why (or why not): If you are a millennial trying to get all your friends in the tri-state area together for a boozy daytime birthday celebration, this apparently is the spot. All the benefits of a cliche LES boozy brunch experience, conveniently located 10 minutes from both Grand Central & Penn station. If you do not fall into this category, your meal may be overshadowed by a waiter leaning over your table retaking the perfect instagram for the very loud table next to you. Not all restaurants are meant for everyone. I do not hate this establishment for catering to a certain group of people. The food, drinks and prices were great!

This is a Small, cozy, tight spot for some solid brunch and drinks.Reservations for 4 during Sunday brunch 12:30p.My table ordered:Apps: Guac. and chips - Get a pretty big bowl of guac to share among 4 people per order.Mains1. Tacos - Fresh and filling. You get your normal salsa and guac fixings on the side to dress it up.2. Chorizo with eggs - Big breakfast/brunch dish. Good to pair it with a drink.3. French toast - looked horrible and bread looked super soggy. No complaints to the taste, however it was heavy and sweet.4. Enchilada- Pretty well made and flavorful, filling and wholesome.Drinks: Sangria, Mirosa, and Mojito. Drinks were pretty good. The glasses were a bit small and the ice took up a lot of space. Net liquid gold is on the low side. So after finishing the drinks I felt like they could've been bigger and a little stronger. Service was super attentive. Our water was always filled. If you have dietary restrictions, it's best to tell them in advanced. Reservations for brunch is highly recommended. Street parking can be hard to find on the weekends.

Got lots of love for Momofuku Noodle Bar! Finding it though, is not so easy.My friend and I came on a Tuesday night and it was packed! We sat at the bar and was able to ogle all the food before it went out.We had:- Smoothie Drink - A sweet alcoholic smoothie, how can it be bad??- Pork Buns - Delicious- Momofuku Ramen - Delicious, with a poached egg, yummy noodles and a fish cake. It also had a piece of pork belly in it. Very good.The service is very good, they have a very small space to work in and make do. Very good dining experience.

Oh, man. What a long-awaited visit. Since its opening, I've been lusting after King. Reservations have been hard to come by. Expectations grew by the day. You know when you've been on dating apps and you've talked to a potential mate for like 2-3 weeks before actually meeting up with them in person and you build up this fantasy in your head (involuntarily) of how they're going to be, not taking into account that fantasy and reality never match and you're doomed for disappointment, even if the first date goes really well?* Well, that was my experience with King. Our experience here was lovely--maybe even 4.5 stars. High expectations often lead to discouragement, even when reality presents you with something awesome. Apparently this is getting philosophical now. Reeling myself back in here, I'll say that we had a great time at King. Some things were unbelievable, some things were just above-average. Considering King changes its menu daily, inconsistencies are bound to happen. So overall, worth the trip. And I'm intrigued enough to return come spring/summer.Made a reservation for 8:15pm on a Saturday night. MAKE A REZ BEFOREHAND. This place is popular and I don't think it's going away anytime soon. I'll jump right in and say that the service here is fantastic. From the hostess to the bartender to our waiter, everyone was fabulous. We weren't seated in the main dining space right away, so we got to enjoy a couple of adult beverages at a table by the bar while waiting. Cocktail-wise, King offers a nice array of options, most which are on the stronger side (you've been warned). I ended up trying the Cochonnet (Gin, Cognac, Cocchi Americano, Crème de Peche) first, which was spirit-forward but definitely drinkable. A unique flavor--memorable for sure, but not for the faint of heart. My second drink--which isn't on the online menu--was a scotch-based cocktail called the "Blood and ____". That's all I've got for ya. To my knowledge, it's the only scotch-based drink on the menu, so just keep an eye out for it. Perfect winter cocktail. This is coming from someone who doesn't even like scotch. If you're more in the mood for wine, be prepared to shell out some serious cash. The cheapest bottles here are in the $60 range, and there aren't many of 'em. Wines by the glass are equally expensive and frankly, not worth considering.As mentioned, King changes its menu daily. A worthy concept, for sure. The dishes I'm about to list may very well not be on the menu when you decide to go. Ingredients are seasonal, so you'll definitely get something different if you check King out in a few months. In any case, the menu is on the small side (not like they can change a diner-sized menu everyday) but there's a nice amount of variety. Our eats, below:Panisse: A-A solid starter, though I wouldn't have said that upon first bite. Pretty bland at first. Not sure what kind of Willy Wonka magic was going on, though, because they managed to improve throughout the nibbling process. Definitely much better with a lemon squeeze (provided). That all said, probably better to order with a larger group of people--these aren't something you'll want to fill up on before the real action starts.Greens/walnuts: A-Because we felt like we needed a veggie. Nothing really to say--simple and refreshing. A nice palette cleanser Scallops/chickpeas: A-Beautifully-cooked scallops, also served with a lemon. This turned me off a bit, simply because 2 out of 3 dishes at this point came with an optional flavoring component. If I'm paying this much, I'd expect the food to be pretty complete, as is. Chickpeas really brought this dish down for me. They looked and tasted like they were left there by accident. Still a good dish overallGnocchi: A+++Utter magic. The couple next to us, who seemed to know the chef, pretty much demanded that we order these. And thank god we did. Though I can't tell you exactly how these were prepared, they were served with some elegant yet decadent cheese. I'm one of those annoying carb-avoiders, and these were worth every bite.
