The best dish I've had anywhere in 2017. Onglet: ABe prepared: served RARE. Seeing beef this rare always scares me, but that has nothing to do with King. I'm just a weenie sometimes. In any case, this entire dish was delicious. Tasty cut, really yummy polenta (I'm typically not a big polenta fan), topped with some sort of cured meat, which was well-received. A rich, warming dish that was pretty fitting for this cold, snowy night. *Oh, and if you were wondering about that whole dating thing, I am now happily paired up. No thanks to those dating apps, which never panned out for me.

Cute French place in the West Village. This place always had a lot of hype due to their brunch offerings but wanted to try what they had to offer for dinner. We were able to get reservations for two on a Friday night. We arrived early and opted to sit at the bar to start off with some cocktails. I got the Pera y Romero which was super refreshing and tasty. The pear and rosemary was great with the rum.We then started with the crispy Brussel sprouts which tasted like general tso chicken but instead with Brussel sprouts. It was very savory and had good crisp from these small round rice crisps. Brussels were roasted nicely. We then shared roasted duck breast which was huge in size, with two large slices of duck with a great charred napa cabbage and a duck jus that complemented the duck well, especially since the duck itself was kind of dry. We also got the braised short rib which was super tender, easily pulled apart by the fork on top of mashed potatoes that was super creamy. Very delicious.Overall, it was very pleasant and had a great intimate setting. I definitely would be interested to come back to try their brunch.

Delicious and Fun! If you are from LA, especially from the valley and missing Boiling Crab, this place will satisfy you cravings!My girlfriend told me about this place and wanted to have dinner here on her visit. So we made reservations at 4:30 since the restaurant opens at 4pm on Sundays. BTW they only take cash!! They have an ATM by the door but they really should put a sign up as well.We arrived around 10 minutes late to our reservation since we accidentally google mapped The Broiler room ( don't do that!). Fortunately it was not very busy and the staff was super nice about it. The seafood cost $15 and up by the pound. If you get 2lbs combos it includes corn and potatoes automatically! There are choices for sauces but the boil special which is a blend of all the sauces I believe... they also have a lot of beers available!We ended up ordering some fries, a beer, a coke, and 2lbs of shrimp with the boil sauce and with medium spicy. The restaurant provides bibs and gloves! Which was really nice since your hands don't get super dirty. The food arrived quickly and it was delicious!The fries were crispy and also seasoned nicely. The shrimps were plump and juicy in the sauce although for some reason the veins on the shrimp really bothered me. Normally this is not a big deal but for some reason the veins were very prominent in each shrimp as I peeled away the shells. The sauce as delicious! The butter flavor just hits you in the face. The sauce for me was too buttery and not citrusy enough, but that's because in loooove lemon on my shrimp. That also makes me bring up that they didn't offer fresh lemon and pepper on the side ( Like boiling crab does) Overall this place was great! definitely go to place in the city to get your hands smelling like garlic and spices :)!

I'm not really sure how many stars I should give this place. On one hand they have roast dinner, which is a god gift on a cold Sunday afternoon, on the other hand, the roast dinner is not as good as the one in the UK. And also quite expensive.:)Their mulled cider was quite good, we weren't sure at 1st whether it was cider or just apple juice - but this is the alcoholic kind.The roast dinner itself, I didn't care much about he gravy, the potatoes, the vegs, nor the Yorkshire puddings :(The meat was pretty all right. I guess the overall meal wasn't too bad, given we are in New York - it was just me, and you can't really expect stuff to be the same. :)

Excellent dining experience in the West Village.I've had my eye on L'Artusi given its positive reviews and my love for Italian food. I try to get in a couple of nice dinner dates with the lady around the holidays so we came here on a Friday night (12/16/16) before life became hectic with work parties and traveling. I'm happy to say we really enjoyed our meal.It seems difficult to get a table during peak hours so I made a reservation on OpenTable far in advance. Sure enough, this place was hopping from the moment we walked in and far after we left. The restaurant is unassumingly beautiful, consisting of sleek table settings and attractive décor. The atmosphere was lively, and our server was able to keep up with the pace.The food was great. We started with a couple of cheeses to pair with our wine, and the one featuring truffle was particularly tasty. Next were the dayboat scallops, followed by the garganelli (mushroom, ragu, ricotta salata) and gnocchi (rabbit, tomato, basil, parmesan) pastas. We thought the crudo and pasta dishes were well prepared and flavorful. We capped things off with a delicious hazelnut chocolate torta.I highly recommend this restaurant, and I will certainly be back for seconds!

What kind of crack is their cheese made of!? I seriously can't get enough of it! Since I live so close, I made it my personal mission to try everything on their menu and as of now, I'm failing so bad. I simply can't get past their 6 Taco deal and their nachos (of course)! I did try their Juicy Lucy as well, which was absolutely DELICIOUS with that tasty gooey cheese and perfectly toasted bun. You have to order the fries separate if you want any, though. Still, I'm pretty convinced that you can't go wrong with any of the foods here- except anything deep fried, like veggie chips, if you're ordering delivery as they naturally get soggy. Yes, the food is pretty expensive, but not more so than anything else on this street. The multiple online menus for this place sort of differ from each other, but it seems to be priced accordingly and they're SUPER quick with pick-up orders. The food is fairly portioned for what you get and most importantly, freakin' delicious. Absolutely my new go-to.

That milk shake doe....The lines for this grungy, dive-y, hole in the wall (in the Parker Meridien hotel which is *not* grungy or dive-y) can be outrageous and long so avoid regular lunch/dinner hours OR call ahead and order to go.The seating is somewhat limited but if you can find space to park your rear, do it. It's a fun aesthetic and makes you feel like you could grow up to be a punk rocker...or at least a punk rock groupie. At least.Overpriced (Cheeseburger- $10.25, fries- $4.50/small, milkshake- $5+), but what isn't overpriced in this town??Cheeseburger is good. Juicy, greasy, and exactly how you expect it. Milkshake tastes like the ones I used to make when I was a kid after school (read: delicious, amazing, REAL, solid milk flavor, and not overly processed. Also see: legit).

If you brush your teeth with cheese, Raclette is for you. If your perfume smells like cheese, Raclette is for you. If your laundry detergent is cheese-scented, Raclette is for you. You catch my drift. Cheese lovers, rejoice! There's a new place in town and it STINKS! I mean...REEKS. When I first walked in it's like someone took a wheel of cheese and pounded me on the head with it. Wowza! The smell! After five minutes of pure nausea, I got used to it and began this cheesy feast.My friend and I each got a drink and one of the Raclette options. I had the Suisse and she was all fancy and got the New York, which comes with steak. Both were excellent! From the quality, to the presentation, to the second helping of scraped cheese heaven, our insides began sticking together.Make a reservation, you're going to need it. 8pm on a Saturday night and people are standing outside in the snow waiting for at least an hour, being teased by that cheesy smell each time the door opens and they catch a whiff.I do have to say, the menu is minimal and it definitely is more of a lunch place but if you know what you're getting yourself into, you're good to go.There you have it, you cheesy traveler. Raclette, a one-stop-shop for all your cholesterol needs.

Jean George's West Side GemBrunch // Dinner // DrinksHave been coming here for many years, and always come back for their herb crusted tuna... but little did I realize they were open and had quite a unique brunch. My duck hash was delicious, as was the brioche french toast with suspended maple bacon.Entirely too tempting for the morning and afternoon. You'll want to go to the gym after you've been here.The Scene: Upscale, Chic, FrenchDestination Rating: 8Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 3Strong Suggestion: Seating at the bar is first come first serve.

Super cute tiny dessert place tucked away in koreatown :) great for a quick bite to catch up with your gals or meet someone for coffee!Atmosphere: very light and airy. They have rustic wooden seating with cute tree stumps as chairs. Only downside was the lack of seating but they utilized the space very well for how much space they have. Price: kinda weird because some tiny pastries are more expensive than the larger ones but maybe they're better? I got the cake and shared. Perfect for 2-3 people to share. The drinks are pretty much the same as any other coffee shop. Staff: nice and efficient. They were nice to answer questions and explain what the pastries were. Food: yum! The cake was a liiiiittle dry but maybe just because it was late in the day. But besides that, totally lived to the hype. I got the maple hot chocolate- SO YUMMY. Will I be back? Yes, most likely!

Interior - The Grey Dog - Sunday, 11 AMFour fresh faced youths emerge in the rustic, warm dwelling of The Grey Dog. They look left. They look right. Heck, they even look straight. There is no dog to be seen. Rather, there is copious paraphernalia from the state of Michigan. This is never explained. We don't dare ask. Sat comfortably in the back, the four youths fiend for breakfast. Something to take the edge off. It's been 12 long hours since they last laid waste to sustenance of any kind. The table is reserved with a bandana, and much like the Michigan motif, we never learn what this represents (conceivably 'the grey dog' once wore it, we only venture to guess).Bravely leaving their coats at the table, vulnerable to theft, the patrons make their way to the counter. It's time to order. What happens next is a blur, but we know they ordered something good. It's now coffee time and the coffee is earthy, textured, delicious, and decidedly hot. No one burns their tongue; this is a great omen. Waiters pace to and fro, shouting names of customers who must claim their food, for if they don't, it will be fed to the grey dog (whom, at this juncture, we had yet to see). Finally, the man of the group receives his dish. Wouldn't you know it, it's a bacon egg & cheese on a croissant with potatoes. This is hearty, well portioned, and in some ways sweet sweet revenge on the travails of hunger. Yes, a revenge croissant indeed.Everyone is eating now, everyone is getting revenge. But with so much liquid ingested, the man is now getting the urge to expel said liquids. The bathroom is tastefully marked with a red fire hydrant and the man tentatives pulls the door open. It is there that his jaw goes slack. He stares forward, eyes unmoving. He's gazing at a tasteful artist rendering of the grey dog itself. It's so realistic, he almost wants to touch it, but in his heart he knows it wouldn't be furry. It's just a drawing, after all. Right? This raises more questions than it answers - is the grey dog still alive? Is the grey dog a metaphor? What does any of it have to do with Michigan? The friends collect their coats, which were pleasantly NOT stolen, and make their way out. The daylight is piercing, intense, and instantly makes them realize they had taken for granted the quiet, soft homeliness of The Grey Dog.Also, they didn't accept Discover card.

Waited an hour to try Dō - that's my review, the end. I thought I could skip the line by planning my visit on a weekday morning but my, was I wrong. They let you try up to 4 flavors - sounds like it used to be unlimited but sadly that's no longer true, but 4 should be enough for anyone in my humble opinion. The staff is friendly and helpful, and they try to be efficient by moving the line quickly but it looked like the guys were having a hard time scooping. You would think cookie dough's softer than ice cream and easier to scoop but it didn't appear that way. So my scoop ended up being smaller, my two scoops looked like my friend's one scoop. I'll ask for my $7's worth next time, only if his arm wasn't trembling this time..You can choose up to 3 scoops and they can be mixed with ice cream, which is great. But I went all dough this time and chose Confetti and Chocolate Dream on a red velvet cone. I thought those were both good choices. No big surprises but good consistency, delicious cookie dough, and definitely sweet. Chocolate one's a bit sweeter so I prefer the signature. I used to pick out the cookie dough in Ben&Jerry's to save till the end and hog it, so this works very well for me. Although, I would like it to be served cold if possible.It's all very pink inside the store and fun and exciting. There are tables and seats available.

My mom wants me to buy a new sofa. My interior decorating skills rival only those of a 12 year old, so needless to say, the thought of picking out a couch increased my stress level to an unprecedented high. After multiple hours of one of my best friends leading me through West Elm + Crate & Barrel by the hand, I was so Hangry that I could've starred in a Snickers commercial.She suggested Burger & Lobster. At that point, I would've happily eaten sand. We got to the restaurant at about 7:30 on a Saturday night and it was packed. We were quoted at an hour wait for two people, but we were told that the bar was first come, first serve, and that there were bars on both levels of the restaurant. We decided to check out the downstairs bar.There were two seats at the bar when we got down there, so we scooped them up immediately. Our bartender was the absolute SWEETEST. Service was easily 5 stars. He was really friendly & knowledgeable, and didn't pressure us into getting drinks even though we were sitting at the bar. He took one look at us and realized that we were practically ravenous and immediately took our order. We also informed him that my friend is gluten free and he asked us SEVERAL questions to make sure he got our order right, which was awesome. We split:THE LONDON: ($16) 6 oz beef burger with the works, fries, & saladTHE ORIGINAL: ($28) 1.5 pound whole lobster with fries & salad The Burger: Delicious. We ordered ours medium but it honestly came out well done (in my opinion, whatever, but I can see how this would be irritating). The toppings were super fresh, the pickle must've been soaked in magical brine, and you get bacon + cheese for no extra charge. It came with both fries & a small salad. The burger was falling apart a little bit but it was still good. The Lobster: Worth $28? Maybe. Fish itself was fresh and the lemon garlic butter sauce may or may not be made with actual fairy dust. This dish was certainly enjoyable. Fries & salad: Salad was a cute addition - was pretty standard but was nice for breaking up the meal. I loved the fries - they were crunchy.Non-edible comments: -While I felt really good about the pricing of this place, I feel like it isn't as cheap as people give it credit for. $16 for a burger and fries is on the cheaper side in NYC, but it isn't...cheap...either. The drink menu was also standard for NYC ($8 for a Mocktail? What?). The lobster is probably the real deal, but $20-28 isn't really a cheap meal, either. I definitely wasn't complaining about the price, but I am surprised at how people think that this is dirt cheap, because it certainly isn't your local Gray's Papaya.-The crowd at this place is super diverse- you have people in gym clothes & sneakers and in dresses & button downs. Not really a positive or a negative, just a fact. -The bathrooms were fairly gross. Spilled / mostly congealed soap on the floor, severe lack of toilet paper, etc. Overall feelings: B&L exceeded my expectations and filled me up; I was honestly torn between a 4 & a 5 star on this one. We had an awesome experience and I would definitely go back. Next time, though, I hope I can skip the furniture shopping beforehand.

I happen to be on the UES which happens almost never unless I am going to the Apple Store. With a two hour wait for a cracked screen repair, I decided I allowed Yelp to direct me to a restaurant. My husband and I decided to give it a try based on the reviews on Yelp and their website. I am a sucker for a well laid out website for a dining establishment. But seriously you should go look at it. Given it was Christmas Eve and around brunch time I thought it would be a busy time for them. My husband and I walked in and there was only one other table. We decided to grab a table at the bar and we were greeted by the sweetest bartender ever. I forget her name but I do remember she was from Ukraine and we were talking food and everything else. It is nice to come across a bartender that has good convo sometimes. I ordered the french toast and bacon. The french toast could have been a little bit more sweet, and it had very eggy taste. The size of the french toast was enough for two people to share although I only ordered it for myself. Mela East you won me over. When I am on the UES I will make this a spot that I will frequent.

Great place for happy hour drinks! They have happy hour till 8PM every day: $5 beer, $6 wine and well drinks. They also have a great selection of craft beers not on happy hour (but still around $8-10.I recently tried their pumpkin cider ($8), a seasonal drink. Great tasting, super refreshing, and very different than their standard cider.There's three floors to this establishment. Floors 1-2 are good for sit down; 2 has outdoor seating and standing room by the bar, 3 is a small rooftop bar! Unfortunately the rooftop doesn't overlook anything, but it's a nice place to enjoy the weather!In terms of food, there is no happy hour pricing on these, but I love their nachos and wings. The nachos are loaded with cheese, crema, pico de gallo, and guac. The Southern fried wings were tasty too!

Came here with the bf for dinner during restaurant week and had a great experience. Ambiance: Small restaurant overall and isles near tables were pretty tight but the decor of the restaurant gave it a very chill and comfortable vibe. There were some interesting displays of art on the walls and around the restaurant that had me scratching my head but no big deal. There was also a bar with seats, which had happy hour until 7. I tried a passion fruit margarita which was delicious and definitely had its share of tequila. Food: Let me start with the BEST part of the night. The duck confit flautas were the highlight of the entire meal, and I wish they were made as an entree instead of appetizer. Perfectly crisp, a good portion of duck in each bite, and covered in a sauce that had me scraping the plate. I mean, who doesn't like duck and flautas? So paired together, it as a match made in Duck heaven. Me and the bf both ordered the fish tacos as our entree and while he seemed to enjoy them, I couldn't get through 1 whole taco. The slaw they put on it had a weird taste and the fish itself tasted bland, as if it hadn't been seasoned. Dessert was also meh, but possibly because I'm not a big fan of flan or churros. I would definitely go back to La Loteria simply for the duck flautas and because the server I had was very professional and really made the night a special one. Next time, I may opt to sit at the bar for the delicious happy hour margaritas and my duck. Quack!

Darn good Cuban food. And great live music too (on Saturday nights). Warm and inviting atmosphere...I've walked past this place many times and overlooked it. Come here on a Saturday night and by 8-9 pm, it's packed! So definitely make a reservation.Service is a bit haphazard but they were great with accommodating our growing party.I ordered the ropa vieja, which was good but not the best I've had. The bowl that held the meat on my plate was made of plantain chips and I thought they were a bit elastic-y...not soft, not crunchy. The meat itself was delicious. They bring complimentary black beans. The food my table mates ordered all looked great from the paella to the seafood combo platter. Great experience, would love to go back.

If you've taken the time to trek to the Far West area of Hell's Kitchen, you may have stumbled upon a little donut shop inside a car wash. Many people heard the good word about Underwest donuts, and finally they've expanded to a small kiosk on the street level outside Penn Station. Yes, the donuts are $3.25ea - and they are a far cry from New York's sole location of Krispy Kreme (read: never has "Hot Doughnuts Now" due to their location within Penn Station) downstairs on the Amtrak level. Their "Carwash" donut is their signature and most popular, with hints of vanilla and lavender. It's moist, and has just the right amount of sweetness to hold you over. Next time I'll have to try the Banana Milk, their newest creation that's gotten many great reviews! I wasn't a huge fan of the "Mulled Cider" donut, but hey, can't love every item on the menu. Just on a coffee break? They have a full espresso menu serving coffee by Joe. All in all, I'm glad that Penn Station has continued to up their food offerings - this is a great addition to the area (and across the street from work!).

When it is cold outside and all you want is a good cup of soup is when I come here. Given that I am vegan and gluten free, I have only been able to try their roasted tomato soup. But it is oh so delicious. You can taste the roasted tomatoes - it's seasoned to perfection and is hearty without being creamy or fatty. Their blue "cauldrons" as I call them are kept on hot plates that keeps their souls forever warm. For the roasted tomato they do a drizzle of balsamic which is just perfect. One piece of recommendation is that they should carry gluten free bread and hopefully can add more soup options that meet dietary restrictions such as mine!

Visited Raymi on a windy weekday night. It was totally worth the trip. Upon entrance, the vibrant ambiance and cozy/beach style decoration will erase the chilly winds off you memory. Host is very friendly. Cocktails are pretty good. I also like their high tables where you can enjoy a private conversation with a better view. Hanger steak: slightly chewy. The giant corns underneath the steaks are really nice--Starchy and flavorful.Ceviche mixto: solid dish. Seafood is fresh and tasty. The fried crispy bread pillows make this dish perfect as an appetizer and drink companion. Roasted pork belly: nice crispy skin with right amount of meat to fat ratio. A satisfying dish.Recommend to bring your friends or date for a fun night.

Location: this place is very close to Chinatown, but it would be much easier to take F train and get off at East Broadway to reach this one.Mei Yu Spring is very much another hidden gem. They are right next to a bakery store. The place is relatively spacious because they actually have more than 8 tables for dine in.Food: I think this place is more of a breakfast cafe. I originally wanted to order #9,#10,#12. But since it is already 2pm, they ran out of #10. So I have #9 taro fried cake, and #12 pancake.Damn, I think I just had my best taro fried cake in NYC.Very flavorbut still maintain the rich flavor of taro. The outlier is crispy and inside is full of taro.wowPrice: my total is 2.5 and i was so full that I only finished 1/4 of the pancake.Service: they can do both cantonese and english.4 stars

If you want good hot pot and have some money to spend, try this place!All you can eat hot pot with lots of drinks and dessert included. Broth: lots of choices. we got 1 spicy, 1 nonspicy. pork bbq garlic and the beef thai spicy. both were really good. but be careful.. the spicy (we got medium) was PRETTY SPICY (and i'm pretty good with spicy). What i did like about the hot pot was that the flavor of the broth really did get into all the stuff you put into it. Sometimes, you don't really get the flavor when you scoop out your meat or tofu. Meats: lamb and beef were our fave. pork belly was good too. Others: tofu (all types), lobster dumplings, all veggies were good. quail eggs!! were a pleasant surprise. basically, you can get whatever you want as much as you want. service: was really good. they were very quick about bringing out more meats, tofu, etc. when we asked for more. Drinks: soft drinks included! go ham. but don't waste. got to try a lot of asian drinks which were good. also, yakult ALL YOU CAN DRINK? AWWW YEAH. our table went a lil crazy and had about 4 each haha. Ice cream: all you can eat self serve ice cream with like 10+ flavors. awesome. Price: SIGH. this is the only reason i can't give this place a 5 star. I ended up paying $38 total (tax tip included) While it was really good food and nice to have AYCE drinks, ice cream too, 38 is just too much for hot pot! hot pot should be MAXimum $30. overall, this place is really good for hot pot but just be prepared to feel a little poor after

Make sure you visit the website and reserve your seats prior to coming in, for the best selection. The theaters are much smaller than your typical AMC/Regal so the tickets will sell quickly. There are two tiers: "Premium" - seats don't recline and you won't have table service, and "Premium Plus" - reclining seats complete with a pillow and blanket, as well as a waiter at your service. I opted for Premium at $18 and was pleasantly surprised at how large and comfortable the seats were, despite not being able to recline. I would recommend you choose the farthest row back from the screen, as the other 2 in front of me would definitely have been too close. The Premium Plus seats are almost twice as expensive - I have tried them at the iPic location back in Maryland and don't necessarily think they're worth the extra money unless you're splurging on a date night. Prior to the movie, I arrived a little earlier and got my own drink at the bar. My friend also got some sweet potato fries. The prices are, of course, a little inflated - it is New York and a luxe theater after all, but I didn't think they were egregious (around $14 incl. tax for a drink, $10 for a generous bowl of fries). The service is a *tad* slow but I can chalk it up to still being green.The facilities are gorgeous, new, clean - definitely one of the better movie-going experiences you will have. One minor complaint is that the bathrooms are one level ABOVE the theaters - so if you need to run out in the middle of a movie, it may take a bit longer than you are used to. Overall, the Premium seats at $18 are on par with the cost of going to AMC/Regal so I would much prefer coming here.

I had a wonderful experience a Tamarind, though I've only been once. The food is really great but the atmosphere, decor, ambiance and service really make this a 5 star experience.This is not a standard Indian spot. It's high end and priced accordingly. The chicken tikka masala, which some may describe as "basic" is delicious. As are the lamb, rices, roti and desserts. Side bar: if you think chicken tikka masala is basic, you're a judgmental hater. It's delicious!If you are a fan of Indian food but are looking for a much more upscale experience, this is the place for you. Great spot for a date, with parents or for work.

If your workouts are leaving you feeling a bit too virtuous, give your corset or belt a challenge and your fat cells some TLC and race here. At this Chelsea outpost of Creamline, you'll find all sorts of comfort foods that will easily expand your waistline, should you go down the hedonistic path and make this your second home. Take solace in the fact that Creamline uses free range eggs, grass fed beef, organic peanut butter--you won't find GMOs in your calories here.The menu's pretty simple. For breakfast, there's staples like pancakes and oatmeal. It's the other foods that snare you into the caloric web. Fried chicken, burgers, fries, and grilled cheese. The only complicated thing is how you are going to work all this off, especially the milk shakes and fried oreos that you will have a difficult time resisting. Eat now, run it off later. Or sleep it off on your couch, if your mode of exercise is clicking on the remote.On opening day, Creamline was generously giving out fried oreos and hot chocolate. I've always avoided the former at fairs, thinking they were just an overly sweet mess fried in cheap oil. Don't, I repeat, don't eschew the ones here. The oreo I had was superb, not greasy, melty and surprisingly not too sweet. You don't taste stale oil. They serve it with a huge dollop of Ronnybrook whipped cream,which you can decline if you want to avoid the hair shirt later. I dumped the remainder of mine into my hot chocolate. Self flagellation? No, not me! The hot chocolate was good, not the best I've had(that is still Jacque Torres), made better when I realized there was a puddle of rich, dark choolate on the bottom of my cup. Stir up the chocolate, and savor it mixed with the milk, the glop of whipped cream on top and the swirl of chocolate sauce. I probably would have given Creamline five stars had they had just a few more vegetarian options but they do well on the simple things they offer, and their best sellers are probably their burgers and fried chicken. For non carnivores, you are limited. On a cold, damp day, I didn't feel like tuna salad. I don't love grilled cheese and tomato soup is something rarely eat. The other non meat option is the grilled PB&J. I should be a responsible adult and not list fried oreos and milkshakes as non meat meal choices, but I'm feeling reckless today. But Creamline to me is a burger joint with milkshakes primarily or a milkshake place with burgers and fries!The store is tiny, with a counter and 8(?) stools for those dining in. On opening day, it was packed but most people ate and were gracious about giving up space. If you find the aroma of cooking grease a turn-on, then by all means linger. Walls are white with colorful lettering on one side and the left is a huge blackboard over white tiles, and the cooks and cashiers. Staff was very friendly. This is a bright, clean place serving delicious comfort food that should have no problem becoming a neighborhood fixture. Heck, they converted me to their fried oreos.

We came here recently with our friends and their two kids for a low key lunch/brunch - We were drawn to the Hill and Bay menu, particularly because they offer plenty of "non egg" options for those (like us) that already ate breakfast beforehand. They manage to pull off a bright, coffee shop-esque feel during the daytime hours, but the space is versatile enough to serve as an intimate happy hour/evening spot if drinks are the priority. We were all happy with our food selections (two burgers, mac & cheese, burrata bowl, challah french toast) and the service was friendly and efficient.

As a recent broke college graduate, I decided to try this place out just for the heck of it. This place is very fancy and upscale so be prepared to look top notch when you go in. there are 2 levels with a spiral staircase leading upstairs. There is a restaurant both upstairs and downstairs and I honestly don't know the difference. There is also a bar both upstairs and downstairs. with lounge sofas to sit and chat on. Crowd is full of young professionals, more women than men I felt like probably because of the free champagne in the women's bathroom which is a really nice rose. There is also a nice lounge spot in the bathroom if you need a break from men. All the cocktails are $17 so I decided to splurge on the Beauty Elixir which was one of the best cocktails I've ever had in my life. I would def come here again.

Very under rated Jewish deli that serves up hearty home style yummy nosh. Excellent pastrami, brisket, and corned beef. Now these sandwiches are not these enormous sandwiches that many of the well known jewish delis in NYC serve, they are also not $22/ea. Well portioned sandwiches at a good price (ie. $15.95). Awesome latkes. Delicious hearty soups (split pea, mushroom barley are sooo good! Love the matzo ball..). Pricing is less expensive than other Jewish delis in the area. Old school diner style atmosphere. This place never changes, which is just fine by me... Been coming by since my college days back in the 1990s. I order delivery these days and it always satisfies. Portions are generous!

If you're looking for an asian/ethnic bar/dance place that plays hip hop then this is your place!COVER: $5 for girls, $10 for guys. Even though we came at 9:50 pm we still had to pay cover.COAT CHECK: For those of us not used to cold nights in NYC, a coat check is your best friend. Come bundled up for the bar but then shed your outer layers to reveal your cute outfit underneath without freezing to death! It's free (you can tip) and hassle free.ATMOSPHERE: When we first got there the DJ was spinning mostly 90s and older hip hop with people surrounding the bar drinking and sitting down. The bar is in the middle in an oval shape with high chairs surrounding it. It's pretty easy to flag down a bartender. As you walk in there's a small dance floor with 4 booths/tables surrounding it and then the bathrooms. There's a little bit of counter space on the sides of the bar for people to stand and drink but overall it's pretty small.CROWD: In the beginning it was mostly couples (20-30 years old) drinking and slightly moving to the beat of a song they liked. There was a small group of people dancing but it wasn't much. The crowd started coming around 11:30 - midnight and then it was popping. I'd say the ratio of girls to guys wasn't bad, there were a few larger groups of girls, mixed groups, a few guys but no one too creepy. Definitely asians and latinos with a few other races mixed in, mostly late 20s to early 30s. The crowd was fun for the most part, a few people who would bump into you and some couples who are just grinding and not caring if they are in the way but overall fun. What I liked was that it was at the perfect capacity, not too crowded where you can't dance or get down but not dead enough where you feel like you're the only one dancing. There was a line outside around midnight and it took our friends some time to get in.MUSIC: From when we got there until about 11:30 it was mostly older hip hop (90s) with a random top 40 song thrown in there and then back to the oldies. It wasn't until midnight where the top 40 hip hop and popular hip hop songs started playing. It was really fun dancing to them and the whole crowd would get excited. There was even a small bit of EDM they played (Calvin Harris/Chainsmokers/Avicii) and there was also a time where there was more latin flavored music.Overall, it was really fun but if you come before 11:30 it's not going to be as crowded and the music will be different.

Is it the elaborate decor or the plentiful pescetarian offerings of a typical Japanese establishment that captivated me about Kajitsu? Not! As a bona fide carnivore the only thing vegetarian about my diet are the cows I eat in bulk. I know all about the health hazards of over consuming red meat but as Mr. Chow put it: "blah, blah, blah, who cares..." So then why pray tell you may be thinking would I shell out over 200 bucks a person to eat rabbit food?So here's the deal: This joint is worth your hard earned cash. Not because of the insane amounts of black AND white truffles which they lavish in you; but because what they prepare is a gastronomic festival of flavors made from vegetables exclusively. (please know that on a second visit the truffles were absent but the price point remained the same). Kajitsu adjusts its menu to the available veggies of the season. So my tip is to visit Kajitsu during truffle season.Service is what you would expect from a 1 star Michelin restaurant. Perhaps in 2017 Kajitsu will earn back their lost second star?

I was here celebrating a birthday this past weekend we came for the Sunday brunch.Waiting for our party to arrive we had some drinks at the bar, I had the Sangria . not bad. birthday girl had the Mimosa, not bad either. Once our full party arrived we were seated in the back area since it was a large group. Drinks I ended up switching & trying the Kentucky mule this was good interesting taste with a nice amount of alcohol, Mojito was good as well. To start we tried the Avocado toast very good nice creamy avocado great taste. The Truffle Tater tots were good as well could use more truffle oil taste.Main dish I had the Mac & Cheese omelette interesting combo here very good comes w roasted potatoes good as well. Also tried the Fried chicken...yum nice tasting good with the spicy sauce, the Truffle Mac & cheese w Lobster was delicious nice truffle taste. As for the restaurant nice set up place looks like it belongs in a museum w all the old decorations gives it a cool, fun vintage look. They definitely have Great, great music playing. Service was good, prices are reasonable fun laid back vibe here we definitely enjoyed our brunch.

Do not go on the weekend and you should have a nice experience. After reading some of the other reviews, most of the negative ones are about wait time. Each time I've been here on a Tuesday around noon and I felt like I had the store to myself each time. They do not take appointments which is nice because you can just pop in anytime and try on dresses. I never felt rushed by my consultant Nadine. She was patient and kind. I didn't feel pressured and the environment was relaxed unlike some of the more commercialized stores. They carry many of the same dresses as Kleinfeld. I've visited several bridal stores over the past few months just to see the kind of styles I like and what looks good on me. RK Bridal kept popping up every time I searched for places. I finally visited. The showroom in midtown is absolutely beautiful. My favorite part about RK Bridal is that you can set up an account online and look at all of the different dresses they have by designer and save the ones you like. By the time I got to the store I had a list of the item numbers I wanted to try. This expedites and facilitates the process. You will be assigned a consultant when you arrive. Each time I went I was in the fitting room within 20 minutes more/less. They have TV screens where you can test how you will look on camera with your dress :) nice touch! On my last visit I tried on many dresses and finally found the one!! My sister, mom and soon to be mother-in-law were with me and I said yes to the dress! They have hundreds of dresses organized by designer. They carry reputable designers (Justin Alexander, Maggie Sottero, Watters & Watters, etc..). I've had a great experience so far. My dress should arrive within 3-4 months and they will store it for me until the wedding. In regards to payment, you pay deposit (half of the cost) on the day you pick your dress. The rest is to be paid at the "try-on" appointment when the dress arrives. Good luck and I highly recommend visiting RK Bridal on a weekday. Avoid the weekends and you should be fine :) lots of beautiful options!

We haven't been to this location in over 12 years, but we were seeing a show a few blocks away and figured, why not?Carmine's is still as good as ever. We came for lunch on the day of a snow storm so the restaurant was fairly empty. We were very quickly shown to our table and greeted by our very friendly waiter. After explaining several menu items to us, we had:- Stuffed Artichokes - huge portion! You get 2 artichokes, the hubby and I were full after this course. The breadcrumb stuffing was delicious. - Spaghetti with Garlic and Oil - another huge portion! It was delicious, even my finicky daughter loved.- Eggplant Parmigiana - enormous portion! It was totally yum, we all thoroughly enjoyed it. It was super thick under a blanket of mozzarella cheese.- Kids Meatball Slider - my daughter loved.- Ravioli - my other daughter loved.The only negative to the meal was the bread basket. The bread was fresh but the focaccia with tomato sauce was ice cold. If it didn't have the sauce on it, I would have been fine with it not being warm. With the sauce....eh. That being said, considering the size of portions you are getting, you are better off not eating the bread.

After many times of booking and cancelling, I was finally lucky enough to have some free time to try Untitled at the Whitney, with the added bonus of having Mike Solomonov in the kitchen as a guest chef that night. The space has a very casual, yet elevated vibe, and I do like the glass encasing around the dining area, which allows for a lot of natural light. Also, I'm always a fan of the open kitchen, and it was really cool to see both Chef Anthony and Solomonov giving direction to the sous chefs throughout the meal. What we got:- Hummus with fava beans (guest chef menu)- Salatim (guest chef menu)- Oysters on the half shell (regular menu)- Smoked sable toad in a hole (guest chef menu)- Fluke crudo (regular menu)- green bean blini (regular menu)- Short rib with fried cauliflower and rice (guest chef menu)My favorites were the hummus (duh), the smoked sable with egg in the hole, the oysters, and the short rib. The hummus was super velvety as usual, just like at Dizengoff. The smoked sable was a very unique texture, and the runny egg on top was just great. The oysters had a really clean, creamy finish, which I really enjoyed. The short rib, while not a large portion, definitely had a great texture, and the fried cauliflower was a great accompaniment. Service was very attentive and friendly, and gave us great recommendations. We both were very pleased with the wine that we got, and just felt very comfortable. The prices are a bit on the expensive side, especially for a cafe-type setting, but the food was well-plated and executed, so at least you know you're getting a great meal.Definitely a great place to have a meal after touring the Whitney museum. I would definitely come back to try their rotating menus for date night, or even a small group.

Summary: A must try if you've never been to a crawfish place in New Orleans or in China. Find a bar nearby for the wait. 4 or less people is better. 1 star off for baby crawfish and limited dessert menu, but a top pick on my crustacean list.Note: Bring Cash or an ATM card. No credit cards. Atmosphere: It looks like the NY version of a crawfish boil place. You have your gloves, buckets, and simple furnishings, but more stylish LES chic vs. my experience in the South, and also a lot more diverse (because who doesn't love seafood). Even with the chicness of the crowd, people aren't afraid to get their grub on with bib to catch any droppings. Totally my kind of people. If thinking to bring friends who have not tried a crawfish boil, this is likely the most attractive version.Service: Very professional and focused. The space is tight and there is so much to navigate. No reservations, but they have a high end system that will call you with a 15min warning when your table is ready. There are a ton of nearby bars. The perfect set-up is to go put your name in, have your friends meet at the bar and then head over. Mommy always says flakey friends - while fun - hold you back; and here she's right. You have to have your party count down, as you get seated only once everyone is there and there is no adding seats after the fact. Save flakey for a different spot.They have bus staff and wait staff ready to sort you out as soon as you seat. Be prepared to sort out what you want ASAP. They come back regularly and the food comes quick, but this is one of those places with the vibe where you want to just order.The Food: There really are some instructions for ordering at The Boil:2lbs of the same "order type" is better than 1 lb because it gets you corn and potatoes. I was hungry and 1.5 lbs plus aps was good. We had 3lbs of meat at the table and that served 3 of us plus appetizer. According to the internet, 4lbs is normal and 7lbs is for Cajun locals.Sauces: You really should just get "The Boil", but they have "The Boil" sauce components separately, i.e. Garlic and butter Ole' Bay and lime. We tried The Boil sauce and The Boil sauce minus the butter. All very awesome. It would be wrong to go sauceless. Just wrong. As for spicey, we went Spicey. I think Medium might have been better for some in our group. I eat sirachi by the spoonful and did feel spicey required a bit more water drinking than I would have liked. Really spicey is for people is for those trying to prove a point while eating. I would avoid that unless this is your deal.Sauce Delivery Mechanisms:Crawfish & Shrimp: Currently $13/lb. These are two great budget choices and will deliver that amazing sauce right to your palate. For those familiar with Crawfish, these are the tiniest I have ever seen. Some, with head, are smaller than a medium size shrimp. (Note: A crawfish grows to 4-6 inches, the size of a tiger shrimp, not 1 inch) Minus 1/2 a star. The sauce is so great though, I got over this crawfish infantaside and sucked down that head like a champ. Plus, it's almost like soft shelled crawfish at that point. Potato and Corn - These are soaked in the same sauce and are absolutely delicious. Get the 2 lbs and order more to toss in.Crab - Crab meat is sweeter than Crawfish, shrimp or lobstar and that, my friends, is why the Crab is so awesome it gets its own astrological sign. Order it.Catfish appetizer - This is perfectly cooked, with flakey white meat and delicious freshly fried breading. You can tell they are being good about changing out that oil regularly. The fries are drenched in ole bay seasoning yummy goodness.Desert choices are two flan like items. They're good. But seriously, here's a note to management. Get some better desserts. Think cold pies like Key Lime or Chocolate Meringue or some Truffle like yumminess. I mean, if your clientele just sucked down a pound of butter and yummy cholesterol filled meat, they are also totally game for some delicious calorie filled dessert to top it off. Minus 1/2 a point.

Ah, the comfort of familiarity. When I visited Carroll Place on Monday night, I had never entered the space before. Yet I felt like I had, without knowing why. But the why became pretty clear upon my first scan of the menu. The organization, the font, the menu offerings--serious deja vu going on. And then it hit me: I had recently eaten at one of my very favorite Italian spots on the Upper West Side, Osteria Cotta. I've been to Cotta six or seven times at this point so am--you guessed--familiar with the menu. This is a really long-winded way of saying that Carroll Place is in fact Cotta's sister restaurant and my visit here can only be described as serendipity (though if I'm being totally honest, I like Cotta better!). Both well-priced, both a great time.Like Cotta, the interior is beautiful--but in a different way. Whereas Cotta feels cozier and intimate, Carroll Place is more spacious and social. Majestically high ceilings with beautiful lighting fixtures, an expansive bar area, Beauty and the Beast level candles, etc. And that's just in the front space. The back is more of what you'd typically find in a sit-down restaurant--brighter lighting, smaller tables and quieter than the more gastropub-esque setting in front. I'm also pretty sure there's seating on the balcony--another Cotta feature. Overall, while this could be considered a date spot, I'd say it's suitable for any type of occasion. Carroll Place is a wine bar above all else. They do offer a number of beer and cocktails, but upon looking at the menu here it's pretty clear that wine is the specialty. That said, we actually started with cocktails first. I wasn't feeling wine (initially). We each got a different cocktail so I had the wonderful opportunity to try three drinks: the Bontempo (gin, fragoli wild strawberry liquor, lemon, mint, cava rose), the Bleeker Street Sour (rye, amaretto, lemon, egg white, angostura montepulciano float) and the Ginger Derby (bourbon, ginger liqueur, grapefruit, honey syrup). These drinks looked a lot better on paper than they actually were. Of the three, the Bontempo was my favorite and the Ginger Derby, my least favorite. And as luck would have it, that was my drink. Oh well. Onto the wine......so Carroll place offers the glorious deal of half-off bottles of wine on Monday nights. Because who goes out drinking on a Monday? The answer is us. We do. So we ordered a bottle of Rioja ($26 w/ the deal) and it was absolutely fantastic. Do this. Just stick with wine unless you're really not a wine person. It's worth it. I do have to mention here that one thing that really soured our experience here was the service. Our waitress was MIA most of the time. Which was odd, because she kept butting in on our conversations (at least we know she is adamantly anti-Trump) unannounced. I would've been able to put up for that if not for the spotty attention otherwise. But let's get to the good. 4 for $11 Bruschetta: mascarpone & clover honey, buratta & red pepper, ricotta & basil pesto, caponata & goat cheese: AOther than the menu's template and font, this helped solidify my conviction that the similarities between Carroll Place and Cotta were more than just coincidence. And like Cotta, Carroll Places offers a superb deal on bruschetta that I'd recommend to anyone--with the exception of those intolerant of lactose. Each taste of bruschetta here is rich and luxurious (try to read this in a non-redundant way). I could honestly eat this for desert. The mascarpone and honey is slightly sweet, fluffy and heavenly. And seriously addicting. I adore buratta so my enjoyment of that one was no surprise. And who doesn't love pesto (other than those allergic to tree nuts--I just know many people with allergies so this apparently comes up a lot)? Hard to go wrong here--and these were a hit with everyone. Two orders of 2 for $11 Market Sides: A- overall-Broccoli rabe -Brussels sprouts w/ pancetta -Butternut squash -Asparagus w/ parmesanI'm just going to lump all of our sides into one paragraph because none of them were particularly bad, nor exceptional. They're sides at a wine bar so let's keep our expectations reasonable, shall we? The broccoli rabe was meh and probably my least favorite of the bunch. I had just eaten some bomb broccoli rabe at Ladybird a few days prior, so this one paled in comparison. The asparagus and parm was seriously tasty though. Not the healthiest preparation but it really hit the spot. The brussels sprouts were also incredibly tasty. Cooked perfectly and pairing them with pancetta typically Wood fired rosemary wings: B+/A-Also little to say about these. The rosemary was dope, the wood-fired, not so much. Trust me, I always prefer my chicken to be cooked cautiously (i.e. overcooked). But the dryness of these took away from the flavor, which was yummy. I'd honestly still recommend these because done right, these are a crowd favorite. Possible that this was just an off night.

Looking to adopt or just admire, nap, play with the kitties, Koneko is a worthwhile visit. I made a reservation quite easily online, for $15 per person for one hour. Bonus, it is okay to snack in the cat nap room while playing with the cats, if you choose to do so. Photos allowed, but no flash photography of course.I did not try the food or drink at Koneko, but specifically went to see the cats. A reservation for 2 ppl on a Sunday was easily arranged a few days before. The cats are immensely adorable, and any cat lover will have a great time. The cat nap rooms include two floors, each with a small room filled with some cat toys and napping beds and shelves for climbing. By 4PM, most of the cats were burned out and sleeping. I would suggest trying to go earlier in the day as the cats will be possibly more awake and active. Still, it was a nice time just lounging around with and petting the cats. They were super well behaved and tame for the most part and did not mind the constant flow of a stranger's company. The cats are really adorable, and we both had a great time just seeing the variety. They had about 15 cats for that evening.We really enjoyed our time at Koneko. Their cats are lovely, the cafe itself is cute. I would come back and try some of their coffee and/or small bites. Otherwise I would agree the main attraction are the cats. You can spend only $15 to spend time in the cat nap room for one hour, or take a peek when passing through. Otherwise, worthwhile visit for any cat lover out there.

I honestly wasn't sure what to expect but my boyfriend swore their burgers were amazing and I am going to have to agree! The best part, it came with tater tots. One of my ultimate weaknesses. The bar/restaurant isn't huge but there's plenty of bar space as well as tables all along the restaurant. I started off with their herbalicious mojito and it was freaken good, made with a load of cilantro. It was super flavorful from the mounds of fresh cilantro they used, coupled with sweet and acid from the mojito blend they did. It was really good and the presentation on its own was beautiful.As for the Daddy-O burger, yum yum yum. Ultra juicy from the brisket blend, huge in size. The patty was the perfect size for the gigantic sesame seed buns. Coupled with simple lettuce, tomatoes, onions, ketchup and mayo. Everything held together well. It was the perfect burger. The tater tots were just as good, freshly made with a great crunch on the outside. Overall, a great pick for just hanging out and eating some good simple food. Service was nice and TVs around the bar for sports entertainment.

i wanna be a swedish cutieart kidwith a kanken backpackso i got one in 2013in a baby lilac color that's now discontinuedand i remember marvelling at the impressive panoply of kankens @ the mott st storeit's held up wellsturdy, practical, holds all my stuffbut the strapsthe straps are killerbecause whatever they rub againstwill pill rip my cashmere poncho

Solid brunch experience in Chelsea.The lady and I were enjoying a stroll outside of our neighborhood this past weekend (12/4/16), and our stomachs started to growl. We did a nearby search on Yelp and decided to check out Foragers Table. It turned out to be a great choice!The restaurant was buzzing around 11:00 AM, which I can imagine is a common theme. We had to wait about 15 minutes for some seats at the bar, which wasn't bad considering we perused their market to pass the time. Regardless, I would recommend making a reservation if you get the chance.The restaurant is quaint, featuring table service and bar seating where you can watch the meals being prepared. Service was very friendly, and we appreciated the helpful walkthrough of the food menu. The atmosphere was casual with a trendy twist, which we thought was nice.The food tasted fresh thanks to the farm-to-table concept. We shared a peach scone to begin our meal, and it was wonderful. I ordered the whole wheat wrap and my better half tried the chili. The wrap contained scrambled eggs, steak, and cheddar, while the chili included a runny egg on top and cornbread on the bottom. These meals were enjoyable and filling.I definitely recommend this place for brunch, and I hope to try their dinner menu soon!

Luke's. Delicious. Not a lot of fillers (lettuce, mayo overload, etc). Straightforward menu. Bread is perfect. Lobster is plump and delish. Tasty and flavorful. So much yum, y'all.The shrimp roll is also good. Shrimps are small and look like the little ones that come in the freezer section of the grocery store but tastier. I felt like my shrimp roll was a bit light on the shrimp but I still devoured every bit of it.Nomz.

My mother picked this spot for a quick pre-theater dinner. Based on the location, I expected over-sized strollers, M&M bags and thick Reebok sneakers to liter the restaurant. But, boy- I was wrong.Who: The couples of Hell's Kitchen, a few theater people and some Barclays bankers (throwing them back at the bar)What: Drinks- Extensive drink menu, wine and tequila selections are endless- overwhelming variety of cocktails just waiting to be instagrammed.Food- Food is on the lighter side. You are not coming to this restaurant to eat until you hurt (as I do at places like The Palm, Hillstone, Nanni's etc.) Our table ordered calamari, variety of toast and steak fret. Atmosphere- The restaurant has this 'Vintage' old time theme. (which is difficult to explain without making it sound like a Cracker Barrel). Beautifully decorated. When: I came here before a show around 5:45. We asked for them to speed up the order to make a show and they brought everything out very quickly. Where: Smack center of where Broadway shows are playing. The outside of this building is disguised as a vintage antique store, covered in vines. Very easy to miss. Why: Lets face it- New Yorkers will do anything they can to avoid this area and being around aggressive street performers and burnt out tourist families. However, when we entertain out-of-towners we are always roped into a Time Square Olive Garden. This restaurant is an amazing alternative to a traditional stressful pre-theater dinner.

Nothing Dirty About this PlaceMouthwatering French // SolidWhat didn't we eat here? This place was unreal. The pork by far was the best item on the table, the baked clams shouldn't be missed, and everything was great. Some of the seating seemed a bit squished in our booth, and when the drinks were delayed they kindly gave them to us on the house. All around a good experience, would go back.The Scene: Trendy, Upscale, FrenchDestination Rating: 7Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 4Strong Suggestion: bring some friends, you'll get to try more dishes.

By some stroke of luck, Mr. Joy managed to get a same-day reservation. I knew this place was generating serious hype, but I wasn't expecting it to be THIS cramped... or THIS small. Oh NYC, this city's capitalist dreams overrides any concerns over space issues... unless of course, the fire department happens to intervene. To squeeze us in, the hostess had to pull the small table all the way out towards the doorway, and asked which one of us would like to be trapped in the corner. ('Trapped' is me loosely interpreting the situation.) Given my small frame and the fact that I am vertically challenged, obviously I said I would sit there. To give more color, the space is more suited for a takeout sandwich counter than a trendy cheese & charcuterie restaurant with waiter service. Actually, you can purchase takeout, but only their sandwiches. Raclettes are only for those who dine in, so you can enjoy it hot and fresh. Otherwise, the cheese would seize up and become tough. Aside from lack of space, it is also very, very warm in here. Luckily, we had the good fortune to eat here when it was still about 70 degrees outside, but I don't think I could handle it during a heat wave. First of all, it's hot because it needs to be. The wheels of cheese need to be heated under heat lamps. Secondly, there is no AC or fans. Thirdly, they don't serve ice. Our water glasses were nearly warm. An elderly lady asked for ice for her water and the waitress apologized and said they don't have ice.I don't blame any of the staff. They're doing their best to accommodate the guests and it shows. I don't intend to complain, but anyone that plans to eat here should be aware that you need to be okay with the idea of being somewhat uncomfortable. In fact, I'll have to take away a star for the level of discomfort.As for the food, it was delicious! The Raclette comes with cured meats, and you can choose from Viande sechee (dried beef), Prosciutto di Parma, Jambon de Paris. We opted for the Jambon de Paris. It ended up being not as good as the prosciutto, but it was good to try considering our tartine already had prosciutto. $15 Savoyarde Raclette - melted & scraped tableside; roasted potatoes, cornichons, pickled white pearl onions, sliced baguette, arugula salad w/ champagne vinaigrette:Glancing around our table, I wasn't sure how the server would even have room to scrape the raclette tableside. We were shoulder to shoulder with the people next to us. Our server actually managed very well by positioning herself over Mr. Joy's shoulder. The beautiful, gooey cheese plopped down over the roasted potatoes. They step away for a few minutes before providing you with a second scraping of cheese. It was hot and stringy with a mild, nutty flavor. It's best if you eat a little bit of everything together - some cheese, a little ham, and arugula on top of the baguette. I also really like cornichons and pearl onions, but I would have liked it more if they had left the pearl onions sweet instead of pickled, since there was plenty of acid from the cornichons. It's also a good idea to eat quickly, because the cheese cools and can solidify & toughen pretty quickly.$12.40 Fig Tartine - Brillat savarin, figs, prosciutto, toasted hazelnuts, mache, balsamic reduction on toasted baguette:Not only did this tartine taste amazing, but I also appreciated the work that went into it. It looks like slices of prosciutto were rolled up, sliced, and meticulously positioned with the figs onto the baguette. It was an excellent balance of salty and sweet with plenty of prosciutto. The baguette was also toasted perfectly, just nice and crunchy.I might have enjoyed the tartine more than I did the raclette.Afterwards, I was once again reminded of the lack of space in here. The hostess was busy taking a phone order, so Mr. Joy maneuvered the table, so that I could maneuver myself out of the restaurant. I raised my eyebrows when I overheard the waitresses say they were prepping a table for a party of 7. (o.O) ??? Um, yeah, this place ain't right for groups.I'm curious to try their Havana Croque in the future, but I'd definitely order it to go. Now that I've tried their raclettes, I wouldn't go through the trouble of trying to book a reservation or waiting for a table again, but it is worth a try. I hope their success allows them to obtain a larger space more suitable for their operations.

My family and I love Vietnamese cuisine. We were in the city today, heading home and I was in the mood for a fish sandwich. I found Vietnaam; the reviews and food pics looked amazeballs, especially the sole banh mì. When we arrived, we found street parking fairly quickly and right down the block, the place was pretty empty and we just made it because there was a downpour soon after being seated. They offer outdoor seating but we declined due to the impending weather. We ordered quite a few items because I love trying EVERYTHING...ok, calming down. We started with Flank Steak Summer Rolls and Garlic Chive Shrimp Moon Dumplings. Both dishes were really good. The dumplings tasted so good and the rolls were huge. The accompanying sauces were very tasty as well. They have Vietnamese coffee, both hot and iced, which tasted very nice. I love the coffee. It's so much better than the swill they sling in Dunkin Donuts. I ordered a Ginger Iced Tea but it's sweetened already and I just couldn't deal. I like my teas unsweetened. We also asked for a cold sake. There's only one size but it was a nice reprieve from the tea. Hubby ordered Beef Bun Xao, a very flavourful noodle dish that filled him up. My son got a Roast Pork Shoulder Banh Mì and I ordered their Classic Filet of Sole Banh Mì. I also ordered the Duck Fried Rice and Boneless Chicken Thigh Banh Mì. Everything tasted very good. The Banh Mì are great, although I feel like there could have been a bit more meat. The bread was nice and crusty on the outside but still soft. Some places where we've had those sandwiches serve them on really hard bread that ends up cutting my gums and the roof of my mouth. The sole was moist, with a perfectly browned breaded coating. I threw some jalapeños on that bad boy and ate half. I polished off some of the chicken banh mì as well. It was super juicy with a smoky, charred flavor, like they grilled it; it smelled and tasted divine. Lastly, the duck fried rice was great! It had a nice ducky flavour without being gamey but it definitely could have used a couple of squeezes of fresh lime juice. Everything we ordered was good. No complaints about the food. The portions are big and enough to share and try a few things for variety. We had plenty of food to take home. The service was excellent. The staff was attentive and helpful when answering questions about the menu and they all chip in so you're not searching for you server. We'll definitely return if in the area.

Allouche Gallery, a gorgeous space across from the new Whitney Museum, is now open and bursting with buzz. Opening in June 2016, already there have been several contemporary art exhibitions. Currently the gallery is presenting pop and street artist Ron English's Guernica as its first solo show in the new space.The gallery is spacious with a wide open views to/from the street, and full of natural light during the day.Eric Allouche, formerly of Opera Gallery in Soho, made a wise decision to open in the heart of the trendy West Chelsea / Meatpacking arts scene. It's a great stop right at the end (or beginning) of the High Line.

-First Impression- Super cute, yet small place. I was a bit skeptical the party I was with (9 in total) would be able to fit at one table comfortably, but the staff rearranged the tables for us a bit, which was nice! We were greeted by the super energetic bartender (didn't catch his name, but other Yelpers have posted pictures of him) and seated quickly by the hostess.-Food- The guacamole was great. We inhaled it! We also ordered a couple sides of bacon to share because... well... BACON. It looked a bit different than how I'm used to seeing it though. I'm guessing it was just prepared differently because it tasted fine! All the food was good (see pictures). Everything was prepared how we asked.-Service- Our server was the cutest little thing! She was so sweet and she even filmed the mannequin challenge for us LMAO! My receipt says her name is Gina, so I hope that's right. She was great! -Price- Very reasonable pricing for the amount of food you get plus 90 minutes of bottomless mimosas-Did Not Like- I wish there were more options on the brunch menu-Noteworthy- Gina! If you're reading this, YOU ROCK!-Recommended?- Yes! I'd like to come back here for dinner!

This Sushi Burrito Is amazing and Really Impressed!I went in here about an hour before closing on Friday on my walk to the subway and saw sushi burrito and needed to try this. When i got inside it look like your typical fast casual restaurant style but has a very cool piece of artwork the size of the wall. The guy at the counter was really nice in explaining to me the different types of Sushi Burritos people get and the best options to put inside for what I like.In the end I got a white rice, Atlantic salmon, tobanjan mayo (spicy mayo), carrot and daikon pickled, cucumber, and tempura crunch. It was extremely delicious and flavorful and hit the spot perfectly and because I checked in on the Yelp App I got a free ginger green tea which was extremely fresh and refreshing.In short:- Delicious sushi burrito- Great service

Collective gasps from an audience are always a great way to start a show. Enter Liev, stage left and it was hard to keep your eyes off of the man we have all come to expect such great talent from. Janet McTeer was witty and a delight to watch, almost prancing, about the stage. The supporting cast also held their own. It was my personal thrill to see Ora Jones cast as Madame de Volanges, and Birgitte Sorenson (from Pitch Perfect 2) was somehow able to make Madame de Tourvel a likeable character.The play itself was moved along with unexpected humor, but as true drama was able to captivate the audience with dark silences and brooding moments of expectation. I walked in wanting to like this play and found myself enjoying it despite its excesses in length. Whoever said all seats lead to favorable views told a small fib. Front and center or mezzanine center works best for this play. Despite this, I rather enjoyed the glimpses into the potential side rooms from my view up in the right mezzanine.That particular night, sometimes the accents injured the plot but by the time the intermission rolled around all was well. Bravo to Tom Scutt for wonderful costume and set designs along with very detailed and precise costume and jewelry accents. As for most Broadway plays, having a slight familiarity with the plot made the production much more enjoyable. The flaws were greatly overcast by the successes and I definitely recommend taking a gander at this play of subtle repartee.

If you have never stumbled into 10 Degrees before, you might want to rethink your path through the neighborhood. This place gets more full than your belly after your third serving of Thanksgiving stuffing, but when 2-for-1 on **any** drink is up for grabs, you expect it. Just suck it up and suck down your drink. This includes beer, specialty cocktails AND pours of straight liquor so wiggle into a seat (if you can) and hunker down for a few rounds. It is well worth it. Plus, the 2-4-1 is all week long (12-8) so if you prefer an earlier Saturday to avoid the crowds, then do it up! The food is also pretty delicious. I enjoyed the guac as a table starter. Their sliders are delicious and perfect belly padding for the alcohol you've been pouring down your gullet. There is table service if you've been lucky enough to snag a seat but sometimes when the place is particularly packed, you may have a hard time grabbing a server. Ours was pretty amazing the last time we were there. She was weaving through the hoards of people like a champion of non-spillage.

Gem of a cafe located on the second floor of the popular Polo Ralph Lauren store no 5th ave. A great place to retreat from the shopping madness of 5th ave. They offer a large variety of coffee and tea drinks in addition to baked goods and prepared sandwiches and lunch items. The decor and atmosphere is perfect for studying or catching up with a friend. Skip the starbucks and stop in here next time you're getting your shop on on 5th ave!

We came here with a large group of friends (about 12). Usually this is no easy feat to get seating for 12 people at a cocktail bar in lower Manhattan. Thus the reason why we ventured up this far. We did want to try their butter infused cocktail but unfortunately they were out of it. The service here was pretty good too! And we sat on a very interesting looking wood table which looked like it was carved out of a tree. The drinks were amazing as was the ambiance. I would recommend coming here!

This Le Pain is located near where I go to church. It's very convenient before or after I attend. If you've read one of my Le Pain reviews it's pretty much the same. I love the quality food, service and friendly welcoming employees. There was a time when I was obsessed with the salad at Le Pain. After a time I found the same quality elsewhere for less. The food is very good. I've been to several of their locations. If you go during peak hours the dining becomes an adventure. I really don't like rubbing elbows with someone I don't know while I'm eating. These days when I go to Le Pain it is for the pastry counter. I get a little sweet treat and take it home. In summary it is a very nice neighborhood dining experience. It's a matter of personal taste and in my case budget!

When my friends planned a happy hour at a place called Bua, I didn't like the name. Plus they only had bar food and I needed a meal. Coming from friends who are bar regulars at One on One (they do sit outside though.), I wasn't expecting much.I was actually shocked at how cute Bua was, with its wooded Portland Oregon Pub interior, and bar menu that looked enticing. The place had a certain non urban newer hominess about it, sans a few NYC denizen behaviours - A. 2 separate people with laptops each occupying the entire 4 top patio tables, with not an ounce of guilt, andB. 3 young woman holding a banal conversation at mega plus decibels that was impossible not to be immersed in. The sound of their voices were so loud it hurt. Well, cie la vie right?  Live and let live I suppose. Although eventually they left, and the bright light shone - $15 wine carafes for happy hour. I picked the Côte de Rhone, was I dreaming ? Perhaps, it was sunny, and I got a table by the open air patio window.When the bartender asked me if I only wanted one glass for the carafe the idea of needing two glasses for the carafe was a concept I couldn't grasp. "Just the carafe". I responded out of synch.I ordered the brussel sprout salad, which actually tasted healthy, although id be more inclined to call it a kale salad with grilled brussel sprouts. And it's only $9. (That's two cokes at the MOMA cafe or 4 single razors at a LES bodega.). The salad was fresh and delightful with sliced apples. Man I went through that carafe like it was water. I would've ordered another one but I had an art opening to attend. Bua has a homey charm of a cool pub in a cool college town.  It also manages to be happily no frills but still has a conscience and serves a good product.  Bar food highlights - Brussel sprout kale salad, burger, and fried cheese curds (which sounds wonderful and gross all at once.)15 wine carafes 3-8pm.Small place with a patio.

An experience unlike any I've had in New York City.I've never been to a critically acclaimed restaurant in New York where no one rushes you. Forget about rushing to take away your plates or rushing to present you with a bill, accompanied by the fake "no rush" aside, no one bothers you at all should you be doing nothing other than just shooting the breeze with your dining companions (we were there for an hour after our meal was complete). True, there wasn't a long line of customers waiting to be seated, but even in the 10 minutes that someone was actually waiting for a table, no one even walked near our table to message us subliminally :) The whole meal felt leisurely paced as it would in the Indian subcontinent, not Manhattan.At the same time, true to a meal in the Indian subcontinent, the smell of spices permeated the air inside this small Nepali restaurant, should that bother people who like well ventilated spaces. I expect it shouldn't, because most of the diners here would have followed the reputation of Dhaulagiri Kitchen from Jackson Heights (where they were initially located), particularly after the glowing NY Times review a few years back.For those unfamiliar with the cuisine, ordering a Thali is the most efficient way to sample as much as you can. We focused instead on ordering a bunch of "appetizers", as they are described on the menu even if the quantity is greater than what one expects from appetizers. Two of the appetizers were more like evening snacks: Dum Aloo (potatoes with red peppers, turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger, garlic) and Sandheko Waiwai (ramen noodles that have been fried with green pepper, onions, cilantro, scallion and served with a wedge of lime). They were both spicy, not terribly so but still my friend had some trouble managing the heat. Be warned, for some reason this was the 1st restaurant I've been to where no one warned about the spice level of the food assuming we could handle it.These (4.5 stars) snacks were followed by Sukuti beef, that seemed like beef jerky that had been stewed for a while so as to be both chewy and pliant. I liked it (4 stars), though my friend didn't rate it as highly. The dish that wasn't high on the spice index was Chicken Chow Mein, which reminded me of the way noodles are cooked in the Indian subcontinent. The heat index didn't discomfort us one bit, and the noodles were very flavorful.The only let down in the menu were the vegetable momos. Now granted the server had recommended chicken instead, but I didn't have any expectations in the first place as I just don't find momos particularly interesting as far as dumplings go: their texture is chewy, almost rubbery and there is absolutely no juice inside when you bite into them. So, texturally and taste wise I'm not a fan of momos anywhere.But, I am a fan of Dhaulagiri Kitchen. Food was boldly flavored, authentically spiced (not dumbed down, or amped up unnaturally as in Handy Nasty), and freshly prepared. I was bummed not to be able to get the doughnut looking bread, sel roti, but they'd run out of it when we got there. Our meal for two cost $40 before tips and so really wallet friendly as well. The restaurant is open late (till 2 am), so if the Murray Hill crowd is looking for a late night meal featuring a spice challenge - definitely stop by.

The dessert trend of late has skewed heavily towards Thai-rolled ice cream and egg waffles, so it's hard for me to clearly distinguish one new dessert shop versus another. Pink Bear, a small storefront aptly located just east of Union Square, recently opened this past summer, and has seen its fair share of acclaim.There's a lot of good things Pink Bear has going for it, including a solid offering of ice cream bases and flavors, as well as an array of (hypothetically) unlimited toppings to choose from. You have your pick of tapioca and mochi cubes, sliced strawberries and pineapples, Teddy Grahams and wafers, sprinkles and syrups... the possibilities are only limited by the space available in your ice cream bowl, as well as the balancing skills of your ice cream maker. The final price of $7 includes tax, so payment is a short and simple process. If you happen to lean more towards an Egg Waffle Ice Cream, it's only a dollar more for an equally appealing treat.On the chilly and rainy evening we stopped by, there were only a few other guests present, so were able to quickly enter, skim the menu, and place our order. There's just shy of ten or so tempting ice cream bases, including Green Tea and Strawberry (Matcha Shawty), Thai Iced Tea and Lychee (Tang Thaied), Mango and Vanilla (Mango Tango), but we opted to go with the Brewtiful Morning, which utilizes a Vietnamese Coffee base, and watched as our server worked the ice cream base into a thin sheet on the anti-griddle, and proceeded to roll it into six even swirls of ice cream. When it came time to select the toppings, he made sure to pause numerous times to make sure we had listed out all of our desired ingredients.Unfortunately, the space at Pink Bear isn't large; the counter seats near the entrance can only accommodate four people, and a small bench against the wall can seat two people as well. In the summer, this isn't much of an issue as most people can take their treats to go, or even eat outside, but I imagine it'll be an inconvenience once the weather makes a sharp turn downwards in the colder months.
