Nonetheless, it's a friendly environment that provides plenty to see (although the constant making of ice cream can get noisy), and the staff were kind enough to let us try a few test flavors they were making, including an avocado-pistachio, which will hopefully make its way on the menu soon.If you happen to be in the area and looking for something to satisfy your sweet tooth, Pink Bear is well-worth a visit. Given the less-than-average wait and the fact that there is no minimum on card, it makes it even more difficult to turn down.

Decided to give this new soul food spot a try and I wasn't disappointed. The inside of the restaurant is very spacious, they have a full bar as well as happy hour specials (50 cent wings and $5 drinks), TVs everywhere which is definitely a plus, the music and ambiance were also great! The service was also very attentive and friendly. We ordered the sweet/sour and Hennessey wings to start, they were both good but I preferred the sweet/sour. For our main course we had fried shrimp with mac & cheese and candied yams, along with the fried catfish with greens and potato salad. The food came out rather quickly and was delicious. I was actually impressed. For dessert we had the banana pudding and that was amazing too! Needless to say that I'll be back, hopefully the service and the food stay at the same or higher quality.

Kidnapping Korean mammas so they can cook for you would be considered execrable in any civilized society. So Woorijip is here to keep fill the void in your stomach. The food here may not be authentic Korean mamma quality, despite the name, but if you don't know one, and want fast, convenient food you can eat in or take out, you can avail yourself of the wide range of food here. There are prepackaged foods, from cold pickles, to soups, to rice to entrees to choose from. The salad and hot food buffet serves many of the same food in the packages, though you can pick and choose what you want and have fun trying foods you've never tasted. Arshi K. was indeed correct in stating there are many vegetarian options, a bonus. Everything usually looks fresh, and mostly is, probably due in part to the high turnover. I been here numerous times and have never had a bad meal here. My fish the other day was actually tender and moist, which if you know grilled mackerel isn't always an easy feat. Eat in paper containers are free, take out plastic ones will cost you. Water is free. There are tables for eat in, though at busy hours they might enforce the time limit they state. It's not a place for lingering anyway, too much traffic, too much noise. My favorite here is the fresh squid salad in chili sauce, with enough garlic to scare Dracula into converting to Christianity. I also like the jap chae, the futomaki, and the tofu stew over the kimchi fried rice. This place was a staple when I went to school close by. It's a fun place to eat, because of all the variety here. And depending on what you choose, the food can be quite good.

As you may know from my review of The District, I am now fully back on the horse and dating.I went on a first date here last night, and I gotta say, most of these reviews are pretty on the nose. It is like a speakeasy meets haunted mansion. I want to live there.My date and I arrived around 7:30pm to a nearly empty bar. We were told to sit wherever and the decision was basically between a bunch of options where there are two chairs and a coffee table. I think it is similar to Madam Puddifoot's in Harry Potter--aka where Harry and Cho Chang go on their date and Cho cries into her cup of coffee because she misses Cedric and Roger Davies also asked her out, btw. What I mean by this comparison is that The Auction House was clearly designed for couples. But what's weird is that the chairs are mostly side-by-side. I just met this guy, I am trying to look at his face, not hold his hand. We sat in a corner, on what can best be described as two thrones. This chair I was sitting in made me feel so regal, so elegant, so....tiny (that's a good thing). Kind of in-theme, my date and I discussed all the normal things: jobs, families, cannibalism. He was funny, I was funny. I started with a sweet and smokey, which was a little too sweet, not enough smokey. I knew I would be hungover if I continued that route, so I switched to chardonnay.The specialty cocktails are $12My date drank Jack which was $7I think the wine was $7We spent about 2 and a half hours there, and then my date walked me home. We hugged goodnight and are now planning a second date.

I had been wanting to check out Ferrara since I moved back to NY. I had heard so much about this legendary bakery, so I had high expectations. A few of their goodies were on display behind the counter, but I was expecting more, way more. I ordered the pistachio gelato, which was a miss for me, but the lobster claw was delicious. But again, it was nothing so original that it warranted coming all the way to Little Italy. Had a taste of my friend's chocolate cake and it was very rich and dense.Service was decent, though our waitress was very pushy about ordering the lobster claw, which I was going to order anyway. Sadly, my coffee was cold before it even got to our table. Kind of pricey for just dessert. If you come here, come for the novelty more than anything else.

These are all the things I wish someone told me before I came here - - You WILL be walking/standing/running/stair climbing the ENTIRE time. WEAR COMFORTABLE SHOES. - The actors will not talk. Ever. - There is a storyline...try your hardest to figure it out. And when you do, can you tell me what it is? - The characters will walk away... you can follow them! Chase them! See what they're doing! Or you can just walk around the entire time... I didn't find chasing them particularly rewarding, I did however just walk into scenes and found that more enjoyable. - Sequence of events: Walk in, get you jacket/bagged check for ($4).. bring cash/credit and put in your pocket, go upstairs to bar area, drink bar drinks, go in elevator, be set loose into the hotel floors to walk around and do/view as you wish. This is an "interactive" play (interactive being loosely applied). The characters are mulling around 3-4 floors in this hotel and the you walk around watching / walking into scenes that are happening. It's up to you to piece it together. There is no guide. The scenery, in my opinion, was one of the best parts. It was really beautiful scenery!! You can not take photos so I'm not sure how useful it is to have your phone (if you don't have a pocket) after bag check ($4).

Oh the cronut. If you don't want to wait in line or take the chance that they will run out you can pre-order in advance. Every Monday at 11:00 am they open up the website so you can login and pick an exact date and time to reserve your cronuts 2 weeks in advance. The website crashed on me twice but keep refreshing and you should eventually be able to check out with PayPal.PICKING UP - when you get there, you don't have to stand in the line that's ordering. You can walk right up to a cashier and pick up the cronuts. It seems a little weird because people will assume you are cutting but just go for it. You also don't have to print out the little sheet or show any ID, just tell them your name. I also don't think you have to go there right on time because they didn't check or care that we were a little late.ATMOSPHERE: pretty small inside but they have a cute little garden, which is nice to eat your cronut. There's both a covered section and an outside section with a grass wall.CRONUT - each month they have a different flavor and thats the only flavor you can get. For October 2016 it was Caramelized Banana and Dulce de Leche. The cronut itself was a little disappointing. It wasn't as flaky and fluffy as I was expecting, perhaps because it was supposed to be donut and croissant it had to be a little doughy. It almost tasted like a slightly stale croissant. I also wasn't expecting there to be cream/filling in between some of the layers.  Overall, it was good but not mind blowing.DKA - this was amazing. It's a crispy, crunchy croissant type of pastry on the outside but inside is soft and chewy and moist. Very good and definitely worth getting, they don't run out of these so if you miss out on a cronut, it's okay.Overall, definitely worth trying but reserve in advance because I don't think it's worth waiting at 6 or 7am for. Also, make sure to try the DKA.

This dim sum joint is a hidden gem. Go here over Jing Fong and Golden Unicorn if you want real value and no wait. Well the wait can accumulate but my fiancé and I came around 11am on a Sat and were seated right away. The restaurant isn't big, and we wished our favorites like the turnip cake and tofu fan were readily available but we didn't stay long either. We had the typical tasty crystal shrimp, veggie dumplings, shrimp rice rolls (they have themwith the Chinese congee bread here which is a plus), really good sticky rice, fresh and cheap greens (ordered from menu - normally a premium at most places). Think that was all. We also saw but didn't get : char siu Bao, all the sweets that are fried, plenty of Chinese ordering chow mein etc and other stuff from the menu, congee, trip (bleh) and other usual stuff. Definitely recommend. Seems to be popular among the locals. Our meal came to just over $20.

The Palm court is located inside the plaza hotel. I usually come to the Palm court for high tea when I have friends visit. Although the Palm court is not my go to for high tea it is proper and Elegant enough for tea. I have been here for lunch and for dinner. There 2 completely different experiences! The service is always good for tea. The pastry are always very nice compliment to a good cup. I was here a month ago with my ex and here mom for tea and it was very nice. Recently the Palm court renovated and put a huge bar in the middle of the room. I have been here for drinks a few times with friends. The chances of you running into a local here are slim to non. Mostly tourists are at the hotel. The service during dinner time is good. They do not offer a happy hour. I usually order scotch. The last time I came here I ordered a 18yr old mccallan it was $46 for 1 shot. I bought my cousin a drink and it was $25 for a house cocktail. Now I'm from the city. I eat everywhere and drink everywhere. Normally I order 18yr old. It's cheaper in other places just as nice if not nicer on the UES. The $25 for my cousins drink was normal price usually specialty cocktails cost anywhere from $19-26 a drink. Granted. The drinks are fantastic. The food we got I also thought was expensive. For dinner. You can't win them all lolOverall. I will continue to come to the Palm court for high tea. Prob not for drinks anymore. I prefer the tea service hands down over the late night drinks. The drinks are amazing here just expensive. I do recommend trying the Palm court.

Good addition to the West Village.Their tag line is "Light, fresh, Asian", which describes them (and me!) perfectly. Anyone familiar with ShopHouse Kitchen (the Asian fusion Chipotle), Vien is a clone of that, which isn't a bad thing: pick a starch, pick a meat (or two or three), and pick some toppings.We ordered a metric shit-ton of food from them, and everything was punch full of flavor. From the fresh cut pineapples, carrot radish pickles, and various sauces to their lemongrass chicken, ginger beef, fatty pork (my favorite), and spice roasted veggies, there was something for everyone.

When you noticed that the after work line is all female, without a shadow of doubt, you know that the food is proper to bring home. It seems that the seafood is the top pick. I noticed how the salmon was glistening in its tropical sauce. It called to me. But everyone was choosing the fried crab and prawns, as a side dish. I joined the line by the front door. That pan was swapped out before I paid for my food. Very popular! The reach in cooler for the drinks was not cold. I grabbed the pineapple ginger and pink Ting and was alarmed. Good thing I noticed a cooler behind the counter. A sorrel and an Irish Moss filled the order. The takeout line moved as fast as the 2/5 trains dropped people off. From entry to exit took about nine minutes. It was a little pricey. But I would have dropped that much in a bistro. My salmon was moist. A nice five ounce portion, coupled with a sticky pumpkin rice, and crisp cabbage and carrot medley. No complaints.Got two servings out of it. And will return.

I know it's been around for a long time, but I still like the Frying Pan. Just like any place there are good points and bad, but for me, the good still outweigh the bad.First, it is one of the few places you can drink on the water in the City. In all 5 boroughs there are maybe a dozen places that let you do this. You come out to the Frying Pan on a nice day, and you get to sit outdoors watching the Hudson, and have clear views of the FiDi skyline.Drink and food prices are not unreasonable, with pitchers of beer about $24, pitchers of sangria at $37, and burger and fries at $12.The downside here is the crowd that normally frequents this joint. The loud, early-20s, party crowd smells like spray tan and axe body spray. If that's your scene great, but I generally prefer more sophisticated company.If you are lucky, you can get a good spot on the boat to sit and relax away, daydreaming whilst looking out on the river, but the bar is back on the pier so make sure you have somebody watch your spot when you get a refill.

Diaspora: 1. Derived from the Greek verb diaspeirō, "I scatter". *I was born in the US, but they say I'm not American because.My parents were born in Vietnam, troi oi!, but they say they are not Vietnamese because. My grandparents were born in China, but they say they are not Chinese, 太厉害 了!If I open a restaurant selling burgers, some Yelpers might saySTAY AWAY FROM THESE CROOKS. She's not even American. She's not speaking English.She must not think American thoughts.She must not have American feelings.She must have no denial.She must have no fear.2. The movement of the population from its original homeland. *Stef H. says STAY AWAY FROM THESE CROOKS. They're not even Vietnamese. Cindy T. spreads about her tongue on #39A:grilled lemongrass pork shoulder banh mi. Tastes the food of womb, before it was numbered.Tastes like Saturdays, when my parents could afford to buy meat.Cindy T. dips her memories into Saiguette's nuoc mam:tastes like White fear of fish sauce,tastes like the spirit of fierce young girls, watered down.3. Historical mass dispersions of an involuntary nature, such as the expulsion of Jews from Judea, the fleeing of Greeks after the fall of Constantinople, the African Trans-Atlantic slave trade, the southern Chinese or Hindus of South Asia during the coolie trade, the Irish during and after the Irish Famine, the displacement of Palestinians in the 20th century. *How dare they use English words on their menu.That's not authentic!How dare you say that this is #3when it is obviously cha giò--might as well call it minced pork sausageor the dead men in our families.How dare they have absolutely no comfortable seating.That's not authentic!America is rich and dreamywith infinite spaces to steal.-----* Wikipedia-----Tips:- GET: dumplings (any kind), banh mi- SKIP: bun (noodle salad)

Quaint little movie theater in the heart of Bronxville. At one time it may have been independent, but now it's part of Bow Tie Cinemas - a regional chain with locations primarily in the northeast US. This is really no-frills movie-going. With only three theaters, you can imagine the place is small. The box office is immediately to your right upon entering, followed by a small concession stand and the theaters. Overall, a good alternative to the big-box multiplexes in Yonkers. You won't find every movie playing here, but if they're showing something you want to see it's a nice place to take in a picture.

Sometimes more than not, there may be a reason to skip dessert, but ChikaLicious is something you may want to leave room for. This is a tiny, cute spot for any sweets/desserts fan. We went after an early dinner in the East Village on a Sunday. Anticipating that there may be a wait, there actually was none. The entire bar, however, was nearly reserved, but luckily with two free seats available. If anything, you will want to sit at the bar if you can because part of the enjoyment will come from watching them at work, creating really what are works of delicious art. They prepare these with such precision and care but with an apparent level of expertise. Certainly a pleasure to watch.There is the option of a pre-fixe ($16), which is what we each had ordered. This includes Amuse bouche, choice of dessert, and Petits Fours. Wine pairing is $9 additional, but I didn't opt for this. For dessert, we chose the Fromage Blanc Island "Cheese Cake" and Warm Chocolate Tartwith Pink Peppercorn Ice Cream and Red Wine Sauce. I definitely recommend the Fromage Blanc. It is their signature dessert, with a unique preparation, presentation and wonderful flavor. The Warm Chocolate Tart is a great dish for those who particularly like chocolate desserts. I really enjoyed the peppercorn ice cream. The red wine sauce was a nice touch.ChikaLicious desserts are super unique. Off the menu, it might sound ordinary, but it really goes beyond that. If you want a cute spot that offers simple, yet experimental desserts, try ChikaLicious. This spot is great for the serious sweet tooth looking for something good yet reasonably priced to indulge in. For $16, the pre-fixe is certainly not bad for the amount served. I highly recommend the bar too so you can see the chef in action.

Salinas is a luxurious restaurant in Chelsea. Salinas brings a high level of Spanish cuisine to a neighborhood saturated with old school & new school Spanish. The scent of fresh flowers hits you when you enters what feels like a private club.There is a library like dining room with a retractable roof,Ate:Pica PicaSoft shell crabs with ramps and artichokesRoast baby suckling pigDrank- Vega Chardonnay The food was magnificent- the dips were so flavorful, but the one criticism would be to see a higher level bread with the dips. Otherwise, the pig was a show stopper- made to order with milky meat and crispy skin with a hint of rosemary- orgasmic! Knowledgeable service.

You know how I know a salad is good? It's when I'm actually eating the lettuce- NOT BY FORCE, but because it's actually tasty. This place makes damn good salads... and tri tip (obviously!)Of course I'd get the Tri Tip salad with roadhouse onions and blue cheese decor. Portions were SUPER GENEROUS and that tri tip was cooked to a perfect medium rare. The greens were so well-coated in ranch, I found my fork maneuvering through the meats and toppings and straight for the lettuce! Granted that ranch doesn't make it any healthier, it still made me feel good and that's all that matters... Right? The place is small and finding a seat was only a slight challenge despite not being crowded that day. Not too big a deal though since there's also an indoor food court and the outside world as options. If the prices weren't so hard on my wallet, I'd come here everyday!

Cool spot in the West Village.The lady and I were looking for a post-dinner cocktail one Saturday evening not too long ago. My friend mentioned Employees Only was worth checking out, and it turned out we were nearby. Seemed like the no-brainer option, and we ended up having a good experience.This lounge has a speakeasy feel to it. The storefront has a fluorescent "psychic" sign in one of the windows and the establishment's symbol (looks like a sideways EO) on the awning. Walk inside, past the psychic (who's actually working), and through the covered entrance to find the bar. We showed up around 9:30/10:00, and there was a bouncer outside with a very short line. He was friendly, and we were let in within 5 minutes of showing up. Reservations can only be made if you're having dinner.The space inside is nice. There's a bar and limited table seating in the front and a lounge with more table seating towards the back up a short flight of stairs. While there was no line outside, the place was packed. Standing space was tight so we stood by the fireplace for a bit until some seats at the bar became available. The crowd was lively, ranging from friends grabbing dinner to drunken first encounter make-out sessions. Needless to say, it made for some good people-watching.The cocktails were solid. The servers carried themselves professionally, making an array of alcoholic concoctions for a large crowd with ease. I tried the Quiet Storm (bourbon based), while the lady tried the Provencal (gin based). Both drinks were refreshing and well crafted. There is also two food menus (dinner and late night), but we did not try anything since we were coming from dinner.I would come back again to try their food or grab another drink. Check it out!

I live for their fried unicorns of love. These wings aren't JUST wings, they're WANGS...the epitome of cool, chic and NY downtown. Who cares about the rest of the menu, Gyna. I'm here for one thing only: fried chicken. Everything else is just bells, whistles and misses.This is just like the sister spot in K-town, in terms of the chicken. The vibe, however, is not even close to the odd, lovable, K-Pop world that is Turntable Mad for Chicken/Chicken Jazz (or whatever they call it now) on 5th ave. Why does that spot keep changing their name? I digress. I was here for one of the HH specials, which was basically a choice of wings or drums, an app and an entree, for $24. They're small plates and it's a decent deal considering this is the place that has the nerve to charge 48$ for basically a pitcher of coors light served in a lava lamp dispenser just because they can. The lowdown-Drinks:I had the HH soju shot and beer ( again, see horrible pic for ref). The lame, tiny, mug filled 3/4 of the way is just, blah. I'm not a soju drinker. I'm also not a, "throw the glass in the glass" and slam it kind of dude. Pass. The "bar" is odd, because it isn't one. (Alexander) Wangs: ... the chicken here is exactly the same as the midtown spot: extremely, super-duper flavorful, spicy and crispy without being greasy. These wings are so good, it makes me question humanity... and velcro, at the same time. The only reason I don't eat these everyday is that it would kill you. Then again, so can a cab or a falling AC unit. Main:The Kim Chi fried rice with the fried egg on top is better then sex. Not really, but it's close. I need this in my life...everyday. And by that I mean sex, not this, because white rice is bad for you. No racial. App: The Beef Bulgogi (see lame pic that's attached ). Great flavor flav, but a little too chewy and dry. Might have been an off night though, because I was told it's always good here. A possible remix is in the future. The stools:WTF is up with the small ass chairs? I have no ass, but those stools can barely rest one of my boney ass cheeks. Awkward. Can you imagine what would happen if a Kardashian had to sit on that? GET WIDER STOOLS, before someone gets hurt. Service:Professional and attentive, although the place was only 1/4 full. Not that it matters, but they also don't have K-Pop cast offs here either like the other spot. No real Bar: This, & their crazy non HH $, is gonna be this place's downfall. Their original joint has, and it's the first thing you see, so I don't get their "after thought" of a bar here. The rest of the food just isn't good enough for me to keep coming back and they way they designed the dining area is the way a bar does, an afterthought. They serve bar food but no bar? A bar sets the tone and the tone here is soulless, which is ironic for a Korean joint. Would I come here again? Duh, but only at HH, because I live for fried chicken...especially these Korean Fried Chicken Wangs. Yes, you could get two buckets of chicken at Popeyes with sides and feed a family of 12 for what you pay here, but that's like comparing Uniqlo to Alexander Wang, it's apples and bowling balls. Turntable's Wangs are worth every penny. The rest of this place, not so much.

A hidden gem in the Hamilton Heights neighborhood. I'm knocking it to 4 stars only because the track isn't maintained in the winter. Also, the bathrooms: emergencies yes, otherwise avoid. But that's pretty standard for a rec center. I'm a runner, so I typically utilize the track area. It can get a little crowded depending on the weather & day. But, I find it kind of fun to dodge flying soccer balls & children while I'm running. It's like a video game. Running in a giant circle is a lot more exciting that way! There's also plenty of space around the park in general, so you can run & get a great view of the river if you wish. Pools, gyms, picnic areas, skating rinks in the winter... and no (or at least, few) tourists! So happy to have you, Riverbank!

Eataly, how I describe thee:Children : Walt Disney World :: Foodies : EatalyRemember analogies from school?So when I visited Eataly on opening day, crowded would be a understatement. I waited on a line that snaked and turned. I managed to purchase some focaccia. Dang it, I know where I am going to feed my bread addiction. I work upstairs and this Eataly is just too close. I am mad that it is so accessible now to feed my bread addiction. There are all kinds of carb here. The bread with fig in it was pretty tasty. I was so tempted to get a loaf but I think next time will be better since I got two slices of focaccia already....I mean....it's like an alcoholic living next to the liquor store or bar, woe-is-me.I admit it, it's super fun in here, albeit expensive. There is some seating but for the amount of people that come through, there is not a lot of seating unless you go to one of the sit down restaurants. There are some take out stations, like at a food court but much more upscale.The layout at 4 WTC feels better than the layout at the other Eataly in the Flatiron District. The location at the Flatiron district is a little too chaotic for me. Like their Flatiron location, they do not want you to hang out too long unless you are at one of their sit-down restaurants.

Called to see if I needed to make a reservation for a Monday afternoon. Chris at the bar mentioned that weekends it gets very busy and we should be fine.If you want to have an afternoon Tea experience, definitely try out Two E Bar/Lounge. Have been to the Pierre Hotel long time ago in the past and things have certainly changed. The Pierre is a beautiful hotel right across from the entrance to Central Park. Much need break for my mom who has been taking care of my sick dad for the past 6 months and this was a treat for her. Get nicely dressed up and have some time to ourselves as well as a break from it all. This was just perfect. Thomas was our server and provided great service- Walked us through the whole process of Royal Tea Service. Gave us good suggestions when it came to selecting our pot of tea. We went for The Pierre Blend and The Lapsang Souchong (Smoky Flavor)The three tier tea stand came out with Tea Sandwiches on the top. The Pumpernickel bread was a bit salty- Salmon was good.My favorite was the Spiced Chicken TartletMiniature dates & Babaganoush Crepe was creamyMiddle tier had the scones and buttered cookies. Like using both the Lemon Curd and Devonshire Cream.Bottom tier had pastries-blueberry & raspberry tarts, macaroons, and chocolate madelines just to name a few.It was a hidden oasis for the time spent here. We were not rushed and Thomas came back to check up on us to see if we need more hot water.It is a level of sophistication that you definitely need to experience. Felt like we were in the grey room/parlor.

It was great. It was hot. Deliciousness. So good after every bite, you pull in the perfect ratio of layers and scarf it down while trying to make the moment last. Juicy. Burgers are AH-MAZING!!!!! Seriously, I don't know why they even have the hot sauces and such out. Ketchup, however, was a delight when dipping those hot onion rings. These rings were filled with real onions, so bonus points for quality. Milkshakes are just thick enough, and lemonades just-so tart. Perfection.Flaws: No access to a bathroom. But the real flaw is that I cannot figure out why this place doesn't have greater capacity for seating? I would definitely recommend and plan to return.

IT'SSSS SCCCIENCEE!!!I'm no science whiz but when I hear nitro, coffee, and de-con-structed... I'm like babe, we're going to Coffee Project ASAP. We ordered the coffee float, and the nitro flight. The whole experience was kind of whimsical, the staff are exceptionally knowledgable which made the tasting that much more interesting.Pinkies up! Because this coffee joint my friends, is not your average cup of joe.

Nyonya has solidly earned an extra star! Tried their chicken wings and the raved about Beef Rendang. My good GOD were those some of the most DIVINE (see what I did there?! ;-) wangs I have had in a LONG time! Tender, juicy, PERFECTION in the seasoning department, just the right amount and kind of sticky, and that sweet onion chutney!!!And then there was that beef.....I gave it some side eye when I first saw how much I received for the price I paid....until I did that first fork pull of that tender, though still a bit of firm, nailed temperature beef....and that AMAZING curry.....which paired so well with the coconut rice as to get a "goodt Godt DANGIT!" from me!Ohm to the frickin' NOM, y'all!!!!! Get up in this ish!!!!!

No doubt Pasquale Jones is good. I was not quite as impressed as I hoped, especially compared to Charlie Bird; however, I enjoyed the experience immensely. The pizza is great. Luckily, when I went, they had a truffle pizza special. Oh my god, I actually thought I was having an orgasm while I consumed each cheesy, crispy, truffly bite. This should totally be a regular menu item. While the clam pizza was very good, I didn't find it destination worthy. The rigatoni was pretty disappointing. The meat was tasty, but the pasta itself was not worth consuming. Like Charlie Bird, the wine selection is excellent. The staff is extremely knowledgeable and helped us select something that paired perfectly with our food and was exactly what we were looking for.The space is a bit cramped but the decor is welcoming. Moreover, I did not find the music selection to be quite Charlie Bird level either, but maybe that's just my love of 90s hip hop talking.

Joy Luck is a decent dim sum restaurant. Can't say much about banquet style dining during the regular week however the food is above par. Since having renovated from Grand Harmony, which it was before for many years prior, it's got a modern feel albeit, a bit stoic. Either way, they are busy at the hours you'd expect it to be for dim sum and not overly packed to the gills. I'm sure that will change in time as more people venture there over the other places throughout chinatown. Definitely worth a try over the other area restaurants I'm used to going to. The draw is definitely the custard buns in the shape of piggies as well as the carrot shaped offering.

This is one of the oldest speakeasies in the modern NYC Speakeasy scene, and it remains one of my favorites. Here's the deal. Call (212) 614-0386 the same day you want to go. Do not get discouraged. Redial until you get through. PDT opens at 6p daily. Enter through Crif Dogs, and a phone booth is on your left. Pick up the receiver, and give them your name. There may be a small wait even if you do have a reservation, but expect multiple hours of waiting if you don't have one. The beauty of PDT is that you can order from next door Crif Dogs while you're downing $16 cocktails. The cocktails are fantastic and delicious, as are the cheesy tater tots you can order from next door. A very impressive place to bring a date - especially you are in from out of town and it's a surprise experience for at least one of you.

I have been following the opening of this fine establishment via Harlem Bespoke blog and was anticipating it opening up. I love Starbucks but I love to support a local coffee shop in my neighborhood as well. Plus I feel like local coffee shops care more about the most important component of coffee....ESPRESSO and minus all the bells and whistles of a millions sweet syrups. This morning I was on my IG feed and saw a post mentioning they are open and serving breakfast. I decided to make it a mission to include them in my day. They are right at the corner of 135 and 7th ave and next door to the IHOP. The storefront has a very inviting appearance and the barista def greets you with a smile and a warm welcome. While waiting for the gentleman I peeping the scene in terms of food. The selection is very limited and I was looking for breakfast items they mentioned on IG but maybe I was expecting too much. In their display of food they had coffee bread , croissants, egg salad sandwich, turkey sandwich, and a pesto mozzarella sandwich. They do have the ability to heat all of these items which is awesome. The setup is pretty nice in which they have a large community table in the back and a couple benches for you to sit and enjoy your caffeine. Their hours are 7 days a week 7:30am-6pm, but I wish they were open a little earlier for those who want a cup of joe on our way to work.Anywho the final test was the coffee obviously and I ordered a mocha with soy milk. The barista, Valentina, prepared my drink and it was perfect. No need to add any thing extra to the drink.ACP Coffee is a great addition to the Harlem neighborhood and I will be back to frequent this business.

When I first moved to NYC, I went to restaurants with the mentality of ordering the fattiest thing on the menu - fries instead of salad, nachos all the time, bacon cheeseburgers, burritos with extra guac. Unfortunately, combining that with a desk job and an unavoidable aversion to the gym left me feeling like I needed a wheelbarrow and a manservant to get around. Which brings me to kale salads. Kefi's in particular. I used to be the world's biggest kale hater, even going so far as to fish out the bits of kale with a spoon whenever someone offered me a kale-fruit smoothie (which I've come around to), but I couldn't deny that eating a kale salad makes me more functional than chowing down on a burrito the size of a small baby. I think this is what adulthood (or becoming vastly more boring) means. But Kefi's kale salad is a glorious pile of greens, topped with small chunks of feta, watermelon (!), and walnuts. Not exactly super filling but that's what the small bin of complimentary bread ...And baklava are for. It's $9.75 so not exactly cheap but you do get a hefty triangle of multiple phyllo layers soaked in honey and studded with nuts. I thought it was a bit too syrupy-sweet but my cousin loved it. I also tried a little bit of the sheep's milk dumplings, and understood the hype as soon as I took my first bite - fluffy and warm and pairs perfectly with the slightly spicy sausage. The pasta portions are a little small, which is why they recommend adding a side. Broccoli rabe was just okay. When we asked if he could take our photo, the waiter kindly took several (and they all turned out not awkward at all). NEXT TIME: shrimp orzo, bronzino, Kefi salad

Bibble and Sip was a lovely spot for my friend and I to rest our tired feet and have a treat on her recent visit. After a Yelp search, the high number of positive reviews for this tiny cafe won me over. If so many people like it, it's got to be good, right? In this case, absolutely!The location is great for people who are trying to avoid "touristland" aka Time Square. Although my friend did want to walk the main strip of this hellish area, she didn't want to deal with the frantic buzz while just trying to have a cup of tea and pastry. Because Bibble and Sip is nice tucked away just on the outskirts of Time Square, we were able to enjoy our rest and treat with a little peace.Now...Bibble and Sip is super tiny. Not Levain tiny, but tiny enough that you get scrunched up in the line when you're trying to make your way to the register. Is it worth it? I'd say, yes, if you'd like a warm drink with a delicious sweet treat. From my experience, I highly recommend the bruléed egg tart. It balances sweet and savory nicely, and pairs really well with a cappuccino.

I can't believe that I didn't know about this place until recently. Custom Fuel is one of those places where you can get a really good personal pizza (and leftovers because the pizzas are large) for under $10. And yes, they have vegan cheese which I really appreciated.You walk in, order what you would like go around to see if you would like anything else extra (olive oil, parmesan cheese, all that jazz) and just wait. They also have a combo for a drink and some garlic rolls, which I ordered but they forgot to give me the garlic rolls. Otherwise, Custom Fuel is a great way to get your pizza customization on, or just add a bit of your own flare to the ones they already have.

I visited Rebelle's sister restaurant, Pearl & Ash, several years ago and despite the time and the myriad of dishes in-between, I still recall it as one of the most successful and memorable "small plates"-format meals I've had. When Rebelle opened shortly afterwards, I was (unsurprisingly) more than happy to join a few friends here for dinner. Similar to Pearl & Ash, the restaurant has a sleek yet comforting feel to it; the spacious bar makes it a perfect place for an impromptu drink and the dining area is both welcoming and simplistic. The menu is split into four sections that follow the suggested progression from lightest to heaviest of the savory courses, followed by dessert. It's simply a suggestion, however, so feel free to mix and match between courses. I started with the Lamb Tartare, a dish that balanced the gaminess of the protein with just the right amount of acidity and richness. A dotting of green chickpeas for extra brightness and crunch, the hidden espelette for spice, and the blend of olives and yogurt rounded out the Mediterranean flavors in each bite. It's served with a few slices grilled bread drizzled with olive oil, but make sure to ask for a second order of it in order to make the most out of the dish. Also worth noting is one of their most beautiful plates, the Scallop. Two perfectly seared portions of scallop are served with sliced turnips and apples, plated over a fragrant "green juice" and finished with fresh dill. It's, perhaps, a little gimmicky, but the flavors are both light and crisp, and the slight sweetness from the apple complements the scallop perfectly. The few bites from the Fluke and the Halibut that I stole were similarly delicious, and made me regret not ordering my own dish.For the wine lovers and connoisseurs, Rebelle has a top-notch wine program (thanks to their acclaimed wine director, Patrick Cappiello), so you'll be sure to find a selection to suit your tastes. I'm happy to also note that Rebelle was awarded one Michelin star shortly after their opening, and while I personally found the dishes at Pearl & Ash to be more successful, I can say that a dining experience at Rebelle won't disappoint either.

Le Bain is extremely pretentious. Let's just settle that. Now that we've established the fact that this place has a stick up its ass, it can actually be a surprisingly fun place. I've had a great time all three times I've been here, mostly owing to the eclectic mix of sights and sounds, including but not limited to:- A stunning rooftop view- A weird mix of eurotrash/older men dancing awkwardly, thin leggy model types standing there waiting for said men to buy them drinks, and lost and confused out of towners looking at the dance floor in a daze- The odd placement of a pool and the prospect of someone just diving in and mooning the crowdLe Bain is in Meatpacking for a reason. It's not nice. It's snobby. It's bumpin. It's sweaty. It's the epitome of the worst of NYC. Don't be a regular. Visit Le Bain once in a while to be delighted and disgusted at the same time. Just do yourself a favor and don't go sober.

The Quick: Absolutely phenomenal seafood (Peruvian food). Trendy yet romantic interior. Decent staff with an okay cocktail list. Overall 4 star experience with 5 star food. The Details: I dined here for restaurant week and will absolutely be returning to try more of their menu. The ceviches are incredible, you really cannot chose wrong. I had one of the rice dishes with octopus and calamari for my entrée - one of the most delicious things I've eaten in a long time. I highly recommend. That being said, my friend ordered the beet salad and the steak (the few nonseafood options) and was not salivating over every bite like I was. The Damage: Restaurant week is obviously very reasonable, but they have a mix of small plates, and appetizers which are mostly moderately priced.

WARNING!! you need to be in at least decent shape before you attempt this class. As in you exercise regularly and can handle 50 min of nonstop strenuous exercise such as other boot camps (at least..)I don't normally review exercise workouts, but I am making an exception for Tone House because it is that insane and I want put an additional word out there that this is definitely not for the faint of heart. As many people have said, this is a level of its own. As close to torture I will probably ever get...maybe even worse than childbirth...not that I would know at this point. I consider myself a regular class pass-er now and in order to prepare myself for my first session, I went to Barry's and Warrior Boot Camp. Although Barry's and Warrior's were extremely intense in their own way, there were modifications to the exercises that you could do and you could rest at your own pace. So they gave a semblance that everything is within reach. Here at Tone House, it is do or die. There is no giving up...and I don't know if at some point I was actually seeing red or the color was coming from the lit room. The lightning speed at which we were expected to move made me want to give up every step of the way as I was still catching my breath from the warmup...oh god the warmup. I read that the warm-up was bad and I braced myself in the beginning..but I couldn't brace myself for the fact that for the entire rest of the session I felt like I was holding up the team....While I rested...I watched those with extremely defined muscles move like animals on a hunt..it was insane...animals I tell you. Tamara (my instructor for the class) refused to let any of us cheat and for the whole entire time motivated us to perform at full level. Even after reading countless reviews, I don't think anything can prepare you for the beast that is Tone House that it will eat you alive. I did not feel the intimidation of the class until I saw what we were supposed to do next..then again..then another set..all in the flash of an eye. I was always the last to finish, which I expected. I wouldn't feel so bad if I didn't feel like I was holding the class up...I did feel good that I was able to accomplish most (ok half..maybe a third) of all the exercises but I feel like I was just in shock because I was just trying to catch up the entire time. Personally for me, I did not feel like the class got any easier and I don't like to give up....but obviously I was not in good enough shape. I never ran a marathon (let alone half marathon) and I don't go to bootcamp/HIIT classes regularly. Like I go to the girly girl classes like Chaise and maybe an occasional kickboxing class. Also I had a bagel with cream cheese that morning from Russ and Daughters.....It was the closest I felt like throwing up from any of my classpass classes...and there was that heckling cough that came afterwards that a lot of the other reviewers mentioned..my body was just in shock. All in all, I don't think I will be back until I am in dramatically better shape and mentally prepared again to handle this level of torture. For those military style fitness fanatics out there that are seeking for more than your average personal training session, I highly recommend this place. This is definitely an unforgettable experience to say the least...Even a day later, I think my brain is still in the process of catching up to what happened to my body.

The amazing, grass-fed Greek yogurt alone makes Greecologies a destination spot. The well-lit, loungey yogurt bar and cafe serves on-site, homemade Greek yogurt that proves even healthier than your normal store-sold variety. The sleek architecture and airy interior gives the space a perfectly minimalistic ambiance where the only thing enhanced are the fresh colors of the excellent toppings. The honey is an absolute must try. If you want to stand out amongst the fashionistas and models that are often here enjoying their bowl of yogurt, opt for that ultra-rich, grass fed butter coffee. It can make you just as happy.

I've grown to love the appetizers such as the kimchi, fish, macaroni salad, pickles, egg and more! The drinks are also not bad. I love how this place is open until late. When we are in the area late at night, this is one of our top go-to spots.The waiters have always been consistent and attentive. One time, they forgot to bring the tofu soup that came with an entree. They checked the menu and immediately apologized. They brought the tofu soup and then cracked the egg for us.Another time, there was a pot and stone dish that was so hot that it actually stuck onto the table. The waitress was shocked but we eventually removed it slowly without damaging the table.Though I'm not a fan of the tofu soups, I like ordering the kalbi and other beef & kimchi dishes!

This review is only to what I picked up, KatsuSando. Authentically packaged but not showing what I would get was peculiar at first. But there was not so attractive and small photo attaching to its shelve. What I like about TonKatsu (Japanese pork cutlet) sandwich has been the "thick cut" of lean meat. Meat taste better cut think, that is obviously, if the quality of meat is solid. It is also one of my husband's favorite Japanese foods, so I got one for him.This sandwich was tightly sealed in a plastic wrap, and naturally I worried. The sandwich might had gotten soggy, and it was. But seeing the traditionally thick-cut meat that were sandwiched between soft-chewy Japanese white bread, relieved me. But after one bite, I noticed something I was not used to...but I kept eating. It was the sauce. Instead of thick sweet Tonkatsu sauce, it was a house special sauce, a mixture of Japanese BBQ sauce and miso. Miso created unique saltiness to the sauce. After I finished half of soggy sandwich, I was unstoppable and made me want to go back for more. The location is tricky as most mentioned here. Think you are going into the high rise office building with doormen. The lobby is covered by white marble(?), like a gallery. The tiny store is located way back by the elevators on the grand floor. I chatted with only staff, Japanese, to get more info on this place. Their bentos are freshly made every day at the Japanese restaurant Sakagura in the basement of the building.

Came here to meet a girlfriend for dinner before our mutual obsession: a Marvel movie (Civil War). I tried to be a fashion girl and just get two appetizers... Only to decide I also wanted steak as well. Oops. Food:-get the crab-stuffed avocado!! So amazing.-the octopus salad is also a great appetizer option. Mmm. -skip the shrimp in sauce appetizer... Impossibly messy to eat as it comes with heads/shell on and is a tiny portion. -everything here is presented in the prettiest manner. My steak looked like a work of art. -the portion sizes are on the smaller side, but the quality of the food is amazing. Service: great. They were very attentive to us throughout our meal. I loved our waiter. Atmosphere: this is such an impressive spot for midtown/theater district. It would be great for date night before a show. Verdict: worth it if you want a foodie-friendly restaurant option that's not overcrowded before a show.

RedFarm serves high-quality Chinese style food absent all the crap that makes American Chinese style food really bad for you. The soup dumplings were superb as was the beef fried rice. We also ordered the steamed Chinese broccoli that arrived without the broccoli florets--it was a plate of stems. Curious. Fried shrimp stuffed jalapeno poppers were scrumptious. And the plate of two Kumamoto oysters were fresh tasting but I didn't care for the lemon mignonette. I wanted to order more just to sample the various delicious sounding dishes, I exercised rare discipline and left without ordering anything else.  RedFarm is usually packed and for good reason. I stopped by on a Friday prime time. Not a good idea if you want to hear your partner speak. The place is loud and crowded but this adds to the overall festive atmosphere. Service was slow but that's because the place was insanely busy. I'd like to return soon on an off-night in the unlikely event that such a night exists.

Our company works with Amali Mou, and so I wanted to take my fiance and two friends who just got married to the flagship Amali restaurant. We made an easy reservation for Friday at 745 for 4. And were seated in the front. I'd been upstairs before for a meeting and must say sitting upstairs is definitely most impressive. The restaurant is pretty big. We started off with a bottle of rose - I forget the name of it per se but it was definitely of the Greek variety (they're having a rose month so lots of selection- overall there are a ton of wines to choose), it started with an L and was medium bodied.. Lokonikto? Honestly, something like that. Our service was great, very prompt, polite, attentive, gave good recommendations and was good with water refill and communicative.For dinner we shared the grilled octopus (very tasty, well cooked), and farro salad (simple, tasty ingredients). Two of us (myself included) had the famed chicken under a brick- tasty seared chicken breast and leg under pita crackers and Greeks salad (cucumber, olives, etc). My friend had the deep fried rabbit which was not my thing; it was fried well but had a sweet ihs/spicy taste which I didn't love. My fiance had the whole brook trout which was a $42 special and probably the most delicious thing I tried all night - perfectly cooked, tender, juicy with lemon, very healthy and fresh. He ordered a side of delicious roasted broccoli... the dishes are sort of steakhouse style where you get your main meal and have to order sides if you want.For dessert we shared the special cherry pie which I am not sure was made in house but still good (it was a perfect looking tart) -came with some good ice cream, forget the flavor but it was kind of periwinkle in color.They do also have good after dinner coffee- inclusive of a $12 French Press batch for the table.While the food is expensive, it's finer dining NYC prices (high 20s, low 30s) I do think portion sizes are fair. Esp the entree- they give you a lot of food.

The cutest, quaintest little French bistro in the West Village. There is an upstairs and downstairs dining room. Our large party of 14 was sitting in the downstairs dining room. The food was fresh and tasty, everyone in our party seemed pleased with their entrees. I ordered the "Basic" breakfast entree, which came with three soft scrambled eggs and prosciutto di parma. Just the right portion and perfectly scrambled eggs. The coffee was strong and good, though getting a refill or second cup seemed a bit difficult. I had to ask a few times. The staff including our server Yaz were very accommodating. Our brunch was surprisingly affordable too. Definitely check out Dominique Bistro if you're in the area.

I enjoyed this place. Cute little French bistro that is kid friendly on the UES! I did have a hard time finding this location. The sign says ERIC KAYSER! On Yelp and Google Eric kayser does not exist! There is a MAYSON KYSER! I asked the staff. The hostess told me, this location is a MAYSON kayser. But Mason's brother Eric owns this location and put his name on the sign. Lol talk about confusing. Anyways. Located on 74th and 3rd ave. when I arrived here my cousin and 2 kids were already in the back. The hostess was so nice. She told me the kids are expecting you, right this way. ( when she said that I was laughing inside). We had a nice area in the back. There is a take out bakery attached to this Eric kayser. I do recommend using the entrance for the bistro. The entrance to the bakery was sooo crowded. A lot of people were waiting inline for there pastries and breads. We started with some croissants for the kids. After the croissants were finished. Me and my cousin ordered tea. We got a cheese plate for the kids. The cheese platter was small, but for kids it was perfect size. There was Gouda havardie and some other type of cheese. The platter did not come with bread. We asked for bread and they brought us a lightly toasted baguette from the bakery. My cousin had a apple tart. I took the waiters recommendation for the chocolate cake thing. It was fantastic! It was very rich and creamy. I needed a lot of water and tea because of the richness. Our waiter was very nice and knowledgeable. The only thing was they were busy. I wish he came around to our table more. EX: I needed another orange juice. When you have little kids as patient as they will be. Eventually there asking why isn't my orange juice here!! Overall. I would defiantly come back here! 100% kid friendly. Nice for tea and dessert!

This lounge sits at the periphery of Koreatown. I had no idea it existed, so I wasn't surprised to see lots of empty seats for a Friday evening - the real crowd was upstairs gorging on their buffet. Then again, it was early. (I hear the buffet gets packed late nights.)You're here to drink, and Ichi delivers. If you break a glass, they'll sweet it up pronto. Want bottles? They're stocked. Want shotglasses? Tell them how many. Service is quick and eager to please. If you're hungry and not willing to leave, get the wings; they're quite tasty.

Gotta give this place some credit. I've been here a few times (mostly stopped by in Saturday nights after the clubs close) and the staff has always been nice to everyone. It's a very small spot, maybe only enough room to seat a handful of people. I'm a simple girl, so I very rarely order anything other than a plain slice. You'll get a big slice here! And though I miss the days of pizza only costing a dollar, I would say it's worth the price here. I don't know the menu, but there are lots of different delicious looking things to choose from! Definitely worth a try if you're in the area, especially after a night of... libations, as some of the other reviews have suggested lol

This is one of the very very few stores in Manhattan that I can get all the ingredients I would need to make my favorite Asian dishes. Many of the other Asian markets; e.g. Hong Kong Market, do not carry many, well barely any, Filipino ingredients causing me to make multiple stops but Asia Market Corp has been a one stop shop for me.Outside the market they have all their fresh items as well as some fish on ice and etc. Walk through the plastic "curtain" and you'll find yourself inside the store. The aisles are a tight fit but their selection is wide. The store goes into a second back area, down some stairs, with many more items so ask for help if there is something specific you need and don't see it. The store definitely does not have a clean feeling to it, but I don't think I've been to an Asian market that does, so that is not my concern.The prices have been pretty fair and have kept me coming back for over 5.5 years. My biggest issue with Asia Market Corp is that their hours are always off. It'll say online that they are open till 6pm, then I get there at 5:30pm and they are closed. UGGGHHHHHH!! I now go with the basic rule of, if the sun is down then don't even try. But important to note, I will never stop trying, because this place is essential for my cooking =D.

I was lucky to be able to finally try Morimoto-san's new digs - Momosan - on a random Thursday evening while some friends and I were chilling at nearby Salvation Taco. After walking by and seeing a crowd outside, I wondered what this ever so popular place was... turns out it was Momosan! I quickly had the brilliant idea of putting our group's name down at the hostess so we could wait and do happy hour at the same time. After about an hour, our group of 7 were seated (extremely, extremely tightly) into a booth. Let me just say that Momosan is NOT good for groups, especially at it's current state of popularity. I would not come here with more than 4 people.Despite our awkward seating arrangement, the waiters and hostess and chefs here were extremely welcoming and hospitable. There was always someone coming by to check how we were doing. It was also nice to see Chef Morimoto hard at work, preparing food and serving food to patrons just like any normal person.As is usual, I found the appetizers to be, well, more intriguing and appetizing than the ramen itself. To start, we got the tuna starter, which didn't really tickle my fancy all that much because it was overly marinated and you couldn't really taste the tuna. The cucumber in it reminded me of the Chinese marinated cucumber. I really enjoyed the fried pigs ear - it was fried to perfection - crispy and flavorful and well seasoned on the outside and soft and slightly cartilaginous on the inside. It didn't even need the sauce it came with. Finally, we had 3 orders (2 pc each) of the sticky ribs. I could eat a whole rack of these things - I prefer this somewhat fried, sweet and spicy version over American BBQ ribs any day. I would most definitely order this again - wish they had this as an entree! We were also presented with house-made kimchi - this kimchi, is probably my one of two of my favorite kimchi I've ever had. As for the ramen, I ordered the tonkotsu - my go to for every ramen joint, if I can. I wished they had a spicy version, but they have a chili oil/sauce that is a perfect addition to the rich soup, for those wanting a kick. At $10 a bowl, this is a ridiculous steal of a price for something with the name "Morimoto" attached to it and even for NYC prices. Ippudo charges at least $15 for the same thing. Though I prefer the thin straight noodles in my ramen, the curly, special Momosan/Sun Noodle noodle that doesn't go "soggy" were a perfect texture and not too firm or soft. I'll give them that - definitely not some Shin cup noodles for sure! The soup was not too salty, but we all decided it must be filled with MSG or something because we all left with dry mouth and craving a ton of water. The broth was rich, but not too thick, and full of flavor just like I like it. I prefer slices of char siu over the "pulled" version they have at Momosan. How does Momosan rank with all my other ramen joints? Probably fourth - Totto / Jun-Men / Ippudo coming before them. Regardless, this is a spot that one should try at least once - more than once might not be as appealing if you have to wait an hour every time to eat. Great job, chef Jae Lee and Morimoto!

I have been wanting to try this dessert spot for a while - even had it bookmarked!Yesterday we just finished up at the Pier 51 Playground and wanted a sweet treat. When I checked my handy dandy Yelp app, I saw that we were 4 blocks away from Aux Merveilleux de Fred so we figured we would give it a shot.To our surprise it is a take-out only restaurant. When I asked where the seating was, I was directed to the benches outside. Totally fine, but unexpected. They served brioche and merveileux which is a cream and merengue pastry covered in shaved chocolate or nuts. The consistency is extremely light. You don't feel stuffed after eating one. We had:- iced coffee - very good- sugar brioche - very good and not too sweet- Coffee Merveilleux - excellent- Dark Chocolate Merveilleux - my kids liked this better than I did. I am not a big chocolate person- Cherry Merveilleux - delicious and not too sweet- Hazelnut Merveilleux - very good- Caramel Merveilleux - delicious- White Chocolate Merveileux - my favorite When dining in the Village or the Meat Packing District, I would definitely stop in again for these super yummy treats.

We kept it old school this Mother's Day and dined at Roberto's. While I've known of this restaurant for a while, I had never dined here before tonight. Roberto's is owned by chef Roberto Paciullo, who also owns Zero Otto Nove around the corner on Arthur Ave. While Zero Otto Nove is arguably more well known (he opened two more of them in Manhattan and Armonk), it all started here for Paciullo at his namesake restaurant.Like most restaurants on Arthur Ave, Roberto's is small; upon entry, there's a small foyer containing a bar with an archway that leads into the main dining area. The atmosphere is intimate with low lighting and music playing. The color scheme is warm with dark beiges, browns, and woods.The menu contains slightly elevated Italian cuisine. The bread basket contained a simple Italian loaf and a few slices of focaccia. I totally succumbed to my carb cravings as soon as it hit the table; the bread was so simple yet so amazing - being on Arthur Ave I didn't expect anything less. My app of Italian sausage with cannellini beans and broccoli rabe was super tasty - the flavors paired well and I'm always a sucker for broccoli rabe. For my main I had the pollo con spinaci which was a chicken breast with proscuitto and spinach topped with melted mozzarella in a wine sauce. The entree was fairly simple but it was tasty - the chicken was massive =O. For dessert I had the tiramisu which was good - my cappuccino was slightly bitter but it wasn't a deal breaker. Service was great, everyone was very friendly - I was especially impressed by our server who memorized the massive specials menu to a T. Roberto's is definitely a place to get the real-deal Arthur Ave Italian dining experience and clearly shows why Roberto Paciullo has been so successful in his endeavors. While I still prefer Zero Otto Nove, Roberto's doesn't disappoint.

The "Abbreviated" MetModern // Engaging // Manageable Was not quite sure what to expect, and quite enjoyed my visit to the Met Breuer. With an entirely new layout, a myriad of different styles of artwork which included some rather well known names. Such a pleasant little surprise. The entryway boasts of a modern eye catching ceiling with ample room for receiving guests for any event. The sound of a jazz trio trickled into the lobby when we entered. Which drew us in to an overpacked room filled with listeners. Excellent choice, each musician clearly talented.The main exhibition explores unfinished work from a multitude of people, some subjects missing faces, while others may be waiting for a scene or a background. It brings great insight into the mind of each artist and the way their mind works, in addition to their personal process. On the second floor, modernist, Nasreen Mohamedi's inaugural exhibition is expansive, covering an entire floor. Female, and from India, her work is not to be missed. The Scene: Anything goes, chic modern, casual or posh Destination Rating: 8Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 7Note: just imagine if Moma and the Met had a baby. That's what's breueing here! You can relax and enjoy the art without feeling overwhelmed or short of time.

Was this place always here? I dunno but THANK GOD it exists. Coming from San Francisco to New York City, it's been hard to find an Asian mart to cook the foods of my people! Still, nothing compares to my city by the bay in terms of variety and prices... It's a very narrow shop with decently spacious aisles enough for one and a half people. I'm impressed with how modern, clean and bright it is inside! Despite coming at very busy hours, the check out is always super fast. I love that there's a large area of fresh produce and and a pretty decent selection of Asian snacks. They don't have everything but GOOD ENOUGH! Despite being cheaper than normal grocery markets, it's still not Chinatown cheap.

Delmonico's is one of the few places in the Financial District that's close to 5-Stars, primarily because of it's rich history.I mean, any restaurant that's been around since 1837 and was a favorite of Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, JP Morgan, Charles Dickens, Napoleon III and Mark Twain, has to be on that list.I give Delmonico's only 4-Stars as the food is not up to 5-Star quality, in my opinion. I wouldn't come here just based on the food, as I think it's good, but not necessarily great. But the history definitely is great. Here's my breakdown:History: 5.0-StarsAmbiance: 4.0-StarsFood: 3.5-StarsWine: 3.0-StarsPrice: 2.5-StarsSo, the question you're probably asking, is, why would Elton be recommending this place so highly if the food is just ok? Well, here are a few facts about Delmonico's that makes it more unique than any other restaurant in the United States, and a reason why I think it deserves at least one visit.Delmonico's Is The:- First & Oldest Fine Dining Restaurant in the U.S., since 1837- First to use the French word "Restaurant" to describe itself- First Restaurant to use a Printed Menu- First Restaurant to use Tablecloths & Silverware- Restaurant with the Largest Wine Cellar in the U.S. at that timeIn addition, Delmonico's created/invented these dishes, which are still popular almost 200 years later:- Eggs Benedict- Manhattan Clam Chowder- Delmonico's Steak- Delmonico Potatoes- Lobster Newburg- Chicken A La King- Baked AlaskaIf you haven't had any of these dishes, I highly recommend you try them as they're all good, in my opinion. And if you get a chance to try them at Delmonico's, even better. Although, to be honest, other places have perfected these dishes, so I'm not saying Delmonico's is the best version, but it is the original.Lastly, if you're a "foodie" and looking to be blown away by amazing cuisine, then this is not the place for that and I can assure you that you'll be disappointed. Yes, there are better steaks in the city, yes, there are better eggs benedict, chowder, etc. at other places, and yes, the ambiance is really old school and frankly, old. But, there's no denying that Delmonico's is what started the restaurant industry here in the United Stats, and for that, I think it's worth a visit.

This is a great place to come to hang out and catch up with friends! They have a very open floor plan which makes it very casual. Also, the space is pretty big so it's easy to fit large parties.Green tea shaved ice: Yum! I got this with bubbles, strawberry, condensed milk, and mochi. I'd definitely recommend this combo. The only thing is that I wish the bubbles weren't hot because it melted the shaved ice.Korean fried donut: I found this to be wayyyyy too sweet. I could only take one little bite of it. They put a lot of syrup and is overwhelming. The ice cream on the side is not very good, either. If you like very sweet stuff, you might like this.Teas: I love the way they present their tea here because they put it in a cute little tea pot with a little cup on the side. They just high quality tea bags.

When I first went to Ramen Lab, Chef Nakamura's torigara and miso ramen were the only types of ramen there. I loved everything about those first couple of months of Ramen Lab--the tight seating...err, standing, the very scientific and simple layout of the menu, tip-inclusion, and those two outstanding types of bowls. I wanted it to last forever. Mind you, I like that Ramen Lab is now a pop-up, a place that'll host a certain chef for a couple of weeks before it moves on to the next. It's exciting and it adds to the 'lab' feel. That said, I do miss that atmosphere. When I heard that Nakamura-san opened a store in the LES with those same torigara and miso ramen bowls on the menu, I was excited! But aside from the menu and the original beaker cups, Nakamura has a different feel because it's a sit-down place. There are no counter seats. It's become slightly more glamorous. Nakamura is still experimenting with tips. Since I had loved his rich (vegan!) miso and clean torigara ramens at Ramen Lab, I decided to go for the yuzu dashi this time. The yuzu dashi was clean and refreshing, with a very strong yuzu presence. The citrus notes weren't overpowering, but I do wish I had added on an egg on the side for some added depth. The noodles were thin and I felt like the noodle to broth ratio was perfect. A large, lean slice of pork covered nearly a quarter of the bowl. He has done it again. The gyoza appetizer was also very good. The skin on each gyoza was so thin and the filling so juicy and gingery; it was somehow very flavorful without being too heavy. It came sizzling on a hot plate with the tops crisped just-so. Likelihood of another visit:I guess with a sit-down restaurant comes a more relaxed feel. It certainly makes having conversations with dining mates easier and permissible. I'm also happy to know that his menu is here to stay in a permanent space--I'll definitely be back.

A cross between a classic cocktail bar, southern plantation shabby chic, gastropub, and boozy cool ambiance kind of joint. Perfect date spot and gathering point for drinks and light eats with friends.Most bars in this area of bro-Murray Hill are kind of lame, but this one stands out above them. So much better than the fratty drunkfest meathead bars close by. Nice classy decor, atmosphere, friendly bouncer, good bartenders, and helpful staff. Decent food, selection of beers on tap, and a solid cocktail list. Prices are fair overall.After work during happy hour gets pretty crowded, but drop in later on the weekend nights for a less crowded space with a DJ spinning a great mix of music. A standout in a much maligned part of town known for it's less than spectacular bro-bar scene.

Those who want to take a healthy lunch break should consider Green Symphony. A super tiny, independently-owned salad bar/smoothie bar/deli that packs a great selection off their menu and buffet stations. They offer a ton of natural fruit and vegetable smoothies and drinks. If you check out their full menu, they have specialty items like rice bowls (containing brown rice only), creative wraps, creative salads, and so forth. The options are simply great. They offer delivery and pick-up for your convenience. While they have their buffet stations, I just go straight to ordering off their menu. I've tried a good share of their options which includes the Sesame Tofu Steak Salad, Tofu Mania Bowl, Chicken Bowl, New Yorker Bowl, and the Dalai Lama Bowl. Their salads range about $7-10, and I think they are pretty fair price-wise. The portions are very good, and they come with plenty of the toppings that are being offered. Regarding the 'Bowls', they are simply rice bowls that come with a variety of different toppings (much like bibimbap). They strictly use brown rice for these, and none of the ingredients are fried. It's my personal favorite to order when I get lunch from here, if not the wraps. The smoothies and speciality mixed drinks packed with only healthy ingredients are also worth the try. They have an extensive smoothies menu that is probably the best I have encountered around here.Green Symphony is definitely one of my favorite hidden deli spots. Vegetarians/vegans would particularly love this spot because they offer so much in terms of non-meat options. Good, healthy and reasonably priced food does exist in Times Square, and this spot has consistently proven that on my several visits for lunch.

Three words: Rosemary Tater Tots. Seriously so good! Do yourself a favor and order them. I had been here before a while ago, but don't really remember much from that visit. I went back this weekend for an early (10:30) brunch on Sunday. There were some other tables, but it wasn't too crowded. It was starting to fill up more when we left around noon. I was feeling slightly hung over from the night before, so I decided I needed some hair of the dog, and ordered a bacon bloody mary. This was good, but I imagined there would be a long, crispy stick of bacon in the glass, but the bacon was crumbled up on top. It was good, but not exactly what I was expecting. I also felt like I should order something carby to absorb all the alcohol in my bloodstream, and ordered the BEC. The waitress said it wasn't that big and suggested I ordered a side. I got the rosemary tater tots! Best decision ever, but to be honest I thought the sandwich was kind of big and would have been fine without the side. The bacon was a bit thicker cut; the egg wasn't runny which was nice. My cousin took a bite out of his steak sandwich and the egg opened and dripped down his hand. Overall I thought the BEC was good, and I liked the brioche bun. I didn't taste anyone else's food, but everyone seemed to enjoy what they got. I shared my tater tots and I think everyone agreed they were amazing. I don't know why I never really think to come here, but it's definitely a good spot! I'll have to remember and come back some time soon.

Wonderful ambiance, festive feeling, fantastic service and an amazing customized drink.My friend and I stopped here for a drink after meeting at another bar - she recommended Felice as a favorite and wanted a place with some energy / people present which this had.The bartender was very personable, witty - had a great personality and hung my coat when it slipped off my chair. When I told him my likes and that I loved Mezcel, he recommended the Felice Old Fashioned with Mexcel. Mmm fantastic.Recommend as a place to meet with friends or a date.

Super sexy & sophisticated, this very New York spot like the Marlton serves up some grand style with tasty eats. The room downstairs is a wow with red velvet banquettes and a small bar. Andy Warhol pics around the room. I must shout out the exceptional staff- all stellar. Kudos. I really enjoy the dining experience when staff are down to earth.Ordered: Atlantic salmon with asparagus and Romesco Simple, well prepared and tasty. Grape and Vine is a Manhattan Star!

Definitely will satisfy your noodle needs when in the area.Cons - it's a very small space, and as it's recommended that you eat your noodles right away, this makes for a cramped dining experience. Pros - I haven't been too adventurous in ordering, but the Seitan ribbon noodle was a "yes." Huge portions & super friendly staff.Life Recommendation: As it's located on the block of awesome, you can spend your day doing work/bingeing on coffee & pastries at The Chipped Cup, head to The Hand Pulled Noodle for a carby scrumptious dinner, & then go get your drink on at At the Wallace.You're welcome.

Little Collins is easily my favorite take out option in Midtown East. I come here specifically for a few stand out items, though I'm sure the rest of the menu items are fantastic as well. The Turkey Confit sandwich was my intro to LC. It is nothing short of amazing, probably not like any turkey sandwich you have ever had. I like their Avocado Smash for a lighter, healthier option. They mix some feta into theirs, which I really like. Today I finally tried the famous Sweet Uncle Fred... Wow, just wow. Whoever concocted this glorious thing is brilliant. It's breakfast perfection. The coffee here is very good and they have a nice selection of pastries. The staff is always friendly and helpful and I appreciate that their lines move quickly because the place is usually packed. I wouldn't recommend sitting down to eat here for that reason, but it's an excellent to-go option. I will say I have been a little underwhelmed by some of the salad options, but apart from that everything I have had has been solid!

David's Cafe but where is David?This cute little restaurant feels very homey and has a ambiance where you feel like you are walking into a family kitchen. There are not that many tables in here and they get filled quickly for brunch but the wait was not long for me. There are not many big tables here so if you are a group of more than 4 it might be difficult to get a seat quick so I would make a reservation. One thing you will notice is this place is extremely disorganized but the staff is very friendly so it makes up for it.When we got seated we ordered right away and got coffee & juice but had to send back some silverware because it was dirty. Ewww. The food came very quickly but they messed up one of the orders which was the Classic Benedict we asked for no hollandaise sauce on it and they waitress confirmed it but the kitchen messed up. Where they made up for it is they were able to get us a new one right away without the hollandaise. I got the farmers omelet which was very good with the mixture of cheddar cheese, mushroom, and chives mixed really well. All together we thought the quality of the food was very good the coffee was strong and my juice was fresh squeezed and delicious. In short:- Delicious food- fast friendly service- very disorganized- went here when they first opened so it's bound to improve based on how good the food was

Matcha Latte, how do I count thee ways? I've always wondered how they've figured out how to stay in the limelight and now that I've finally stepped foot through those doors, now I know too. As for what they offer, they're great but something I feel is missing, like ample space. 4.4/5.0I've often walked by and attempted to grab a seat, only to find it extremely jam-packed- Not once or twice, but many many times over. Any given day, it really didn't matter. I wanted to sit down and experience this magical drink that's been instagrammed to death. Last night, I finally had that opportunity as it was barely half full, which was a rarity.I sat down with my friend for a hot matcha latte, and appearances do not disappoint... before me was this magical elixir, topped with a fair sprinkle of matcha tea/powder. As anyone can tell you, a latte is a latte, and it tasted of exactly that. The flavor was subtle but very present.Drinks aside, the cafe offers a great place to sit down, grab a bite and drink, and at times, relax, if it's not buzzing with conversations and energy. I'd even venture to try another drink on the menu since they have several to choose from.

a nice food court, surprisingly not crowded on a Saturday afternoon given the fact it's located close to time square! Quality food and nice ambiance (clean, bright and modern). Nothing is more soul-and-stomach filling than a bowl of good ramen after 45miles cycling! I ordered the Kuro-Obi (creamy chicken soup ramen) with umami egg. The light yellow marinated running egg yolk is absolutely delicious!!! The ramen soup is super rich (I like it better than some of the ippudo ones.) and the ramen is chewy. There also sushi, Mediterranean food, lobster rolls and Mexican food available as well. Worth a visit if you want a quick bite.

I came here for my birthday back in August with my brother, parents and grandpa. We were trying to find a place that has a tasting menu that is not extremely expensive and that had availability (we tend to make plans very last minute). We all really enjoyed our meals except my grandpa who claimed his Russian maid cooks better food (we all found this funny considering he is a super stubborn 90 year old Russian man).
