We got an amuse bouche of truffle arancini which was SOOOO good that I could have eaten all of them (and considering it was my birthday it would have been nice if my family let me but that was not the case sadly). We also got three other things, one that had some kind of white fish rolled up in a cracker, another that looked like a tart but I do not remember what it was, and a cold pea soup shot. They were all good but the arancini was the best.For my appetizer course I got the kampachi crudo. It was good, not great, nor was it really memorable. My brother had the foie gras which he really enjoyed and my grandpa had the pork ravioli which was the only dish he really liked/For my vegetable course I got the hen of the woods, tofu and onion dish.It was really amazing and the mushrooms were perfectly cooked (unlike the ones I had for my previous birthday at Marea that were super chewy).For the entree I got the scallops which were the best scallops I have ever had. They were perfectly cooked and were jumbo. For dessert I had some white chocolate mousse or cake I do not really remember. It was good. They also brought a plate with macaroons and ice cream. The two things that were really memorable were the arancini (though they are not on the menu, they really should be) and the scallops. I think for the price of three it is really worth it (85 for 3 courses) and I would maybe skip dessert but for 4 it is 98 pp (not including wine) and at that price I would prefer Blue Hill. Nonetheless, the food was still really good and I would go back.

Very short version: Solid Tex-Mex in Hell's Kitchen with 23 flavors of margarita and complimentary dessert that you will get as long as you don't act like an asshole. Short version: I filled up on the nacho chips and salsa, and slowly ate my way through my veggie quesadilla as my stomach turned into leaden cement. Did I still eat most of the free tres leches dessert, even though I had that exact same dessert five hours ago? Yes. Because life is all about eating free food. Slightly longer version: The manager cares a lot about this restaurant, and it shows. He treated every table as though they were regulars. I like trying out new places in the city, so, rather unfortunately, I'm pretty much a newbie at every place I visit. I've seen a lot of restaurant owners belly up to regulars and spend the whole evening cracking jokes, and then toss a perfunctory "How are things" at my table. Here, the manager took the time to explain how the dishes were made without any animal fats, MSG or lard; he encouraged us to try the tres leches; and, best of all, he refilled our two buckets of chips when he saw we were running low. The table next to us had two birthdays, and he ran to get a second serving of tres leches for the other girl. When one customer left her scarf behind, he had a waiter run out and return it. The food is pretty standard Tex-Mex (though my friend demolished his steak nachos), but the service was absolutely top-notch. NEXT TIME: one of the 23 margarita flavors, seafood enchilada, mango chicken

Great local Chelsea spot for either lunch or dinner. Plenty of tables with a large communal table in back but a large bar area to sit down to have a drink or meal. The service was great. The 2 female bartenders behind the bar was so nice, attentive, and made great suggestions for a order. They also mixed a great bloody mary. Nice spicey kick with hearty bloody mary mix and alcohol.The go to meatballs here for me were the lamb and mushroom, juicy, not too gamey and moist and the pork meatball, full of flavor and moist as well with the tomato sauce. I went with the sliders without buns and it was still a hearty filling meal. The dessert ice cream sandwiches were great as well. They make their ice cream in house and it shows. Had the espresso and snickerdoodle cookie. You can see the espresso grounds in the ice cream and had a nice coffee taste. The snickerdoodle cookie had the right amount of crunch and softness that made for a great ice cream sandwich.Great for groups or for a meal just for yourself. I'll be back.

Was there ever a time when you couldn't decide between eating sushi or a Chop't salad for lunch? Do you ever crave a Chipotle bowl but you don't want to get E. coli or Norovirus?Now you can! A healthier mix of all of the above at Pokéworks! Apparently this idea of a build-your-own poke bowl/salad/burrito was commercialized (and wildly popular) in the place of all things innovative and Asian, California. Of course, it was adapted from the poke of Hawaiian cuisine. (Poke is a Hawaiian term that means "to cut crosswise into pieces," which is now used widely with not only raw fish, but even avocados and tofu!)Oops, I digress. At Pokéworks, you can order one of eight suggested combinations e.g. Hawaiian Classic, Umami Classic (we got this one), Spicy Ahi. Otherwise, you can "poké your way:"1. Choose a bowl (white or brown rice or quinoa) , burrito (Pokiritto with seaweed wrap), or salad (Romaine lettuce).2. Pick your protein e.g. ahi tuna, salmon, shrimp, scallops, chicken, tofu3. Pick a flavor e.g. salt, umami shoyu, red chili, srirachi aioli4. Choose toppings e.g. fried lotus root (the guy recommended this one, we really liked it!), kale, masago, avocado (an extra $1.50), and tons more!They also have a miso soup vending machine (free with a Facebook check-in) and mango coco jelly whatttt! Since this was our pre-dinner snack, will definitely be dropping by to try that dessert next time.For about $12, this was such a good deal! Can't wait to come back!PS; they have a few stool seats in the front, but it's a small space!

Early valentine's day dinner in zero degree weather makes this meal definitely memorable.Reservations are definitely needed for Dieci since it is indeed an intimate venue. Keep in mind that they have a communal table and a good handful individual tables. Service was very attentive and better yet, they split your dishes without asking! Ordered:1. Uni scrambled egg- I felt like there wasn't enough uni when we got it!2. Beef tartare- favorite appetizer of the night. The aioli that accompanied it was delish. Don't worry the uni is mixed inside the beef for all of you who will be exclaiming out "Where's the uni?!"3. Tagliolini- loved the thick tomato sauce4. Roast duck breast- perfectly cooked and so tender. 5. Earl tea creme brulee- I am usually not a big person on ordering dessert but to share, this was delicious and light. It wasn't too sweet at all!If you are an uni lover and want to try an array of dishes with it, Dieci is for you! I would say this place reminds me of Sakamai, if you aren't able to get ressies at one or the other.

I love this little dump of a bar. I live in the neighborhood and I am surrounded by small plates and glasses of wine. Organic this and free range that. Sometimes, I just want cheap booze and some laughs with the guys in a relaxed environment.Johnny's is just north of 12th street on Greenwich Ave and is a lovely little hole in the wall. The service is friendly and they make your drinks with little fuss. I came here with a group of guys and we had a ball. There are always some strange characters, locals and other sorts that make the patrons of this place a hodge-podge of the neighborhood. The only downside to this place is that it is very small and it can be tough to move around when it gets busy.

Thank you Momofuku for having a location on the UWS that is absolutely not crowded, especially on a Saturday night. There was tons of seating and the staff was so friendly.I had to try to cereal milk ice cream ($6 + toppings are extra) and a cup is more than enough. Certainly, the flavor takes some time to acquire, but if you've grown up slurping the bottom of your bowl of milk after finishing the cereal, you'll definitely enjoy the cereal milk ice cream because it tastes like corn flake soaked milk. We also had the chocolate covered pretzel milkshake ($8), which wasn't really too great. That we definitely couldn't acquire the taste as it just tasted like a chocolate milkshake with a ton of salt poured into it. And yes, I mean a ton of salt that it didn't even taste like a chocolate covered pretzel anymore.Overall, would come back for the ice cream, maybe skip the milkshake next time.

If you want a fun dinner, with a good scene and a killer playlist... This is your place.The food is so good. Get the oysters, it's like an escargot style and dip the bread in the sauce. I could come here just for this. But the short rib is easily one of my favorite entrees here. It's French food- seriously how wrong can you go?But this place is special because it's not stuffy, and there's always good people watching. Great cocktails here and wine. Come here and bring some good company and you will have a blast.

New York City is no longer a stranger to the phenomenon of Thai rolled (or smashed) ice cream, and I CE NY is one of a handful of ice cream shops that specialize in this genre of desserts. For the unfamiliar, Thai rolled ice cream requires a process of spreading an even layer of ice cream base on a frozen plate chilled to -15 degrees F; the "rolled" ice cream is then made by evenly scraping thin strips into a swirl. Repeat five or six times (or more, depending on the size of the ice cream) and the end product one of the most beautiful (and time-intensive) ice cream cups that you'll lay eyes on.Located in the ever-busy epicenter of Greenwich Village, I CE NY is a pint-sized storefront easily identifiable by its seemingly never-ending line patrons that can run out the door; given that each ice cream is made to order, it's not surprising that waits are an inevitable occurrence. We'd done our best to arrive at an off-hour, but still wound up waiting for twenty or so minutes until we were able to make our way to the counter. It gave us plenty of time to review their menu, however, which offers a number of present concoctions as well as the option to customize your own ice cream given a choice of ice cream bases, mix-in ingredients, and final toppings and sauces.We wound up ordering the namesake Thai IC-E Tea, which began with a base of Thai Iced Tea Ice Cream and topped off the bowl with lychees, Choco Wafers, a drizzle of condensed milk, and whipped cream. The texture of the rolled ice cream is one of the more distinct qualities of this dessert; it's simultaneously light and creamy and seems to melt the moment it hits the tongue. While the actual flavor of the Thai Iced Tea wasn't as robust as I was hoping for, the final product was a success in taste and texture, and made for a sweet and surprisingly balanced spoonful, perfect for a warm day; after all, how can you go wrong with Choco Wafers and lychees?While it may be a little too complex and time-intensive of a treat to enjoy on a regular basis, I certainly give I CE NY credit for producing a quality dessert that's now available outside of its original borders. Give it at least one or two tries - and if you happen to pass by when there isn't a line out the door, you'll know that luck is one your side.

Pros:* Amy Ruth is a must-try in Harlem and worth the wait! * Amazingly delicious food! We had the fried chicken & waffles, mac & cheese, and mashed potatoes and everything was so so good. The waffles was the best I've had in a very long time.* Unassuming and chill atmosphere* Great service! Cons:* The wait system is a little unorganized so make sure to put your name down with the hostess and hover around the door to make sure you don't miss your name being called out. We went on the Sunday morning 12:30PM and we waited about 30 min. * Loved that you get cornbread as a free starter, but was disappointed as it was surprisingly dry :( The pictures looked so moist!

Back in the spring of 1998, I saw "Phantom..." on Broadway for the first time. It was part of a field trip with my 8th grade class. My priorities at the age of 13: Checking out the cool new stores down at South Street Seaport (when it was a viable mall), buying a cool "South Park" bumper sticker (since it was all the rage back at its inception), and general goofing off. When we arrived at the theater, Times Square was still more seedy than family-friendly; I still remember seeing a billboard for an adult theater boasting "XXXPlosive Orgasms Guaranteed!" (And, thanks to all of the "What's Happening To By Body?" books one of my aunts insisted on buying me during my formative years, I knew exactly what that billboard was referring to; telling my classmates made them laugh hysterically. Haaa.) My class did read the original novel as a class assignment prior to seeing the play; all I remember was being monumentally bored and being very disappointed when the chandelier took roughly five minutes to drop while the score pressed on. (In actuality, it probably took 15 seconds, but, in "kid time"...) It's not that I hated it, but I viewed it as forced educational experience at the time. Flash forward 18 years, when I was given the opportunity to view it again. My appreciation of this musical is now, post-viewing, firmly in place. At a rousing two and a half hours (with one intermission), I fell in love with the plot, the characters, and the use of special effects. Honest to goodness, some of them (without giving away plot lines), are akin to any top - of - the - line magician's performance. The use of light and fire were wild; being 6 rows from the front of the stage, one part in Act II which had fire flaming on the stage made my face burn and my eyes scrunch. Conversely, I think the theater might want to forewarn anyone prone to seizures that there is ample use of flash lighting in this show; I had dots floating in my eyes on occasion after any particular use of them! The plot...well, it's very theatrical. Ha! To be expected, right? I heard one fellow audience member refer to the Phantom as a "Stage Five Clinger", and now, I'll probably always think of him that way. I loved many of the main characters, though, admittedly, Christine started to grate on me after a while. Despite his Stage Five Clinginess, I felt great empathy for The Phantom. Towards the finale, I started to get all of the feels, as the kids would say. I can definitely see why this has earned its title as the longest running musical on Broadway. It's a spectacle to be seen! Though I wouldn't be one of those people that sees it 10 more times, I am glad I was able to see it a second, as an adult. I definitely appreciated it more, and I am glad I was able to.

A "bang for your buck" notion is truly exemplified here. The slice of cheese is killer *bang bang* for a $1. Probably the best dollar I have ever spent and here's why:- Dough consistency (crisp, foldable, light and flavorful)...money- Sauce flavor (tangy and a tat bit sweet)...money- Sauce to dough ratio (just the right amount of sauce)...money- Crust consistency (crunchy yet chewy)...money Surely, all of those money points should add up to more than a $1. Don't you go getting ideas in raising the price Joey! Is this the best pizza I have ever eaten? Most likely not, but it is the best pizza that I have eaten for a dollar!!

After Raku, we came here to finish up our Sunday brunch. Asked one of the green tea baristas what should we get? He pointed out Wabi Matcha Latte ($4.75?) that was the first on the list. We all got the same and liked our teas, a lot. Nice green tea scent and good matcha flavor was pleasant. Lightly sweetened latte was smooth to drink. Our cups were beautiful green cups with heart, smile, or leaves design on the top. I would like to come back to try their homemade matcha pastries, that were tempting, and their rice bowl + miso soup combo as lunch but the barista said "....as a breakfast?" He continued "The cafe is part of the hair salon, next door, and customers can order from this cafe" But is it free? I didn't ask....

Caught an Umphrey McGee show here and was blown away. This building is charming and beautiful. The art deco lamps, Tiffany windows, and chandelier are stunning. I love shiny wood. Check out the murals by standing at the front of the stage. I like how the staff greets and nods as I say "hello". But yo, they have a Terror Squad at the Front Door looking for contraband. But they are not digging in your stuff like TSA Officials.The Dark and Stormy drink was aiight. The Draft beer was...beer. They knocked the edge off while waiting to be seated Sound system was better than anticipated. Which made me wonder since UM had an extra package that featured super max wireless headphones. I was dancing in the aisles with five young women and a dude from the Chi. I don't think that would have been possible with the headphones.For another UM show, that is a definite yes. For another show, sure...

Ok so pizza is the "it food" right now or has it always been, and I'm just now taking notice? Scary for my pants, that it's right around the corner! We would stop by at 3am for a quick post-drunk feast but now, finding myself wanting to come here all hours of the day. For you UESders, IV is like Salvo's sauce without the grease of Gotham-- though depending on my palette, any of the other two might do on a fickle day. If Gotham is the $.99 cent version, then IV falls in between and Salvo's reigns on the more high-end slice. But IV holds its own. They only offer slices and 16" or 18" pies , the 16" which yields 6 NY-style, large slices for $13. Hot, freshly made-to-order, orgasmic pizza. This is they type of pizza that inspires one to wear pizza attire! I'll be getting mine from Amazon shortly.

Tavern 29 is a American style craft brewery/ lounge/ restaurant in midtown. I came here to meet 6 friends on the weekend. Looking on tavern 29s website I was debating making reservations. There is 3 floors and the location didn't look that small. Good thing I made reservations the place was packed at 4:30pm on a Saturday. The hostess and security guard we're very nice and accommodating. The security and hostess helped us through the crowd to our private lounge table in the back. Thank you staff!!The lounge was private. But this place is noisy. There is top 20 hits playing and of coarse all of the people talking and laughing. It was a 20s-30 crowd. They put candles on every table to set the mood. At a bar?! Hmmm I would not recommend if you are on a date. Unless you like to go to loud bars on dates. The staff was above and beyond here for me! Our waitress was so funny even before I started drinking. She was busy but was attentive. When we were done the security guard came and escorted us back out this isn't LAVO or Provocateer or Tao. remember this is at a BAR!! A complete first for me, but a very nice gesture. I only had 1 issue here. On tavern 29s website. They list there menu and beer list. There is 3 floors at tavern 29. The beer list on the first floor where our lounge was. Was completely different than the list upstairs on the roof. Some of the menu items were different. This really confused me. It's not a bad thing. Just be aware of this. The beer list is all craft brewery's. You can buy growlers. If you are with a group. Buying s growler is cheaper than individual bottles. Of coarse no one wanted the same beer lol. I was the only one not drinking beer. I had 5 shots of belvedere. They had no grey goose at the bar. They did have some really good single malts I was tempted by. The food: the food was very good here. Tavern 29 has American style bar food taken to the next level. A lot of sandwiches and burgers. We ended up just getting 2 flatbreads to share. We started with the margarita flat bread. A very simple flat bread with sauce and fresh mozzarella. The flatbread was very good it had a nice char from the wood oven and was super Crispy. The second flat bread was the BBQ pulled pork flatbread. Personally I liked the BBQ flat bread better. There was way more flavor. It was pulled pork onions bacon cheese and BBQ sauce. Just so my YELPERs know. When you check in here you get a free guacamole app. My waitress had no issue with the check in. I don't eat guacamole but my friend said it was very good and creamy. Overall. Tavern 29 was nice. The flatbreads were great. The staff was fantastic. Just keep in mind about the menu. I would come back with friends for the food. They do honor the Yelp free guacamole check in!!!

For my 300th Review, I thought I'd review a place dear to my heart, haha. Kind of funny cause this is a dirty, cheesy, old school club in Tribeca, where I used to live, and have been coming to since the '90s."M1-5" is the city's zoning code for the neighborhood, which used to be 'Industrial', and a no-man's land between Chinatown and Tribeca. But the condo boom has swallowed up the area and called it 'Tribeca' to get higher apartment prices, changing the whole feel of the place.I gave M1-5 a 4-Star Rating for one thing and one thing only - for being and knowing what it is, which is one of the last remaining old school clubs in the city (along with Santos Party House) going back to the '80s/'90s. As Manhattan gentrified over the past 20 years, development unfortunately pushed out all the old clubs...The Tunnel, Roxy, Wetlands, Limelight, Palladium, Arc, Sway, Don Hill's, Twilo, Sound Factory, Subliminal, Centrofly, Vinyl, Nasa, Moskva, Brownies, Exit, Avalon, Save the Robots, etc, etc. Now, M1-5 doesn't hold a candle to the places above, but it does have a similar feel to them. And it's not like the annoying clubs of today (Marquee, Provocateur, Lavo, Avenue, Tao, for example).At M1-5, there's:No Velvet RopeNo Bottle Service crapNo Fashion StatementsNo Model WannabeesNo Spoiled Club Kids on MollyNo GlamourNo Cover chargeNo StatusNo TablesJust an All-Out, Free-For-All, Dance Party. Anyone can come in, you can wear whatever you want and you can dance wherever you want.Unfortunately though, these types of places will never be seen again in NYC as it's a different time now, different people, different scene, and different needs/wants. I actually read, that back in the '90s/'00s, there were 1,700 clubs with cabaret licenses operating in NYC...now there are around 100. A "cabaret license" is issued by the city, and is what is required for a bar/club to legally allow people to 'dance'. It's a dumb law that goes back to 1920's Prohibition. And because of this and development, the glory days of NYC clubs is long gone, relegated to the handful of velvet rope, Vegas-style clubs. A trend started by the first velvet rope club to open in Meatpacking in 2001, called Lotus, and to which Jennifer Lopez (remember her? lol) helped make famous and start the velvet rope era. Great, thanks J-Lo.The clubs have now turned into posers crammed at tiny tables with girls in Louboutins thinking they'll meet a rich guy there, but as we all know, hardly anyone has money in those clubs as they're all feeding off the promoters. And on top of all that, the '90s/'00s alcohol-fueled dance & makeout sessions on an actual dance floor have turned into the '10s Molly-fueled clubbers "rolling" to music by themselves, in a sardine-packed table. As you can see, times have changed.But fortunately, a tiny glimmer of the past still exists at M1-5, but don't expect too much, after all, it is just a dirty, cheesy, old school dance club that has fallen out of favor in NYC these days.And one last IMPORTANT thing...DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT show up here SOBER. You have to already have a few drinks in you to be able to handle this place. I've come sober before and had a horrible time - way too loud, people bumping into you, drinks getting spilled on you, etc. BUT, when I've come after a few drinks, I've had a great time. So, take my advice and have a few before you get there.And, of course...Enjoy (or maybe not enjoy) a taste of Old New York, haha.

I legit LIVE FOR NOODLES! I had been trying to come back to this place for the past 4 years. Only 2 things have stopped me from completing my task: 1- Bad memory of a wonderful date I had 2- The 45 people constantly waiting for the 14 SEATS that are available inside. While this prevented me from waiting the constant hour long wait to get a seat for noodles, I was in the area yesterday running errands and like the sun on a cloudy day, the sky parted and there was no one waiting for seats. Soon to be remedied as 15 people showed up 10 mins after I sat down. I promptly ran down the stairs for the 1 spot at the bar that remained. OMG, Sooooooo tasty and fast. Reminds me of cold nights in Tokyo at my favorite noodle shop. The bowls are HUGE so bring your stomach. Noodles are made fresh in front of you, ingredients and all added at your pleasure, Don't wear WHITE bc there will be some splash- action happening! Everything on the menu is tasty.

Holy Maroni! What an interesting concept. For lazy days, cold days, potluck days, and stress-eating days, get a pot of pasta delivered to your door ($15 delivery fee) or pick it up from the restaurant. You can also dine here, but I think it's really cool that you can order a piping hot meal to eat at home. From there, you can heat the pot directly on the stove and eat your meal for leftovers over the course of a couple of days.The pots come in 3 sizes, but the small one fits more than enough food for 2 people to share for at least 3 meals. Really!We ordered the small pot of spaghetti with meatballs and it was still pretty hot even after walking 20 blocks with it. The meatballs could have been seasoned a tad more, but the spaghetti was cooked al dente and wasn't limp at all; the sauce was robust and plentiful. Likelihood of another visit:If you bring back the pot at the time of your next meal, you get a $4 discount. I'd love to try their penne alla vodka next time.

THIS IS FOR THE EAT24 ORDER: What I got: Turkey burger with added toppings: sauteed onions, sauteed mushrooms, pepperjack cheese, jalapenos, and pickles. Sweet potato fries on the side. Food: Definitely not the healthiest but...... The turkey burger hit the spot- it was delicious! I bet it tastes better when you actually dine in. Since I got mine delivered, the bun was a bit too soft. But the meat was perfectly juicy and cooked, the toppings werent overwhelming and were properly sauteed like I had asked. The sweet potato fries were no where near crunchy or crisp, they were just too oily and super limpy. But given that I didnt dine in and had it delivered on a super windy, rainy NYC evening, I won't complain too much. Service: My 4 stars mainly stem from the fact that delivery was so quick and they also paid attention to any extra notes I made, like sending an extra plate and mustard on the side. I find it hard to have reliable delivery in NYC but this place seems attentive. Price: Eh, average. I spent $16 for food and tip included so it wasn't bad, but I'd definitely get more bang for my buck if I had gone elsewhere.Will I order again?Idk about order, but if I'm around, I'd be curious to dine in and see if theres any difference in the quality of the food.

Paradou can be a hit or miss in both atmosphere and food. If you're seated towards the front and order, 'the wrong entree', you will be experiencing a miss, if you ask to be seated towards the back and order what I would say is, 'the right entree', you're provided with a loud music dance party with a satisfying tasty meal that results imo as a hit. On this, one of my many visits, I was yet again handed a hit. I have had many experiences here, many, and this one can be added as another hit of a great time. I generally know what to order when coming here, so I can leave the establishment filled with a decent meal, which on this day was the Lamb Burger with figs and goat cheese spread, sooo good! Plus, enjoy my fill of many bottles of 'champagne', in this case inexpensive sparkling wines within a two hour time limit. What I enjoy about Paradou is that 8 times out of 10 brunch always and I mean always ends up with people dancing on chairs and tables, so funny and so much fun to watch. On this afternoon, aside from the usual girls dancing and a few boys dancing on tables, I had the opportunity to see the biggest guy I've ever seen twerk with the quickness of ease. Yo', just imagine say a big bearded Joey Fatone standing on a chair towards the back corner of the restaurant, hands against the wall and twerking. He did it so well to whatever trap song that was playing that we were asking him to please do it again...he refused, lol!! We were thoroughly entertained with all the shenanigans to say the least. I know I should be tired of spots like this and just deal with the quaint all you can eat buffets or I should be in search of a restaurant mainly for the food; there are plenty of spots like that all over. But my mission for this afternoons, dragged through the wee hours of the night event, was clearly to have a freaking good time. And that I did with a few of my Yelp peeps aka Mercedes, Sunshine, Ruthy and Jason, that included so much fun, talk, laughter, good music, lots of 'champs' and dancing. Mission Accomplished!

Recently, I went on a quest to find bars that I had not visited before in the lower east side. Nothing fancy, I enjoy a good dive bar if it has a pleasant bar tender (and even some that don't). I found Old Man Hustle on Yelp and decided that I needed to give it a try. Let me start by saying that the bar is *tiny*. There were only a group of three there before us so we took over the back corner (10 of us). Old Man has a decent can selection for such a small spot. They had a variety that allowed for everyone to pick something different that they enjoyed. On top of that, there is a great happy hour special that included a dollar well shot for every beer purchased. We cashed in on those immediately. They have a little platform area with benches that the girls took over while the guys pounded shots for the birthday boy. The bartender was super nice and friendly. She was even patient when we were trying to order rounds of all different drinks. Overall, this place was a great way to start the night.

In the heart of the Broadway Theater District, Yakitori Totto is a small restaurant up a flight of stairs. Every time we've been here there has been a mostly young Japanese crowd eating or waiting for tables. The room conjures an intimate, cool hipster vibe in the middle of Tourist Central. This time we had a table reservation and got a semi-private room which barely fit six. Lucky for us we didn't get seated in the main room where the tables are tightly spaced.The restaurant used to be known for its raw chicken sashimi specialty, but I didn't see it on the menu, not that I would've risked ordering it. Be sure you're In the mood for grilled food on a skewer because that's what Yakitori Totto specializes in, especially chicken and all of its parts (knees, bones, tail). We had fun selecting grill choices, with my fav being the Shishito Tsukune which is Japanese green pepper stuffed with chicken. The other excellent and re-ordered dish was the grilled Eringi Bacon, so tasty! Everyone ordered their own rice dish to complete the meal. My Nega Tori Don, chicken and egg over rice was simple and filling. Our young waiter was awesome, and kept up with our constant menu questions, beer re-orders and grill re-orders. The grill selections don't seem too expensive, but with re-orders they add up fast! It's a great little communal place to dine once you manage to get a seat.

One of my favorite regular spots. I only order the TWO items and nothing else. Soup Dumplings & Pan Fried Pork Dumplings!! So delicious! Granted this place is small, railroad style restaurant. First come, first serve. Clean but sometimes their utensils, have residue from the soap on them. Normally, I would dip the utensils in the hot tea they serve and wipe it down with a napkin. Reason being for 4 stars, would have been a 5 star but the utensils has become a regular thing for me when I go there. It has become a paranoid and weird habit for me because now even if there is no residue. I still dip them in hot tea. Yes, I could ask for new utensils but it's the same. Well, in my case.

I noticed a sign recently for this place on 3rd ave, and bookmarked it so I would remember to check it out sometime. I finally made it there last week for lunch with my mom. We were just picking up to take back to the office, but the space is really nice! When you walk in it seems pretty minimal. There's a counter right away where you order, and then you walk back and there's a large area for seating and even a skylight! I would definitely come back sometime and eat in. They have hot dogs, milkshakes and ice cream, but I came for the poke. I'd actually never had it before, but it seemed like something I would enjoy. I went with the ahi tuna, the Shoyu (non-spicy) sauce, and added some edamame to it. My mom ordered the half & half with tuna and salmon, got the spicy sauce and added garlic krispies. They gave us a buzzer and we stood by the seating area waiting for our food. It didn't take too long, and it's an open kitchen area, so you can see them preparing your food. Once it was ready we grabbed it, and went back to the office to eat.  It was a generous sized portion. There was rice (I got brown), cucumbers, greens, seaweed salad, tobiko, tuna and the edamame I got as extra. It was a little hard to mix everything together in the container, but it wasn't too big of a deal for me. The fish and everything was really fresh. I tried my mom's to see how spicy the spicy sauce was, but it wasn't too bad. It would be like getting a spicy tuna roll or something when you get sushi. The whole thing was really good, and very filling. This is a definitely a good, unique addition to the neighborhood. I definitely plan on going back!

DomoDomo is a cute, new, intimate and albeit small/mid sized Japanese spot. Reservations are advised, especially if you are planning a special occasion. We sat at the sushi bar with the intention of trying the Domokase, or basically their Omakase -- multi course signature meal of various sushi and hand rolls ($75). As my guest best put it, it is a 'starter' Omakase. For those with more Omakase experience, I wouldn't prepare oneself to be mind blown, but the sushi here was tasty overall.With the Domokase, we had a bottle of the Dassai50 Nigori Sake, which was a pleasant, smooth nigori to complement our variety of sushi. Below is a list of the various sushi provided with this meal --(oyster sampler) Jumbo oyster w/scallop, yuzu foam and ikuraEgg custard w/black truffle sauceChutoroMarinated SalmonSpanish MackerelHouse smoked Kampachi (similar to squid)King Salmon (smoky)Scallop w/yuzu (super puffy with slight tang)Japanese spot prawn w/topping of caviar (very clean, nice finish)Hand Rolls course and seasonal based (chef's choice premium sushi) --Negi Toro hand rollLobster hand rollUni hand roll (sweet and smoky)Because we were still hungry and also curious of this item, we tried their full Oyster sampler separate from the Domokase. This included the jumbo oyster w/scallop and yuzu plus Kumamoto oysters.Overall, I would say the Omakase here is small in comparison to some others I've experienced, though the $75 price tag is a bit of a reflection of that. Though while the portion seemed a bit on the smaller size, it was hard to point out particular stand out pieces but I did have my favorites. The Scallop w/yuzu was perhaps my favorite in the first half, the Uni hand roll was great in the hand roll course. My least favorite was the oyster sampler. While this dish looked incredible, the oysters were quite lackluster, and this was while in season. In general though, all the sushi was made of high quality ingredients and made with precision/TLC, so this is respectable Omakase. If you are looking for a 'starter' Omakase, I would highly recommend DomoDomo. I would personally return again for the lower cost yet quality Omakase in a more intimate/modern environment. Comparatively to some lower cost Omakase spots, DomoDomo has the upper hand with the classier and more modern space.

Hubby was looking for something interesting we could get into this weekend and he came across The Slipper Room. The midnight show looked promising so we got all gussied up and headed down to LES to have a fun Saturday night. Tickets aren't available until around 1130 and if there are folks still patronizing from earlier shows, chances are you won't get a good seat so dunno if this would help but I suggest getting there super early to MAYBE get a good seat. We had to stand but were by the window so I hopped my cute little booty up on the sill and was able to get a bird's eye view of the show. I also suggest to check your coats for $3 if you weren't lucky enough to grab a seat. If you're parked close, your best bet is probably to just leave them in the car. There are viewing areas on two levels and you're probably going to find a spot at the very top of you're early enough. They have a bar and servers so you can definitely stay and chill. The host, Murray Hill, was hilarious. This particular night, he was dressed like furniture...inside joke. We only stayed for the midnight show but they have another after intermission at 1AM and I believe they turn into a go-go bar with live dj after the last show. All of the acts were good. It's a quirky show but I'm into Burlesque which tends to be eccentric. We had a good time, save for some of the younger spectators that definitely showed their ages and I would definitely go again but dress more casual and definitely wear FLATS!

Hot dang, even though I have been here a few times now I'm finally writing a review for Joe's. What the heck is wrong with me? This is one of the best spots on the UWS to chill out at!Tasty burgers. Even though I am no longer eating red meat I can still rave about the juicy goodness of their cheeseburgers here. Oh, and the bowl of fries is damn skippy too! Great music - old school 70's rock & roll, hip hop, and rap classics playing at any time.Eclectic beer list. More than enough of a selection on tap, in cans, and bottles. Sierra Nevada, Founders, Dogfish, Left Hand, Ballast Point, Evil Twin, Troegs, Victory, Ballast Point, etc.House cocktail list. With concoctions such as the Sex Machine, Night Fever, Scooby Snack, and Flash Gordon's Breakfast you can't go wrong. Then again, just have a Burt Reynolds and all will be ok with the world ( a beer and a shot of whiskey).Friendly staff and bartenders. From the bouncer/manager to the bar staff they are all pretty cool.Terrific vibe. Long bar with plenty of stools, comfy bench seating and tables. Nice decor.Kitchen open late. Yeah, because sometimes after a late night out partying you just need a good burger. Small menu though. The times I have been here we have rolled in after midnight. Food! Boom!Prices are ok but for what they do charge for a burger you would think a side of fries would accompany it. Charging for both separately gets a bit costly. At least they do offer a happy hour here too. Can't ask for much more than that. If you want to avoid the fratty crowds that pack into the beer swilling bars up in this part of town, and want a more mature laid back place to spend a few hours or more in a cozy atmosphere, then saunter up alongside Joe's and let him take you on a magic carpet ride.

I came here today after getting a craving for kalbi/Korean BBQ. With only the non-ideal/overpriced Mill Korean nearby, I lamented my situation -- until I remembered iFood! I've only eaten here once before, when I ordered the tacos which no longer seem to be on the menu. The tacos were a bit pricy, given the size (small corn tortilla) and high shredded cabbage/lettuce to meat ratio. There was a lot of sauce, which was delicious, but a tad much for a single corn tortilla to handle.Today, I ordered the regular spicy pork (jeyeuk) for $7. While not exactly what I had in mind, it was certainly good enough to fill my craving. The regular size comes with a fair portion of meat over a large serving of rice and a side of pickled daikon slices and a couple pickles. The meat is well seasoned and flavorful, and consists of a good mix of lean pieces and a few fattier ones. The "spicy" doesn't have much heat to it, but it does have the flavor of gochujang, albeit milder. Overall, iFood provides a nice, cheap lunch which is nice in a city (and especially the Morningside neighborhood) lacking Korean food for under $15. Looking at other reviews, it seems the ddeokbokki might be the best dish here, and I'll be sure to try it next time.

I came here with some hesitation as this bowling alley is attached to port authority and I thought it had the possibility of being the sketchiest thing ever. HOWEVER, I came here and was blown away but how great it was. There was complimentary coat check on the bottom floors and the whole place looked nice and clean. My friend had set up a party here, reserving three lanes for a group of friends. Each lane came with either a beer tower or a pitcher of margarita. We got pomegranate flavor and it was delicious. We also got a side of fries which were crispy and hot. Delicious!As for the lanes, they were clean with plenty of bowling bowls, a table and cubbies to put shoes or purses. It had everything that was needed. This place had multiple areas including a couple of bar areas with TVs playing sports and plenty of space for sitting down. The music that night was hip hop and my friends and I couldn't help but get down and dirty. When Puff Daddy calls out his bad boys for life, we just had to obey. Overall, it was a great time. Great food, friends, bowling and drinks. I would definitely recommend it for group gatherings looking for something to do.

They have a great lunch buffet in terms of diversity of items as well as the taste. I came during the huge Blizzard of 2016, and they were still open and remarkably full. The lunch buffet goes until 4pm! So that's perfect for those night owls who can't get up before noon on the weekends...In any case, the decor itself is nice. I guess the one annoying thing that happened was that when we arrived at 2:50pm during the blizzard, there was one other party there. We were told to sit anywhere we want. We chose a 4-person table at one corner with good lighting. Someone ran over and told us that we couldn't sit there. We asked why, and they said they had a reservation. We asked when. They said 2:50pm. I was going to get angry right there. It was obviously a lie. Who makes a reservation during a blizzard for an Indian buffet at 2:50pm??? In any case, we didn't escalate it and sat at a dark 4-person table. We later brought it up to the manager, and he apologized and said it should never have happened. The buffet itself was delicious. They had your standard chicken tikka masala as well as lamb and fish options. In addition, they had a vegetarian section with saag paneer (tasted different than others I've had...) and some kind of breaded veggie. In any case, all good. They also had a dessert bar with mango pudding and rice pudding. Very good. Overall, the price was also reasonable, at under $15.

Beautiful atmosphere to indulge your sweet tooth! I keep hearing about Lady M and just happened by this location accidentally. Inside you will find lovely fresh flowers, a peaceful atmosphere and table service. The table service increases the cost. You can purchase whole cakes or order a slice. The average cost for a slice is between $5-9.00. After I inquired about the ingredients I decided to pass today. My allergies couldn't take it. The employee was very gracious explaining the ingredients in detail so I would be sure not to overdose on something that might cause a problem. I have friends to entertain at times. I'm sure this would be a great place to share a sweet experience. I'll come back and try one of the little chocolate treats!! In the mean time please enjoy! Let me know what you think!

Speakeasies are all the rage these days, but how often do you find a ramen shop tucked away inside a coffee café? Welcome to Kopi Ramen, a 1-month old new Japanese noodle restaurant in the heart of West Village. My gf and I first entered through the Kopi Kopi Coffee shop and walked to the back where we were greeted by the host, who slid open the back door to reveal a quaint, cute eatery. The lighting is dim, the space cozy, and the atmosphere sultry. They have an open kitchen where you can watch the chefs prepare your dishes.The menus is short, with about 5 appetizers and 5 noodle dishes, along with some sakes and other alcohol drinks. We pretty much ordered all the appetizers, the spicy miso ramen, and the shoyu ramen. The miso-braised pork belly came with five pieces, each sitting on seaweed and garnished with scallions/chives. They were cooked perfectly and was by far the best appetizer choice. The stuffed-chicken-wing gyoza came out to be more interesting in concept than execution. While the chicken was delicious, the inside stuffing felt bland and could have used more seasoning. The charred edamame is a spin on the usual raw edamame. My gf did not like the roasted taste. I thought it gave it character that other edamames do not have. I will say that roasting them makes it more difficult to eat, as some parts of the shell are blackened and add a soot-y taste. The last appetizer was the tofu salad. It was pretty average.My shoyu ramen was delicious - as a soy-sauce base ramen, it was very light yet filling. The chashu pieces were cooked perfectly. The slices melted in your mouth. My gf's spicy miso ramen was more hearty and thick. I preferred that one because I like it when the broth is overflowing with flavor. So depending on your preference, you can go with the lighter shoyu or the heavier miso. Overall, the ramen made a solid impression on us and the attentive service made me a fan!

An interesting Korean dessert place, we stumbled upon this place as we were walking through West Village. After being away from New York for a few months, its one of the things that I missed about this cool city - the ability to stumble upon hidden charms while walking through the city. We got the katen (which is basically jelly noodles) with peach sauce and fresh fruits, basically its jelly with added cut fruit. It was quite good - and I am looking forward to coming back here to try some of their other desserts - sesame shaved ice which the owner told me they were experimenting making with soy milk among others.Also super friendly staff!

What's big and round, goes down fast, and can make a hard landing? No, it's not a UFO! Nor is it me after my full belly makes me topple over and crash. It's these huge, fluffy doughnuts that seem to swoosh down your gullet and crash on your hips if you eat too many. The service remains friendly and welcoming at this Flatiron outpost, the doughnuts still delightful with their softy, yeasty interior. I did have to subtract one star on my 2016 updated review for their glazes. For some reason, the glazes don't pack the punch they used to. I am not sure if it was an off day but the brilliantly hued hibiscus was a dull pink. Sis noticed it immediately as it was her fave flavor. It also was not as tart as usual. Then my old standby, the salted chocolate caramel, also lacked some oomph. There nice contrast of salt versus the sweetness of chocolate wasn't as powerful as many times before. I can't say the passionfruit wowed me as amazingly as before. Dough, oh Dough, what happened? Did you change your baking standards? I wish you would make minis, as you did on the Holiday Hangover. I am still fond of your doughnuts and will be back to taste them soon and hopefully up my rating back to 5 stars again.

Looking for a place to get more liquid calories than solid? Well, look no further! This is the place for you. If you're a fan of tequila/mezcal based drinks, even better. This place has some of the best in NYC. Even the tacky slushy style margaritas they pump out of a machine from behind the bar deliver amazing balance, flavor, and, of course, alcohol.Food? Yeah, they supply that too, but I'd rate it only worthy of alcohol absorbing. The salsas are alright, with the pico de gallo outshining the verde by several watts. The queso fundido is also pretty tasty, along with refried beans. Basically, anything that is best eaten on a chip is good here. Getting any ideas? Yep! Go get a margarita and some chips to munch!

"Let's take a stroll in the park shall we?"This place is pretty magical at night, upon getting inside there was a small wait which I didn't mind waiting because I was waiting for my friends to park their cars and stuff but once when we got in it was like a rush of good feelings and a nice flowy vibe going. This place has a restaurant and a full bar on the first floor but I advice you not eat here because the food really wasn't all that great when I had it. That's really was my only complaint about this place, they could really do a better job in terms of quality, and presentation of the food overall. However, "the park atmosphere" brings happy feelings to life, with lighting on the trees in the building it really puts a good vibe to your soul making you want to get up and have an epic time."Let me take you threw the rooms"Literally as you get upstairs you will notice there are plenty and I mean PLENTY of rooms that you can go into with different music to suit your dancing needs for the night. I say base it on your mood. They mainly play some of the best house/hip-hop/edm music out there and each dj is really on point with their mixes, so you will find yourself grooving to the beat non-stop then your gonna realize it's time to go the next second you look at your phone. Some rooms offer a really cool view of New York and has a full bar also on the upper parts of the room. Plenty of seats for big groups and parties I highly suggest if you want a seat, reserve seat ahead of time so you avoid people being anal about seat arrangements."Overall"Come walk around the park with your friends, it's magical. If your looking for that house vibe/hip-hop/edm or just looking for an epic night to tell your future grandkids, well this is the place to do that.

Who would have thought that French moroccan food for brunch would hit the spot?! La Shuk is a little gem hidden in Spanish Harlem. Service was great (maybe because we were the only ones there though.) but still great! Prices are reasonable and portions are generous. It has a very low key ambiance. Ordered:1. Green shashuka- baked eggs cooked in tomato sauce with spinach and feta. This would have made this dish even more delicious if the eggs were poached instead.. I got fooled by one of the yelp pictures for some reason..2. Spicy Lamb kebab platter- the kebab was more like a spicy lamb sausage but still delicious nonetheless..If you happen to be in the area and need something different to tease your palate, definitely stop by La Shuk!

I hired this company to move me from Brooklyn to Long Island City. From what I can tell, they seem to have the most reasonable pricing. That being said, you do get what you pay for. The move didn't go completely without a hitch, but for the price you really can't beat it. I think they tend to overbook, so unfortunately the move happened an hour later than expected, however they were good about staying in touch and letting us know about the delay, which I appreciated. Another thing that was a little bothersome was that I was initially quoted for two movers, but instead three showed up, which obviously affected the price. In the end it worked out fine and the move went faster and more pain free having the extra help. I think they also added additional fees that weren't initially mentioned, though I'm not entirely sure for what.Apart from that, everything was great. The movers were very nice and came prepared with tools and packing materials. They were quick and efficient, and moved everything in neatly. No broken items or scratched up hallways.I would recommend this company to those looking for moving services that don't want to spend an arm and a leg, and who are ok with being a little more laid back about the process. What I mean is, if you're paying these kinds of prices, don't expect perfection or the professionalism you might find with a company charging double or triple. Was my experience perfect, no, but the move got done and life was a lot easier not having to deal with any of it myself.

Bohemian Restaurant is that boy in your high school English Lit class with whom you (and every other girl) were fabulously infatuated but you've never actually spoken to him. In fact, he rarely speaks. Last time he said something in class, you heard that some girl fainted on site. Then there are stories about him rescuing kittens from trees and performing CPR on a drowning kid last summer.Basically, he wears a cloak of mystery and inaccessibility. And for that, you are curious. You want to get to know him.He is the Bohemian Restaurant.As many have mentioned already, you need to get the phone number from someone who has dined here previously (or have the googling skills of my 85 year old grandma - I promise, it's out there). Be prepared to spell out the first AND last name of the person who you gave you said number. (No, I am not giving you my last name.) Alternatively, you can email them with a description of yourself and why you want a reservation. (Check their website for more details.)After seeing the place for myself (someone's cozy living room fitted with 6 pairs of low-to-the-ground leisure accent chairs, a signed guitar, hanging artwork, standing coat rack, and an indoor Japanese garden), I imagine that they want to maintain a chill dining atmosphere in which everyone who walks in is especially welcome because they were introduced by a friend. It's like having your friend vouch for you on a blind date -- yeah, man, she's cool, I swear. We went to preschool together and she was great at sharing. They also have the fact that the space was once owned by Andy Warhol and used as a studio for street-artist Jean Michel Basquiat, playing up the laidback, artsy vibe going for them.When I called, I was told that they only had bar seating available. But upon arrival (walk down the long hallway to the left of the Japanese Premium Beef butcher shop), we were offered table seating! It was our lucky day! (Actually, the two large 6-person tables were empty the entire time we were there 6:30PM-9PM.)Even though it was our first visit, we ordered a la carte because most of the dishes we wanted to try were not in the $58 tasting menu.The absolute star of the night (besides the panna cotta) was the Uni Croquette. It was perfectly fried and crispy on the outside with a lightly flavored mushroom cream inside (soft peaks, y'all bakers). The dollop of uni on top completed the trifecta as its "fishiness" (if any) was completely masked by the mushroom. Ingenious, really. Each piece is $13 so make sure you order one for each of you. WORTH IT.As a non-cheese loving person, my fave part about the Mac & Cheese was the tomato butter toast. The mac & cheese itself was extremely cheesy and they used cheeses with a sharp finish (blue cheese, maybe?). But when you slather it atop the toast, it tasted like gourmet pizza for a moment, YUM. Bohemian was playing my emotions now.The Miso Black Cod and Washu Beef Steak were alright. The size of a Miso Black Cod was just smaller than a 20-something girl's fist (you get 2 pieces). It was a little too charred and salty for our tastes, but it was definitely cooked just right. The black cod nearly fell apart as we chopstick-ed it to our personal plates. When we ordered the Washu Beef Steak (market price), our server brought out a chalkboard in the shape of a cow to physically show us the beef cuts they had available. We ordered the 10.5 oz flat iron (shoulder) cut; the mound of rare steaks covered a bed of roughly cut potatoes and fried garlic cloves.The Yuzu Panna Cotta was silky and light with bursts of sourness if you get a piece of the yuzu jelly in that helping. It's actually not listed on the normal dessert menu, but our server happily brought it out for us upon our request. So good!!Ah, and we ordered the Plum Sake and the Bergamot (earl grey infused gin with raw egg whites, pomegranate syrup & bitters), both light drinks that complemented our meal.Minor things we were disappointed in:- Seemingly lack of knowledge about the cuts of beef - our server could not confidently explain each cut in layman's terms e.g. rib-eye, sirloin, T-bone: "Maybe this area or this area," he said.- We were never asked as to how we like our steak cooked. I understand that this may have been the chef's choice, but if we don't usually eat rare steaks (this child aka me is getting there... slowly), I doubt we will suddenly realize that this mess of blood and juice has changed our lives forever -- but we powered through most of it (& took the remainder home).Now that we've walked through this cloud of secrecy and seen the other side, I assure you Curious Georges that it's a good dining experience, but it won't be the best meal of your life.Clear eyes, full hearts, can't lose.

Are you a fan of Chinese, but not a fan of meat? Add Buddha Bodai to your speed dial.And c'mon, that name! It just rolls off the tongue. Repeat after me: Buddha Bodai. Buddha Bodai.Their vegetarian "chicken" with mixed veggies comes in a curry sauce and is a sure fire crowd pleaser ($16.45). Be sure to try their portobello mushroom in black pepper sauce (14.45). The mushroom slices are huge. And get the brown rice, because it's good for you.Yeah it's pricey, but go vegetarian like Ghostface Killah.

It was a definite good time. We both terrified and entertained our mixologist, Dave. He, in turn, gave us mind blowing, tasty drinks. The old fashioned was divine. Beware the strength of the sazerac. They also offer beer and wine. Everyone was happy.Ordered the chicken liver pate that also came with a side of bacon jam and crusty, delicious bread; two pickled carrots were part of the presentation. Paté is made in-house and was smooth with a hint of sweet. Yum. (I heard and smelled good things about the steak sandwiches --next on my list).Laid back atmosphere, great for a quick stop or a longer stay. The restrooms are tiny but efficient. Happy hour is a must. Crowd is mixed but interesting. Worth the visit--and a repeat.

I arrived here at the tail-end of my friends' dinner and just had a cocktail with them, so I can't say too much about the food. Actually, I didn't eat anything or order my own, but I did try the scraps from my friend Brian's truffle burger. As I mentioned, they were already finished and I had dinner plans somewhere else. I can't remember the name of the cocktail I drank, which was served in this cute copper mug, had whiskey + lime juice or something...it was amazing. I drank every drop and would've had more, but we were moving on to the next venue. Back to this appropriately named "You Fancy Huh? Truffle Burger" of Brian's. By the time I showed up, their food scraps were cold, but my friend insisted that I sample this wonderful thing. I can't lie. Even when this thing was cold and cheese no longer gooey, caramelized onions were limp and lifeless..THIS BURGER WAS BANGIN! I can only imagine the happiness it brought to my friend before my arrival. I was almost tempted to order one on the spot! However, this delicious thing and I will have to set another date. Oh yeah: Big screen TV and a projector for football. Decent sized bar area. I'll pay better attention next time I'm there and actually order something. Or many somethings.

At first glance, El Rey is one of the last places you'd find me in. It initially appears to be an agglomeration of the most recent health food trends of late, espousing a vegetable-centric menu where ingredients such as chia seeds, quinoa, avocado, and farro are all readily found. Nonetheless, the overwhelmingly positive reviews sparked my curiosity and when a few friends suggested it for a weekend brunch, I was more than willing to see what it had to offer.El Rey is aptly located in the Lower East Side, a tiny venue that sports a bustling kitchen counter where seating consists of a handful of tables and various counters; holding over ten people at a time would be pushing its capacity, so dining in isn't necessarily a guarantee. Orders are placed at the counter and assigned a number; it's a simple and efficient process that easily falls in the "fast casual" category. The food, however, is far from what you'll find at your typical chain restaurant.First, the "Everything Bagel" I tried was one of the most creative riffs on the traditional breakfast item. Instead of the traditional dough, a dense base of Za'atar bread was used, and served as the perfect vehicle for the generous serving of ricotta cheese, dill, and seeds. A few slivers of sliced red onion for freshness, and you have a perfect compilation of flavors and textures, and a surprisingly successful take on one of my guilty pleasures.Another surprise was the Lost Bread Egg Frittata, a dish that I would best describe as a chilled egg custard. The "lost bread" comes into play because of the addition of brioche in the egg custard, which gives it the unique denseness and texture. Drizzled in a fragrant pesto and topped with a shaved fennel salad and crushed avocado, it's a surprisingly delicious and well-balanced dish, and certainly one that tastes better than it actually looks.I have to say that El Rey surpassed my expectations, and I can see why it's done so well in NYC. Some might write it off as just another place following the health-conscious food trends of late, but the dishes served here are a unique blend of Middle Eastern and Mexican ingredients and flavors that are surprisingly successful in execution. I'd recommend visiting at an off-hour to make sure you can get a seat, or planning on taking your order to go; certainly, it's fair to say their popularity is justified.

Rai Rai Ken is our go-to ramen spot in the EV. Ippudo and Momofuku are great, but the lines can be crazy long and sometimes, you just gotta get a good bowl of ramen fast.I almost always get the lunch or dinner specials here, which comes with a bowl of any ramen, an appetizer, a drink, and a mochi for dessert. I can't remember the prices exactly, but I think it was around $14.The pork buns here are amazing, rivaling Ippudo's. The housemade sweet and spicy chili sauce they serve with them is out of this world, and I am glad they give me a bowl big enough to spread all over my bun.The ramen is solid. I tend to get the shoyu ramen, but have also had the japanese curry ramen base here. Both of which are great. I like a lot of spice, to I usually dump that sweet chili oil into my broth too. There is a good ratio of noodles to broth, a well-cooked soft-boiled egg, some pork, some green onions and other garnish as well. Delicious.I have only had to wait here one time for a table, it seems that Rai Rai Ken has found a good balance of quick service, and a crowd that likes a quick turnaround. I wouldn't expect a party to come here and sit for hours, it's in-eat-out for most.The place is small and not as well decorated as some of their competitors, but does that really matter? I put Rai Rai Ken solidly in the top three ramen spots in the neighborhood.

The so-called Doughnut Bubble is less likely to burst than the Cupcake Bubble. Remember the cupcake penetration of roughly 2008 - 2013? Cupcake shops, cupcake food trucks, cupcake competition TV shows, cupcakes EVERYWHERE. Then...*kaboom*. While a few did survive the explosion (Hey, Molly's!), many were left in the dust. In the ashes, artisanal doughnuts started to take their place. While cupcakes are a fun treat, they don't have the portability that a doughnut has. That's why I don't see the Doughnut Bubble bursting anytime soon.The Doughnut Project is an excellent addition to many of the other awesome and creative doughnut shops in NYC. Having only yeast doughnuts (my fave!), their flavors don't necessarily rival other places like Doughnut Plant or Dough, so it provides a good competition for them. I went with a couple of friends after gorging ourselves on brunch up the street, so I took mine to go! I ordered the Bronx (olive oil and black pepper; savory-sounding, but actually sweet!), the Constanza (chocolate-dipped with crushed pretzels), and the Pumpkin King (glazed with cinnamon-roasted pepitas). I loved all of them equally, the subtlety of the Bronx lending it to be my favorite of the three. My friends got the peanut butter and jelly doughnut, seemingly enjoying theirs! My only minor complaint would be the flakiness I encountered with the glazes; they seemed to crumble off of the doughnuts quite easily with the white-glazed donuts (the Bronx and the Pumpkin King), though the chocolate glaze stayed more in tact with the Constanza. The interior is absolutely crazy, with a huge emphasis on "Star Wars" and splashy bright colors! There is limited seating, but enough to post up and enjoy a sweet treat while people watching folks strolling along Morton Street. I can't wait to try out more flavors in the future! If I wasn't so full from brunch, I would have gone for the bacon-topped doughnut stick, but at least I have a goal for my next visit. ;-)- - - -NOTE: After further discussion with my friends, it turns out that there wasn't any peanut butter inside of their PB&J doughnut! I remember noting this and saying that maybe it was simply in the dough, but They realized it after looking through photos on Yelp and seeing Mike C.'s photo of the PB&J. This doesn't affect my review, per se, but they were a little bummed once they made the realization. Haaa. Hopefully they can go back for one that's absolutely LOADED with it.

Mission Chinese is both a three star experience and a four star review. It is very difficult for me to rate these folks three stars primarily because of the high quality ingredients they employ. And since taste is highly subjective I'm not going to suggest that my taste buds are any better than yours. We ordered the $40 per person tasting menu and mapo tofu was amongst the dishes. The mapo tofu for instance, was the best I've ever had but I don't like mapo tofu. Since there was no substitution of dishes permitted we begrudgingly dealt with it. Stir fried celery was NBFD. Stealing the evening was the green tea noodles. Double happiness yummy. I enjoyed the fried chicken but be forewarned that they go out of the way to make it extra spicy. My company couldn't handle it. I'm told that the pizza is good. Apparently there was a preexisting pizza oven when MC took over the spot and the owners decided to keep it. Annoying to me was the obscure wine list. Since I'm not an oenophile perhaps I didn't know the selections. However I felt that folks like moi should be able to identify at least one red or white from the menu. It isn't a big deal to add a red and white Mondavi to the list; just say you're out when an nitwit like yours truly orders it.  The place was hopping with hipster DBs going out of their millennial minds to converse at heavy metal concert decibels. The wait staff--which was composed of the same folks--were pushy and indifferent. MC is most certainly not a place for non-hip geezers--once again like yours truly. However, the very happy greeting gents at the door were excellent!I probably will not return but that doesn't mean you shouldn't visit. After all, when are you likely to stumble across a Chinese (Szechuan/Hunan) inspired food joint that uses excellent ingredients?

I ordered delivery from this place on a Sunday. I got two entrees because... YOLO? (My alternate theory is PMS). I am torn between a 3 star and 4 star review, but decided to round up because I'm assuming that most of my complaints are due to the fact that I ordered food (i.e., burger and fries) that doesn't really keep its texture during the delivery process. -The Chipotle burger, ordered medium rare, with fries: The burger and fries combo is famously difficult get right in a delivery order. It always comes with a soggy bun and uncrispy fries, and yet I never learn. This time the burger was actually really good (more like a medium than medium rare though) but the fries were not that crispy. I think I would have loved this if I ordered it piping hot in the restaurant. Note that the Chipotle burger doesn't come with lettuce and tomatoes. -The Volcan (skirt steak with rice, beans, and pico de gallo-like salad): The steak was a bit on the tough side (overcooked), but flavorful. The rice and beans were AMAZING and same with the salad. If you order this, be sure to order the steak medium rare or rare because the cook seems to cook everything one or two degrees more done than it should be. This dish was substantial in portion size. Conclusion: I'll be open to giving this place a try again, especially as dine-in.

Delicious burger and cottage fries!JG Melon does not take reservations nor credit cards. Make sure you bring CASH. Make sure everyone is present or you will have to stand.You can sit indoors or outdoors. The service was decent.I had a cheeseburger and cottage fries. In case you were wondering what cottage fries were, they are deep fried slices of potatoes. And they are delicious. The burger was amazing, so juicy and delicious. Top it with lots of ketchup... YUM.JG Melon, I'll be back for more.

What a great little coffee shop in FiDi. FiDi is getting very glossy with the high end shops and fancy condos opening up, but down a mildy-creepy alley is Bleustone Coffee. It is a tiny hole in the wall. You could easily walk right by the place. However, where else would all those financial district types be going in such an alleyway. Another thing I have come to find out is that Australians love coffee in a major way. I had no idea. I just got a regular old coffee. I am not a coffee snob, but it was very good. Others seem to agree. The place was packed and there was a line waiting to order in the middle of the afternoon.Need coffee when traipsing around Wall Street? Sneak down the alley just behind and pop into Bluestone.

Very hospitable cafe with healthy menu options. This is one of those restaurants in which you could spend either 30 minutes or 2 hours of your time, meaning great convenient quick food in a very relaxed and welcoming environment. Dante definitely masters this dichotomy by its quaint and rustic atmosphere. Great place to catch up with friends or to simply get a quick meal.

Very cute, small, specialty French goods store that is a sister-store to La Bergamote Bakery across the street. Even the person working at the counter is full-fledged French with a heavy accent lol. I would've given them 5-Stars, but that rating belongs to Le District market at the World Trade Center as that's the best French Market in NYC hands down. But La Bergamote is a close second, and much smaller and without wine. This store just opened and they have a number of awesome food products, all from France:Duck RilletteSaucissonPateFoie GrasJamsHoneyDijon mustardSardines from BrittanyGoat & Camembert CheesesCheese boardsLaguiole knivesChocolatesCandiesCrackers, etc, etc. If you're into French food, then this is your spot!

Truly an excellent venue for an event. Came here for a friend's bday and we had the entire upstairs to ourselves. On the menu was porkbelly tacos, chicken tacos, plantains, shrimp, chips w/ salsa and guac and some of the most addicting delicious churros with chocolate sauce I could ever imagine. I had like 15 of them, no joke. Usually I have a lot to complain about at these events because waiters are often terrible about bringing drinks and food in a timely manner and being attentive to the entire group. Mayahuel was the exception. We had one waitress and two food runners. They were on point. The waitress would ask about my next drink perfectly on time, every time when I had about 1/4 of my drink remaining.Every food item was always present on the table and if something sat for too long it was promptly replaced.  Drinks were delicious too. I never made it past the tequila & mezcal old fashioned. Picture a smokey old fashioned. Quite delightful. I definitely want to come back here.

It has really been awhile since I dined in French restaurant. Saju Bistro at the Theater District in Midtown Manhattan reminded me of how fine the French inspired dining experience can be.The dining hall is adorned by various chandeliers accentuated by a high ceiling. The ambiance is cozy and romantic, the table setting was arranged to casual elegant, the table for two were comfortable and spacious.As soon as we are seated, the waiter served us a bowl of mixed olives marinated with olive oil with garlic, baguette and butter. The Provencal Fare dominated the dinner menu. I selected the off menu French version of Spaghetti Bolognese, it tasted really good, the ingredients are fresh and it went beautifully well with a modest bottle of Pinot Grigio.The customer service was awesome. Upon request of the check, our server complemented us with a variety of home made cookies. Certainly a place to be recommended.

This restaurant is a local gem!The hubby and I have been wanting to give this place a try for a while and recently had our chance to do so.When we arrived, we were greeted like old friends by the hostess. She made us feel extremely welcome. Our waiter, Oscar, was just as lovely. He took very good care of us. Oscar made terrific recommendations on what we would enjoy eating most.We had:- Salad Frisee - delicious- Roasted Baby Beets Salad - terrific- Coq Au Vin - so good!- Canard A La 'Orange - delicious- Mashed Potatoes - very goodOur cocktails and dessert were also extremely good. The decor is really nice, intimate but not overbearing. Very clean lines. The restrooms are also super clean. We will definitely come back!

Pizza is pretty good!! I didn't know what to expect, but I'm on a mission to try as many different pizza places as possible. Starting with my neighborhood. I was with my sister so we ordered two pies. We got the fresh mozzarella pie (which was just ok), and then got one with mushrooms and peppers. That one was really good and I saved some of each for later. They were both good as left overs, but I think I'll be ordering pizzas with different toppings instead of the plain mozzarella. I will definitely order again from here and I'm glad this place is very close.

Southern Eats // Sports-Bar-ChicMouthwatering MenuCame here for the duck waffles... will come back for the ribs. Though the duck waffle photo looked enticing there was something about the plate that left me thinking maybe a small smidge of greens on the plate would give you a more well balanced meal. Lots of starch and meat, was a bit much on it's own. I added a little salt which proved to be a good move. Overall a very creative idea and a good dish to share if you're also ordering other things.Plenty of TV's in the main bar area which you can see from the dining area, if you're in the mood to watch sports Distilled is rather spacious so you won't feel cramped.The service, it was great! They left us alone just enough, and were helpful in navigating menu choices and choosing cocktails. I could see this being a regular spot for me if I lived nearby. Not a destination restaurant in my book...definitely a solid casual neighborhood place.If you're dining alone you'll feel comfortable sitting at the bar.The Scene: Casual, Hip, SportsbarDestination Rating: 6Date Rating: 5Hob Nob Potential: 7 Note: This location seems to be able to handle large parties, and I would assume gets pretty busy.

So I left a 1 star review prior, but things changed in the last 24hrs. I received a call from Ngam Management yesterday late noon, saying they are sorry for all the inconvenience caused and they will be keeping my reservation. Including discounting me 15% off the bill. (I thought that was a really professional thing to do)We got there and were seated right away. All of us starving as usual. We ordered a bunch of apps. The chicken wings were ah-mazing! Super spicy and very very flavorful with big chunks of chicken. The Surf and Turf was quite the platter too. I wasn't a huge fan of the shitake mushroom spring rolls, they were mediocre at best. We then ordered a couple of bottles of Rioja red wine! Paired perfectly with all the dishes. Mains we got some pad thai dishes, the burger, lamb and hung lai. I was not a fan of the burger. I think it was way too spicy for a burger. It just didn't work. The lamb pot pie was delicious and so was the hung lai. Our waitress was really helpful and friendly. I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for fusion thai food.

This place is pretty nomtastic.I love, love, love the Pozole Roja soup. So flipping good, doesn't have bullshit 'veggie' fillers like celery, AND it's shockingly low in calories. The shrimp taco is also a solid choice. Yum! They don't skimp on loading it up and it's low in calories. Perfection.I always take my food to go (or have it delivered) which means I haven't spent much time inside the location but they're quick on the to go orders and the delivery doesn't take long either. The food doesn't always look bright & 'perfect' because they don't add artificial colors and preservatives but it tastes delish and I don't feel like shit afterwards so yeah, exactly what we all need a little more of in NYC.Go. No, stop overthinking it. Go. Do ittttt.

Came here with a group of friends and I must say it was quite fun. You can do an AYCE and drink option or just the AYCE. The servers are great with keeping the drinks bottomless and serving your food quick.The way it works is that after you're seated and choose if you want the drink option or not, everyone gets to order from the tablets they hand out. The tablet menus have pictures as well as descriptions to what your options are, and it isn't just sushi. They have edamame, egg rolls, noodles, soups, salads, pastries, etc. After choosing everything you want you just hit send and wait. Usually in less that 10mins you already have some of your items in your order heading your way, depending on how many items you processed through.All-in-all it is a fun spot to eat and drink with a group of friends before going out bar hopping or to any event.

When fuku+ opened a little closer to me in a dining space behind Momofuku Milk Bar, I thought, 'hey, why not?' so we made a little visit on a Saturday around 1pm. To our surprise, there was no line at all! While all of the tables with seats were occupied, the standing bar and standing center tables were pretty empty. Given its location, I'm sure the lunchtime crowds during the week are unbearable, so I'd suggest coming here during the weekend for a proper meal. Things were a bit hectic that day because the POS broke down, so we had to wait a bit for our food. Here's what we ate: - MiniMe: This was a smaller version of original fuku's signature fried chicken sandwich. Sweet potato rolls sandwiched a giant piece of spicy fried chicken--the bun to chicken ratio was almost comical. The breading was spicy and the dark meat chicken itself was pretty juicy, and I understood why fuku was so popular. While being a miniature version of the original, I felt like the piece of fried chicken was large, so it was actually quite filling.  - Fuku Bites: These were small crispy nuggets, again with the same spicy breading. The green thick sauce that came with it made it so much better, though. It contained a heavy dose of garlic and honey.  - Juicy Lucy: This was an off-menu item that was a burger filled with cheese.
