The grilled cheese is also very good here, but I could never pick it over the burger (blasphemy).If you don't get this place, then good. Stick to your $20+ burgers with beef flown in from Argentina, topped with ground civet coffee and Cambodian breast milk cheese. Leave the down to earth places to the down to earth people and take your fancy ass elsewhere. Being successful in life doesn't mean losing a grip on reality--nor your taste buds.

I really like this place. Their cocktail list isn't as adventurous or extensive as some of the other big hitters, but that's ok because you can just tell them what you like!I walked in, told the bartender what I liked and he made me a drink and broke it down for me. I preferred the improv cocktails to the menu so I ordered one that was basically on the other end of the spectrum and he nailed it. In addition to making awesome drinks, the staff is incredibly nice. They're nice in a shy, 'catering-to-you' way, not in the 'we're trying to sell you something' way. They're super friendly and I never felt like I was being waited on, they were just casually checking up.

I was really debating whether to give this place 3 or 4 starts but since my problem with this place has to do with the hostess I went with 4. I called earlier in the day to make a reservation for 3 people around 8:30 but I was told they don't take reservations for less than 6 people and that there would be a 25 minute wait so I should come in around 8. I got here at 8:15 and I was told the wait is 35 minutes. Around 8:45 we checked in with the hostess to see how much longer and she told us about 30 minutes which made no sense because we already waited 30 min. We brought this up to her and she said that there's nothing she can do about it because "this happens every night". After we complained to her she told us she would seat us next which took about 10-15 min. Now the good part. The calamari ($7) we got was very soft and you could tell it's fresh. It was a decently sized portion, especially for the price. I got the Gorgonzola and pear ravioli ($9) which was absolutely delicious. It was the smallest of the three pastas we got but in my opinion it was the best tasting. The pappardelle was the largest portion. If you want bread you have to ask for it. It is complimentary but unless you request it they won't give you any. I would highly recommend this place for good cheap fresh pasta but you should be prepared to wait a while if you don't have reservations

I was very fortunate to obtain preview tickets to the One World Trade Center observatory before it's grand opening on May 29th. To enter the tour area you go through an entrance specifically set aside for this purpose. When you go in there is a ticket booth and then you head downstairs to a security check area. It's very similar to airport security complete with a full body scanner and X-ray machine. You do not however have to take your shoes off. Be warned, like a plane you cannot bring liquids in (lots of people were disposing of bottles of water).Once you enter it goes from a very bright setting to a very dim one as you are greeted by a GIGANTIC screen that gives you information about the building including how many visitors have been there and from where. From there you go through a hallway that has bedrock embedded in the walls with a video discussing construction of the building. You can actually reach out and touch the rock which is cool. From that section you wind up at the elevators.The observatory is on the 102nd floor, so to get you up there you wind up taking elevators that are among the fastest in the world. My ears popped three times! Never mind that however because on the way up the elevators put on an amazing show. Yes that's right, the *elevators* put on a show. Every wall in the elevator is really an LCD screen tied to a presentation. As you go up it is as if you are moving through the history of New York City (complete with a year counter in the corner) and you see the city rise up around you as you go up. If you're afraid of heights this may not be for you but I thought it was amazing.Once you exit you are ushered into a long room with a big screen. A video about New York City is played for you and then suddenly the entire screen lifts up and you are greeted with the sky! It's a very dramatic presentation and everyone clapped and gasps were heard throughout the room. It was a gorgeous presentation. After that my group was let loose to explore.There are two floors were you can drink in views. The 102nd floor is the highest, but the floor below is also great for views. You can get some amazing pictures but be warned if it's foggy (as it was the day I went) your views will be limited. All that said, there is nothing like seeing New York City from so high up. Even better, you can walk around in a circle to get views in all directions. On one side you'll see the Brooklyn Bridge, on another you see New Jersey. The word breathtaking barely does the view justice.A neat feature is the "Sky Portal", a platform where screens below show you the street scene below you, simulating what it would look like if you were floating high above the city. it was super fun.There is also a series of LCD screens arranged in a circle to facilitate a presentation about New York City run by the staff. No matter who you are the presenter makes you an "honorary New Yorker" which is cute. Near that display is the gift shop. The prices aren't cheap so if you're going to shop there get ready to burn some cash.There are rest rooms for folks to use and they were clean and well maintained. Staff is constantly in maintenance mode here so that is hardly a surprise.When you take the elevator down gives you a completely different presentation which is cool to see and yes, your ears will pop again.This was a great experience, but be warned there's a $32 price tag per person to get in so budget accordingly. Still, if you love New York City (or amazing views) you owe it to yourself to experience this at least once in your life.

I tried the Bamberg here and fell in love. So delicious.The Bamberg has chicken, cucumbers, and dijon mustard. You'd think that this is just a normal sandwich, but it's not. The chicken is fried to perfection. It's so juicy, thin, and flavorful. The cucumbers and mustard are the perfect combination to have with the chicken. The bread is just okay, but I am too focused on the rest of the sandwich anyway. Yum!If you don't like cucumbers or dijon mustard, try the Sweet Onion sandwich which has cabbage and a tzatziki sauce instead. This one is delicious as well, but IMO the Bamberg is better.

A sunny, cozy Israeli-ish spot with a broad menu of mezze, sandwiches, soups, entrees, and drinks. There are more than 12 chairs here--it's not a tiny place, though it has the feel of one, and it has room for groups. In warmer weather, the storefront opens up and it all feels light and airy. I've been here a couple of times and ordered or shared a fair amount of things, and I wasn't taking notes so I'm a little blurry on details. The summary, however, is that I liked just about everything, and got the impression that there wasn't anything especially bad to order. Details remembered:- They mix a hard-boiled egg into their guacamole--this is both unexpected and delicious.- I first came to try the Israeli breakfast, which is usually combination of eggs, an Israeli salad (tomato, cucumber, a bit of onion, mint and parsley or in any case some sort of herb, dressed in oil or maybe yogurt), bread, some feta, maybe olives, maybe a few other things. At 12 Chairs, those other things include teeny dipping bowls of labneh (strained yogurt), guacamole, remarkably salty cilantro-pesto, and tunafish salad. So, it's a little quirky, as far as the classic dish goes, but still satisfying.- Soup! I tried the borscht and the Yemenite soups. The borscht was basically a hearty vegetable soup, heavy on tomato flavor but a bit too light on the beet flavor. (This is partly personal bias, I like my borscht light on the tomato, heavy on the beet.) The Yemenite soup is a spicy Chicken soup and though it wasn't bad, it was a bit boring, and I'd skip it if only because there are better things to be had at 12 Chairs.- The sandwiches are large, you could easily split one between two people so's to have more room for mezze or dessert. I tried a nice grilled vegetable sandwich and the chicken sandwich. Both solid-to-good.- Hummus, falafel, Israeli pickles... all excellent and all as you would expect. If you crave these things, you'll be happy with them here.- For dessert, the 12 Chairs Blintz is great, but note they're presented more like crepes than like blintzes, fanned out folded triangles, very lightly filled. I was hoping for the traditional fat rolled-up blintzes stuffed full of sweet cheese. Still, we loved the dish, which comes sided and topped with fresh fruit and toasted walnuts, cream, and chocolate drizzle.

What a great find next to Port Authority! Definitely come to Bea for the amazing drinks and charming decor. It's a great place for a girl's night out or catching up with friends.They have delicious girly cocktails, broken down in liquor categories, that pleases everyone. Since I love my gin, I adored Over the Moon - rosemary infused aviation gin with aperol, lime juice, and orange san pelligrino. As one can probably imagine, it is citrusy, bubbly, sweet, and VERY STRONG and delicious. My friends each got a drink in the vodka & whiskey section, and are also pleased. While the drinks and delicious and well-crafted, I'll also point out that they're the same price (or more expensive) than some plates. Oh well, a girl's gotta have her tasty cocktail with her meal.Their menu is strangely organized and scattered as they are all small bites, more like tapas. The heartier fare are collected on one page while the lighter fare on the other. I had the shrimp toast and roasted beet salad, in which the former are two satisfying bites and the latter refreshing and lightly dressed. Other plates include Uncle Tommy's Pie (hearty) and Green Pasta (creamy, perfectly al-dente noodles).Ambiance is very cute and charming. They have exposed brick walls, and they play old movies on them. There are plenty of dim lighting, candles, and cozy seats.They also have an open air atrium/patio in the back, which was closed when I visited due to weather, but I would imagine it to be lovely on a summer night.Highly recommend! And of course - make reservations if you want a seat instead of the bar area.

Located down a couple flights of stairs you'll find Reunion. Been here a few times and each time has been a different experience. The first time we came there were probably only two other groups of 3-4ppl in the entire place. We sat at the bar to watch the baseball game and the bartender was very nice. He even gave us a couple shots to try that were flavored in house. My boyfriend loves their mojitos and said it was the best one he'd ever had. If I had written my review after this night I'd say it was a chill super themed place to grab a drink and chill.So we went back on another night and it was crazy packed, I mean seriously you had to be touching someone to be inside. This time it totally was like the gay bars I've been to; just totally fun, lots of dancing and energy. A full 180 from our initial visit.All-in-all I really like their drinks, food and the place as a whole. The only reason I can't get myself to give it five stars is because it isn't consistent on what to expect on a given night. but if you don't care either way, then hey, this is definitely a place for you to check out on whatever night.

Every day gourmet is a 24 hour deli located in between 40th and 41st on Lexington Avenue. First I have to tell you that every day gourmet has every thing that you could imagine food wise. If you are one of those people that cannot decide on what they want to have for lunch today come to this place and you will find something that will fill your stomach up. From the outside every day gourmet does not look like much boy was I wrong. When I say that every day gourmet deli has everything it literally has everything. They have a salad and fruit bar that is huge you cannot tell what's on the other end of the salad and fruit bar that's how long it is. In the back of every day gourmet they have an entire pizza station where there are pizzas that you can purchase as well as slices to go. They have a make your own salad station with a guy that stands behind the counter and you can create whatever type of salad that you want. Their salad station kind of remind me of a subway chain restaurant where you can just pick whatever you want and the worker will put everything together for you. The guy that was behind the counter had a very good memory because when I ordered my food I told him what I wanted and it was not on the menu and he remembered everything I asked for on my sandwich. To the left of the salad station they have a cold cut and hot sandwich station. They do serve boars head cold cuts here and you can get a hot sandwich or a cold sandwich. Their hot sandwich as well as their cold sandwich menu is very extensive. I ended up getting a grilled chipotle chicken wrap with lettuce and cheese. My wrap was very good. They had a lot of different types of grilled marinated chicken they had grilled marinated steak in teriyaki sauce and sweet Thai chili sauce. This deli also had cheeseburgers and gyros. I was really amazed at the selection that they had at gourmet deli. What I also like about this location is they are very close to Grand Central Station but there is also a Dunkin donuts across the street after I get my food I can go to the Dunkin' Donuts get my hot tea and then I can take the train. Overall I highly recommend coming every day gourmet it's very close to Grand Central Station the prices here are not bad and they do have one of the biggest selections I have seen in the deli in a very long time whether you're very health conscious or you want to eat something that will stick to your ribs I really think that every day gourmet will suit your needs for hunger. PROS: - Close to Grand Central Station- huge variety of food- they have a salad station- they have one of the biggest fruit bars I've seen in Manhattan

ATTENTION ALL THE SINGLE LADIES!!!Whenever I visit this location during lunch midweek, it's full of single men. Now, I didn't ask everyone if they are single but they had a look of being single to me. There were TONS of single dudes!! The other day I was sitting waiting for my order and there were 18 men waiting around for their food. Mind you, the place is a tiny little place so I was basically surrounded by a ton of men. Oh, it's raining men, hallelujah! It's raining men, AMEN! Now for the food, it is near where I work. Is there places with better curry, yes but I do not have the time to travel far during lunch. I even like my own Japanese curry better but that is not the point. Go! Go! Curry is not super expensive like the other places near the WTC area and it is filling. That is all I need when it comes to food for lunch. Is it a satisfying portion with a price that is good for the portion size and quick, yes, then it fits the bill. The katsu is not dry. That is all there is to this place. You get free topping coupons if you buy something on days with "5"...5th, 15th, 25th.

Stew's and I go way back - I remember as a kid driving from the Bronx to their store in Norwalk, CT and being amazed by all the interactive stuff around the store I could bring to life with the press of a button. When the Yonkers location opened in the late 90s Stew's became a more regular place for me, and as an adult I realized how awesome this place is. First off, how great is the location? Right off I-87, it's easily accessible from the north and the south - plus it's housed with a Costco and Home Depot below it and Ridge Hill shopping mall on the other side of the highway. Stew's has a large selection, though one can argue they don't carry every product one would regularly food-shop for. There are no aisles, you simply shop as you walk through the store. Their strengths are definitely meat, seafood, and dairy - and they also have good produce and deli sections; their hot buffet has a large selection as well. I may get some gripe for this but I don't think they have the best bakery; I find most of Stew's baked goods taste very processed, more comparable to Entenmann's than an in-house bakery. There are always a ton of free samples throughout the store, you can definitely skip lunch and nosh away at the samples.Stew's is more than just food, though - they do a lot beyond the main store. Before you hit the food there's a huge outdoor area they use for seasonal products. In the spring/summer they sell flowers, pumpkins in the fall, and Christmas trees in the winter. They also have an outdoor food court seasonally which serves barbecue-style food. There's a petting zoo and a wine shop as well. My favorite "extra" though is the ice cream counter - if you spend over $100 in the store (which I usually do) you get a free cup or cone. I really don't think I've ever paid for ice cream at Stew's - it's a great perk I hope they don't stop it!Stew's definitely made it's mark in NY - I don't come here too often but when I do it's never a disappointment.

After seeing nearly everyone on my friends list rave about this place, I decided that I reallyyyy need to check this place out. And I'm so glad I did!We made reservations because we heard about how crowded it got, but the backroom didn't get busy/loud/full until about 6:30!We came for happy hour oysters:- $1 Happy Hour Oysters from 5-7PM (all day on Monday) - all fresh and cleaned well!- $5 draft beers - Long Island sea salt ale, pilsner, lager- $7 cocktails- booth seating and bar in the front, tables in the back- They do have a small HH menu but we didn't order it (eyes on the prize, guys)- Complimentary sesame cookie with butter (more savory than Asian shortbread) + chocolate mousse served with checkYou know I'll be back!

The Handpulled Noodle is a legit spot that just opened up a couple blocks from my house in West Harlem (/Hamilton Heights, depending on whom you ask) nearest the 1 train, easily accessible by the ABCD.A great location, near a park and bars so you can carb-up before you liquor-up! It runs about 10$/pp and really is enough for two meals though I doubt anyone can put the chopsticks down once you start digging in. They offer fare for omni's and vegans alike. I was surprised to learn they carry seitan, which is a wonderful variation away from simply just veggies or tofu. Their noodles are (of course) naturally fresh, and have an amazing chewy texture you miss in prepackaged noodles. My favorite here is the seitan and veggie stirfry with ribbon noodles which is perfectly balanced between spice and saltiness. The cumin seitan isn't anything to write home about, however. They also have scallion pancakes, which I didn't really enjoy but Thrilla seemed to like.It's a small place, with some seating so grab one quick if you can (unless you see The Vanilla Gorilla standing behind you, then save me a seat instead!) but don't ABSOLUTELY plan on eating here unless you're fine with waiting 5-10 minutes. There's a lovely park a block away, enjoy it by the water if the weather is nice! But as they say here, eat as soon as possible as fresh noodles can become soggy and lose their texture relatively quickly.I am trying to get the owner to bring in some miso soup broth so I can try those, so we will see how that goes! Maybe when / if they do I can add another star! Some vegan dumplings would be great too, and popular with the growing list of vegan hipsters *slowly raises hand* moving into the neighborhood.

My new favorite place to order from.... The primo panini is really good. It doesn't come on what you would consider panini bread. It's more like actual bread, not the thinner and flimsier bread typically used at a deli or diner for example. It has steak, sliced mozzarella, tomato, arugula, basil, and portobello mushrooms. The steak isn't the best steak ever but it's only $13!!! I usually stay away from anything green, but I have a newfound appreciation for arugula now. Ok... The fries. You can either have greens (ew) or fries on the side. I'm not really a fan of either but these fries are SO GOOD!! They aren't the thin rectangular kind of fries you usually get on the side. They're also not "curly fries" although they are curly. They're cut thicker and they're a medium brown color, not a light yellow. Next time I will take pictures of this beautiful panini/fries combination. Which will be very soon. Probably tomorrow. Moving on to the grilled salmon wrap. Aside from the obvious salmon, it has fresh spinach, roasted peppers, avocado, and balsamic vinaigrette. Also comes with either fries or salad. It was pretty good. I ate half (it comes as a hot wrap), and then the rest later after it was in the fridge for a while. Not sure if I liked it better hot or cold. Bland, but I kind of like bland food sometimes (is that weird?)  2018 UPDATE:Tried the veggie wrap today and it's good and a little spicy because of the mayo. I was pretty hungry and kind of wish I had gotten two wraps and no side. I opted for the mashed potatoes as a side since it was a free add-on and not all of them were (some were $4) but I like mashed potatoes so I didn't mind. They of course came with gravy on the side or I would've been very disappointed. Everything I previously posted is still true to this day, although maybe after ordering the primo panini so many times, the steak is sometimes fattier than others and I don't like the fat because of the texture. Keep forgetting to take pictures, my bad.

I don't mind navigating through the standers who want a taste of this and a taste of that, anymore. Stand there. Say duh?! proudly. Because I am gettin' mine. My dairy-free coco and mango are singing out to me like a siren to a sailor. Yes dear I am going to crash with the best of them...after I add some wet cashews. What?! Another reward, already? sheesh! *evil grin*This place is always packed inside and outside.It is okay. Anticipate scattered folk to turn around quickly and change their minds. Guard your goodies. That little kid is going to make a mess. Side step. Get out. and enjoy scoop after scoop of blissful coolness.

After a prolonged period of exercise hibernation due to surgery and work, this fattie decided to throw herself head first into a new class to get her body together... and that new class happened to be SLT!(yeah at first glance I thought it was spelling something else too... whoops)SLT stands for "Strengthen Lengthen Tone" and focuses on making your body do those tiny quiver and shakes that really activate your slow twitch fibers. This class is great for those of us that need that harder something extra to get our tummy muscles (as well as every last effing muscle strand in our body) stronger and tighter. The teachers know what they're doing and I love that they come around to make sure we are doing proper form to help prevent injury. I am five classes in at this point in time and even though I still suck, I'm starting to notice I suck just a tiny bit little less each time.One of my favorite things about this class is that you can buy packages of classes and you just need to use them up within a certain amount of time. You can make your own schedule (depending on availability) online and their website makes it so easy to book or cancel. With classes maxing out at 11 people in most cases, you will need to plan ahead but it's not that hard at all. All classes for the following month will open up for reservations on the 15th of the month before. For example, for June classes I will have to really be on top of my schedule on May 15th to get the classes I want since they have high traffic.Now I admit, I've never done any kind of specialized Pilates-reformer-thingamajiggy type class before so when I first walked into the studio, I thought I was entering Christian Grey's fun room. I mean, come on... crazy bed-like devices with springs attached and straps for your wrists and ankles?? Whose mind wouldn't go there?Oh... wait... I'm the only one? Alright then, good to know. Too late now. You're thinking it too. And remember, better sore than sorry!

Do you like fancy?Do you like sexy?Do you like opulence? Do you like seriously quality made drinks with a lot of booze in them?Then head on over to The Back Room at One57. It's located inside the sleek new Park Hyatt Hotel in midtown. The lobby host greets with a smile and directs you to take the elevator up to the 3rd floor restaurant. As the doors part you walk into a room of high ceilings and luxury surroundings. Think marble, glass, couches, and refined ambiance. The kind of spot where the men are smartly dressed in suit and tie, and the ladies in designer dress wear. We sat at the bar on this night and had a wonderful experience. The staff here is very professional, and offers exemplary service. Great bartenders that will offer polite conversation and attend to your needs. If you chat them up and get to know them a bit they are actually friendly guys. Plus, they make a mean cocktail.As we had just come from a big steak dinner the craving for something sweet kicked in and we ordered a few desserts to share. Totally delicious with terrific plating. They even put out a few trays of assorted nuts and olives to nosh on. Perfect way to cap off our boys night out toasting our drinks among manly men. A great spot for a mid-week late evening nightcap if your enjoy a stiff drink while sitting in a sexy sleek opulent environment for sure. Pricey, yes, but it's a great spot to enjoy a libation in a very adult environment devoid of fratty meatheads, drunken sorostitutes, and bridge and tunnel yokels. Oh, and make sure you hit the bathrooms here. They are as big as my apartment and just as luxurious as the rest of the bar area.

I love living on the Upper West Side. I really do. But the nightlife, to put it bluntly, sucks. Exhibit A: Amsterdam Avenue. Lined with bars that are all some blend of fratty and creepy, this area tends to be a disappointment on most nights. But not to fear, Upper West-Siders! Dead Poet is a diamond in the rough here. Here are my notes:-Wonderful and friendly staff. Most of the nights I have come here (including last night), the place has been packed. But the bartenders, with their Usain Bolt-like speed, manage to serve you pretty quickly, even if you order one of their signature cocktails-FREE POPCORN. Okay, I almost never eat it, but if I'm somewhere in between tipsy and drunk, I like to know that it's there, waiting for me, like a trusty pet or a whipped significant other.-Beer and whiskey selection is solid.-Everything here, as you could imagine, is poet-themed. The decor, the drinks, the table adornments, everything. -So onto the drinks: Though these aren't the most elegant cocktails I've ever had, they're really tasty and tend to pack a punch. The drink menu changes occasionally, but my go-to girly cocktail here is the Walt Whitman (Lemon vodka, gin, coconut rum, and orange liqueur). Don't get this if you're not about sweets - really really sugary. Last night I also got the Dorothy Parker (Gin, Aperol, Punt E Mes and a dash of chili powder). Quite different from the Walt Whitman (as you'd expect, given the chili powder), but equally good. I have an affinity for spicy gin drinks, so I'd be remiss if I didn't try this one out.-Ambiance: Much cozier and typically more low key than the rest of the bars on Amsterdam. It can definitely get rowdy at times (especially when Columbia students venture down on Thursday-Saturday nights), but never overwhelmingly so. It's smaller than a lot of the other bars in the area as well, so overall it's a relatively chill establishment. Also a note: A+ on the music. There's jukebox that I'd suggest taking advantage of - great selection, and tunes from any era you can think of. They generally play a lot of throwbacks and I like a bit of nostalgia with my alcohol every so often.

Yakiniku means grilled meat dishes in Japanese. Yakiniku West did not disappoint at all by offering a wide variety of grilled dishes and more.Our party of six had arrived at our reservation time promptly and were instructed by the wait staff to take off our shoes. We were told to store it in the shoe shelves and follow him to the table.The sunken floor table that was given to us was very comfortable and spacious. We were able to move our arms around freely without knocking any items off the table. It was also equipped with two grill stoves that could be conveniently shared by three people.We all opted for individualized Yakiniku dinner sets that included edamame as an appetizer to share, a vegetable salad with ginger dressing, miso soup and ice cream dessert per order. I chose the rib eye dinner set that was served with Napa cabbage, a slice of corn and green pepper. I decided to cap my dinner with a ginger flavored ice cream. They had other flavors such as black sesame, red bean, vanilla and green tea. The ambiance at our table was indeed jovial, especially with the bottle of sake we unanimously selected which complemented the grilled meat and vegetables dishes perfectly well.The dinner was definitely scrumptious since the meat was so fresh! It was a great night entertaining a visitor from Central Asia.

Really cool vibes at this Flatiron speakeasy. Expect low lights, quiet background instrumental music, sexy people, and delicious cocktails. We had to wait about an hour on a Saturday night so we went across the street to Rye. We then had to wait about 30 minutes by the bar inside Raines law room for a couch to open up, but we didn't mind one bit. The bartender impressed us with his hospitality and awesome cocktails. For my second drink I asked for something with strawberries and blackberries with rum and he made me an awesome "strawberry-blackberry rickie" which was not on the menu but was absolutely amazing. Like I want one right now. The couches are facing one another so if you go as a couple, you will be sat across from another party. Therefore, either be prepared to be friendly or bring a party of 4-6. Minus one star for the wait and because I don't want everyone to invade one of my new favorite bars ;-)

Great prices, great food.Friendly, quick staff and the food tastes like legit Korean without having to be in Koreatown. I can always appreciate that!3 different types of kimchi that are free for the taking.Upstairs cafeteria style, downstairs is sit down eating, at the front is a cafe filled with coffee, tea, and other grab-and-go goodies.Servings are large and prices are low. Lots of seating options.'Side order' of BBQ pork $4 (Huge portion. Could barely finish half!)Cup/bowl of rice $1 Already dying to go back!

This Chinese-operated Americanized Japanese dining experience is better than the other Chinese-operated Americanized Japanese dining experiences on 9th Ave. Where else can you get a Lady Gaga Roll with your General Tso's Chicken?Actually we stuck to their raw fish this time. The Sushi and Sashimi For 2 was very fresh and filling. The sushi chefs plated beautifully! The medium size cuts were perfect. The sushi rice was a good sticky and passed the "don't fall apart before getting to my mouth test."California and Spicy Tuna Rolls were included but a bit small. The crab and fish were less than generous. I didn't find the spicy tuna spicy, but the roll had lots of tobiku.Service was efficient and maybe a bit too hurried. With the fish this fresh and of high quality, I'll come back again real soon. I don't care who operates the place.

I am still not sure how I feel about Momofuku but whoever thought of cereal milk ice cream is a genius in my eyes. I have never had corn flakes cereal really before this so it was a new experience. I was expecting the soft serve itself to be really sweet but to my surprise it was not. It was even a little sour to me. I really love the sweetened corn flakes they put around the rim, it goes perfectly with the soft serve. It was a pleasant surprise to find them at the bottom of the cup. I don't think Momofuku is overrated, i think it's a very unique idea that elevates the status of regular soft serve. However the price is a little much ( close to $6) that will probably continue to skyrocket. The size is smaller than a regular soft serve than you would probably get at McDonald's, the cup they put it in is like the size of a mouthwash cup.

Salad. Steak. Frites. For Everyone. As the waitress says, "it makes things simple." So simple, in fact, that one should not bother asking for ketchup, mayo, or butter. They are not available at this restaurant. I love this concept already. The salad is serviceable, just a bit over-lathered with the mustard vinaigrette. The walnuts are a nice touch. On the other hand, there cannot not be enough of that secret sauce on the steak. Creamy, buttery, flavorful. and light. Order your steak medium and you will be served tender, juicy and thin slices of steak accompanied by crispy fries that are actually very soft on the inside. At first the portion looks small, but then you will be surprised (perhaps not anymore after reading this) by a second serving shortly thereafter.L'Entrecôte is an excellent dining spot for both lunch and dinner. For the indecisive, bistro-like spot is a godsend with its singular focus menu. It often caters to professionals in midtown area, tourists, and leans towards a mature, middle-aged demographic. But no matter who it caters to, the refreshing simplicity and satisfaction of their offering is exactly on-point.

It's impossible for me to write about Brookfield Place without a heaping dose of nostalgia. But cut me some slack; as someone who spent the last three years calling this place my office, it should be a given.As with any long-term relationship, there have been highs and lows, and an endless number of changes. When I first started working here in the summer of 2012, the venue was still deemed the World Financial Center (WFC) and the first facades of construction were underway. Businesses started to close (a process that wasn't helped by Hurricane Sandy in fall of 2013) and construction barrier after barrier was put up in preparation for a complete overhaul. When it was officially renamed Brookfield Place, I watched as the luxury stores started to open, Hudson Eats and Le District transformed into dining staples, and the passageway connecting to the World Trade Center PATH was completed.I have yet to find another venue like it in the city. It's a space that's actually welcoming for tourists and visitors, offering free WiFi, a myriad of seating, shopping, and dining options, and a gorgeous waterfront view bordering the Battery Park City Esplanade. You'll occasionally find art exhibitions, performances, and even concerts being held intermittently throughout the year as well; keep an eye on the Brookfield Place website for details on events. And although the Winter Gardens are only a shadow of what it used to be, there's something inexplicably calming about sitting under the foliage of a handful of palm trees while the last few rays of sunlight filter through the glass roof overhead. I've lost count of the number of times I've retreated to those benches or to the waterfront when the pressures of the workday occasionally became too much.For those in the area who need an hour or two to rest, recharge, and regroup - there is no better place than Brookfield Place. Although I'm saddened to leave this building right before the opening of Parm and L'Atelier by Joël Robuchon, I'm sure I'll return again at some point. Until then Brookfield Place... sayonara.

Actual rating: 4.5 StarsOh no. I have an issue. I am a California native. We will rep In N Out until death. Then I tried Shake Shack and my heart is SO confused. So I'm going to be very diplomatic about this. They are different burgers. There are so many minute different components between Shake Shack and In N Out that you cannot really compare them. What they have in common is that they are both delicious. Shake Shack is good. The fries are incredible (sorry In N Out, Shake Shack is the clear winner there. Cheese fries take over animal fries. Please don't hurt me.). The fries are the right amount of crispy. It we could mix Shake Shack fries with In N Out sauce, that would be perfection. The burger is solid. It's a good chuck of beef, delicious ripe tomatoes, earthy lettuce, and their sauce wrapped in a delicious egg bun. The bun is arguable one of the best things about the burger. Everything together -- so good. So. Damn. Good. Shake Shack is good. It is solid. I would recommend it to anyone who is a burger fan.

Filipinos are passionate people.. and they are certainly passionate about their food (which in my opinion, makes it all the more delicious)! Although my bf is Filipino, this is the first time experiencing kamayan night which is only offered on certain days of the week. You will also need a reservation and there is a set price per person, so it is important to check the schedule and call ahead otherwise you will not be able to part take in the kamayan style meal. My experience at Jeepney was certainly very unique and enjoyable, especially with a large group of friends. What makes kamayan night unique is that you eat with your hands. This authentic type of Filipino cuisine means you won't be provided any utensils or plates and everything is laid out in front of you on large banana leafs. The food is plentiful and delicious. I especially loved the candied bananas and lumpias. There is also plenty of rice and longganisa (sausage). It does take a little getting used to, eating with your hands and it certainly adds to the dinner experience. The servers explain to you how to optimally eat with your hands, so don't worry, they will try to help you out! Overall, this was a pleasant and unique experience. There was so much food, that even our table of 11 had a few boxes of doggy bags to take home. The aromas, tastes and ambiance were really chill and fun. The service was attentive and kept our beers coming. If you are looking for something different and authentic, make sure to check out Kamayan night at Jeepney, it was delicious and fun!

The seedy building that houses Drunk Shakespeare threw me off, but man -- what an entertaining show it ended up being! I loved how seamlessly Shakespeare, alcohol, pop-culture references, and raunchy humor blended within the structure of Macbeth. The cast was witty, engaging, and totally able to keep the audience in stitches (and I mean, STITCHES) throughout the entire performance.I jotted down a lot of notes to incorporate into this review -- you know, having gone with complimentary tickets from Yelp and all -- but I also don't want to give anything away. Here's a list of five things that sound like total gibberish but would make sense to anyone who went to the same performance I did (December 10, 2014):   - Watermelon sexy talk   - Fresh........ Prince!   - Audience phone call challenge   - Southern Baptist MacDuff   - #shitgoingdownI wouldn't recommend Drunk Shakespeare to anyone who is uptight, easily offended, or prudish. But... we probably wouldn't be friends to begin with anyways, right? Choose your seats based on how comfortable you are with touching you, your companion, and/or your drink!

My 4 star review is an average of 2 separate visits to Vinny Vincenz.When my go-to pizzeria (Two Bros) closed down on 1st Ave, I immediately sought a replacement. My first trip to VV was last summer and I got my standard order: 2 slices and a soda. The pizza then was solidly average. Nothing spectacular, nothing really wrong with it either. At that time, the crowds in here were non-existent, i suspect due to the lack of air conditioning. I would have rated it a 3-star.Fast forward to last week.viewing.nyc/meet-the-guy…After the Instagram account @DollarPizzaSliceNYC rated this the highest thus far in the city, I came back for another trial order. This time, the pizza tasted completely different than before. Now the likelihood of them changing their recipe in the past 6 months is slim, so I attribute the change of quality to the increased patronage generated by the Instagram account, and closing of other nearby pizzerias. The more people there are, the quicker pies come out and the fresher the slice you get to shove into your mouth.The fresh dough was chewy but not spongy, thin but solid, great cheese density and sauce to cheese ratio. The sauce itself was a bit on the sweet side for me, but still a solid slice. I would have rated them 5 stars for a dollar pizza joint based on this slice.But... due to the inconsistency between the two visits, I thought it only fair to present them with an average, a 4-star rating. But in the end, does it really matter? You are going to eat a dollar slice based on convenience not on rating anyway... just know that if you have to duck in here for a slice or two, you will probably be alright.

Wow. Fancy Indian buffet! No, really! I wanted to stop by for my first round of Indian food in the city, and this one was quite close to where I live. Found that they offered a lunch buffet that was $17 (definitely on the pricy side), but I was hungry, and that was that. In any case, I was very impressed by the decor, service, and food. Not only were there ample fresh and flavorful entrees (your staple curries, tikka masalas, paneer), but there were also items that were freshly prepared and brought to your table. There were these appetizer potato patties with onions (awesome), flat pancake-like fried things (awesome), and naan (expected, but still awesome). They gave the two of us like 6 pieces of naan, which is a lot.Even the Kheer and sugar balls (not sure what real name is...) were delicious. Overall, loved the experience. Wish the price was slightly lower, but you do get higher quality food, service, and some freshly-prepared extras. Enjoy!

This place is beautiful. Drinks are priced a little high but that is expected for a rooftop lounge. It's quite scenic with great views of the city. The lounge is set up as a garden. It's an organic feel inside the Concrete Jungle. The set up alone makes it worth while. It does get packed and the lines to get drinks are way too long for my liking.But I would definitely come back

One of my best friends here in the city grew up in Las Vegas. Every day, she said, she passed a specific billboard on her way to school with a bunch of women bending over, their behinds shapely and beautiful; it was an advertisement for a strip club in the area. She's well-versed, and I trust her taste, so when she said we were going to Sapphire to celebrate her Big 2-9, I trusted her judgement. Only the best for her! As it turns out, it was only the best for all of her guests, including myself, as well!A mutual friend got everything arranged for us, from the party bus to and from his apartment in Hell's Kitchen, a comped drink for each of us, to a nice reserved area between the main stage and the secondary platform. I mean...literally, there were girls dancing less than six feet away from me any any given point of the evening! Backing up a bit, the check-in process was simple and streamlined; the bouncers were friendly yet you could tell they take no bullshit. They checked our IDs, ushered us into the coat check, and led us into the main room. DAMN. Not sure what Shanna C.'s review was about. I'm not calling her a liar; everyone has a different experience. All I'm saying is that the vast majority of our group of thirteen was women (eight women and five men), and we were treated equally as any male customer with no bad reception. A friend in our group bought me a lapdance (...as he so eloquently stated, "I'm not going to a strip club with Allison and NOT buying her a lapdance!"), and my dancer, Selina, was such a sweetheart and gorgeous to boot! I'm not prude, and this was not my first visit to a gentlemens' club, but it WAS my first lapdance. (Something to cross off of a bucket list, I suppose?) I was not expecting it, so I spent the first minute or so giggling like a little kid and I could feel myself blushing. Once I got over that, I actually enjoyed it! I told her that the beau (who wasn't able to make it out; poor him!) would have loved to see this. Ha! My friend, the birthday girl, had four (!!!) lapdances, and even got a Wicked Entertainment t-shirt from the night's guest, Jessica Drake. I swear, you've never seen a happier person in the whole entire world. The place is gorgeous, the music was bumpin', the girls were gorgeous, the staff was friendly yet firm with any troublemakers, and the dancers were never pushy about lap dances, et al. We all had an epic time, and a memorable birthday party was definitely had. It was definitely one for the record books!

So, I've been going to Les Halles since 1999, the year after Anthony Bourdain started in 1998, and it's always been a go-to spot for me for very good casual French country cuisine. Unfortunately though, it seems that the average rating is lower now (3.5), mainly because of the Bourdain "followers" who have unusually high expectations for this place. I think they come here with the expectation to be blown away by a 5-star restaurant because this is Anthony Bourdain's first Executive Chef role, and where he remains as a "Chef-at-Large", but they have to remember that this is after all, a Brasserie (meaning casual with hearty food with beer/wine) serving simple, comfort dishes all-day, at a fair, maybe even low, price, in my opinion.The place is meant to be casual, with French country food from Gascony (the "Breadbasket of France") such as Duck Confit, Cassoulet, SaucIsse, Rabbit, Foie Gras, Roquefort cheese, Coq Au Vin, Steak Au Poivre, Pate, Escargot, etc. Along with an excellent list of wines from almost every region in France - Burgundy, Northern Rhone, Loire Valley, etc...Monday nights are the best as ALL bottles are 50% off!This is one of my favorite casual go-to restaurants, when I don't know what I want to eat, and where I don't want to spend a ton of money, but I do want some good wine & ambiance, and when I don't want to have to deal with a reservation (I've always been seated immediately or within 10 minutes). If this sounds like you, then this is your spot. And, I do prefer this location to the John Street location.ps...for those "followers' who knock this place, if you really know Bourdain, you'd know he's much more a fan of simple, accessible, and reasonably priced food like this than anything else.

I went to a Fashion Week party here in February. As someone who has partied extremely way too hard, but is now into other stuff, it was kinda like hanging out with the Ghost of Christmas Past.All the tropes were traipsed:-the inventive, broke-down entrance that makes you feel special for knowing that the seediness is actually the work of a CitiBike-riding art director-the open bar with the super-sweet signature drink of the night that contains little to no alcohol, but bitches still be acting mad drunk ehhhh-the mess of winter coats piled high on leather couches, people rifling through fifty identical black wool pea coats to find their own-the nightlife photographers, oh man, i'd forgotten about them! The weird power dynamics of who is bestowing whom with social cache.-frickin' heels man.-yelling into your friend's ear to be heard. Or worse, when she shouts into your ear so loudly that it hurts something deep in your head, like you know you're permanently damaging something in there, but you still can't hear what she's saying, and the night is long and the floor is sticky, so with a final flutter of your mascara-laden lashes, you admit defeat and nod and smile AS IF you heard. -And now you are a scoundrel.-90s music spun by tiny popsicle stick-limbed people wearing giant headphones-scanning, oh all the scanning! you scan, i scan, we all scan. looking for what? faces we recognize. bodies that titillate. dead eyes and thigh gaps. sizing people up with recklessly long side-eye.-and of course, in the center of it all, refusing to be snuffed out, to be grown out of, to be matriculated into something more sustainable, is your teenage heart. the one that hopes and despairs in turn with every beat. shuddering at the sudden realization that you might be the ugliest, lamest, least cool person in the whole place and everybody knows it. then you catch your reflection in one of the mirrored walls and the lighting is just right and suddenly you are thoroughly, violently, magnificent and full of loathing for the masses around you --why are you slumming it like this, you handsome devil. and of course in the next second, you are in the tar pits of self-worth again, reckoning with some new inferiority.This is the ocean of adolescenceThis is the metronome of self-imageThis is what lies buried under your sensible puffy coatThat makes you look like a sofaYou are forever fifteen point five years oldAnd the Electric Room understands thatGive-up on the grow-upYou will always careAbout your hair.

Campbell Apartment is one of my favorite speakeasys in the city. Located within the depths of Grand Central, it used to serve as the private office and salon of John W. Campbell. You access the bar either by the elevators on the left hand side of Grand Central Oyster, or from the Vanderbilt side of Grand Central. The bar itself is extremely dark and has two floors. An older claim to fame was its cameo in the Gossip Girl series. There are seats around the bar, or sofas and couches scattered throughout the room. I recommend making a reservation or else the wait can be a joy kill. That said, the ambience is great for groups. It isn't an intimate setting, so it's not ideal for dates since you will probably be spending half the time asking your date to repeat what he or she said. The upper level is a bit more intimate and quiet but it is darker and usually reserved for larger parties. My go to drink here is the Prohibition Punch. This is served in a large fish bowl glass and is composed of Moet, Grand Marnier and Rum. If you're in the mood for something a little harder, they have a great selection of bourbons.

I had a great time here last night. A bar with skeeball, pool, live music and old school pacman is hard to beat. There was a decent amount of beer on tap and bar service was quick. I believe it was $7 per beer which is average in this area. I also liked the lights hanging from the ceiling. The way they were strung was similar to how they would appear on a back patio, so in a way I felt like I could be outside. Next time I'm in the area and looking for drinks, I will come back.

Just opened up right next to my office!Service is quick, everyone is pretty friendly.Decor is kinda quirky but not in a bad way. Reminds me a little of Wahoo's on 3rd Ave. They've got this cool little aquarium in the middle of the space and everything's a little yellow or themed Hawaiian.Walk up to the counter to order and then sit down to get your food, no need to tip!Food is not bad. I've only tried one thing, the Big Kahuna burrito, which comes out to a little over $10 with tax added in. The burrito itself was ok; nothing to shout about, but solid portion size. The rice was done well and seemed pretty fresh, which I like. The beans and chicken/meat seemed to taste a little dry and I think it could use stronger flavors, but definitely filling. The salsa was a little lacking in firepower, but it seems like a different mix than your usual tex-mex salsa.Overall, not bad. Prices are pretty standard for Mexican-like fare in this area, and they've got some interesting items on their menu. Looking forward to trying one of their mahimahi dishes for lunch sometime!

Very solid tapas restaurant; probably one of the better ones I've been to in the city.First off, the waiters know their stuff. Ask for a wine recommendation, and you'll get probably the most honest and usefully-descriptive answer you've ever gotten from a restaurant. They have a pretty wide selection of wines with some unique options, like a "living" red wine.Then, take a look at the menu and refrain from ordering one of everything. Will say that the goat cheese crostini is good, as Yelpers recommend; we also enjoyed the duck hash and crab bolognese, both of which were very savory and actually fairly filling.Only downside I can see is that the restaurant is fairly small (ie not good for groups), though they do allow reservations. The decor is pretty cool with all the exposed brick and the smoke marks above the candles.The food comes out super quickly, so this is perhaps a "safe" date location in the sense that it provides a convenient escape route...

4.5 for me. I grew up in C-Town so I've seen a lot. The good, the bad and the ugly. I wanted to move out as a kid mostly because of the gang activity. My own brother was accosted all the time by gangs to recruit him. Not everything is great in C-town. Of course everyone knows the great things about it, the awesome roast pork buns from Hop Shing, the bbq items hanging from the windows, the soup dumplings, the cheap quality imitations, and cheap prices in general. But we have our share of corruption, rudeness, city rats, and skid row looking areas. Despite moving away several times in my life, I find myself missing C-town when I am too far. Not so much the rude people but more the hustle and bustle, the stores, and being around people like me....and I really miss Hop Shing's baked roast pork buns and Cha Chang Tang's Fish Fillet with Spaghetti and tomato sauce and Heping's soup dumplings! One thing changing is the Cantonese stores and restaurants that once populated the entire area are now dwindling down to near nothing. This saddens me. That is what I grew up with. Watching C-town change through the years is quite disheartening to the Cantonese part of me. But one thing that will never change....you can take the girl outta Chinatown but never Chinatown outta the girl.

Imagine an overly dramatized informercial... you're frustrated, sitting in front of a mirror poking and prodding at your eye. You have somehow managed to get glue all over your vanity, hair, and fingers. You sigh and shake your head, clearly defeated, into the lens of the camera. Applying false lashes requires patience and innumerable tools. Measure twice, cut once, to avoid cutting off too much. The solution? One easy payment of $95.00. My lashes are thin, short, and sparse. Like a great push-up bra, mascara is a quick and easy fix but with obvious limitations... Applying strip lashes is a costly and inefficient process. It is unideal for every-day application. The clear alternative is eyelash extensions.G-Lash is tucked away on 32nd Street of Koreatown behind an array of over-sized signs, underneath a frame of poles erected for a construction project. The location is upstairs on the fourth floor hidden behind a door of frosted glass. Upon entering, you are immediately checked in to your appointment and whisked away. The front desk and the room of beds are split by a partition. The technician I worked with is Naomi. She quickly consulted me before our appointment. She presented me with a frame of samples of individual lashes. The curl of the lashes range from J, G, and C. The length ranges from 0.8 mm to 0.15 mm. For the most natural look, she recommended a mixture of 0.9 mm and 0.10 mm. The room consists of a row of massage tables. Each table is covered with clean white bed sheets, complete with a fleece blanket and a neck pillow filled with micro-beads. Comfort is an important quality at any eyelash salon. A session can last from thirty minutes to an hour long depending on the extension type. Naomi diligently and gently applied the classic set onto my eyes. They have stayed on for two weeks thus far with very little fall-out. Some Pro Tips: If you need to cancel your appointment, cancel at least 6 hours before. Missing your appointment results in an automatic $50 charge on your credit card. If you are more than 10 minutes late, your appointment will automatically be rescheduled. Avoid wearing any liquid eyeliner or mascara the day of your appointment. To avoid paying full price, Groupon deals are available for $45 for a classic set. Subsequent to your first visit, you receive two coupons for 30% and 20% off future visits.

In a dark, deserted land far, far away...ahem. In Times Square, the land of glittery lights and people who walk at the pace of tortoises (and tortoises rarely win races in NYC) you are frustratingly walking in search of something to eat. If you're with a group of people, go to [1]. If you're alone, go to [2]. [1] Derrick wants to eat something light because he just had a big, late, catered lunch. You and Ilana are very hungry. Adam just wants to satisfy his sweet tooth. Sophie is just annoying. If you don't care for Sophie so much and you decide you want to ditch them all, go to [8]. If you're hungry, but you want everyone to be satisfied, go on your Yelp app and decide on City Kitchen because they're new and they get bonus points for taking credit cards; go to [3]. [2] You decide on City Kitchen, located smack in the middle of Times Square on 44th and 8th. After walking up a flight of stairs, you admire the clean, modern look of the food hall and wander around. You see that the place is buzzing with people even for an early dinner time and you admire the diversity of food vendors that are crammed into this one spot. Right now you want something soupy and warm, but you do make note of lobster rolls (Luke's Lobster), burgers (Whitman's), shawarma (ilili Box), and sushi (Azuki Sushi) as well as dessert options. You'll think about desserts later. But first--ramen. Go to [4]. [3] Just a couple of blocks away from Port Authority and on the second level, you all realize that there are so many food vendors crammed into one location. There's Luke's Lobster, Whitman's, Azuki Sushi (which has its own counter/seating area), ilili Box, Gabriela's Taqueria, and Kuro-Obi. The last one intrigues you. It's an offshoot of Ippudo and you know just how massive the lines for the real locations can be. You decide on some ramen to satisfy your hunger. Your group is equally happy with the amount of choices available; even Adam is surprised that there are so many dessert options here. You ask Sophie to look for a table. Go to [4]. [4] You go to the far corner where Kuro-Obi is situated. There are three ramen options, but you go with the Shiro-Obi Classic. You also notice that Ippudo's infamous pork buns are here. You calculate your total...the ramen is $12 and the buns are $9 for two...but you pay for them anyway. You don't have to wait long before your name is called and you're given your bowl, your pork buns in a plastic container, and a cup containing wet wipes, a napkin, a ramen spoon, and chopsticks. If you're with a group, go to [5]. If you're alone, go to [6]. [5] You carefully carry your items and search for Sophie. The center tables are filled with people, but you discover a dark, back room that has longer tables and find Sophie and some of your group members there. Adam has gotten a leche shaved snow from Wooly's and Derrick is content with his dulce de leche Dough doughnut. You dig in. Go to [7].[6] You easily find a stool for yourself at one of the window counters around the perimeter of the area. You relish in the fact that you can eat while people-watching. Go to [7]. [7] For takeout ramen made quickly and with zero wait, you like it, but it's $12 for a bowl in a paper container. You wonder if this is a good enough deal. The broth is thin, refreshing and hot, and the noodles are flat and perfectly al-dente, but the two chashu slices on top are so thin and leaves you wanting more. You do appreciate the fact that the spoon is large enough that it will never sink into the soup in your bowl. The buns are pillowy goodness, though, and you only miss your $9 briefly. You finish one, and decide to take the other home. The doughnuts look good and will be the perfect snack later; you go to Dough and order two doughnuts. You notice that the flavors rotate. Go to [9] with a paper bag of doughnuts in your hand.[8] Make up a story and go home.[9] Go home stuffed and content.

I came here for drinks with a couple of girlfriends on a spring Friday. The views are great, and this a great spot in general. I used to come here often a few years ago when I used to work downtown. Although, they have revamped their cocktail menu since then. And by that I mean the prosecco pops. At $25 with tip, it sure is pricey. Although, quite delicious. I got the rum infused peach ginger popsicle and my friends got the blackberry mint. Would I come here again to have the prosecco pop? YesDo I think it is a little overpriced? YesDo I think they would sell more if the pops were priced at $15-$16? Yes

Eaten here a couple of times...The pulled pork is delicious, well seasoned, and unsauced. The hard roll is very well made and complements the bbq. The sweet potato fries and regular fries I think are fresh made but Not crunchy..more soogy. A bit heavy.Also, the mac and cheese is divine. Don't share. Get your own. The Mash potatoes have chunks of potatoes mixed in but is extremely bland.  Do ask for butter or drippings from the pork or brisket. The bread pudding is awful. It's like they took whole wheat sliced bread cut it up, drenched it with coconut milk and a little caramel. I did get this to go but it's was disgusting maybe leaving it in the skillet and eating it there may make it better. Also the Texas half rib is pretty good. They are huge...The location is on stone street where the ground is made of cobble stone. That street area reminds me of a movie set because the architecture is so unique in addition to the cobble stone. U should check it out. Definitely try the food. It's a great place for happy hour and they have out door seating!

A nice addition to this part of town that is on the border of LES/Chinatown. This area is already home to some really great food places including Dimes, Mission Chinese, forgetmenot, Cafe Grumpy. So Pies n Thighs fits in naturally. On a Thursday morning, I decided to give this place a try. The restaurant is just adorable. Old school counter top with seats that look right into the kitchen, two-tops in booth like arrangements, and a few four-tops for your big groups. This place just opened, so the masses have not descended yet (happy about that) and I was able to get a two-top immediately. I'm not much a meat eater, but I was hungry, so I ordered the Egg Breafast ($8.50), which includes two eggs cooked to your liking, biscuit and your choice of home fries, salad or grits. I opted for home fries, but now looking back, regret that decision because it was just too much food! The plate we well made, nothing to complain about. Great, flaky biscuit and home fries very tasty. I didn't end up eating all my breakfast and had some leftover for a snack later. I will definitely be back to try the pies, doughnuts and cookies on seductive display right by the window. I'm sure plenty of people will just stop in to order those yummy sweet treats. Good luck PNT here in LES, welcome to the neighborhood!

Saturday lunch 1PMWe had hotpot with two different soup bases, spicy and herbal. 99 Favor Taste is a good pan-asian hotpot restaurant in the city (I liked the clean bathroom with a loud music too). I do not recommend mezzanine tables or any booths, isolating steam and smoke thus smelly hair and clothing after. Fun to cook what we liked with friends and not thinking of how much we spend. We were so stuffed even before tow hours time slot. My choice of drink, a cold herbal tea (not sweet), helped to enjoy my meal even better, a slight bitterness rounded the complex flavors. I loved the spicy soup more than herbal. It became a great soup at the end with Udon noodle. That numbness sensation from Sichuan peppers are hard to find in most Sichuan restaurants in the city but this spicy soup packed with Sichuan peppers and left great numbness in the soup with all the flavors from what we put in and I couldn't get over how good that was. I wonder there are any customer asking for leftover soups to go and it's my great regret that I didn't ask.Banchan; Kimchi - I was very surprised to have a good Kimchi from non-Korean establishment.Ssweet wood-ear mushrooms complemented nicely with the Kimchi. Protain;Lamb - the contrary to my surprise, the lamb didn't overpower the flavor in soups and it was a lean meat.Our server impressed all of us. For example, taking our re-orders with tablet on one hand and her eyes were charged into my friend ordering and her another hand detected the messy table with dirty plates AND cleaned them. She was amazing. Japanese Shabu Shabu is only with water and Kombu seaweed base soup vs Chinese hotpot offers many different soup choices, big bone, kimchi, congee and more. I like Chinese version better. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sh… My wish;Make-your-won dipping sauce is a great idea but I never get it right so eat without sauce most of the time. I guess I could taste my dipping sauce each time when I introduce a new ingredient. Best is half Chinese and half Japanese style. Chinese offers more variety of ingredients to suite to your taste. Japanese Shabu Shabu comes with only two kinds of special sauces. They are creamy sesame and Yuzu-soy dipping sauce but that's it. How about we add toppings to chef created sauces?

My amazing girlfriend brought me here with the added surprise of sitting at the chef's pass counter for my big 3-0 bday. It was completely worth the show. We started with the quail and the octopus. The quail was expertly seasoned and the two small pieces were placed nicely on the farro, which is a favorite grain of mine. The octopus I think was the best I have ever had. I have had a lot of lousy versions, and a ton of perfectly tenderized octopi, but this the way they grilled and and marinated it took the prize. Then came the beef neck and my striped bass. The beef neck was the best beef I have ever had in a restaurant. It just pulled apart and was tender. The striper was indeed good and perfectly prepared, but I had dreams about the beef neck. The apple cider doughnuts were fried to perfection with sweetened apple bits to accompany them. I am not a dessert person, but I would go back for them alone. The wine list is prized to be diverse and boy it was. There was nothing generic or standard about it. I love wine and know a lot about wine, and I did not know 70% of this list. The server also needed a little more education on them. Our server was very nice and professional. He was very cheery and was eager to help us.

You need to know ahead of time that Cafe Gitane is located off of Hotel Jane's lobby for if you rely on signage you simply will not find this gem of a spot. Walk up the 3/4 flight of steps at 113 Jane St to enter the floor to ceiling wood panelled lobby. Turn left into Cafe Gitane, which transposes you directly to Casablanca. Northwest Africa meets French colonial chic, complete with a stuffed crocodile scaling the wall behind the bar and several long-shafted ceiling fans encroach upon the void between the noggin and the ceiling. Missing--to complete the fantasy--is Sam playing the the non-existent piano and a white-smoking jacket adorned Rick lighting a cigarette at the bar. In this post Bloomberg era cigarette chic is out but one can always channel the 40s and imagine what is was like not being able to breathe indoors? I enjoyed the couscous with merguez sausage and she had the chicken sandwich. We ordered delivery of the same the night before and we were 'jonesing' for a repeat. Food goes down easier when the throat is lubricated with a decent and relatively inexpensive offering from Margaux. I would have preferred a vin from Algiers to keep it thematic. There was consolation knowing the Margaux would simply taste better.I'll be back this evening which isn't soon enough...Post Script, I failed to mention that we ordered one of the most amazing and simplest desserts: vanilla ice cream encrusted with pistachios (orgasmic experience).

Contra's strengths lie in its affordable tasting menu ($55 for five courses), its creative, maybe unconventional ingredients, and its whimsical menu (changes daily), shrouding each diner with mystery and curiosity until arrival. That could be a hit or miss, depending on the night. Especially if you have strict dietary restrictions/allergies, definitely call ahead to make sure they can accommodate you.The menu on July 18, 2014 was: tomato, cucumber, eggplantclam, scallop, cabbage, leeksweetbreads, beans, currantswild chamomile, strawberry, olive oilyogurt, grains, seedsLike everyone else said, definitely order the bread for an additional $3. It's absolutely worth it, and the butter was melt-in-your-mouth amazing! Good thing I learned that it was goat's milk butter later, because I normally don't eat it. As my first time having sweetbread (I believe ours was thymus), it wasn't as horrific as I imagined. The blackcurrant surprisingly masked the earthy/gamey taste very well. My friend and I did end up eating everyone else's sweetbread though haha.The chamomile ice cream with strawberry reduction sauce was lovely, and I was impressed by how well they teased out the fragrance of the chamomile ice cream. The (buckwheat?) yogurt with grains and seeds was my absolute favorite though!On the night that we came, the desserts stood out more than the main dishes. I'll be sure to give Contra another try, but I hope they improve their service (cold and hurried) and spacing between courses (we had empty dishes that weren't cleared for over 20 minutes and there were a few long gaps). Also, the portions are on the smaller side - if I hadn't gobbled up everyone else's sweetbreads, I probably would have left hungry. 3.5 stars.Notes:- space is hipster chic complete with brick walls and long wooden benches- food has clear Nordic influences- be sure to make a reservation!

Whoa! Packed at 10:30 on a Sunday night and only one tiny bathroom for all. Hold it in and get another cocktail!If you are lucky enough to score a seat at the bar in front of bartender Dev you're in for a treat. He's got personality and makes a quality libation! Terrific cocktail list here, but as always, just tell the mixologists what you are hankering for. Can't go wrong with Bartender's Choice.A few of us came here after this past weekend's Yelp Holiday Hangover Hornblower booze cruise for a nightcap. Look for the Speakeasyish faux front with the tarot card reader in the window. Be respectful to the doorman and show ID's. He seems like a nice chap anyway.You might have to stand for a bit with your drink if looking to score a seat at the bar. Just peruse the room and take it all in. Sexy classy dimly lit panty dropper vibe going on here. A mix of young and old elbow to elbow, stylishly dressed ladies and smartly dressed men. Candlelit along with a working fireplace. This ain't no ratty t-shirt and jeans dive bar scene. Great music too that fits the ambiance. Be prepared. It's always crowded, and pricey. Make a reservation to eat and drink in the back dining room if you want to spend some quality time here. Especially if bringing a date or with more than two people. The food is pretty solid. After grabbing a few seats at the bar we ordered the steak tartare which was prepared right in front of us by the bartender and all ingredients explained. Very cool, and very tasty!One of the best cocktail bars in the city. Period. Expect to drop some serious cash here though but so worth it. Bring a date and hope to get lucky. Boom.

I have been here about 4 times now and it is always a pleasant brunch. I Take my brunch recs from my roomate's cousin who has never skipped a beat on recommending a good brunch spot. It has a wonderful ambiance and is under the same ownership as cookshop so you will notice some similarly delicious items.Their menu is always a changin' but some things to definitely try include their goat cheese and sage bread pudding, brioche french toast, cinnamon rolls, pancakes, and honey buttered biscuits. I think I just made a huge mistake writing about this place while doing a detox cleanse. I need that goat cheese and sage bread pudding and I need it all dey every day. Oh wait, don't forget about their bloody mary with an oyster on top...brunch cocktail perfection!!!!

$3.00 makeup brushes! Who, what, why..... Why didn't anyone tell me about this?!? I've been wasting all this time, energy and MONEY with Sephora. I will admit that I did have to tighten the e.l.f blush brush head to the body, but it still hasn't come loose again. Plus who cares??? 3 bucks vs. 28... I don't care if it doesn't last 6 months. I hate cleaning my Sephora foundation brush and if I had only paid $3.00 for it, I would have tossed it bought a new one by now. You know... for hygiene purposes. Not because I'm lazy and wasteful. Sure this e.l.f Studio isn't nearly as large and comprehensive as Sephora, but I'm nobody's makeup artiste, so it's not that serious. I'm still buying Revlon ColorStay when it's BOGO50% at CVS. Hey, don't knock the ColorStay. It's pretty damn good coverage and lasts all day. But at e.l.f Studio's price point, I feel freer to experiment with new products and techniques. If I don't like it, at least I only paid 3 bucks for it.

I have never been to a better dentist office in my life! Since I have been coming to Mimi Lai since I was a child. I remember their old location on Elizabeth but this new location has a more modern office space. The staff is friendly and professional, great since of humor and so personable. It really does depend on the dentist. I recommend find one and sticking with that person. I usually come here once every six month for a cleaning. One of the things about that I noticed is that the appointment that was schedule for you will always be delayed. So give yourself a good amount of time and bring something to do!

Not sure how much original commentary I have to offer on The Otheroom, but here goes. I wonder if the owners/employees of The Otheroom are aware that this a go-to spot for couples who aren't afraid of a little PDA. I mean, it's pretty impossible to ignore. Other than one larger group in the back, everyone here was paired up when I came here on Saturday night. It's basically a makeout den (that's a huge exaggeration - we did not walk into an orgy - it's just sexy). I wouldn't come here on a first date though - go with someone you're really interested in.Everything about this place is intimate. For starters, it's nestled away on Perry St., so it's removed from the craziness of the West Village. When you enter, you find yourself in the love cave. It's probably the darkest bar I've been to, the only lighting coming from small candles on each table. For seating, you have your choice of chairs or couches. But mostly couches. So don't despair if you can't sit at a table immediately - there's plenty of couch space between tables as well. This place is exclusively a wine and beer establishment, so go elsewhere if you want a gin and tonic. I stuck with beer given that personally, I've found that wine drunk is very, very dangerous. Sadly, I wasn't a huge fan of the two beers I ordered. They weren't bad, just not what I was hoping for. Oh well. Didn't stop me from having a good time (everyone sitting around us on Saturday knows what I'm talking about..)

One of the best halal carts in NYC and definitely the best in the 'hospital row' area of the UES. The chicken gyro on pita is fresh with full of flavor. Have both the white & hot sauce on it! So good and it'll cost you $4 ...can't beat that. They also have chicken/lamb over rice which seems to be a popular choice. They never have Falafel...I noticed there's no deep fryer. They make only what can be cooked on a flat top. If you're craving chicken or lamb Halal style this is the cart to go to! There's always a line and there's a reason. Try going after 2pm and you don't have to wait. And the 2 guys that run it are super nice.

What an experience. Was a little skeptical of this cozy, unassuming space. Had a negroni and thé last Word at thé bartender's recommendation. They were delicious and thé barkeep keeps thé vibe flowing.The space is tiny and I didnt use thé restroom so I cannot comment on that. However, what you do see is a very well ordered space that has a lot of potential. I was quite surprised at this little Harlem gem. Not much in this area but be aware that these cocktails are priced at downtown ratés. Kitchen closed at 11-ish. I would recommend for a small group or informal date.

looking for beer oasis/comfy man cave without all the strange stuff and creepy friends that scare away women? then BEER CULTURE might be your place. beer culture is a craft beer neighborhood joint for locals. went there @ ~10 pm. packed with the late 20s/mid 30s/ early 40s crowd. lots of beards, 'staches, Canada gEEse, Chuck Taylor footed, flats (no heels) wearin' dudes and broads. laid back crowd. a lil bro'ed out as some folks got a lil pushy (literally) trying to order the brews. it's a medium-sized place. a fair amount of seating with tables in the front and towards the back. the bar is decently sized. there is a bunch of different refrigerated beer wall units that are organized by region and type of beer (the normal priced beer bottle and cans) as well as an old school white fridge full of $3 canned beers like Narragansett (works for me!). of course there are a bunch of draft microbrews on tap. the chalkboard menu displays the fresh bubbly brew choices. there are more refrigerated units the back past the high tables. found the beer pricy here on the pricier side in terms of cans and bottles ($7-$9). drafts were pretty much average. the discount can beers were the best bang for the buck. if you buy beer to take home, i'm not sure if it's cheaper than if you bought and drank it in the bar (assume it's cheaper). service was a little slow because there was only like two bartenders and 1 barback handling the bar--not sure why they don't have more staff? weird. however service was friendly and helpful in terms of rec'ing beers from the coolers or the draft taps. patience is a virtue here. rolled in here with 5 other people. we all drank a fair amount of beer. no buy backs though despite fairly generous tipping by all of us on each individual purchase. are buybacks dead in the city?
