woe is me.despite being in the crosshairs of the theater district and the ever gentrified HK--this place remains true to its beer culture and keeps a relaxed non-touristy vibe, where you and your friends can kick back, laugh, and drink some curated beers.had a great time here because we spotted Tom Green of MTV fame and had an awesome time laughing it up as we joked around about talking to him, taking photos with him, etc. ALL things we did NOT do to ruin Mr. Green's night but had a hilarious time partaking in TOMfoolery #seewhatididthere. other positives: underneath the actual bar countertop were coat hooks and USB ports to charge your phones and other devices--AWESOME. they do serve food here. we didn't indulge. it was a lot of sandwich and carb-y fare. it errs more on the side of gastro-pub like food than having wings, nachos, and potato skins, and other more junky bar food. originally i was going to give this place 3 stars. however Tom Green and the revolving comedy of my friends and me pushed this place to 4 stars. however i do think the can and bottle prices are high, despite being in a nice part of Manhattan. no buybacks is lame especially since we were there for at least an 1 1/2 hours. not sure i'd go back, but then again it's not my 'hood.drops mic, so i can stealth-selfie a pic with Tom Green!i out.

Such a beautifully, almost starry lit entrance greets you when you get to Wallsé. To be honest, it's when I pass by Wallsé on my way home and see how pretty it is that enticed me to first suggest coming here when our overseas buddy came for a recent work trip. It is really the first and only place I have come to try Austrian/ German food in NYC and our group of friends were all pretty excited to try this top rated restaurant on our bucket list. Upon arriving, we noticed the art decor and coziness of the restaurant. It's very cozy, very cute and the ambiance truly deserves all the praise it gets. After we were escorted to our seats and I found the plush couches very comfortable and luxurious. For the food, we were pleasantly surprised to find that you didn't have to order a pre-fix dinner, so we opted to order randomly (not that pre-fixes are bad, that night we just weren't in the mood to eat a multi-course meal). We did share a few apps, one of which was the foie gras. My whole group really recommends this, especially if you are a foie gras person. For my entree, I opted for the lamb which was super tender and absolutely delish. The veggies that come with it are also superbly cooked. For the most part, everything was made wonderfully but I didn't have a favorite that really stuck out to me, other than what I ordered. My friends had some of mine and they agreed that they also enjoyed the lamb over their scallops and rabbit. Both of those other dishes were also tasty, but perhaps we don't quite have the pallet for rabbit so we couldn't fully appreciate the taste. Overall, it was a nice experience here. The service and quality are what you expect from a Michelin rated NYC restaurant. Venturing to Wallsé is definitely worth it, especially if you want to try Austrian German food. Of course we thought the food was great, but I really loved the decor (even the bathroom is cute).

BYOB is a dying business in NYC, and there is no concept more suitable for groups. We came here with 9 On a Friday to celebrate bf's bday. You can bring it on just no beer. I booked 2 weeks in advance for the preset banquet menu. We had 10 originally but one of us couldn't make it so we ended up getting food for 10 (that's their minimum for the banquet menu ) ad splitting it with less folks. The menu is $34 per person and you get: Appetizers which included dumplings (they will alter for vegetarians), spare rib, spring roll - just ok. The hot and sour soup- right portion, not too small or big. Also standard but perhaps a little thinner so less on corn starch. Two Peking duck which we ooh and aahed at. Wrapped in a tortilla (was surprised it wasn't the bao) with a little too much hoisin and scallion. Imwas cool with the wrapper. The duck themselves were good- maybe a bit dry on meat and much skin. They were not big ducks. (Vegetarians got bbq veggies inside)The rest of the entrees were: Beef and broccoli- eh takeout quality Orange flavored chicken - like general tso consistency and skin, I liked this orange flavor they used real oranges.Crispy sea bass with a sweet garlic sauce- even though the sauce was thick the crispy skin of the fish never faltered. And the white I sides remained yummy and soft. Shrimp mayo sauce - this could have been crispier it wasn't like the traditional style with candied walnuts which I think is money. Shrimp fried rice- delicious, not too brown or fried with ham, veggiesVeggie fried rice - didn't try, looked good. String beans with minced pork - delicious Sichuan classic but a bit early For dessert, they brought us a deep fried banana which went well with he banana cake that I brought on my own from Billy's bakery (plug: that cake is awesome- like a banana bread). The staff was nice enough to light a candle and cut it up. Overall they were accommodating and prompt (minus a mishap with one person not getting veg sliders instead of duck). My only other compliant we had to wait 30 min almost to be seated when our reservation was at 830. They also freaked out when we brought home axe liquor in a Perrier bottle claiming they sell it - we explained, they understood. They are quick on opening wine bottles. No corkage, we were $55 pp and we had plenty of cake, wine and food. A good experience (EXperience over food here$Total came to $55 pp with service fee included.

After all these years, May Wah continues to being well-oiled machine pumping out Taiwanese style "pork chop over rice" boxes to go like nobody's business. This open-kitchen, hole-in-the-wall still looks old and run down like your typical Americanized Chinese takeout spot. With that said, the prices seem to be as old as its kitchenware as their signature dish is still under $5 (tea egg is now an add-on item). May Wah actually added a sit-down area next door recently as well. Taiwan Pork Chop House on Doyer Street is the only other restaurant that serves the pork chop over rice with grounded pork stew and pickled vegetables. And while Taiwan Pork Chop House may serve a better (and fresher) version of the dish, May Wah will always have a place in the heart of this Yelper as a pillar of Manhattan Chinatown serving the community all these years. There aren't many of those left.

"It feels like home," said Streetbird employee, Jennifer, who was answering my question "How do you like working here?"Jennifer - thanks for being so friendly, I couldn't agree with you any more.Chef Marcus Samuelsson, you did it again. Much like Red Rooster and Ginny's Supper Club, Streetbird pays homage to old Harlem, but not in the 1920s speakeasy kind of way - this time we are bringing it back to 80s. It's unusual to see pairs of sneakers hanging from the ceiling of a restaurant, but if you know Harlem in the 80s and 90s, then you'll understand the concept. I absolutely love the funky decor.The restaurant has only been open three days prior to our visit, so they were not accepting reservations yet. We arrived at 7:30pm and walked into a full house. Chef Marcus, was standing at the entrance, which was very exciting! After I snapped a pic with him, I made my way to the bar to wait for our table. There wasn't a drink menu, but the bartenders were able to list the cocktails for me. I went with the Juicy Fruit, which I believe is made with mango puree, rum, and a splash of pickle - very tasty. We ordered Crispy Bird, Old Broadway Wings and New Jack Fried Rice. Everything was bomb, as I expected. The wings are super spicy, but so good, and the Crispy Bird is juicy and flavorful. I don't know what spices and rubs they're putting on their chicken, but trust me when I say the flavors are all there. Oh, and the fried rice was actually the best fried rice I've ever had - better than any Asian restaurant I've been to. Our meal was just under $30, and the Juicy Fruit was $9.I always step back and assess new businesses and properties in Harlem and ask myself if it diminishes or preserves the culture of the neighborhood. Well Streetbird definitely preserves the culture, and as a Harlem native, I appreciate how Chef Marcus is working the neighborhood's restaurant scene. I wish I had enough time to tell him this when I met him, but no worries. I have a feeling I'll be seeing him around the way more often.

After 8 months in Hell's Kitchen, I'm ready to pop the question: Will you be my neighborhood bar, Alfie's?!Seriously, Alfie's has it all (or should I say All-fie's?):A: lcohol brunch deal. $13-16 will get you a huge cocktail and a delicious entree. Not your typical gastropub grub, either - think Crab & Asparagus Frittatas. Lobster Eggs Benedict. (Don't worry - not everything is so blatantly non-kosher, Nana.) L: ocation, location, location. On the prime corner of 53rd and 9th, the location and the spacious, non-sticky gastropub atmosphere with awesome music (think Otis Redding, Van Morrison) can't be beat.F: ive dollar Happy Hour, 11 am - 8 pm, M-F, select beer, wine, well drinks, AND shots. ALL draft beers are also $5 from midnight-4 am.I: deal crowd. Young, but not too young. Hip, but not hipster. Dudes and chicks, co-existing in balanced ratio. Beautiful.E: rin is there. A lot. That's me. I'm over there guzzling the massive Bloody Mary with thick slices of jalapeños floating on top. S: ee you there!

Now this place is lovely. If you have a date and you wanna do Indian food, this is the place to be. I must say the service, ambiance, decor, and staff was 5 stars. From walking through the doors to my exit out, it was such smooth transition. Food wise I felt it was good but not great. The way 4 waiters came and in total coordination placed the food on the table was awesome.I put some pics of my dishes, I will say it was over priced based off of food, but as a total package I wouldn't mind coming here again. The food was flavorful but it didn't hit the spot. The coolest part to me besides the decor was the fact that we had left overs and the waiter took the food, and gave us a ticket number. 15 minutes later on the way out we were presented with the food at the exit.That is awesomeDefinetly a high end Date spot

Well, the first thing I can say is that the reservation process is out of this world. It appears that they have "improved" from their opening but the process is still lackluster. I've dined at some of the most notable restaurants in the city and I've never had such a ridiculous experience with just making a reservation. Needless to say, I was a little miffed. Alas, 6 weeks later when my reservation date came I had cooled off and was looking forward to dinner at The Polo Bar.For those looking to go and just "look" please note that you will not make it past the threshold of the front door as these days the Host/Hostess wait outside and check your reservations. No more getting thru the velvet curtains. Luckily, for them, my reservation was not lost and was on the infamous "list."Hedge fund, narcissistic, pretentious, socialite, fashionista, Upper Eastside crowd. Imagine this. Walking past the bar area where a man, with Albert Einstein hair and looked orange from over tanning is talking a bit too loudly about how many billionaires he knows.My small dinner party entered with great anticipation and the only thing I can say is that there is no question in my mind or anyone blind that this is a polo themed bar. Everything and I mean everything was polo related but in the Ralph Lauren green and signature plaid and colors. From the deep, rich forest green on the walls, to the plaid pillows that sat in the corners. To the polo sticks, to the walls completely covered with pictures of polo players and horses. This was and is a polo themed restaurant/bar. When I say that the walls are covered I mean covered. Every inch covered with various sized framed pictures of horses and people who ride them. I would guess that there was at least a 1-2 finger width space left between each picture. But, the green that escaped from the wall was a beautiful color. Deep like a forest but full of richness. Outside of the extensive amount of pictures of horses there were plenty of mirrors. The mirrors were seated eye level and lined the walls around the dining embankments. Here's the best way to describe it. If you wanted to slyly check out the people at the other table all you had to do was look like you were looking at your dinner guest and you had an eye shot of the other tables on the other side and behind you. We were escorted downstairs to our table where the dining room opened up into a sea of people. We were directed to our table and as I sat down I was left with the impression that this is what country club dinners must be like. But not everyone had country club flare because at the table next to my party was a woman dressed in a skin tight Herve Leger dress and I think newly done boobs because she took the butter dish which was ablaze with a Polo Bar logo paper cover and balanced it on her boobs and took a selfie. I kid you not. She will be forever known as butter boobs.Now for the food and drinks. Nicely done. A sampling of the typical fare, steak, seafood, chicken, burger and sides. I skipped ordering an appetizer because I wanted dessert. For my entrée, I ordered the Veal Chop which was outstanding. I tried to get every last morsel off the bone and was tempted...yes tempted to pick up the bone with my right hand and get Fred Flinstone-like and polish off the last bits of veal with my teeth....But I did not. The cocktail list was nice. All I have to say is get the Moscow Mule. They did an amazing job with the drink. Not too gingery and just right amount of lemon and kick. Now for dessert. What girl doesn't love chocolate? Well, there are probably some that don't but I love chocolate. I ordered the seven layer Chocolate Cake and begrudgingly agreed to share it. I knew I was going to regret that decision as soon as they brought this big slice of heaven to the table. My mouth was watering even before I picked up my fork which must have been too slow because the next thing I know a chunk of the cake was gone. Calming myself I did not want to turn this evening out into Oz prison scene, I gathered my composure and took a small but healthy bite out of the slice and ohhhhhhh boy. It was delicious. Delicious doesn't even seem like the right word to use for how good this was.If you can get in, I would say go to the Polo Bar. Was it the best experience I ever had? No, there are other restaurants in the city where the experience is better but if you love the game of polo, want to touch polo sticks, are a fan of all things Ralph Lauren and love chocolate cake, I would say absolutely go.

One Monday morning, I was being The World's Best Daughter, picking up my mother from Grand Central to squire her to Penn Station for a trip down to D.C. She basically bullied me into buying her breakfast...I mean, I willingly wanted to treat my mother to breakfast! I knew we had some time to sit and eat, but not a lot of time by the same measure. I didn't want to sit down someplace fancy. I didn't want to drag her into a Starbucks. After a bit of Yelp-searching, FIKA seemed like a good option.It's set back just west of Bryant Park, and it was blocked by scaffolding and delivery trucks when we got there; I almost walked right past it! However, once we entered, it was lovely. It's bright, modern, with some pleasant cool music playing (not too loudly) in the background. While pastries were teasing us from the display case, my mama was looking for a heartier breakfast, while the Pumpkin & Chia Oatmeal is what caught my eye. She ended up getting a nice order of scrambled eggs with spinach, which came with a side salad and toast. I had to laugh: my grandfather, her father, ran a restaurant when she grew up, so she has had her share of scrambled eggs in her life. By the way she ate and praised these eggs, you'd think that these were the best scrambled eggs in the whole entire world! (Well, they very well could have been!) Seriously, an hour later when we got to Penn Station, she was still talking about the eggs. Ha! (Oh. MOMS. Y'all say the cutest things.) As for me, I really enjoyed my oatmeal. It was $5 for a bowl, and this was a BOWL. I mean, oats, pumpkin seeds, chia, strawberries, lingonberries, cranberries, you name it. It was basically everything but the kitchen sink. I couldn't finish it, I ended up so full! I did not eat again until 6 that night, eight hours after eating it, I kid you not. Thank you, FIKA, for one, a great breakfast and two, for making my mama a very happy camper and traveler.

Been here so many times throughout the years and on many different nights; from the more laid back weeknights to having to pay cover on the weekends, and even on Thanksgiving. There is plenty of counter space along the walls that surround the bar and around the bar itself. In the back area they have tables, which is where my party has also sat to have dinner prior to the place becoming a lounge/club.They play a great hip-hop/pop/r&b mixture on most nights, and on some nights they have some great guest DJs spinning. On any of my visits, I have never left unhappy.Fat Buddha has delicious food, awesome music, and most importantly ... a great drink/cocktail selection. The only reason the one star is missing is because they tend to overcrowd the joint on some nights causing it to be very uncomfortable throughout the night.Fat Buddha is definitely one of my regular spots when I'm in the East Village/Alphabet City.

Whole Burger is the new replacement for Bowery Burger. Thankfully more has changed than just the name. The location, Houston's Whole Foods on the street level across the hot bar and next to the sushi bar.The Bowery Burger started off as something great. It had deliciously juicy burgers with fresh ingredients. That changed quite quickly and the burgers transformed into super dry blobs of beef that needed to be drowned in some sort of condiment to be eaten. I learned watching my burgers being crushed with a spatula while being cooked had a way of depressing me.Enters Whole Burger in the same location as Bowery Burger.Signature Burgers (grass-fed beef, turkey, vegan beet burger) $8: #1 gruyere, shitake, caramelized onion, truffle mayo, local bun #2 pepper jack, fried onion, spicy pickle, chipotle mayo, local bun #3 queso blanco, avocado, salsa fresca, cilantro-lime mayo, local bun #4 cheddar, beer onions, smoked bacon, bbq sauce, local bun #5 buttermilk bleu, red onion, argula, balsamic glaze, local bunClassic Burger $5; Classic Hot Dog (beef and pork) $3Sides $3: French Fries, Sweet Potato Fries, and Onion RingsYou can also make your grass-fed beef or turkey burger a double for an additional $4And if none of those burgers interest you, build your own for the same $8.I struggled with a decision between #1 and #4 but finally chose #4 because bacon was involved. I also made it a double. As I found out, I assure you it is very rare that you will need to upgrade to a double!WARNING!!!! These burgers are huge! Unless you are trying to share your food with your local book club, about to go into hibernation, or protein loading in hopes of becoming the World's Strongest Body Builder, you don't need a double.The entire burger was good and I struggled to finish.Everything on the burger is basically all-local everything. Even the meat is fresh. You don't get a patty to start. You get a big blob of fresh-grounded meat shaped into the form of a burger there on the grill. That's fresh!

As you can tell, I am a fan of "hidden gems". This restaurant is located behind a non nondescript butcher shop on Greater Jones Street. The door, while glass, is opaque, shielding the interior to outsiders. What I like most about this place is the privacy. The dining room could probably seat 20 people at most. The staff is extremely knowledgeable and polite. The menu offers an array of seasonal delights as well as permanent dishes. What stood out to me was the miso cod. Everyone in New York raves about Nobu's miso cod, but I personally feel that Bohemian serves a much better miso cod. Other note worthy dishes include the uni croquette. The croquette offered a delicate balance of tastes that allow you to enjoy the creaminess of both the sea urchin and the potato, without overpowering one another. I begrudgingly agreed to order the vegetable fondue but it was more decorative than delicious. The branzino was also well done but it is meant for FOUR. Since I went there with one other person, it was way too much food and we both ended up overeating.

gain 10 pounds in one meal!!! if you're looking for a quick way to gain weight, look no further.. :P rich and decadant is the name of the game here. thankfully, balthazar does rich and decadant well. hubby and i have been on a "explore old new york" kick, so when we happened on balthazar we were excited. the insides of this space is EXPANSIVE, very high ceilings, dim lights,rustic large mirrors with old booth seats. it reminded me of frank & musso's back in los angeles. the place is buzzing with waiters and servers bustling around and laughter and chatter all around. service is IMPECCABLE. i chuckled because the servers were so attentive - they would refill our water every time it looked half way full!! to order: escargots (appetizer): really meaty and flavorful. it's not drenched in butter and so you actually taste the snails ... down to each little texture and antenna o.Obalthazar salad: really refreshing crisp salad with asparagus, beans and lightly dressed. steak w/ spinach & frites: they happily split it for us and decided to give us a TON of frites each. they are good fries. the steak was AMAZING!!! it's got this thick black pepper crust and savory bearnaise sauce that was not too salty. man. i instantly added inches to my waistline cuz i could not stop eating it all...and all the fries!!!

This place is pretty ducking great. Pardon me, I should apologize for my fowl language.Okay, now that those puns are out of my system, Ducks Eatery really is a great spot with great food. If an intriguing fusion between southern and Asian-inspired comfort food sounds alluring to you, it's certainly worth a visit. The space is small but scoring a table isn't too difficult. And the cinephile in me appreciates the projector towards the back silently showing classic films against a brick wall. It might seem a little gimmicky but it adds a very nice touch of atmosphere.Of course, the food is the real draw and Ducks Eatery absolutely delivers. The Whole Goat Neck for two is quite possibly the biggest draw. The meat is fall-off-the-bone tender and can easily be eaten with a fork. Goat neck probably isn't the most popular cut of meat in New York, but even if it were, this one would surely rank as one of the best.Also terrific is the Duck and Waffle, which is conveniently available on the dinner menu. The duck is moist and tender (I'm sensing a theme here), and the breading is well seasoned. The waffles are good but not exemplary, though they do the job of tying the dish together.I'd be amiss if I didn't bring up the drink selection too. The beer list isn't long but consists of a nice choice of craft brews. And with choices of great beers for $5 and under, there isn't a lot of scope for improvement. There's also a decent list of wine and cocktails if that's more your taste. But whatever you prefer, between the food, the drinks, and the solid prices, there surely is a reason to pay Ducks Eatery a visit.

I don't know how my peeps in the homeland aren't dead before 40. I mean, our food is delicious and all, but damn, we need to learn how to spell SALAD every now and then... does this make me, less Filipino? I digress...After three visits this is the 411:Skip it: Shrimp balls, pork buns, dumplings and Calamari Rings. Not terrible, just blah. Life's too short for a repeat of blah and it's a waste of calories. Get another drank, playa. Speaking of: the Weng-Weng. This was on the cocktail menu and even though it was strong it was way too sweet, which isn't my tang. Repeat offenders:The Sisig was on point. It had more liver then I like, but was dope and it deserves a return visit at a future date when I'm craving it. The Dasilog was tight. Cooked well and tasty. It's $2 more then what you would pay for at Cafe 81 and just as good. To me, this is one of those dishes that's like pizza, even when it sucks, it's still aight. And as much as I want to say, "damn, I only pay $6/7 bones for this in JC or in Queens" I won't, cuz that's not fair with the rent these peeps must be paying up in here. Ditto, the Longsilog dish. I'm pretty sure the longanisa was made in-house or sourced locally, because it didn't taste frozen like it can at some Flip joints that pose as a legit restaurant. The garlic fried rice that comes with isn't as "garlicky" as I would love, but it's still good.The Laing is one the best I've ever had...ever. The thing with Flip food(or any food for that matter) is that everyone cooks it a little different. Some joints will serve this mad runny/soupy and way too salty or worse, put msg in it. This was heaven for a brother. It's thick and rich, with that coconut flavor that brings me back to a place called, home. That said, the taro leaves were still the star, which it should be, 'cuz "nobody puts baby in the corner". the star:The shrimp adobo is an instant foodboner for this Pinoy boy. This was a nice twist on something traditional. I always eat pork or chicken adobo. Matter of fact, it's the only Filipino dish I know how to make that I don't use those packets for; I got my own take on it and it's DOPE! But, I digress...First off, its fried with the head on and if you ain't know me, I LOVE SKRIMP HEADS. If i've said it once, I've said it a zillion times... the flavor is in THE HEAD! GET IT!!! Don't just suck the juice from the head(*twss) - eat it whole, because the entire skrimp has been fried to perfection & ready for your pleasure with that sticky sweet sauce that's bursting with mad flavor in your ear. It's muy Del'eh'see'oh'so and is the Sofía Vergara of Flip dishes; it makes you do a double take, cuz something this old school shouldn't look this new and it's even better then you thought it was going to be...on yo TONGUE! But, I digress... The staff: Friendly and efficient. They do a good job, even when it gets busy and it gets busy on fridays. The space:It's longer then it looks (I wish she said that. Wait,what?) Tables in the back are too close for my liking when it gets packed. I'm a fan of the two tops at the bar area for max chill. But, if you bring the fam bam, I guess one has to put up with the shit show that is the dining area. The rest of my B. S. : They got Kamayan nights, like Jeepney. Haven't done yet, but then again all it is really is eating the same stuff, but with your hands. Yeah, I do that at home anyway. It gets hoppin around 8ish, cuz the DJ starts setting up for his 9 o'clock set. You know you're Filipino when you got a family memeber who's a DJ and you can't wait for some hip hop and R&B sounds to eat with your Sisig. Double down dawg, it's here. Tuesday's happy hour is all night. Yes, you read right... All... Night... Long...just the way she likes it. When downtown and dining alone, I go to Cafe 81. It's cheaper by a few bucks and quiet, which is my steez when (Han) solo. When with friend(s) and feeling something more traditional in food, but with a dope beat to step to, this is the spot. The menu isn't as extensive as Cafe 81 (or is as traditional:see shrimp adobo) and isn't as new and hip as Jeepney; It's in the middle & leans a tip (just the tip) toward traditional then updated. Mainly a 50% young, cool, downtown Filipino crowd the 3x I dined in and that should tell you something. Old school hip hop blares overhead even before the DJ's set starts and the vibe is chill, just like my (Nia) peoples. It doesn't feel like lola's house, but more like your older cousin's crib on a friday night, sans strippers and the weed. And who wouldn't want to be a part of THAT! Duh!

I am writing this review based on the service & the taiyaki. I tried the takoyaki for the 1st time here but I have never had it before so I will write a review update once I try takoyaki at a different location. Taiyaki (Medetai?): There are 2 kinds, one with red bean & one with banana + nutella. I ordered a taiyaki with just plain nutella in it. I waited for a really long time for my taiyaki and the woman behind the counter saw this and gave me another red bean taiyaki for free which was extremely kind of her. The taiyaki is typical but I have had better taiyaki before with more filling and for less. But then again, I got one for free so I cannot complain. Takoyaki:as i said before I had never had this before. They look pretty cool and I am a big fan of octopus. They put fishy benito flakes on top and some kind of mayo sauce. I think next time I will order the takoyaki without the flakes or mayo because I am a typical American who likes starchy chewy things and I need to develop a taste for Japanese food.  But be careful to completely cool your takoyaki because it is super HOTThey have combo deals as well. Cons: no seating inside, cash only, there is only a bench outside to sit with a friend when the weather is warmPros: friendly staff, cute interior, can watch how the food is made Their seasonal desserts are cute. I think they are running a promo on matcha taiyaki

I love escape games live or online or in an app. The problem I had is not with the game, I love the zombie and I love the game. I was just not happy with a couple of the teammates. We had a couple of people on our team who were not team players and basically were so full of themselves and forgot there were other players in the room. They would not communicate even when asked direct questions. That is not fun to play with people like that so with that said, pick your team wisely. I do not recommend leaving it to chance who your teammates are because if you end up with someone who is arrogant and is not a team player...it's not cool. Most important thing about this game is teamwork and communication. If you find a clue, share it with your team. Do not keep the clue to yourself, involve your team. There is no "I" in team. I can not stress that enough. The live version of the escape game is just like the online escape adventure games or the ones in apps. You will be physically locked in a room with other players and a zombie. You will have to use elements of the room to solve a series of puzzles, find clues, and escape the room within a set time limit, which in our case it was one hour. The players explore their surroundings in order to find these puzzles, clues, keys, locks, etc. You have to be observant and use critical thinking skills get out of the room....hopefully within the time limit or it will be game over for you. The zombie will try their best to tag you out. The zombie is on a chain where the chain will be a foot longer every 5 minutes. You have to quickly move around this zombie in order not to get tagged. If you get tagged, you will have to stand in the corner of the room for the rest of the game and only contribute verbally. Bring friends who are good at team work and communication. No one wants someone who holds clues for themselves and not share the game with others. Tell everyone when you find a clue!!!!!!! Let the room figure it out. NOT A TIME TO BE SELFISH!!!!! If you get a room full of people you know....it's more fun. But you can join others' games too. Bring a notebook to keep track of the clues and SHARE THE CLUES! Let everyone in the room take a look at all clues. Give others a crack at the clues! I can't stress this enough. It's a GROUP EFFORT. It's a team exercise. There is no "I" in team!Keep track of the time. In our game we had a gamekeeper who kinda nudged at us when she felt like we needed help. Make sure you get to the game early and on time. They do lock the door behind you. Wear comfy clothes. It's not a place to wear heels and short skirts, you might have to look under things and crawl a bit. Last but not least, for goodness sake, go to the bathroom before the door is locked!!!!!!!!!!ENJOY AND HAVE FUN!

Delicious // Local OrganicLots of Healthy Options + Fresh Veggie SidesI'm a fan of Westville in general. This location is great, can get a bit crowded, so going at a non-peak hour is advised if you can manage. Their market veggies are my favorite. Plates here are pretty large in portion, and I usually order extra food to keep some at home in the fridge. Solid delivery, service is pretty good depending on the day, but the quality overall makes up for it when it's a bit "off" I love their daily specials which actually change, and seasonal items too, as they should. When I'm not sure what I want to order or where I want to eat I know I can always order from one of their locations. So happy to have Westville nearby.The Scene: Earthy, CasualDestination Rating: 6Date Rating: 4Hob Nob Potential: N/A Note: Limited seating, small cozy spot. Additional locations nearby.

1). All things come to those who wait.2). All is well that ends well. I think those are two proverbial phrases that nicely sum up my first* visit to Cosme. Let me explain!1). All things come to those who wait. And wait we did. This restaurant has been super popular, so I understood that getting a reservation would be near impossible, but when we somehow (luckily! astonishingly!) did get a last-minute reservation we hoped that we'd at least get seated soon after our arrival. But we waited for 45 minutes before we were seated!! The hostess was apologetic, but still!The 45 minutes did give us plenty of time to observe the dining room and really peruse the food and drinks menu. While the bar area was crowded and loud with anxious walk-in diners, the dining room area was spacious, dark, sexy and cool. And despite the dim lights elsewhere, lights shone down from above onto each table so diners knew exactly what their food looked like. The drinks menu was dizzyingly impressive; there were lots of creatively-named cocktails ("Jack be Nimble, Jack be Quick"!), Mexico City staples, wines (so many from Spain, Chile, France, and even one from Lebanon!), tequilas, and mezcales. The waiting didn't really stop. We were brought to our table and still had to wait a few minutes for our server to take our orders. Then more for the drinks to come. Then quite a bit until complimentary blue corn tostadas (so delicious!) with a pumpkin seed and habanero butter (packed some heat!) came.2). All is well that ends well. Then...a dish came. We looked at it and took small bites that quickly turned into enthusiastic bites, and it was almost like our earlier disappointment had never even happened. After one big sigh of relief, an overwhelming sense of excitement for what was to come washed over us. I do have to say that the first dish that came out was something we didn't order, but they let us eat it anyway. Win.a. Uni tostada: The crunchy, earthy goodness of that tostada was the perfect vehicle for the avocado, uni, bone marrow salsa, and a splash of lime. I was surprised with the generous amount of smooth, silky uni that was on top. J's shellfish allergy prevented him from enjoying this, but it was actually only an amount for one person anyway.b. Chicarron: The chicarron was huge, crispy, and well-seasoned. The tomato-y hot sauce was the real winner of this dish, though. We jokingly considered ways to sneak the bottle out. c. Burrata: I was surprised that he wanted to order this, but I was glad we did! The burrata was thick on the outside with a really creamy center and that center mixed wonderfully with the salsa verde to create a heavenly dip of sorts. There was only one lone tostada to scoop everything with, though, which was a shame. d. Broiled red snapper: This was the dish that came by mistake, but we were so lucky! The snapper was cooked absolutely perfectly (so lean and moist), and the Thai hoja santa salsa added such a unique burst of flavor to elevate the dish.e. Duck carnitas: Wow. The carnitas were braised in orange and Mexican Coca-Cola and served to us on a big skillet. The duck was sweet in a non-cloying way, and was the softest "melting in your mouth we don't even need knives" duck I've ever had. Building our own warm tortilla tacos with the duck and salsa verde was just...sigh, we felt so spoiled. We chatted briefly with two diners from Mexico seated next to our table who were writing an article about Cosme for a magazine. They were impressed, as were we, and they were happy that the chef was introducing the versatility and energy of Mexican cuisine to New Yorkers. They were also quick to inform us that this was just a small sliver of the different styles of food Mexico has. Until more restaurants open, I'll gladly eat these exciting dishes - dishes that are far from the fast food we've come to associate with the country. Likelihood of another visit:*A second visit is almost guaranteed as the food was so delicious. I can't wait to come with friends. My golly gee, I'm still dreaming of the duck carnitas. The prices were very steep, but none of the dishes disappointed me in the slightest, so the wallet will just have to fatten up before a second visit. Hopefully the service will be better next time.

I came here for lunch on a weekday and really loved this place! It's similar to a Dig Inn, but what I loved about the place is that it's completely gluten free (so I had a lot more options). It's packed during lunch hour as you would expect. But the service is quick and you can always order ahead and just do a pick up. They have soups, bowls (which you can do with one of the four proteins options & different sides - they have both hot & cold sides), salads, sandwiches, cold-pressed juice and GF baked goods. I got the bowl with two sides - with tofu, cold soba noodle salad and charred broccoli. Here's what I liked about the bowl - it was flavorful, filling and healthy. Exactly what you want in a work day lunch. The tofu was grilled and was soft and juicy. The charred broccoli were amazing - cooked and seasoned to perfection and the cold soba noodle salad was exactly how you would expect it - slight and refreshing. My boyfriend got the salmon with side of the beet quinoa. The salmon was fresh and cooked well and the quinoa was a nice side to make the dish wholesome.I would highly recommend coming out here for lunch or dinner. You can try to avoid the long lunch lines by coming a little early, but the service is pretty quick that you can get in and out in 15 minutes max even during peak times. Also, they have a full service restaurant near flatiron that I am on my 'places to try' list.

Atera is a countertop dinner like no other. I have been here only once, so I shall resist the temptation to be overly judgemental.The reservation experience for Atera is a bit frightful. Given the fixed number of seats, they are particular about reminding you of the penalty for late cancellation (price of the dinner). And they appear inflexible about accommodating dietary restrictions, which turns out to not be the case during your visit. They are however quite particular about you arriving on time since late arrivals can put the rest of the diners out of sync with you.You will likely be seated on one of the dozen high chairs if you are not occupying the lone table on the side. And you will get to watch the cooks at work. It has the feel of having front-row seats in a laboratory, which is only fitting since I suspect equal parts of art, chemistry and culinary creativity go into designing the twenty-course menu at Atera. Molecular gastronomy and all that.Several months have passed, and I now only remember the yogurt nuts with beets, the sweet potato dish, the banana ice cream, and the butter cake. But I can say that no two dishes were identical or even similar in taste or presentation. And the service was uniformly attentive throughout the meal.Come to Atera to splurge on a culinary adventure that lasts almost three hours, and would leave you short by at least three hundred dollars a person for dinner and drinks. And if you can afford to go there repeatedly, make sure to take me with you.

BV's Burger is a Times Square hidden gem. Pocketed in a building adjacent to the Bobby Van's restaurant is the very small Bobby Van's Burger joint serving a good number of dishes perfect for breakfast or lunch. They also provide a nice outdoor seating area, away from the street. I never see this area too full. There is always a table and seat to grab. This might be one of my favorite lunch spots at the moment. Because it's inconspicuous, there are never lines. The pricing is also relatively cheap for what you can get, especially compared to mediocre but overpriced delis around here.At some point, I'll have to try their burgers. Believe it or not, burgers are not the only thing being served. I can speak for the semi-healthier options. For one, their salads are absolutely worth it. You get a pretty good portion, and they offer the dressing and cheese on the side, and plenty of it. The Mixed Green Salad ($5) is always a great choice. The french fries and sweet potato fries are also tasty, but I personally prefer the sweet potato fries. The soups are just okay. Had their Seafood Chowder, and it actually tasted a bit bland. The Beef Barley soup is definitely a better choice.I want to check out the breakfast menu here as I am betting it is much better than say Starbucks or Europa. BV is not overpriced at all for what you can get. Don't just settle for that overpriced cafe or deli on the corner. I recommend this spot for anyone who works around here.

Very nice addition to the Murray Hill area close to where I work. It's the sister speakeasy cocktail joint to downtown Little Branch. Lacking the bro-fisting that is normally seen in bars around these parts it's a classier choice to score a liquid refreshment. Heck, Home On The Range is a terrific cocktail, and at $12 a bit cheaper here than most speakeasies in NYC!Been here a few times now for an after work cocktail. As it's kind of hidden in what looks to be just another residential brownstone you can easily walk by, but it's not all that hard to find. There is a plaque on the face of the building with the letters MB along with a wrought iron fence that surrounds it. As it's a two story place the open windows with patrons seen drinking during warmer weather kind of gives it away.Head downstairs to the lower level, walk through the curtain, and enter a dimly candle lit bar area with plenty of communal high tables to rest your elbows on and enjoy a cocktail. Mainly standing room here. The upstairs features a brighter lit room with tables and chairs along with waitress service. A bit more upscale looking. The doorman/host will direct you where to go if you have parties larger than two, or if on a date and want a more intimate deal upstairs. The libation menu is pretty simple and reminds one of the Little Branch offerings. Many cool and fun drink names with descriptions, but I usually go with the Bartender's Choice when I am feeling more adventurous as per usual in a speakeasy spot. Make me something with bourbon or whiskey and I'm a happy camper. Can't go wrong with the great mixologists at these places. I did get a Home On The Range which I really enjoyed, along with a sazerac, and a few other boozy concoctions that escapes my memory. Yes, my liver still hates me.It's a laid back spot that is just so perfect for an after dinner drink to relax and unwind. I am a sucker for a quality cocktail bar with a speakeasy ambiance. Such a different and welcome vibe than the normal bars that dot the Bro-Murray Hill area offer. What it lacks in frattiness and bro-fisting it makes up for with exceptional cocktails and atmosphere.

I paused for a moment when my friend suggested we have dinner here, because I have walked by Beyoglu literally hundreds of times (I live up the street) but for some reason, never stopped in. Always being in the mood for Mediterranean food, it sounded like it would hit the spot and it definitely did.We stopped in on a Saturday evening and had about a half-hour wait, which was fine and easily whiled away at the second floor bar with a glass of sauvignon blanc. The restaurant itself spans two levels with the downstairs area being a bit louder and more chaotic. We were seated upstairs which is quieter and narrower, so feels more intimate (worth considering if you're on a date!). The menu at Beyoglu is pure Turkish classics and everything is excellent. I will say the menu is not terribly extensive, but everything on offer was great. My friend and I started with a meze platter which was a nice mixture including hummus, some excellent eggplant spread, etc. We also shared a shepherd salad which was light and well-dressed and a doner kebab platter (mixed lamb and beef over rice). These items were more than enough for two people, and more would've been too much. (So keep in mind the portions here are huge!)Overall, Beyoglu is an excellent choice and a surprisingly affordable one at that for the Upper East Side. Its popularity is no surprise given the quality of the experience here. Worth a try!

When it comes to unique dining in New York City, Tanoshi Sushi Sake Bar really sets the bar high...without the high prices! The most important thing to consider before going out of your way to get a reservation at Tanoshi is...do you like fish, or LOVE fish? For someone who binges on mediocre quality sushi all to frequently, I didn't expect my dinner at Tanoshi to leave me so hungry. This is in fact, because I'm not consuming Japanese food correctly. The experience at this restaurant is perfectly timed and portioned. So, if you are a ga-vone* such as myself, come for the stellar night of learning, and for some of the most fantastic, mouth watering morsels of fish you've ever consumed (not to leave feeling like you're gonna vom). The atmosphere is also far from trendy. At Tanoshi it's about authenticity, minimal Japanese decor, and feeling welcomed into Chef Toshio's home. If you are looking to wow a date dressed in heels and a short black number, perhaps somewhere like Morimoto is more for you. Our omakase, a Thursday night 7:30PM set was as follows:-- Fluke Treated with Kelp-- Seared King Salmon-- Big Eye Tuna -- Firefly Squid -- Wild Albacore Tuna with Shaved Egg Yolk-- Miso Cured Black Sable -- Poached Scallop-- Marinated Salmon Roe-- Santa Barbara Sea Urchin with Quail Egg-- Salt Water Eel -- Shot of Miso Soup -- Great or Everything Roll -- Tuna Hand Roll-- Salmon Belly (ordered a la carte)Of all of the sampling I found myself most enamored with the miso cured black sable, salmon belly, poached scallop, and fluke with kelp. The poached scallop and black sable were so soft and fresh my mind nearly exploded the very moment I tasted it. I was also pleasantly surprised by the firefly squid and the salt water eel, as these typically aren't my favorites on the grounds of texture but prepared so delicately they were a fantastic bite! As for my first time trying sea urchin...yikes! The diner next to me kept claiming it as 'the butter of the sea,' based on it's creamy consistency but it's far too earthy for my taste. If you're looking to add additional pieces to your meal make sure to ask the sushi chefs as they give great recommendations along with the origins and flavor profiles of the fish. Now that I've rambled on incoherently about sushi for the past 1K+ words I'll leave it to you to decide if this artfully presented sushi exhibition is for you...*Leave it to me to use Italian slang on a review of one of my new favorite Japanese restaurants.

Emmett's is hot hot hot right now. I came at 6:30pm on a Wednesday, put my name and cell phone # in with a 90 minute wait, which ended up being an hour wait. We got a call about 30 minutes in asking if we'd like to place our pizza order, which is unusual, but logical, as it takes 45 minutes for the pizzas to cook. The staff was well-meaning, but flustered, and I could see the helplessness on their faces. This place is small! And when opening, I am certain that the owner did not anticipate this type of buzz or interest in Chicago pizza. New Yorkers are all about the thin crust, right? So I don't want to criticize the staff. However, I can criticize the aggressively obnoxious party of 4 that steamrolled the hostess with "oh, we have 6 people now. Yeah, we'll just squeeze in", then proceeded to unapologetically sit on my purse, and pretend that it was ok to put 6 people in an already tight 4-person table. The girl was literally 1" away from me. If I wanted to eat dinner with a bitch in my lap, I would have brought the dog with me.So the shitshow and popularity of this place aside, this is actually some really great pizza. My only foray into the world of Chicago pizza was going to the old Pizzeria Uno on the Upper West Side when I was little, and I remember being pretty disappointed. Emmett's is what I would expect from the best of the Chicago knife and fork pies. Thick buttery crust, formidable, but not stale or too tough. Thick robust tomato sauce. Good quality pepperoni (I am sure they use the same supplier as my favorite pizza place of the moment - Fiore's). And gobs of stringy mozzarella that make life worth living. My husband and I split a 10" medium pizza and a salad, and that was the perfect amount of food for us. To be fair though, I was pretty hungry going in.The beer and wine list was reasonably priced ($7 Gruner woo hoo!), but I can't see coming back. The popularity, clientele, wait times, and overall helpless hot mess factor is a big detraction for me, so I will definitely stick to takeout.

Employees Only is a bar with a great food selection and a full food menu. I went with my wife and friends and they said the after hours menu was possibly better than their regular menu. My wife had been suggesting we go to employees only for the previous 4 gatherings with friends so I know with that frequency it must have made a great impression on her.First impression, lots of young attractive singles if you're into that type of thing... I'm not one for clubs but this was a nice one.It did not seem like an easy place to get into but since we were only interested in the table service they made sure to separate us from the folks interested in the bar. The drinks area is a lot more in demand.Only one bathroom... how are people supposed to get their drink on?The menu was phenomenal. We ordered the dozen oysters which were fresh, brine-y, and crisp. I ordered the hand cut steak tartar with greens, large slices of croutons, and a steak tartar that was mixed in a bowl with worcester sauce, and egg. Each bite was crunchy, savory, and memorable.We shared a dish of bone marrow poppers which we all ended up wanting all for ourselves.Get the cocktails. I had a Hemingway Daiquiri which was balanced, cool, refreshing, and perfect for slow sipping mid dinner conversation. I had a Mata Hari which was dark, smooth and delicious.Great hang out for a late night.

Spontaneous adventures in NYC are simply the best. Our dinner tonight at Hunt & Fish Club was certainly one of those. My partner in crime and I came here on a whim to check out the official opening of this new restaurant. Part of us didn't want to go too far because of the freezing cold and the other part had been encouraged by a notice from Urban Daddy. We walked in just to grab a drink at the bar but upon noticing already how lovely the interior was, we decided to inquire for a table. We figured why not give this place a chance! From beginning to end we received nothing but attentive service from everyone who worked there. Even the owner (whose name I believe was Lester!) greeted us and told us because we were his very first diners on their first official day, our dessert would be free. Way to make me fall in love with you already... I took a break from alcohol this evening but I could not help but take a gander at their cocktail list. They had a great array of libations to suit every palate. Around the beautiful dining room with its lit up ceiling and marbled floors the waiters were bustling around attending to every guest as if they had no other. Without even a word a gentleman walked over to our table and saw it was a tad wobbly and fixed it before we could even make a comment. Never before have I seen such efficiency on an opening night. Not once did I get an air of pretentiousness or attitude which one might expect from a restaurant with such a name and such interior design. It was absolutely wonderful.Now that I've gushed about the service, let me get to food. I always believe restaurants can strive to better themselves after their openings and I see the potential in H&F's dishes. To start, my PIC and I shared the Baked Littleneck Clams, the Uni, Crab & Ponzu appetizer and the Oxtail & Bone Marrow French Onion Soup. I consider myself to be a baked clam connoisseur and these were delicious! There was an unknown undertone of flavor to the dish that I absolutely loved. I did not love the Uni appetizer (porrrrrr queeeeeee!!!) as it seemed a little too jumbled together in terms of taste and presentation. I can see this working if it was restructured and maybe another element added in. The soup was absolutely out of this world. On nights like tonight where you just want to stick your entire body in an oven to escape the cold, this soup was the perfect remedy. The broth was thick and hearty with chunks of oxtail meat and you could taste the sweet richness of the bone marrow in every drop. This soup is to die for. I would come back just for this dish alone. Highly, highly, HIGHLY recommended.For our mains, she ordered the Cedar Plank Salmon (Bubble & Squeak, Horseradish Créme Fraîche) and I was craving pasta (typical) so I went with the Cavatelli Wild Boar Ragù with Local Smoked Ricotta. After that toe-curling-inducing soup the pasta was a tad underwhelming... but as mentioned earlier I can see the potential in the dish. It needs something to give it more depth in flavor and I think it also needed some more cavatelli. Once I had eaten all of the pasta I still had ample chunks of boar left in my dish (which I of course took home and will find something useful to do with it later). I stole a bite of the salmon which was cooked perfectly medium rare with a dab of the horseradish créme fraîche. So yummy.For dessert it was hard for me to choose. At one point I had chosen the Chocolate Torte at the waiter's recommendation but then I saw the Sundae station out of the corner of my eye... my inner child squealed. They wheeled over two carts- one has a bunch of toppings and the other with my ice cream bowl ready to be doused in goodies! I wish I had asked for a scoop of chocolate ice cream instead of vanilla since I thought my sundae came with both choc and vanilla but it's all good. For toppings you can choose from: fresh berries, chocolate pearls, rice krispies, chocolate walnuts and hot fudge. GET ALL THE TOPPINGS!Oh and to make this meal even more interesting, we were interviewed by a reporter for the NY Post on what we thought about the restaurant and had our photo taken. That's a first for me... but I quite enjoyed it. We were also given a tour of the private rooms and were sold on using this venue in the future. It's such a beautiful restaurant and their attention to detail plus dedication makes us completely confident that they will wow anyone we send there.We also had some fun people sightings such as Charlie Gasparino and Darryl Strawberry. Definitely looking forward to more adventures in the New Year!

Hu Kitchen has really good quality food. You can't feel bad or guilty after eating there lol. It's healthy but taste great too. It's a bit expensive though but you pay for what you get. It's more like a place for breakfast and lunch, although you could also go for a quick and healthy dinner. It's not vegan or raw - they do serve meat. It's a good place to go eat if you are on a special diet.

I have come to really enjoy this place while living in Hell's Kitchen. Being an ave away from my apartment makes it really easy to frequent and I am happy to have stumbled in and squeezed myself into the cramped bar space back in July because I have been a regular here ever since. Whether taking advantage of the dollar oysters (these run out often so try to arrive early before they do), splitting a bottle of wine with friends, or indulging in tapas, Briciola is a great venue to start your night at. No reservations though, sorry. Do not come with a large group. I say 3-4 people should be your max. Be advised that if you are in a group of more than two people you will likely be at a community table so you might need to hold back on talk of your Saturday night underground sex ring excursions (unless of course you think your neighbor may be into some weird shit too). Just kidding guys, not in an underground sex ring, so cool your excitement. Anyway, my go to here is the sangiovese by the glass. I have gotten a few bottles here too but blanking on the types at the moment. The french bartender here seems to know his shit so go to him for a solid Q&A on the wines. You will see the wine list is actually on a tiny wooden slab written in chalk and can be difficult to read at times so again refer to the french dude.Excellent food options here (I just get tapas) include:1. Tuna Tartare2. Lamb Chops3. Grilled Octopus4. BurrataAnd to no surprise, you can't go wrong with a fine selection of cheeses either. Yum Yum.

I'm going to be blunt. I would have never come into this place if I didn't have to use the restroom so bad. The windows were steamed up and I couldn't see inside. And I want to say a hearty "thank you" to the staff! Most places don't let you use the restroom if you're not already a customer, and they definitely don't let you go into the back to use the employee one just because you're doing the pee-pee dance. Enough about my tiny bladder....It's a Soul Food Buffet. A big, comprehensive, delicious Soul Food Buffet. I got as much as I could fit into my styrofoam container. The Jerk Chicken was on point. Great, authentic seasoning. The BBQ Chicken was good as well but it resembled General Tso so much I was expecting it to be spicy. Damn.... now I want General Tso chicken legs. Someone get on that! The macaroni and cheese was adequate. It was like homemade... just not like my home. The collards weren't sweet! I have to qualify it like this because I've been subjected to some gawdawful collards recently. They were full of stems, but that seems to be standard with most places. At least these were thoroughly cooked and soft. They were just fine, really. Now the green beans were great! I should have gotten more. They were cooked with smoked turkey and that was the key to FlavorTown. Ugh... did I just use a Guy Fieri-ism??? Okay, kill me now. They charge by the pound, so all this food totaled up to just over 18 bucks. The counter guys are super friendly. All the guys are super friendly. This is a friendly establishment. There's lots of seating. I would have stayed if I wasn't on my limited break from work. Oh! I almost forgot. The Sweet Yams... pure South. Very sweet and buttery. Maybe too sweet for some, but I'm talking about Southern-sweet where the lemonade tastes like simple syrup. Don't get the big pieces, scoop up the butter drenched dregs.

I came here last Friday on a double date and came away very full and very happy. As you might know, Lupa is one of Mario Batali's more casual restaurants (I would say the vibe is similar to that of Casa Mono's, but the space is much bigger). The menu is quite large, so I'm glad we came as a group as we got to sample a number of dishes. We came in a bit too overzealous and had originally wanted to order a primi and secondi each, but the waiter quickly suggested ordering just three of each in addition to a few appetizers since otherwise we would have too much food. This was comforting; he wasn't trying to upsell us. What we ordered:Appetizers: I am a HUGE fan of cured meats, so we got the Affetati Grande (basically a large meat platter) to share. It came with a selection of 5-6 meats, and I thought the Linga (pickled veal tongue), and Testa (head cheese) were especially delicious. The platter also comes in a smaller size so if you're with just one other person, I would definitely suggest getting it to sample the various meats. We also shared the Spinach & Warm Pancetta Salad, which came exactly as the name would suggest. This was a light dish and brought some greens to our otherwise meat-heavy meal.Primi: We chose to get the Bucatini All'Amatriciana, the Ricotta Gnocchi with Sausage & Fennel, and the Black & White Tagliatelle with Mussels & Jalapeno. My favorite by far was the Bucatini, with the Gnocchi coming in at a close second. The Bucatini was cooked perfectly al dente, and I very much liked the red sauce that came with it. The Tagliatelle was probably the most disappointing, the pasta itself was fine but the dish seemed slightly bland even with the jalapeno scattered throughout.Secondi: At this point we were actually starting to get full, but powered through our Secondi choices which consisted of the Heritage Pork Shoulder, Pollo (Chicken), and Octopus with Salsa Verde & Leeks. The meat on the pork shoulder was super tender and broke apart easily, but my favorite secondi had to have been the octopus - it came in a generous portion, the texture was perfect, and it was incredibly flavorful. I try not to order chicken at most restaurants but Lupa delivered a solid dish here; the skin was crispy but I found the meat to be slightly too dry for my liking. We were too full to try desserts, but I look forward to coming back and trying several next time!

KenScale: 8.0/10Hanjan is a modern Korean restaurant serving chef Hooni Kim's interpretation of Korean pub-style food paying homage to . Given my Korean background, I always have a bit higher standard for my mother country's cuisine. When I visited Hanjan during its early days, I liked the fresh ingredients but felt the seasoning was a bit too salty, probably catering to American audience that had been mobbing the restaurant since its opening. On my recent visit, however, my impression of the restaurant changed completely. Not only was the dining room subdued, but the flavor of the food also evolved to have more faithfulness to authentic Korean cuisine, which was a great pleasant surprise. I really loved a lot of dishes coming out from this kitchen, from the crispy perilla leaf dumplings with shrimp and pork, to short rib and pork belly skewers that were definitely above average with delicious and tender meat, to the beautifully cooked grilled half mackerel. I was somewhat underwhelmed by garlic fried chicken with pickles (with so many good fried chicken places opening these days, I think that was somewhat ineivtable), and spicy squid stir fry with organic somyun noodles was a bit too spicy to show the texture of the squid. On the other hand, I see the signature pork fat "ddukbokki" that I liked during my prior visits was even better than I had tasted before, with absolutely crisp rice cake that gave me delightful sensation. I expected a salty broth from the matsutake mushroom and brisket soup, but the broth turned out to be more or less perfect, with rich flavor without a ton of seasoning that would make it a great dish for cold winter nights. Kimchi and beef brisket fried rice with egg was another winner, a modern take on "bokkeum bap" (fried rice) with great balance of flavor and texture. Unfortunately, I came to dinner a bit too early and couldn't get a taste of the famed Korean spicy ramyun (whose broth is prepared for 12 hours and therefore the dish is available only after 9 p.m. every day). On my last visit, the broth was just overly sweet, but I would definitely love to see if this dish has evolved in the positive direction.On all my prior visits, the restaurant was absolutely packed and the didn't take reservations, so sometimes it would take up to 2 hours to wait for a table. This time, however, my dining companion was able to book a table at 6 p.m. the day before without much problem, and the chaotic dining area was definitely more subdued. The restaurant has a full bar, but I would stick with beer or traditional Korean/Japanese drinks like soju or sake. I've always liked the clean, modern vibe of this restaurant that wasn't too pretentious or divey. I'm glad to report that Hanjan is going on a right direction in showcasing how the Korean cuisine has and will evolve in the modern age. With a ton of terrible Korean restaurants in K-Town, I will gladly visit Hanjan instead whenever I have a huge craving for Korean food.

Thai places are a dime a dozen in this neighborhood, but I go to Pam Real Thai for 1. my pad see ew fix and 2. massive portions & cheap prices. Seriously, Thai food can be affordable in Midtown West!They consistently serve the most affordable and tastiest pad see ew not just in Hell's Kitchen, but in the entire city. The sweet soy sauce they use to make the dish beautifully caramelizes in the pan and gives the flat rice noodles another dimension to the otherwise commonplace dish. I also recommend their ox tail soup, which is a clear, aromatic broth that's absolutely lovely on cold winter days, even better than a bowl of pho.Appetizers worth ordering include: hae kern (the ground crab meat tastes more like fishcake but this satisfies the fried craving), steamed Thai dumpling (the shitake is quite yummy), and papaya salad (huge portion!) Other safe bets that won't blow your mind, but will not let you down: pad kee mao, green curry, tom yum soup, yum seafood (seafood salad). I should also mention that the service is extremely kind and friendly for NYC standards.However, this place is not a solid 5 stars because when you hit the misses, they're really misses. The pad thai was bland and unflavorful, which is surprising considering how tasty the pad see ew is. Fried rice can occasionally be too well-done, and I prefer my fried rice to have springy granules of rice. The spring rolls are absolutely unmemorable.*Cash only* - so head to an ATM beforehand.

Good beers, righteous pigs in a blanket, friendly bartender....What's not to love?Came here with some friends on a Tuesday night and it was a very relaxed place, with great music, plenty of TVs to watch sports and a cool vibe. The dart board was very busy.I don't go that far east that far downtown very often, but if I was in the neighborhood, this would be a good spot to stop in for a beer.

To begin, Danny Bowien is so confident, that he knows you don't need a knife to eat dinner at Mission Cantina. To only receive half of a silver wear setting at a hip chef's LES Mexican joint has to indicate confidence rather than negligence, right? ...There I go again starting a story in the middle. Let's rewind. It's a chill Friday night and my boyfriend and I find ourselves on Stanton Street, early. We're searching for that laid back little cash-only noodle bar across the street from Arlene's Grocery. You know, the one called Noodle Bar. It's gone. In its place stands Mission Cantina, looking like a mix between a diner and a night club with its metallic surfaces, triangle mirrors and neon lights. They take our phone number, we go get drinks elsewhere, they call us to come back. I LOVE when restaurants do this.Once seated, I immediately order a michelada (perfection), and realize that the entire ceiling is hand-painted in a camouflage pattern. I ponder the amount of time and work that must have taken, while I simultaneously realize that the music sounds like my iPod from 2007.* Missy Elliot, Aaliyah, Nelly Furtado, the works. What IS this place? The entire ambiance puts me in the zone, and when the waiter returns I put on my big girl pants and order for my boyfriend and I: -- octopus ceviche with avocado, coconut milk and habanero-- grilled brisket alambres with bacon, queso Oaxaca, peppers and onions-- masa fried chicken with smoked habanero honey, pumpkin seed furikakeDone. I'm satisfied with my order and my boyfriend is jaw-dropped in shock that I made all the decisions for once. Every bite of food we consume is pure euphoria. The brisket dish is my favorite - fatty, but not TOO fatty, it melts in your mouth and the flavors have that distinct balance that reminds you that you're consuming a Bowien creation. Ride or Die B*tch plays as we polish off the honey habanero fried chicken.Before leaving I hit the restroom, and while waiting in line I'm questioned by another patron on which items I ordered. I'm convinced this only happens here.___________* I asked about the playlist - it was a NYE mix by the hostess. Happy New Year, indeed!**Minus one star for service. The rest of the staff seemed on-point, but had our waiter visited us a few more times we definitely would have ordered more drinks - a lose-lose situation.

San Marzano is MARVELOUS SAAAAAAN! been here several times and keep going baaaaack.so what does San Marzano refer to? delish Italian plum tomatoes--perhaps. not clear. what is clear is that this italian eatery in the east village is an AWESOME bang for your buck.the decor: darkly lit. big windows line the exterior of the dining space. lots of dark wood. and metal finishes. a casual cozy feel with touches of modern without feeling detached. there a bunch of two tops, four tops, etc.-- very modular tables to fit your coupling or big group needs. it's a date-y space with friend/family flexibility!san marzano is perfect for a low-key first date, catch-up with a amigo/a, brunch, or a cost-effective dinner with the girl- or boy- fraaand when carb eats need to trump conversation!the food--most of it is priced under $10 per dish! i would never call San Marzano cheap--i would call it great food at a great price! there's no complimentary bread (or hasn't been when i've dined there). i prefer eating meals this way as heaping bread on top of a carb-centric meal seems like overkill. and if you don't eat it...the bread goes to waste. so not having bread is a plus to moi--just sprint right to the apps!appetizers recommendations: meatballs (delish and delectable) , brussel sprouts (crispy n served with chunks of salty pancetta), buratta (creamy melt in your mouth)the calamari appetizer is just okay.the pasta is freshly made in-house and you get to mix-n-match your pasta choice with and sauce choice. the pasta lives up to it's freshness as it's served "al dente" (firm to the tooth. doesn't have that "processed" taste. no mushy pasta served here). every time i've been here i alternate between the papardelle or the garganelle with either the bolognese or wild boar ragu. the firm pasta is perfect with the tasty cling of the sauce--savory yet light. what i love about San Marzano is the portion control...it's a perfect serving of pasta which leaves you wanting more (but full) without feeling like a stuffed pig. i've only been to Italy four times and this is how i remember being served pasta in Florence and the Cinque Terra...just enough pasta for the sauce to flavor. not a gigantic glop of pasta, cheese, and sauce that chain places have cashed in on all around 'Merica. an order of an app and pasta will have you feeling real full without feeling like a blob.there are also paninis served here which folks scarf fairly quickly...so i assume they be tasty.wine and beer are priced for value. most glasses of wine are under 7 bucks--the wine list is decently sized. pork slap in a can for $3 dineros? WHUT! a nice small selection of cans, bottles and draft beers. they also have Sangria priced at $15 a pitcher...nice!service is pretty good. though it can be hit-or-miss when they are slammed on a Friday/Saturday night or during brunch crush as the waitresses don't seem super experienced in running tables, stacking orders, etc. however i have never had a big issue with service...it's always been friendly and genuine. no bs. i prefer eating at San Marzano on non prime time nights: Monday through Wednesday. never a wait for tables or food.sometimes they offer fresh ground pepper, sometimes they offer freshly grated parmesan cheese, sometimes both, or sometimes none of either. it's bizarre. i am a fan of freshly cracked pepper and feel like this sb a standard at any non-fancy italian restaurant, so i am nicking 1/2 star for not having this part of the pasta course be more consistent. while it might be a chef-centric thing...managers should make sure that the runners or waitresses always offer this as i feel it's a nice touch and gives a nice homey touch. i am nicking another 1/2 star because sitting people by the windows during winter is FREEZEY! way too cold. either the windows aren't insulated well or there's no heat on the perimeter of the restaurant. very minor negatives to such great meals. overall: 4 STARS!who needs food deal apps when great food at this eatery in the east village is priced so well? lol. woohoodrops mic, so i can drink my pork slap outta can in one hand and twirl pasta in the other. there's no excuse for eating at chain italian eateries when more authentic joints with better prices exist. i out!

ALWAYS A GOOD TIME! I've been here a bunch of times on different nights at different times. Truely I am partial to the Friday night shows because in my opinion they are more of the traditional high fashion form of Burlesque but Saturday is just a show of fun LES Messes/ performers. Not for the uptight or "stiff". Get there early as it filled up very quickly and there will only be standing room. The seat on stage right is always "Mark Twain's" you'll see the older gentleman with a hat and bow tie every time you come here and always in the same seat alone having a private bubble moment. TIP your bartenders, they are nice guys. There is seating upstairs with more tables but the best seat in in the middle of the balcony or else you see little. Performers can be anything from: Stripping Monkey men, air dancers, burlesque, comical readings, interpretive dance, go go dancing, to out right nake people shaking their bits and pieces on stage. Yes there is full on nudity here after about 12am. Not sure if its legal but its entertaining. OH TO BE IN A WORLD WITHOUT SMARTPHONES WHEN YOUR HOO-AH IS NOT POSSIBLITY ON EVERYTHING CONTRABRAND WEBSITE IN THE FAR OR NEAR EAST. Bathrooms are VERY SMALL and individual upstairs so there will be a LINE. Also the plumming in the LES is OLD...... like very OLD..... Please be concious about your CHOICES!! Always a good time. Closest train I think is the F train. Plus is located in the HEART of LES. So lots of choices after the MAGIC has ended.

Warm personable service, fast delicious hot food, super efficient managers and waiters during the pre-show rush hour period. Perfect when you won tickets to see a hot Broadway show and you have to cancel your plans to go to the East village for dinner.I suspect that the manager was the Owner's son and the wife was one of the bartenders. Such care went into bar tending! Each glass of wine was poured to the exact same level. A table of 4 got 6 glasses and we watched the bartender measure each glass out to exact same volume. Pro tip: make a reservation if you are planning to dine here between 5-7pm. Because everyone else is trying to do the same thing.The Gyro was juicy and just as flavorful as I remembered. And the warm Pita bread was perfect on this chilly Winter evening.

I've enjoyed drinks and appetizers on the rooftop, and outdoor patio in good weather here but never brunch. It's really a nice place to relax and enjoy the scene, with plenty of room and not really that crowded... I came here with a group of 12 for my bestie's birthday. It was one of the few places that could accommodate large parties last minute. Brunch is really not bad at all- complimentary mimosa, or bloody mary as one would expect in this nabe :). I didn't get a coffee but plenty of people did and it seemed ok. I didn't think they did freshly squeezed OJ so I went for a bloody mary which was strong and tall- enjoyed the sizzly tomato juice flavor. Service was fine- a little slow but always available considering the place was so small we could flag her down easily. (Brunch went on for a while and they were kind enough not to kick us out. The crowd is beautiful and sceney with a bit of families/old money types mixed in. Pretty sure our waitress was a model she was tall and skinny. My one complaint was that they tried to seat 12 of us in two little small lounge booths (with small round tables) which could barely fit 6 let alone 13.. fortunately we moved once the entire party arrived to vacant tables on the side which we just pushed together. Now, onto the food: I had the kobe beef burger ($18) which seemed like one of the best items to get- not overly big, juicy, cooked perfectly medium rare, with good white cheddar and avocado. I wasn't a fan of the soggy bun (well the burger was just greasy) and I felt the onions were a bit flyaway but overall I think it was the best choice. Bf got the same. Mostly everywhere else got some kind of omelette or some variety of eggs benedict (they had the usual- with salmon, with veggies, regular, etc). My birthday girl got a fluffy goat cheese and asparagus omelet. Only one person got French Toast which honestly looked a bit sad. Everything savory came with really good crispy fries and there were not that many. When it came time to pay, we were surprised that tip was not included. They also specified they could only take a max of 5 credit cards which is annoying. for people - fyi. Glad we had cash. Came to $31 pp total. I wouldn't come as a brunch destination but would recommend if in the area for sure and didn't want to deal with a crowd.

We walked in and were the second patrons there. Our waitress though nice knew next to nothing about the menú or drinks. She tried to cover by saying pretty much everything was delicious but had to run and ask the mánager about any and everything.We tried the ginger smash, another cocktail and then stuck to Lagunitas IPA. The drinks were good but not potent. Tried the smoked wings, seasonal salad, and the beef and oxtail chili. Wings were ok, had a very ham/bacon flavor with a subtle kick of spice. After a while I felt like I was eating bacon flavored wings. Salad was great but waitress didnt know what grains were in it. Chili was good but could have used more salt and pepper-- just overall flavor but pretty good attempt.Extremely clean and the service was attentive. Bathrooms were immaculate. The televisions were large, ample and clear with great views wherever you looked.Overall ambiance was good and I would return.

The cat girl in me almost keeled over from Acute Kitten Happiness. I first heard of the concept of a "cat cafe" from a co-worker / friend, Katie. She had been to one on a recent visit to South Korea, and the idea of cuddling with a kitten and a cuppa appealed to me greatly! I heard whispers of Meow Parlour for months, and you can bet the two of us were online at work the moment reservations opened up, technical difficulties be damned! We finally snagged a reservation for four on the evening of January 2nd, and it couldn't come soon enough.
