We arrived a few minutes past our 6 p.m. reservation time (damn you, slow F train!), but the staff at the front desk were friendly and understanding. We already paid $4 each for the initial half hour, but were given an official check in time and charged $4 for each additional half hour spent. (Easy enough.) Upon filling out waivers (smart and necessary), we all took off our shoes, Purelled our hands, and made our way towards Kitty Heaven! Admittedly, what took place was a trifle different than what I had in my head; I imagined myself being surrounded by a veritable whirlwind of kitten love. Instead, it was much more peaceful. In fact, many of the kitties said, "Screw you guys. I'm sleeping in this cubby hole!" And you know what? That's okay! There were quite a few that were willing to pal around with us, as we sat on comfortable floor pillows and deployed face and ear scratches. One guy working there was really helpful, friendly, and just overall chatty with us. (Wish I remembered your name, but you were awesome, dude!) He had an affinity for one of the cats, Liza, and even passed her over to me, as she's a big fan of sleeping on laps. Indeed, I got a good five minutes of Liza / Allison cuddle time before she moved off to the next warm lap. The facility itself, for those wondering about the possible well-being of said cats, is pretty immaculate. Strict rules are in place for us, the customers, and they are easy to abide by. The cats' cages, beds, food, litter boxes, et al, are kept in a separate room, though a decorative cut-out hole in the wall allows cats easy access. Surprisingly, I was surprised at how little cat hair I saw, save for a bit on the floor pillows. Finally, unless I'm "nose blind", it did not smell like cats in there. For those that don't know, the cats are up for adoption through Kitty Kind. Many were on their way to new homes in the upcoming week. How wonderful! Though I'm in no position to adopt a cat now, in the future, I'd be so happy to do it through this organization.Unfortunately, since we came late, we didn't get a chance to walk over to the associated cafe to grab a few bites before coming to the actual Meow Parlour, but! There is always next time! What a wonderful and unique way to spend a Friday evening! This place is lovely.Warning: Don't come if you're allergic to cats. *ahem* (Come on...can't you see someone writing a one-star Yelp Review about this place, complaining about how it aggravated their cat dander allergy? Can't you?! Ha!)

Since I only bought the mouth-watering macaroons at the Champs-Élysées Paris location and didn't get to dine there for brunch, I've been wanting to go to the Soho tearoom for brunch/dinner since getting back. I finally got the chance and had delicious ginger tea with huge chunks of fresh ginger, fresh squeezed orange/lemon juice and the Club Champs-Élysées sandwich. The drinks were really tasty and the sandwich was scrumptious - made with thin slivers of eggplant, zucchini, roasted tomatoes, mozzarella, pinenuts and more. It was so delicious and didn't fall short in the taste test. The restaurant/tearoom is gorgeous and the staff were very nice. There is one downside, however. I would suggest the slices of bread for the sandwich get upgraded to a hugher quality bread. It maybe the typical bread used to make club sandwiches, but for me, it brings back childhood memories of slices of white bread like Bunny Bread, Sunbeam bread and Wonder Bread mom used to make peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. I was expecting a higher quality at a famous upscale French tearoom/restaurant. If the bread is upgraded, I'd give 6 stars :-)Next time I go, I'll most likely ask for a gluten free option or opt for a dinner entree.

Part of me wishes Nino's was a little farther from the office, so that I can walk off the pasta carbs to/from lunch... but let's be real, I love having such a solid Italian lunch option so close by! This is in our regular rotation for those full-hour lunch days, and for good reason -- the entrees are fairly priced, each dish is well-prepared and delicious, the portions are more than generous, and the service is attentive (without hovering). I peeked at the menu to see how many different items I've tried, and dudeeee -- I did a great job of trying a little bit of everything. You can't go wrong with anything on this menu, I promise. I mean, I can't even say that I have an "absolute fave" here at Nino's because everything I've had is good (especially for the pastas). I will say that one thing that's been ordered consistently (and by that, I mean every time I've eaten here) is the Truffled Mac & Cheese Bites. No need to explain right?It can get crazy crowded, crazy fast due to the Midtown lunch-crunch so if you have a larger group, make reservations beforehand!

Chubby Donut Patrolling ReportDough is my favorite donut right now!! Their donuts are all so chubby and cute! I eat them once a week at my office with my food blogger team. Check out my photo! I made donut tower. You MUST try super pink Hibiscus flavor. #PowerOfPinkDonut Cutie Patroller is always on the prowl in NYC for cute places and good food."*\(^_^)/*

Oh dear I'm afraid yellow privilege really got the best of me this time. I've been going to Tasty Hand-Pulled Noodles for years and only JUST realized --after reading a review lamenting the dumpling sauce-- that y'all wide-eyes don't have the recipe for a basic dumpling sauce stored in your DNA, inherited from one dynasty to the next.So!I'm gonna tell you what to do, for those times when you don't know what to dip your dumplings into.First off, the dumplings here are truly amazing. No hard little meat anchors here! These dumplings use plenty of napa cabbage to create a juicy, tender, not-too-greasy, filing. The ones I had today were particularly beautifully-made, like freakin' origami. Architectural, brah.Anyway, ok, so the bare bones dumpling sauce only has two ingredients, and they are: Black Vinegar + Soy Sauce. Dats it. The vinegar is sharp and sweet and balances out the earthy and savory soy sauce. And they work perfectly together like a pair of antagonistic muscles in Michael Phelps' swimmery shimmery bodice.If you wanna fancy it up, you can add hot sauce, or sesame oil (not too much eh) and that's basically it. I think one of the hot sauces on the table has crushed garlic in it? That's niiiice.About this place: well, it's super cheap and it's super good. The broth doesn't come to the table particularly salted, it's got this pure animal bone taste that is just heavenly. And then you dress it up to your liking. But man, what a base to work with! It's like building a mountain when you are already on another mountain.The pan-fried noodles are shockingly delicious. Again, seasoned with a light hand. But even before you add any sauces to it, the frickin' thing tastes like pleasure incarnate. Something about the oil they use and how it adheres to the chewy, perfectly-cooked noodles... makes my stomach get all emo in a good way.What else --the cold cucumber is great, with a well-balanced sauce. And service is quick and happy. Tip them well, you cheap bastards!

Seriously had no idea what to expect. Came here with my friend Arianna O. I was in such a rush that I actually didn't get a shot on my way in.We ended up sitting above which meant a partial view (we couldn't see the people sitting below us) but meant we were relatively safe from being targeted during the show. Although it also meant little leg room and sitting on stools for the entire time.Prepare to be entertained and don't take it too seriously and you'll have a great time. I now have a whole new appreciation for Macbeth. Glad I got to experience something so different like this here in NYC!

I used to work in the West Village, so I passed by Cafe Espanol a million times but I never gave it a second thought. It always had the look of a tourist trap type place, but thanks to the prodding of Tom K. and Tricia K., a group of us wound up going to this awesome spot for dinner recently. While the restaurant was quite full in the front, our party of five was quickly ushered into a back seating area (that we had no idea existed) and were given a nice big table where we all sat comfortably. Nearby was a bar and a rest room in convenient (but not gross) proximity. For a Friday night, it was ideal.Instead of just having entrees on our own, we decided on a strategy of a couple entrees on the table with a pile of tapas. Here's the breakdown of some of the more memorable dishes I had that night:Pulpo al Café EspañolFeaturing sautéed octopus w/ chopped onions, garlic, parsley and wine this was some of the most tender octopus I've ever had in a restaurant. No rubbery chewiness, just melt in your mouth goodness with a wonderful, light flavor.Croquetas de Jamon y PolloCroquettes featuring serrano ham and chicken, these delights were crunchy on the outside and bursting with flavor on the inside.Tortilla EspañolaTraditional Spanish omelet with potato, onion and egg. This thing was serious comfort food. Every bite felt like you were being hugged. It was that good.Boquerones Marinated anchovies (fresh) in olive oil with minced garlic. This is a dish that bursts with flavor if you combine all three items. Add in some of the awesome bread they serve with dinner and you have a treat in a bite!We also had the Paella Valenciana (sausage, chicken, seafood and saffron rice) as a shared entree. The dish was good. The texture was nice and there was plenty of seafood to be had. Was it the best Paella I had ever had in my life? No. Was it great enough that I'd order it again? Absolutely!Service was courteous, professional and quick. From the hostess to our waitstaff, I never found anyone lacking.I feel bad I looked Cafe Espanol over as many times as I had in the past. I look forward to my next visit!

Tips for a great experience:- dress up for a special night- get an early ticket time, arrive on time, and wander around the space- say yes to any invitation presented to you and leave any jealousy or resistance at the door... remember it's all for fun and show- follow performers when they grab people and see what happens, being a spectator can be just as much fun as being a participant- the advantage to tickets above gala level are unlimited cocktails (beyond the entry cocktail and table wine) and a dedicated table you can sit at before and after the performance- the advantage to gala seats is more interaction during the performance as your table may become a part of the show or a piece of stage- choose a smaller table if you're hungry, larger if you aren't- empty the wine carafes at least once before dinner is over - barter for additional food with tables who have fewer people- during the show- laugh, clap, make some noise and encourage the performers who put a lot of themselves into the show- enjoy yourself, it's a beautifully performed show of acrobatics meets cabaret with some teasing and fun thrown in :)If sexual teasing or close encounters with strangers makes you VERY uncomfortable:- arrive closer to 8pm so there's no time to explore before the show- stay in the middle of the crowded bar before the show starts- don't wander around the space until the show is doneYou'll still see a beautiful and sexy acrobatic cabaret show with dinner, but you'll miss some of the things that make this a unique experience.

"Life is too short," they said. "Eat the cheese." And so I did--along with fried chicken. No shame, no pain...all gains.I came here a few weeks ago with a friend who suggested we get the Buttermilk Fried Chicken Melt--hold up, FRIED CHICKEN in a grilled cheese? That sounds unusual (I admit I'm not a huge grilled cheese fan), but it was surprisingly delicious because of all the perfect, different ingredients and tastes composed in one--crispy, savory, sourish, creamy, and a hint of spicy.I couldn't wait to go back after that, so I ordered the Truffle Melt the next time I went back. I was really looking forward to this; I am a self-proclaimed truffle aficionado and the thought of it way before I finally got my hands on it, made me drool (literally). Flavor was great and there was a huge truffle presence with a nice touch of arugula, but I expected more. Even though I expected a chunky sandwich as big as the Fried Chicken, I was not disappointed. This didn't get me really full as did the Fried Chicken, and had it not been for LevelUp, I don't think I'd ever pay full-price for them. I'll definitely come back if there's a deal because they have some of the most creative grilled cheese sandwiches in the city, but pricey. The Shop Tots are also pretty good and cheesy (as expected).There are only about 4 small tables in here, so it's hard to find seating sometimes since it's a busy shop. The staff is friendly and accommodating here, which is always a plus!

I prefer the cafe. The creations on that menu are awesome. The wait here is very long (obviously more during certain times of day). The rugelach is insane - the raspberry in particular. They use a combination of seeds and nuts to give the rugelach an amazing crunch and various layers of flavor - it tastes so fresh! Amazing smoked fish - white fish salad is awesome. Overall really good stuff. Not the best bagel I have ever had in my life, though.

Oink oink oink piggy piggy piggyI always get the same thing every time I go to a Filipino restaurant: Longinizza with a side of garlic rice, and a salad, so I can neglect and complain about how much I hate salads. If I was a rabbit, I still wouldn't eat a salad; I'd be a cute rabbit though, one of those bacon eating bunnies that smell good all the time.Anywho, yeah... the first time I've been to a Filipino restaurant... WITH NO LONGINIZZA, dun dun duuuuuuuuuuun (and garlic rice). It didn't really ruin my night because I was feeling adventurous, so I opted for the Sizzling Sisig. Nothing quite says adventure like a mutilated pig head does. At first I didn't want to go for it because the Adobo sounded amazing with it's garlic flavors, and my Filipino friend whom I went with recommended the Sisig, and I was in the mood to spite him for fun. You know, gotta assert your dominance sometimes *gorilla noises*, but it sounded too good to pass up.My friend ordered something else, I don't care, my food tasted too good to pay attention to his dish. So, that's how I felt about that *thumbs up*. The bowl of coconut rice comes in a decent size, which is beautiful because I was in no mood to spend extra money, so my friend had enough of his rice to share hehehe. There's a smoothness to the sweetness in the coconut rice, the kind of smooth I'd expect from the lips of that anorexic girl I have a crush on (must find a way to get her boyfriend out of the picture).The last thing I want to talk about was the first thing that caught my eye: "Add any whiskey to your tea". Yeah, two of my favorite things in the world combined, something I imagine a refined caveman would enjoy drinking. I got the Ginger Darjeeling with their only choice of whiskey (I forgot); it comes in a small pot, so you don't have to worry about getting a tiny cup, and when I got it, there was a sweet musk to it. One of the better smelling liquids I've ever smelt, if you ask me. The delight ends there though, it tasted like complete ass. Complete $7 down the toilet ass. Don't get it. Make it and feed it to your children when they're misbehaving but for the love of tea and whiskey, don't pay for it.

The pedestrian plaza outside this building has always been a popular gathering spot for Harlemites.  Over the years, I can remember attending many memorable events that were celebrated on the Plaza here.  Everything from weekly summer music concerts to the annual Christmas tree lighting during the holiday season where Christmas carolers fan out along to 125th Street. There's also a weekly farmer's market on Tuesdays and Thursdays during the summer and fall that has gone on for years. And you'll without a doubt always find an impromptu circle of drummers, drumming around the base of the statue of the plaza's namesake-- the outspoken 1960's Harlem Congressman Adam Clayton Powell, Jr.There's also been many political and social events celebrated here as well, like when Nelson Mandela was first released from prison and he came here to speak, and when Barack Obama was sworn in as the 44th President. And of course, we cannot forget Bill Clinton speaking here when he decided to locate his post-presidential office only a block away after completing his Presidency.Throughout the year, you'll also find a mix of local street vendors selling their T-shirts and handcrafted wares to tourists on the sidewalk outside the Plaza.  Just sitting for a spell along the landscaped concourse is a favorite pastime for many of the shoppers and office workers that converge on the Plaza during the day. While at night it's left to couples who prefer sitting more intimately under the moonlit sky.The AC Powell Plaza is the place to go to experience the heartbeat of Harlem, and in my mind it will always be the Times Square of this community.

Roc-N-Ramen is a solid 3.8/5.0 in my books and here's why.They're as authentic a ramen shop as you'll get befitting of New Rochelle and especially the cold winter months. Their decor is different in that it strikes me as if it was a former sushi restaurant, although this in itself could be attributed to the lighting.I discovered it with a good friend earlier this week as it appeared relatively new. It'll definitely hit the spot when you're hangry for a ramen fix and can't find yourself motivated to trek into the city.As compared to my top favorites from the city, Totto, Ippudo, Misoya Ramen, and Minca, they do a good job but clearly have to work hard to come close. Upon closer inspection though, they evoke memories of Ramen Setagaya in East Village, the Japanese chain that came to the 'States offering decent ramen. It does the trick. For New Rochelle though, this should be considered quite a feat!They have some further kinks to work out in this relatively new restaurant but for your ramen needs, this ought to be your destination if you're in the area.

OPA! Why spend thousands of dollars flying over to Greece on vacation when you can get a taste of Mykonos right here in NYC?OPA! Grabs plate and smashes it on the floor.Great little spot to grab a Greek snack after a night bar hopping in the LES area. Walking in the decor is set up as a small Greek village look with white walls, blue trim, and even some hanging plants and flora. It's like eating in a faux outdoor cafe along the streets in Greece. OPA! Grabs another plate and smashes it on the floor.The food is simple, delicious, and cheap! Think hummus, lamb, fries, souvlaki, chicken, feta, and pita. On the occasions I have been here I have ordered the very tasty Souvlaki Pita stuffed with chicken, tomato, red onions, fries & tzatziki. Yes, the fries are wrapped inside with the other ingredients. Oh My!OPA! Swipes glass off the neighbor's table and smashes it on the floor.Attentive and friendly service here too that will bring over a cold Mythos beer, glass of Greek wine, or even a cocktail to go along with that souvlaki and sweet native dessert of Loukoumades. Overall, not a wallet buster as prices are very affordable for the delectable food served up. Always worth a stop if in the area and need to fill up when craving Greek delights.OPA! Flips table over and runs out as the manager is calling the cops on me.

My first time at Uva was quite the satisfying experience, and the fact we were lucky enough to score outdoor seating under our reservation was perhaps a contributing positive factor. Reservations seem practical and necessary for here, as well as a request for the outdoor seating if dining at night. We came on a Friday at 6:30PM, and while all things seemed pleasant outside, it exemplified the opposite inside, which remained very noisy and crowded as the night went on. Not too surprising though as Uva offers much to an Italian dining experience. Grab a date, a friend, or small group of friends, as the ambiance carries itself as largely intimate, romantic, and cozy. Though I'll emphasize again the outdoor space should the weather be nice. They have a small outdoor patio space at the very back which provides a pleasant atmosphere for quieter dining. We placed an order of the appetizer, Polpettine di Vitello (mini veal meatballs cooked in tomato sauce, served with Ciabatta bread) to share. For main entrees, I chose the Pappardelle Al Ragu di Vitello (pasta ribbons with ragout of veal and montasio cheese). My guest had the Cavatelli Al Pesto (pasta shells in creamy pesto with ricotta cheese). The veal meatballs, I could have passed on. Meatballs were tasty and the sauce was indeed savory though. First I'll note the portions here are generous, and my guest and I were unable to finish our own entrees. But, had there been no limitation to how much one can eat, I'd continue to indulge on Uva's offerings. Their pasta is amazing, and I can't imagine one going wrong with any of their menu choices. The quality and preparation of the pasta was excellent, in my opinion. I really enjoyed the Pappardelle. This is one of their most popular dinner choices. My guest's Cavatelli was very rich and delicious. I'd love to try the Gnocchi di Ricotta on my next visit. When it comes to Italian, Uva has a lot to offer. The food was exceptional, the atmosphere was very nice, and the service was no issue. Again, the seating indoors was very noisy, but I recommend the outdoor seating if the weather is nice. If you're venturing in the Upper East Side and looking for quality Italian dining, I highly recommend this venue.

Brew Coffeehouse is Throgs Neck's answer to Starbucks.Part caffe and sweet shop, part neighborhood hangout, Brew greets you with a lived-in feel. The space isn't furnished with fancy hipster furniture and stressed woods, but it does make you feel welcome and comfortable, like you stepped into your own living room. Want to watch some TV? Don't be surprised if you're given the remote to surf channels while you sip your latte.Atmosphere aside, there's the friendly owner and workers, the easy conversations with the local patrons...and of course, the food. The baked goods and delicious flavored coffees cap off the overall positive experience.Also, bring your laptop and stay for a while. The WiFi is free.

Came here Saturday night with the boyfriend and it was just want we wanted. We were told about a 10-15 minute wait at about 8:20 pm so we went down the block for a quick drink. About 4 minutes later my phone buzzed that our table was ready. So we finished up and went back. We were seated "outside" on the covered patio. They had heaters (and I knew we were about to eat steaming bowls of soup) so it wasn't so bad, but it was cold enough that we had to keep our jackets on the whole time. So, not ideal. To start we got the sauteed Chinese greens, which I would highly recommend, and the pork meatballs. The meatballs were good but not stellar, lightly fried and topped with bonito. For our ramen bowls, I got the Tokyo Shiyo (salty) and he got the Tokyo Shoyu (sweet). The biggest differences between the two were in the broth. The delicious rye noodles and simple green onion and pork toppings were the same. I slurped the whole thing up. All in all, it was a solid meal. The boyfriend had never had anything but instant ramen so he gave this 2 thumbs way up! The decor is super fun too.

I came for drinks on a Thursday night and enjoyed this place! It was super packed but my bf and I were able to find seats by the bar. This place is known for their beers and cocktails on tap! I ordered the Uncle Jalapeno which is like a spicy marg on tap and also the zombie drink. The zombie drink is strong and so the max limit is 2 zombies per person (it includes absinthe and 151). Also, house whiskey shots are an additional $3 add-ons with beers. The bartender was nice about allowing me to add on the $3 shot with my cocktail.

Passing by after shopping and noticed this small cozy chocolate shop.I came on the right day because they had many different truffles laid out for visitors to try.The pistachio truffle by far was my favorite. Their chocolate is very rich, but it didn't taste or feel too heavy. Great place to pick up some gifts and their prices are pretty affordable for being in the Soho area.

So it would seem that Kitty's Canteen is halfway between a private club and a regular restaurant. I randomly was asked to dinner by a couple that knows the owner, but I'm not sure how you can get a table otherwise. We went on a Wednesday at 7, and there was only like one other party there the whole time which I thought was kind of strange, but the people I was there with swear it is a big late night spot--the owner also owns that kind of intense burlesque sex show place the Box, so I'll believe it. The kitchen serves up Southern comfort food with a mild Jewish flare--all of it, from what I can tell, delicious. We got their take on biscuits, a tender, buttery biscuit/bagel hybrid coated in poppy- and sesame seeds which I believe were called biscels? A little basket was $7, with the options to add on a variety of delicious toppings each for I think $7 each? We got the works, with pastrami, smoked salmon, fried chicken, pickles, and maybe something else? They each came with delicious sauces, which I don't necessarily remember in their entirety but included mustard, horseradish cream, and honey butter. It was a huge amount of food, but great to split in a big group. Almost everyone at the table got the fried chicken, but I am nothing if not a contrarian, plus I got a little bite of it with the biscuits. From that little sample, it seemed really, really good. What I did get was the Kitty's Catch (almost everything on the menu has an awful cheesy cat-themed name), a perfectly cooked cornmeal-crusted trout over a beautiful plate of assorted summer vegetables. Highly recommended. I also tried a bit of the brisket--heavy for summer, but incredibly flavorful. We also tried their obligatory take on a kale salad, which nicely balanced healthy ingredients (quinoa) with yummy salty cheese and a delicious vinaigrette. It was good, but I'd file it under "this is not why you're here," you know? We tried some wonderfully chocolatey dessert and a less fabulous strawberry shortcake (good shortcake, but there was a weird flavor in the strawberries, like an herb or something).Cocktail were quite expensive (starting at $14), but the entrees were, I believe all under $30, which isn't so bad. The restaurant itself is also was pretty great. It's very speakeasy-ish, romantically lit with gorgeous, thousand-dollar-per-yard gold and black wallpaper that artist Molly Crabapple has defaced with drawings of anthopomorphic cats. It's tiny, with brick archways, dim lighting, and a tiny little beautifully-decorated bathroom featuring plenty more of Crabapple's cats. The one downside is that the small space is somewhat awkward, especially in the front alcove where we sat, where the tables seemed quite crammed in.Like I said, I'm not sure if you can actually eat here, but if you get the chance you should definitely go for it.

Indulging in "research" at the newly opened Aldo Sohm Wine Bar proved to be dangerous last night... but as always, risks come with their own delicious rewards.After hearing that the executive sommelier from Le Bernardin started his own wine bar nearby, I knew I had to experience it before it became overrun with the entire population of post-work Midtown. We arrived around 5:30pm on a Wednesday and the scene was already bustling. Luckily we were able to grab 2 spots on the central couch which gives you a perfect view of who is coming in while your back is being supported by gigantic pillows. Win-win sitch.The interior design makes me think if the MOMA had a secret wine bar hidden within its walls, this is definitely what it would look like. Framed prints of artwork are all around as well as an eclectic assortment of objects like a violin and a globe. Might have been a statue of a chicken thrown in... but perhaps that was the third glass of Greek white wine talking.The menu is basically all small plates, charcuterie and cheese which is to be nibbled on and shared. I would not suggest bringing a big group here and having a main meal here because 1. that ish will set you back if you're trying to get fully satisfied and 2. there isn't that much space for parties of more than 4 people. This is more of an intimate setting that I think is the step before going to the place you will end up at for the rest of your evening while out.My PIC (or "partner in crime" as you will) for the evening and I took no mercy on the menu. We knew we wanted to try a bunch of things but to not commit ourselves to total foodie suicide being a worknight and all. To start, we tried to order The Tower (a serving of ALL of their charcuterie offerings, $45) but were advised against it as it might be too much meat for us to handle. Clearly the man doesn't understand who he is dealing with! We then went with his suggestion of his four favorite meats which were: Cacciatorini Sausage, Austrian Style Poached Ham, Ariane Duck Rilettes and Fireplace Smoked Pork Loin. With charcuterie I must have cheese so we also ordered the Murray's "Cheese of the Moment" platter. That came with four cheeses: a goat cheese, a blue cheese, something reminiscent of cheddar and who the hell knows what the fourth one was! Gouda?? I'm losing track of everything! Oh and we also HAD to have the Foie Gras Lollipops... I mean, we'd be absolutely crazy not to.The verdict? I loved EVERYTHING. The meat, the cheese and especially those foie gras lollipops. The foie gras was perfectly cooked and did not have that overwhelming liver taste that foie gras can sometimes have. All the rich flavors came into perfect harmony and just melted in my mouth! At $15 for one, it is pricy but trust me- you will not share it so get your own.The charcuterie + cheese + foie gras were delicious but were we full yet? Nahhhhhhh. Since there was a 1/4 inch spot of room left in our bellies we decided to also order the Truffle Pasta (with grated yak cheese) and the Short Rib Skewer (with fried shallot, red wine reduction)... Yeah I know what you must be thinking. What a bunch of fat asses! Well, so what! That Truffle Pasta is worth getting fat over... I could eat a few more bowls of that anytime, anywhere. If the sound of buttery, truffle pasta covered with freshly grated yak cheese doesn't get your saliva flowing then you must be dead! The Short Rib Skewer was just as yummy with tender, juicy meat that needed no knife to cut it.Yup, I am a fan... and come winter, I can see myself shacking up in here quite often to keep myself warm and cozy from the unwelcome cold. There's good food, excellent wine choices and lots of eye candy to boot. Move over Aldo, you have a permanent after-work tenant!Oh and speaking of Aldo, we spotted Mr. Sohm himself going around the room talking with patrons and shaking hands. We asked our waiter if he could stop by our table so we could say hello, thank you and congratulate him opening such a lovely little spot. He unfortunately was not able to but fingers crossed for next time! Till then, run run on over here while you still can.

My friend and I sat outside and enjoyed a fabulous weekday brunch. I had been wanting to try this for a long time, and it didn't disappoint.Pros:+ Perfect mix of traditional American brunch dishes and Mediterranean items+ Falafel is delightful+ Outdoor seating+ Hash browns are deeeeelishCons:- Everything was great, yet missing some sort of "wow factor."I'd come again!

I was walking to my favorite restaurant of all time and needed a manicure. My talons were unruly. I Yelped, of course, and there were a few in the area, but this one had high marks and an ample number of reviews. I walked on over. I got there and every single seat was full and there were about three people waiting. I'm fairly impatient and had to get in and out to make my dinner reservation, so I assumed I wouldn't be able to stay and wait. A friendly guy came over asking what services I wanted. I told him just a manicure and asked how long the wait was. "7-10 minutes!" he cheerily exclaimed. I figured I was already right near the restaurant, and if the wait time was truly as short as he said, I could stay. I find that many, many times when a nail salon tells you 10 minutes or 5 minutes, they are LIARS. At Pink Blossom, they were not. Literally 5 minutes later I was whisked off to a chair and my manicure was started. It was quick, the space was clean, decent color selection, and the pricing was fair. I will say they could have done a better job on my cuticles, but other than that, no complaints. I knew they weren't being thorough on my cuticles when I was sitting there, but had to get to dinner so I just sort of let it go.While I sat there, more and more women came in. The man who greeted me did a great job or organizing everyone and getting people seen right away. Of note: Tips only in cash. Credit cards accepted otherwise. All tools come out of brand new packaging. No massages while you dry. I'll come back because the location works for me, and the manicure still looks good this morning.

We came here on Sunday to grab some sushi. I have passed this place many times while visiting Chelsea Market and I have wanted to try this place for a while. This is a vegan sushi place and they can accommodate if you are gluten free. I got the spicy shroom rice paper roll. It comes with buckwheat noodles, cashews, and different types of mushrooms (enoki, shiitake and portobello). For the sauce, they give this spicy mayo and also gluten free soy sauce. It was absolutely great and reasonably priced. The portion size is really good for 1 person and it's really fresh and crunchy. A great dish on a warm summer day. The crunchiness of the lettuce and cashews goes really well with the different types cooked mushrooms. And the spicy mayo that it comes with gives it a really nice rich flavor. I would definitely recommend this place and I'm excited to return and try other options at this place!

This was my first (and so far only) taste of Ethiopian, and I'm happy to say, it's been love since first bite.I strongly recommend the honey wine. I'm not a sweet wine fan and I LOVE honey wine. It's sweet and tangy, and pairs really well with the food.I've had both meat and vegetarian options, and to be honest, I really couldn't tell you the difference. I'm a regular meat eater, but I normally go with the veggie options.For appetizers, I love the sambousas. It's two per order, so get more than one plate if you have three or more people with you.The main entree plates are delicious. My personal favorite vegetarian options are: misir wot, shimbra asa, and butecha. By the way, just learned those names while writing this review, and I will likely forget the names next time I go. The good news, the servers are used to the butchering of Ethiopian and are able to follow my gestures to my favorite dishes.First time Ethopian food eaters: be warned, you will try the injera and want to keep on eating it out of the habit of eating bread absent-mindedly. DON'T. This stuff expands in your stomach like a puffer fish being threaten by a killer whale. If you eat too much, you will feel nauseous later and want to give up eating forever. For the sake of your stomach, eat sparingly with your plate.

My mom use to warn me if I drank too much soy milk I would grow Titties...due to the high estrogen content...but I still have not grown any...So I guess it is okay to keep drinking...To describe how much I LOVE soy milk...I can finish 3 Gallons in 2 days...When I found out about this store I was ecstatic...a store in China Town devoted to homemade soy products! Don't be fooled by the by the exterior tho...the soy milk and soy desserts are delicious, fresh, and cheap!This is what I usually get below:1. Tofu fa (Dowfuha) - Pardon my Chinese...it ain't good - About $1 2. Chinese Soy Milk - Dou Jiang - Sweet, but not enough to get you diabetes - About $1Please also note that the guy who runs the store doesn't speak English very well. I speak Mandarin, but I believe he speaks Cantonese. As a result I had to have a fellow customer translate for me. If there is no translator available I suggest you just point to what you want.

Well, I'm always complaining about the lack of quality brunches on the Upper West Side and Cafe Luxembourg has certainly shut me up. Literally, because the food is so good and it makes me just want to eat in silence.So let's get to the most important offerings at Cafe Luxembourg. Their brunch items are simply top notch. Among the items I have tried.. I find it hard to rank -- it really depends on what floats your boat, I guess. The huevos rancheros is served with flavourful black beans, beautifully poached eggs and 2 yummy salsas. I still did ask for tabasco though - pardon me. The french toast is incredible - moist brioche that melts in your mouth, with a tangy melange of berries, and this amazing fromage blanc stuffed in it. It's fantastic. Also fantastic, albeit less indulgent, is the vegetable hash with eggs and sriracha dressing. It's not spicy, but it's a flavour bomb. I suspect these folks use some high quality ingredients. I have also eaten here with carnivores and both the lobster roll and the smoked salmon dishes were greatly appreciated. They have a pretty delicious prosecco, but the sparkling rose is a bit underwhelming. Of course you could be boring and order the orange juice or the chamomile tea. :)They are incredibly welcoming of children, and let me back in although my toddler broke a plate the first time that we ate here. Lastly, they offer these creamy dark chocolates with your check, and I'm hoping that I can buy these by the dozen.The place has this whole Parisian cafe feel to it, which is lovely when you're stuck in Manhattan in the summer with no time for a vacation. While the space can feel a bit cramped at times, the service is incredibly warm and friendly, and the food is delicious. What's not to like?

I have a good time every time I go to Red Rooster. I've been going off and on since they opened 4 years ago. I usually take someone that's visiting Harlem for the first time and we have a blast listening to the live music, meeting new people at the community tables, dancing downstairs before it became Ginny's and even meeting Marcus in person. The food is pretty amazing with great influences from many countries. Never had a meal here that I didn't like. And the atmosphere is A+.Unfortunately, though, sometimes the music is blaring and I have to move to outside seating to enjoy myself. Another con is that some of the items are pricey - $30 for a small bowl of Shrimp and Grits (4 peices of shrimp) - is something a friend ordered and shared. I have to say it was possibly the creamiest bowl of grits I've tasted in my life, but $30 is more than price gauging in my opinion. I would say this is one of those dishes that possibly only tourist consider buying. Being that I can make this at home for $5 makes this price laughable.

I really like this bar and have been here numerous times. The only negative are the guys who do security at the door. They are always very strict/rough with everyone, so it's very uncalled for.The dress code is strict, so don't come in full on "street clothes". After you do get through the door, you go through a curtain and enter the main seating area. On the slower nights you can just sit at any of the tables and a server will take care of you. However, on the busier nights it is very rare that you'll even get a table as they'll probably be reserved anyways. I prefer sitting at the table and getting a server, however if that is not the case, you must go to the bar for a drink.The drinks here are really great and the bartenders really pay attention to detail. The drinks take a little time to make, but it is totally worth it, so don't come here trying to get a red bull vodka.On a couple of the slower nights I came they had a jazz band playing, which was pretty awesome. On the busier nights they were playing current and old school hip-hop and pop.

Come here to binge on eating and people watching! It was that rare sunny-beautiful-perfect day in New York City, and lines stretched long on the first open day of the spring (May 4). I was walking to meet my friend for lunch at Schnipper's, when she texted me and said that Madison Sq. Eats was opening that day. I did a quick google search on the offerings, and said hell yes!Hungry hoards of food hunters grumbled at the long lines on that sunny day, but in the end everyone was having a merry time. Come on, that's why you go to these things- you can find most of these places at their brick-and-mortar locations, but honestly we masochistically love the feeling of waiting in line and feeling like we accomplished something when we FINALLY order! Ok, well, the wide selection all in one place is fun too. Most of the offerings are not cheap, but pretty interesting. It was a tough decision- you could definitely spend a lot of time deciding, or a lot of money trying everything. Go with a group so you can sneak tastes of their food too!I would have loved to try Pig + Khao's adobo, La Sonrisa Empanadas, Arancini Bros rice balls (please serve some vegan ones next time!), and Bar Suzette's crepes. We ended up selecting Seoul Lee's bulgogi bibimbap and Takumi Taco's lunch box (2 tacos and a side). The bulgogi bibimbap definitely hit the spot. The meat was tender, moist, and very well marinated. Perfect bulgogi consistency! Paired with the spicy mayo and veggies and mixed with the rice- I was scraping the bowl clean!Takumi Taco's short rib taco was meh, and the spicy tuna taco could have had more kick to it. The spicy tuna's delicate flavor was good though. Skip the rice and beans side, it was too bland and we added it to our bulgogi bowl to soak up the goodness. I definitely thought the $12 price tag was steep for this. I was so happy basking in the warmth around my favorite things, food and people.

The first move is to put a clamp on the nippleThe next is to gently cradle its bottomBring it so close to your face that you can feel the heat of its meatTenderly, teasinglyNibble on its supple, nubile skinOne small bite releasesa rush of fragrant aromasForm a flower with your lips, andsuck out the savory dew from withinGo ahead, pour a few drops of special saucedown your delicate bao holeAnd in one fell swoop, like the animal that you areShove the whole blessed thing into your gaping, waiting, greedy, bottomless mawAnd masticate, oh MASTICATE like you've never masticated before!IS THERE ANYTHING MORE INTIMATE THAN EATING XIAO LONG BAO?!?!?!?!When it is over, swallowwipe yourselfand say, "Wow mom, that was delicious. Let's order another basket!"

I normally wouldn't pivot an entire review around a comparison to another restaurant, but when you decide to start up a new Cajun seafood boil a few blocks away from The Boil, you do naturally lend yourself to that comparison. So the question really is: how does Claw Daddy's compare to The Boil? And the answer is: it's complicated. But that's only so because both are terrific in their own way. So, to summarize, here's a point-by-point breakdown of the two excellent establishments. And now, let the fight begin...Wait time: At The Boil, expect to wait up to two hours for a table on a Friday or Saturday during peak dinner hours. And while it's worth the wait, Claw Daddy's actually takes reservations so there's no need to hang around the bar for hours on end (though I suppose you may still want to do that). Winner: Claw Daddy'sPayment: The Boil is cash only while Claw Daddy's accepts credit cards. That should be simple enough. Winner: Claw Daddy'sDecor: Claw Daddy's space is much bigger and more open which is nicer and less repellent to the mildly claustrophobic than The Boil's much smaller room. Claw Daddy's also has televisions, which normally wouldn't be a draw, but there happened to be a football game I wanted to catch that night so that was a big win. Winner: Claw Daddy'sMenu: The menus at the two restaurants are nearly identical. In fact, Claw Daddy's has the exact same combination specials that The Boil has at the same prices, plus a couple more for good measure. And while I haven't sampled from the raw bar of either, Claw Daddy's has a wider selection of options. Winner: Claw Daddy'sSpiciness: My philosophy is the spicier, the better. The Boil's hottest spice level, Fire, is pretty impressive, but Claw Daddy's Insane spice level, which uses Trinidad Moruga Scorpion peppers, has the slight edge. Winner: Claw Daddy'sSauce: Of all the considerations listed here, the sauce might just be the most important since it has a huge impact on how good the meal as a whole tastes as well. Claw Daddy's sauce is very tasty but it's lighter and thinner than The Boil's rich, creamy broth. The Boil's sauce somehow seems to absorb the flavor of seafood much better as well. Winner: The BoilPotato: Unfortunately, the potato at Claw Daddy's seemed like it wasn't cooked all the way through. A little to hard and dry for my taste, especially compared to The Boil, where the potatoes truly add something to the meal. Winner: The BoilService: At The Boil, the servers help sauce-proof you by helping tie a lobster bib around your neck. No such pampering at Claw Daddy's where you're left to figure out how to tie it yourself. All in all, while not bad, the service at The Boil has an edge. Winner: The BoilIt's hard to pick a clear winner between the two, and I'm going to save myself the trouble of doing that. There are some aspects of Claw Daddy's make it a better experience than The Boil while there are others which aren't quite up to par. Really, you can't go wrong with either and it might just come down to what you're looking for.

Sylvia's is a well established southern style soul-food joint in Harlem on Lenox Ave and 127th. It is privately owned and operated, but has been here so long there are nationally distributed cookbooks, sauces and other branded goodies you can get all over.We opted to sit outside on the nice summer day and were promptly seated and given a basket of warm, freshly-cooked cornbread -- so delicious!It was tough to decide, but we ordered the Chicken & Waffles platter and the Ribs & Chicken platter, both of which came with a complimentary drink (including a few alcoholic selections). We ordered the tastier dark meat for both of the chicken orders, and got Collard Greens and Baked Mac & Cheese for the complimentary sides.The waffle was light and fluffy on the inside, but browned properly on the outside. The chicken thigh was moist and tender, but crispy and well fried on the outside. Not too much fried batter, but not too little either. The fried batter was not too greasy, but full of flavor.There was nothing wrong with the ribs per-se, but they weren't spectacular. The sauce that was on them was great -- sweet and tangy, with a little kick -- but the ribs were not as tender as I would have liked them to be. I had to work a little to clean the bones. Collard greens were excellent, but the Mac and Cheese was average.If ribs are what you are after, you would probably be best to go to a dedicated Ribs joint, but the Fried Chicken was outstanding here, and the value is very good with all the complimentary offerings on the low-priced combos.

An alternate name of this restaurant could be "Clams on Clams on Clams," although there were a few other options on the menu that featured other seafood as well as chicken and a strip loin. I would highly recommend sticking with their clam dishes as they were the highlight of the night!We made a reservation for 4 people a couple of weeks in advance. Our reservation was at 6 pm and soon after 6 pm, the restaurant was packed with a more sophisticated crowd of West Village natives and a few yuppie couples. The space feels airy and clean. The ceiling is bedazzled with hundreds of pearlescent square tiles and exposed brick added a nice homey touch. Our waitress was very knowledgeable about the menu and didn't rush us when making our decisions. We decided to start with the Campechana Coctel de Camaron. This appetizer is a good choice for groups. The dip consisted of hearty chunks of clam, marinara sauce, lime, and avocados - delicious! I highly recommend it!For our entrees, we ordered the Spaghetti & Clams, Clam Fried Rice, and the Block Island Swordfish with a side of Asparagus. The Spaghetti & Clams was delicious and the presentation was nice - 5 clams around a heaping pile of spaghetti in clam spicy gravy with a leafy bunch of arugula atop the pasta. The spicy gravy was not as spicy, but more salty than I had expected. I appreciated how Chef Price was not stingy at all about the clam in the pasta. I'd even go out on a limb to say it was 60% pasta, 40% clam in spicy gravy.The Clam Fried Rice was my favorite and also less salty than my Spaghetti & Clams dish. There was a medley of pork belly confit, snow peas, and pickled onion that really brought a lot of flavor to the dish without being overwhelmingly salty.Chef Mike Price must be a fan of the miniature croutons as they appeared in the swordfish dish as well as the side of asparagus. The Black Island Swordfish had great presentation, but the dish itself wasn't too amazing in my opinion. Then again, I'm not a huge fan of fish entrees in general. The Grilled Asparagus was pretty delicious. The presentation was nice and the croutons really worked in this dish to add texture. By the end of our meal, we were stuffed and decided to hold back on the dessert, but I'm sure I'll be back in the future for more bivalves and hopefully, this time I'll save room for dessert!

I don't know if it is a tomato tapenade, or some unholy alliance of peppers, olive oil and tomatoes with a different name, but call the SWAT team because that sauce they serve with the bread is the bomb!That's my main takeaway from a delightful dinner at Bella Blu. My old-fashioned was definitely fresh and the mixed sea creature and veggie stir fry appetizer was awesome.  I had a terrific pizza from their oven (although that thing is H-O-T so if you're sitting near it, wear something cool).Desserts were tasty, service was friendly. It's a bit cramped and tables are on top of one another but it's all good. I'd go back here in New York minute! Hell, I'd go back here in a Philadelphia minute and you know how I feel about Philly.

Evelyn had 5 stars before I even had a drink. Any place that has cocktails named after the short stories of my life (Man Down. Beautiful Savage. Mo F'ing Way. Bitter Change. (IT'S POETRY!!!! I even saved my receipt when I got home just because it was so Maya Angelou. Actually no, Bukowski!) - gets full accolades right off the bat. Plus the bartender was cute. The cocktails themselves were splendid, my absolute favorite being the El Topo. I had two of those, my friend had 3. And between us both we tried 4 other varieties. All of them were tasty and - given the prices of cocktails in the now ubiquitous "cocktail bar" elsewhere - not too expensive. For everyone's reference- there is an additional bathroom hidden on the side, as opposed to the obvious two options which are front and center in the main bar area's back wall. Minus a star: Not too crazy about the music in the background. Definite room for improvement on that.

Amali came up in a search for a brunch spot in Manhattan this past weekend. Its name comes from the term used for lands once shared by the places we know today as Greece, Italy and Turkey. This restaurant emphasizes sustainable ingredients with a Mediterranean style of food, both very appealing in today's culinary world.Right from the outside seating area, Amali gives a very comforting feel. Inside, the atmosphere is very much like another world. A combination of a long bar, some paintings on the wall and an an area in the back with natural sunlight flooding in from above makes this a comfortable and lovely place to eat. My girlfriend and I chose to sit in the back area, wanting to enjoy the lighting.Service was very prompt. I had just come from a workout so I was drinking water like a camel and the server who kept refilling my water was very gracious about it. Our waiter was a very nice, funny and soft spoken gent who was efficient to boot. Oddly, he did not recognize what a "Yelp Check-In Offer" was (for the record, there is a 10% off lunch or brunch Yelp check-in offer) so this particular meal didn't get the 10% off. I just saved it for later and figured next time I'll mention it before I'm seated. Really, it wasn't a huge deal to me.So here's what we enjoyed during our visit:BUTTERMILK BISCUITSServed with jam and honey butter. These are not the gigantic, fluffy biscuits you may think of when you think of places like KFC. Instead, these were relatively thin and almost cookie like, but they were absolutely buttery and delicious. They had a crisp crunch on the outside but a nice soft interior. With the honey butter and jam they were utterly delightful.SPANISH OCTOPUSWith castelveltrano olives, yukon potatoes, wild oregano. This dish was amazing. The octopus was cooked perfectly. The oregano and olive oil drizzled over it gave it a wonderful flavor. I'd order this again in a heartbeat.SHRIMP & GRITSFeaturing three tiger prawns served on top of polenta. The shrimp were beautifully cooked and still in the shell. If you enjoy crunching down and drinking the juices of shrimp, you'll love this. The shrimp meat was nicely cooked, not overdone at all and the juices from the shrimp added to the flavor of the polenta. The polenta was very creamy and tasted great. POACHED EGGSServed with sautéed escarole, pecorino on top and grilled ciabatta. This was probably my least favorite dish, but not because anything was wrong with it. I'm just not a huge escarole fan. However, my girlfriend is and she enjoyed it a lot. The eggs were poached perfectly and the runny yolk was perfect on the ciabatta. I thoroughly enjoyed my experience and Amali, and even with the hiccup regarding the Yelp Check-In offer I'm giving it high marks for a wonderful atmosphere, great staff and wonderful food.

"Do you like to.. do it yourself?" Okay pardon my 40-year old virgin reference. But when it comes to serving myself frozen yogurt, I do like to do it myself. This chain recently opened up on Bleecker, a 3-minute walk from my apartment. Very friendly staff inside, greeted immediately upon walking in. I sampled a flavor or two, then tried my luck with the cookies and cream + chocolate flavors. I added blueberries, strawberries and kiwis like the wannabe health nut that I am. The end result was tasty, although I wouldn't say much better than most of the other fro-yo chain's i've tried in NYC. Still, great customer service, many flavors and the location will keep me coming back!

Luckily this was a business dinner so I didn't mind the $750 ($110 for the wine) for four tab sans tip. The waiter kept telling us with a smile "I'm going to do for you..." but never mentioned financial sodomy in his repertoire . Ordinarily price isn't an issue but the steak for two was obnoxiously priced. Moreover, the waiter showed us what he said was a dry-aged, well marbled, USDA prime grade, Porterhouse steak for two. I couldn't tell whether is was dry aged but the marbling of the steak revealed that is was USDA choice and not prime (or the lowest grade of prime - there are three grades but nobody ever mentions this).The waiter somehow forgot to mention that the steak was $180! This is the most I ever paid for a choice steak for two in Manhattan. Hell this is the most I've ever paid for a 'prime' steak for two! It tasted good but...The super-hot Venezuelan hostess aside, the food was interesting and surprisingly good. I can't recall what else we ordered but we managed to finish whatever came to our table--whether it was ours to not. Very lively old-school atmosphere, great food overall and the well informed wait staff made the visit to Carbone pleasant despite the lingering financial pain in the tuchus.

We were invited to try out the club and while we are considering joining, this review is just for the food we've had for dinner. We started off with a strawberry gazpacho with shrimps and avocado. This first course was amazing! It was very refreshing, very tasty and flavorful and the plate looked gorgeous! It came with 3 shrimps, which I find to be a fair serving for the given plate, they were very fresh, clearly cooked on the premises and never frozen. I loved it. The creaminess, the richness, and still very subtle! I couldn't taste any strawberries in it tho, I didn't mind, the soup was amazing. For the second course, I had the halibut with broccoli and asparagus and my husband had the chicken with some sort of puree and vegetables. Both plates were very delicious, but oh SO SMALL. Seriously, the portions were ridiculously small, ridiculous, almost a joke small. That said, my 2 inch square of fish was amazing, perfectly cooked, gently seasoned, the 4 asparagus heads I was given were perfectly grilled, and the two baby broccoli florets kept the crunch I love so much. My husband's plate had a similar plot: amazing 2 inch square of chicken, fantastic tablespoon of puree and delicate mouthful of veggies. Finally, the dessert! It's called the trio of desserts, we had a sliver of tiramisu, a spoonful of creme brulee, one strawberry and one blackberry. Each dessert was very delicious and delicate, the strawberry was perfectly cut in the middle and one knows that takes a special hand. All that said, the food was amazing, but it felt more like a sampler meal that an actual meal. Maybe we are used to having huge plates, but I have a solid appetite and these were no decent sizes at all, so it doesn't matter if members get to eat for free with their guests, if they have to go back out and get a slice of pizza or froyo afterwards, it's not too cool either. We went out afterwards and got froyo... So I will love to go back, maybe even be a member but take this meal as a light meal or big snack. It isn't filling in size, but I guess if you are taking your time and just enjoying, it's cool, but if you rely on this as a real dinner, make sure you have your fill from a late lunch.

Root and Bone - the name of the restaurant alludes to fresh produce and meat and that's exactly what is offered in their dishes. Add in a dash of creativity, lovely Southern charm, and the work of two former Top Chef contestants, and you have yourself quite a winning restaurant.The interior looks a bit like an open cottage with muted grays and browns; splashes of color can be found in the hanging terrariums, tiny flowers on the wall, mismatched plates at each table, and in the food itself. The larger room even has a large china cabinet and it's exactly that cozy, open feel that really brings out the restaurant's farm-to-table quality.The fried chicken n' waffle sandwich (named "Avenue A" on the lunch menu) was really quite divine. Two small round sandwiches came per order, and the buns were replaced with soft cheddar waffles. I was expecting a bit of a crisp edge to the waffles, but they were instead soft; they surprisingly held the large chunks of fried chicken well. The chicken pieces were prepared in a maple whiskey brine and were SO juicy. The bright pickled green tomato slices and bits of watercress were nice accents and balanced out the sandwiches, preventing them from becoming overbearingly sweet and heavy.The jazzed (tarred??...the menu's font was hard to read) feathered fried chicken sandwich (named "Avenue B" on the lunch menu) had the same juicy fried chicken, but it was spiked with Tabasco for a real kick. The sandwich also came with bacon, lettuce, tomato, pickles, and potato rolls, but the greatest part was the buttermilk ranch sauce. Or so I'm told. J liked this sandwich so much that he devoured it before I could steal a bite. We also ordered a side of Grandma Daisy's Angel Biscuits (gosh, look at that name!) which were served with honey butter and peach preserves. Three squarish biscuits came per order. The spreads were good, but the biscuits themselves were a bit dry. This was the only negative note from the meal. Root and Bone also offers twelve different cocktails and a wine list that leans toward American and Australian wines. If all of the cocktails sound great, it's most likely because they are. If you have difficulty picking, try the Filthy Manahttan! The ratio of whiskey, port, and bitters was fantastic. The amarena cherries left at the bottom of the glass were so boozily decadent. Likelihood of another visit:There are so many other menu items I'd love to try: peach caprese, the "BLT that will tickle you pickle", the short rib meatloaf, and the waffle benedict to name a few. There is an adjacent market, the Little Root Market, that sells its buckets of fried chicken and sandwiches to go and I think it's a convenient stop for a quick lunch if you're in Alphabet City.

If I had never read about this spot on Yelp, the I would have never had gone to Sake Bar Decibel. Tucked away inconspicuously in the East Village, there is barely a sign. To compound the inconspicuousness of this place, it's underground, making your search for this spot a tad more difficult. Nonetheless, the times that I've been here, I've had an incredibly chill time drinking and hanging out with friends. Sake Bar Decibel isn't what I'd call a "nice" bar. It's kind of grungy, but at the same time it's not Continental-level grungy. When you walk downstairs and enter this underground sake bar, you're instantly transformed into a scene straight out of old school Japan. With the paper lanterns hanging from the ceiling, compounded with the dim lighting and compact seating gives this place a somewhat intimate feel. The times that I've come here, it wasn't overly packed, so we were able to get seated at a table seamlessly, as well as the ability to talk to each other without yelling across the table. As far as their drink menu goes, you can accurately assume that they have a pretty extensive sake list. I went with my usual Otokoyama which is a Daiginjo. Price-wise, it's not incredibly cheap, but the sake isn't over priced either. Whether or not you order a bottle for the table, or just a carafe for yourself, you're not rushed at all because there's no one standing behind you hovering and hoping that you'll get up and leave the bar. Aside from drinks, they also do serve some food here. Our table ended up ordering some tofu dish that I cant remember the name of, but it was pretty damn good. All in all, Sake Bar Decibel is a great escape from the madness of the East Village. You can actually sit down, relax, and hang out with your friends while enjoying some sake. The decor and atmosphere help compound that laid back feel, while at the same time, transforming you as best as it can, to Japan.

They say it's fusion and to me it's confusion... It took me a while to figure out the French portion out of it - The food at this place is 100% Thai; and the way how they present it is French. I mean, to put small portion of food in the middle of a big plate and place the sauce on it as finishing an abstract paint...that's it! Anyway, I gave it a four star because of the magnificent flavors of wild mushroom dumplings, curry chicken appetizer and the curry duck as entry. You will have great chances to savor your dishes to the fullest, because the restaurant has fewer lighting and is very dark...

For all the suit hunters in New York, this secluded lounge is your game reserve... and boy oh boy, there's big game aplenty.Located within a commonly overlooked nook of Grand Central Terminal, The Campbell Apartment serves as a lively yet classy watering hole for the 20 something to 30 something crowd looking for more than the standard cranberry vodka. Although strong shadows persist throughout, this bar is a place to see and be seen while having that $16 cocktail after a hard day's work. Yes it's pricey but you're paying for the ambiance, the crowd and for the remnants of an extravagant era long since passed. This 13th century Florentine style inspired space used to serve as the private salon and office of 20's mogul John W. Campbell starting in 1923. I imagine the roaring spectacle could have been comparable to the barber shop scene from The Great Gatsby, dancing girls and all. After its 1.5 million dollar restoration in 1999 to bring it back to its former glory, this establishment has since lived up to its reputation with its telling tagline "Cocktails from another era."While the drinks do rack up quite a hefty bill if you're having more than 1, they do pack a solid punch on your liver. The Prohibition Punch alone will set you back $19 and about 1,900 brain cells. That's the ratio nowadays for price to brain cells killed for a libation just in case you wanted to know. The menu boasts an array of cocktails that should suit every palate but from one alcoholic to another, I believe bourbon is the king of poisons.Besides its history and delicious alcoholic concoctions, The Campbell Apartment is impressive in many ways. Once you are allowed by the army of friendly hostesses to step inside the cavernous room, please take a moment to feed your eyes with the architectural beauty in front of you. First look up... then down... then side to side if visibility permits. Hopefully you will have noticed: the beautiful high-beamed ceilings overhead, the stained glass window residing over the bar, the luxurious carpet beneath your feet, the intrinsically carved woodwork throughout and the enormous stone fireplace to keep everyone toasty 3/4 of the year. Oh and don't forget the original quatrefoil mahogany balcony above you where prey I mean GUYS watch the crowd from ... Yup, they're up there. Watching you. Totally unaware of what's going to happen. *waves to unsuspecting victims*All jokes aside, this is obviously one of the classier joints you will encounter for the after-work drink crowd where real adults convene. If you're lucky enough to stop by later in the evening once the train commuters have left, by all means go right ahead. You'll still have a pretty satisfying collection of mixology enthusiasts plus more elbow room to work your magic. Dress code is strictly enforced which keeps out the accidental tourist, the Air Jordans and the people who wear shorts religiously... or even worse, baseball caps. Seriously Red Sox and Yankees fans, I'm calling you out specifically- we get it. You're obsessed and we're not judging you (as much as we could) but please leave your caps in your closet before you even think about stepping foot into this lounge. This dress code ensures a decently dressed crowd for those of us who love a well tailored suit on a fine looking specimen. So the big question is, will you end up with a trophy at the end of your speakeasy safari? It's hard to say... but if you have a cocktail in hand, exude confidence and throw in an "elephant gun" (such as that sexy LBD you've been dying to wear) for good measure, your expedition should prove victorious.Good hunting ladies.

THE DIM SUM COMMANDMENTS1. Get thy butt out of bed and arriveth well before noon. Unless you like standing for two hours in a tiny shopping mall lobby underneath a precariously hanging gaudy chandelier with 500 other people.2. Pace thyself.Especially if you've been waiting for hours to eat, you are no doubt, starving. Do not grab a bunch of garbage off of a cart simply because you're hungry. Wait for the good stuff: Pork buns. Pineapple buns. Shumai. Roast duck. Those peanut things. The worst possible situation is to eat a bunch of rando items you didn't even really want, and then when the thing you were really craving passes by on a cart, you're too full to eat it. Dim sum tragedy, son. That's a damn shame.3. Thou shalt not be lame.There's going to be a bunch of stuff floating around you've never seen before. Everything is under $10. Don't be afraid to try things. If it's gross, it's not the end of the world. Don't be afraid to talk to the ladies. They're mostly nice and will help explain what stuff is (except when they lie - see below). Be adventurous. Man (or woman) up. It's part of the fun of dim sum.4. Beware the Ides of Meat (and Shellfish).I've been here with people who both are vegetarians and are allergic to shrimp and other various shellfish. In one occasion, we asked the lovely cart lady if there was any shrimp in the dumplings in her cart, and they said no. Lo and behold, we took a nice big bite of our dumplings and there were tons of baby shrimp in thurr. Not sure what would motivate a lady to lie like that-- maybe they didn't understand the question or maybe they secretly work on commission and get paid by the dim sum.5. Coca Cola shall quench thee.I don't know why, but dim sum and Coke is magical. Do it.

You go up to the counterSay "one slice" Throw a dollar at themThey throw you a slice on a flimsy paper plateYou walk out the door and down BroadwayFold the slice in half and shove it in your faceThrow that greasy paper plate in a proper garbage receptacle#endscene

A longtime Philly staple, El Vez is finally in NYC!Just down the street from Goldman, the crowd is very button-down and grey slacks heavy. There's also a stroller parking area, which scared the hell out of me, but I guess that's what you get in TriBeCa. After work, the bar is absolutely packed - not easy to snag a seat if you're just popping in sans-reservations. The space is really big - There's outdoor seating as well, and the street it's positioned on (Vesey) is relatively quiet in terms of traffic.The decor is cool - I particularly enjoyed a quartet of bedazzled skulls positioned above our round table. We had a reservation, and they seated us pretty quickly after everyone arrived.As far as drinks go, Margaritas are the obvious choice. If you're into frozen vs on the rocks, be sure to ask first, as some are served frozen without it being explicitly pointed out in the menu (the blood orange one, for example.) I wanted to try more than one kind, however, the red bell pepper spicy margarita was so fantastic, I had to stick with it for 2 drinks. I also tried the cucumber one - but gotta stick with red bell pepper. It's made with mescal, so definitely has a smoky kick to it - but it isn't overwhelmingly spicy and tastes like fresh vegetables.Everyone was raving over the nachos on 4sq, so had to give that a shot, as well as the bazooka limon guacamole. The guacamole is served with goat cheese and pistachio - could have gone without the goat cheese, but the pistachios definitely were a nice touch. Might add that to guac I make at home... And the nachos did live up to the hype. They're served in a pizza dish, so each chip has at least 90% coverage of chesse, beans, jalapeños, etc. Our group shared tacos / quesadillas after that, and the standout was 100% the mahi mahi tacos. (Also tried the zucchini blossom quesadilla - fine, but could've probably made it myself - and the grilled fish tacos, which were very good.) The Mahi Mahi is fried fish with spicy chipotle and vegetables, but in a rolled soft tortilla served almost like an enchilada, sans-sauce. They're easy to slice up and share, and SO GOOD. Service was on top of it - the tacos did take a while to arrive, but we were having a good time and already had our nachos & guac. Definitely an easy, solid choice for a more casual business dinner or a bday celebration.

After the New York winter, my skin felt like it was left in shambles for the spring, as even after living in NYC for 2 years I still haven't quite figured out the ideal skincare routine for the ever-changing weather.Then, Buttercup skin care to the rescue! I made an appointment online (3 weeks in advance - bookings run out quickly!). The office is small but cozily decorated, and there are magazine and Fiji water for those waiting for their appointments.I had the hydrating facial with Jasmine, and enjoyed every minute of it. All the products used smelled heavenly without being overbearing. The extraction process was done by hand & tissues (vs tools - bonus points on being hygienic) and was definitely gentle. My face definitely needed the extra hydration, and looked luminous afterwards without the angry red spots typically associated with status post facials. In fact, I rushed to a class right after and my classmates complimented my skin without knowing I just had a facial.At the end, Jasmine gave me a full assessment of my skin as well as what I should add/subtract from my regimen. I asked Jasmine for recommendations on how to properly hydrate my skin in the NYC weather without weighing it down, and she recommended a very affordable skin care brand that's easily accessible to take care of my problems without breaking the bank. I appreciate that they do not push pricey products on their clientele and is very honest about what works for the client's specific skin type.I will definitely be back in the summer once the heavy humidity sets in. Thank you for saving my skin!

We all know New York has got some fabulous rooftop spots, and while they all share the same beautiful views, they are definitely not all created equal. So far this spot is one of my favorites. I got a tip from a friend and suggested it for an after work happy hour type thing. The one negative that I have to say is getting up there can be a reallll drag. Our group was arriving at different times so that complicated things a bit. The line and wait is generally very long since they do their best not to overcrowd the space, which I can appreciate, but I felt like they took it to an extreme. I was lucky I was even able to get up to join my group....Once you're up there though, all troubles from downstairs are left behind. You step off the elevator and can't help but get the feeling you're not in New York anymore. Instead you're transported to some long forgotten oasis. The vibe up there isn't uppity or super fancy. It's just warm and low key, inviting you to linger for as long as you'd like. And once you're done taking it all in, you mosey on up to the bar, order yourself a nice refreshing beverage and realize you actually are in fact in New York when you see the tab...but you realize it's ok, because you're on this roof. And it's awesome.

I was told that DBK had the best Restaurant Week menu in NYC, hands down. I think I would have to agree.I usually avoid Restaurant Week, because the majority of restaurants tend to dumb down their menus for the sake of saving money. And with the crazy rents in NYC these days, who can blame them? However, David Burke Kitchen does a good job showing off their menu, and I can feel confident that I've tasted something that they would have on a normal night.My friends and I decided that we would try to get various dishes so we could try everything. We started with the pretzel-crusted crab cake, lobster dumplings, tuna/salmon tartare, and the baby octopus. My favorite was the baby octopus, since it was so tender and the puree on the side was bomb. The pretzel-crusted crab cake was very good too, although I felt it was a little too hyped up. The tuna and salmon tartare was the perfect texture and the accompanying sauces were great.Entrees were very good, with my favorite being the short rib with cavatelli pasta. The beef was just the right amount of saltiness and tenderness. Branzino was tender and had a very light, not-too-fishy flavor that I really appreciated.Dessert really was the most decadent part of the meal. We got the toffee monkey bread, which was outrageously good. The homemade whipped cream on top really made a difference, as the cream had a really good density to it. The chocolate hazelnut crunch bar was probably my favorite though, since I'm a chocolate junkie. The crispiness/crunchiness of the chocolate bar was perfect and definitely rich. The strawberries and cream tart was actually very tart, which was fine, but I probably couldn't have eaten a whole serving of it.Service was so-so. The rotating waiters were very quick about water, but our main waitress pretty much forgot our entire drink order until we reminded her 20 minutes later. She seemed really out of it, and while I understand it was busy, she seemed to avoid our table after we told her she forgot our drink order. Yikes. However, it wasn't enough to ruin the experience and we had a great time.Overall, I would definitely come back for the normal a la carte dining menu. The portions were definitely good for the price, and I've been told I need to try the cake pop tree, and the dry-aged ribeye. I'll also be back for the upstairs garden seating at the Treehouse bar.

I know I really shouldn't go out for happy hour drinks as much, but it is too hard to kick the habit, and too hard to pass up after stressful days. I guess I'm really falling into the post-college, adult lifestyle.I met up with a few friends here for happy hour since it's near one of their work places and she loves it...plus, I've never been, and I often hear Blockheads being the Mexican Dallas BBQ for HH. Great atmosphere for a Midtown hub; it's like walking into a restaurant in the south or in Mexico. I got a Passion Fruit Frozen Margarita since the Blockheads specials were too much for me to handle. It was really good, and pretty strong. Then again, I'm a lightweight and three-quarters of it already had me sweating.We also ordered some food and they were exceptional. The Cheese Quesadillas were totally off the hook and heavenly; the melted cheese was everything. Dip this in sour cream all over, and you'll forget the world. We also had the Nachos Grande which had a bit of everything: guacamole, black beans, melted cheese, and the soft tomatoes were just amazing. Eat this fast because it gets soggy really fast. I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're looking for a dinner meal, but definitely great to snack on something and have a few glasses. I'm not going to complain about the complimentary salsa and chips because...c'mon, are we really complaining about FREE salsa and chips?!

Like many brilliant wordsmiths have done before, owner of Krush opted for the naming device of reinventing c-words by replacing the c with a k.*The decor is very of the moment barn chic. Wood is everywhere. So not the usual faux glam of so many other ktown bars, even "sports bars" like players. However like other ktown bars, it's on the 4th floor of a non-descript building. In trendier neighborhoods, this could be called a speakeasy. In ktown, it's called a game of how many drunk Asians can you fit in an elevator on a Saturday night (really fun game). Anyway, on to the critical issues: wings. The draw with many ktown bars is the food. Here, it's a mix of standard American mixed with Korean food. So, burgers are made with Bulgogi, pork cutlet is drizzled with tonkatsu sauce. Lastly, the wings were delicious and come in a variety of flavors like the standard buffalo as well as sweet chili and peanut sauce etc. Prices are standard but right now they're running a bogo deal on beer and appetizers (guess which one is more appealing to me? Lemme know if you want to go in on orders of wings so we can cover the flavors). *i have no idea that this is true, it may very well be that he used the k as an homage to its milieu of ktown.

Chef Bobby Flay "Gato" *\(^_^)/*Bobby Flay's newest restaurant, Gato, opened a few months ago on Lafayette Street in NoHo.
